analyzed: vacana attha vijānanena vidita abhidhamma sāmañña atthassa abhidhamma kathā vuccamānā sobheyyā ti  abhidhamma parijānanam eva ādimhi tad attham pucchati tattha kenaṭṭhena  abhidhammaḥ ti tattha tattha ati abhidhammassa attham pakāsayissāmi iti yat idam vuttam
translated: Since the discussion of the Abhidhamma will be a beautiful thing when it is expounded by one who knows the meaning of the words,🔽it is the knowledge of the Abhidhamma that is fitting at the beginning. So he asks the question in order to expound that: “What is the Abhidhamma? ”🔽Herein, “there” is what was said above with reference to the meaning of the Abhidhamma, namely, “I shall expound the meaning of the Abhidhamma” .

original: tasmiṃ. “Yassa atthaṃ pakāsayissāmī”ti paṭiññātaṃ, so abhidhammo kenaṭṭhena abhidhammoti
analyzed: tasmim yassa attham pakāsayissāmi iti paṭiññātam saḥ abhidhammo kenaṭṭhena abhidhammo ti
translated: The meaning is: “What is the Abhidhamma by the meaning of which the meaning of the Abhidhamma has been proposed? ”

original: attho. Tatthāti vā “abhidhammakatha”nti etasmiṃ vacane yo abhidhammo vutto, so kenaṭṭhena
analyzed: atthaḥ tattha ati vā abhidhamma kathanti etasmim vacane yaḥ abhidhammaḥ vuttaḥ saḥ kenaṭṭhena
translated: Or alternatively, “there” refers to the words “discussion of the Abhidhamma” . The meaning is: “What is the Abhidhamma that is called ‘discussion of the Abhidhamma’? ”

original: abhidhammoti attho. Dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭhenāti ettha dhammo atireko dhammātireko,
analyzed: abhidhammaḥ ti atthaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesa ṭṭhena ati ettha dhammaḥ atirekaḥ dhamma atirekaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the Abhidhamma. As to the meaning of excess of ideas and of distinction of ideas: here, excess of ideas is dhammātirekā ;🔽the meaning is: the text of the Suttanta. Distinction of ideas is dhammāvisesā ;

original: suttantādhikā pāḷīti attho. Dhammo viseso dhammaviseso dhammātisayo, vicittā pāḷīti🔽attho, dhammātirekadhammavisesā eva attho dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭho. Dvinnampi
analyzed: suttanta adhikā pāḷī iti atthaḥ dhammaḥ visesaḥ dhamma visesaḥ dhamma atisayaḥ vicittā pāḷī iti  atthaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesāḥ eva atthaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesaṭṭhaḥ dvinnam pi
translated: the meaning is: the various texts. The meaning of excess of ideas and of distinction of ideas is the meaning of dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭho.🔽The singular number in the words dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭhena is used in the sense of the dual

original: atthānaṃ abhidhammasaddassa atthabhāvena sāmaññato ekavacananiddeso kato. Tasmāti
analyzed: atthānam abhidhamma saddassa attha bhāvena sāmaññataḥ ekavacana niddeso kataḥ tasmā iti
translated: because both meanings are the meanings of the word abhidhamma. Therefore

original: yasmā “abhikkamanti, abhikkantavaṇṇā”tiādīsu viya atirekavisesaṭṭhadīpako abhisaddo,
analyzed: yasmai abhikkamanti abhikkanta vaṇṇā ati ādīsu viya atireka visesa ṭṭha dīpakaḥ abhi saddaḥ
translated: because the word abhi in such passages as “abhikkantaṃ, abhikkantavaṇṇā” is a word that illuminates excess and distinction,

original: tasmā ayampi dhammo dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭhena “abhidhammo”ti vuccatīti sambandho.
analyzed: tasmai ayam pi dhammaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesa ṭṭhena abhidhammaḥ ti vuccati iti sambandho
translated: therefore this Dhamma is called “Abhidhamma” in the sense of the meaning of excess of ideas and of distinction of ideas.

original: Tattha siyā – “abhikkamanti, abhikkantavaṇṇā”ti ettha dhātusaddassa purato payujjamāno
analyzed: tattha siyā abhikkamanti abhikkanta vaṇṇā ti ettha dhātu saddassa puratas payujjamāno
translated: Here it may be asked: in the passage “abhikkantaṃ, abhikkantavaṇṇā” the word abhi used in front of the word dhātu

original: abhisaddo kiriyāya atirekavisesabhāvadīpako hotīti yuttaṃ upasaggabhāvato, dhammasaddo
analyzed: abhisaddaḥ kiriyāya atireka visesa bhāva dīpakaḥ hoti iti yuttam upasagga bhāvataḥ dhammasaddo
translated: is a word that illuminates the excess and distinction of the action. That is proper because of the prefix bhāva. The word dhamma

original: pana na dhātusaddoti etasmā purato abhisaddo payogameva nārahati. Athāpi payujjeyya,
analyzed: pana na dhātu saddo ti etasmai puratas abhisaddo payogam eva na arahati atha api payujjeyya
translated: but it is not a word for element, therefore the prefix abhi is not required before it. But if it were required,

original: kiriyāvisesakā upasaggā, na ca dhammo kiriyāti dhammassa atirekavisesabhāvadīpanaṃ
analyzed: kiriyā visesakāḥ upasaggāḥ na ca dhammaḥ kiriyā ti dhammassa atireka visesa bhāva dīpanam
translated: the prefixes are used to show a particular action, and dhamma is not an action, therefore it is not proper to show a particular action in excess of the dhamma by the prefix.

original: na yuttanti? No na yuttaṃ. Aññassapi hi upasaggassa adhātusaddā purato payujjamānassa
analyzed: na yuttam ti no na yuttam aññassa api hi upasaggassa a dhātu saddā puratas payujjamānassa
translated: Is it not proper? It is proper. For even when a different prefix is used before a word for element,

original: akiriyāyapi atirekavisesabhāvadīpakassa dassanatoti etamatthaṃ vibhāvetuṃ atichattādiudāharaṇaṃ
analyzed: atireka visesa bhāva dīpakassa dassanato ti etam attham vibhāvetum atichatta ādi udāharaṇam
translated: it shows the particular action in excess of the action. In order to make this meaning clear, he gives the example of atichattā, etc.,

original: dassento āha “yathā”tiādi. Evamevāti yathā chattātirekachattavisesādiatthena atichattādayo🔽honti atisaddassa upasaggassa adhātusaddassapi purato payujjamānassa akiriyāya ca
analyzed: āha yathā itiādi evam eva ati yathā chatta atireka chatta visesa ādi atthena ati chatta ādayaḥ  honti a ti saddassa upasaggassa a dhātu saddassa api puratas payujjamānassa a kiriyāya ca
translated: saying “Just as,” etc. Just so: just as atichattā, etc., are so by the meaning of a particular umbrella in excess of an umbrella,🔽because the prefix ati shows that particular state in excess of the action,

original: tabbhāvadīpakattā, evamayampi dhammo dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭhena “abhidhammo”ti
analyzed: tad bhāva dīpaka ttā evam ayam pi dhammaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesa ṭṭhena abhidhammaḥ ti
translated: so too this is called “abhidhamma” by the meaning of a particular dhamma in excess of a dhamma,

original: vuccati abhi-saddassa upasaggassa adhātusaddassapi purato payujjamānassa akiriyāya
analyzed: vuccati abhi saddassa upasaggassa a dhātu saddassa api puratas payujjamānassa a kiriyāya
translated: because the prefix abhi shows that particular state in excess of the action,

original: ca tabbhāvadīpakattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ca tad bhāva dīpaka ttā iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: and the intention is that it is the meaning of that that is illustrated.

original: Ekadeseneva vibhattāti “katame ca, bhikkhave, pañcakkhandhā? Rūpakkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho.
analyzed: eka desena iva vibhattā ati katame ca bhikkhave pañca kkhandhāḥ rūpa kkhandho upe viññāṇa kkhandho
translated: They are analyzed by a single method: “What are the five aggregates? The materiality aggregate … the consciousness aggregate.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, rūpakkhandho? Yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītā…pe… santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati🔽rūpakkhandho”tievamādinā uddesaniddesamatteneva vibhattā, “tattha katamaṃ rūpaṃ atīta”ntievamādinā
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave rūpa kkhandhaḥ yam kiñci rūpam atīta āpe santike vā ayam vuccati  rūpa kkhandhaḥ ti evamādinā uddesa niddesa mattena iva vibhattā tattha katamam rūpam atītam ti evamādinā
translated: What is the materiality aggregate? Whatever materiality there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—this is called

original: paṭiniddesassa abhidhammabhājanīyassa pañhapucchakassa ca abhāvā na nippadesena.🔽Abhidhammaṃ patvā pana…pe… nippadesatova vibhattā, tasmā ayampi dhammo dhammātirekadhammavisesaṭṭhena🔽“abhidhammo”ti vuccati nippadesānaṃ tiṇṇampi nayānaṃ atirekapāḷibhāvato visesapāḷibhāvato
analyzed: paṭiniddesassa abhidhamma bhājanīyassa pañhapucchakassa ca abhāvā na nippadesena  abhidhammam patvā nippadesataḥ va vibhattā tasmai ayam pi dhammaḥ dhamma atireka dhamma visesa ṭṭhena  abhidhammaḥ ti vuccati nippadesānam tiṇṇam pi nayānam atireka pāḷi bhāvataḥ visesa pāḷi bhāvataḥ
translated: the materiality aggregate” . They are analyzed by the mere indication of the exposition in this way. But they are not analyzed by a detailed explanation, because there is no question asked in the way of the Abhidhamma, as there is in the case of the exposition beginning, “Herein, what is materiality that is past? ”🔽But when the Abhidhamma is entered upon, they are analyzed by a detailed explanation, and so on. Consequently this Dhamma is called “Abhidhamma” in the sense of a particular Dhamma that is a further Dhamma in the sense of excess and in the sense of distinction,

original: cāti adhippāyo. Suttante bāvīsatiyā indriyānaṃ ekato anāgatattā indriyavibhaṅge suttantabhājanīyaṃ
analyzed: ca ati adhippāyaḥ suttante bāvīsatiyāḥ indriyānaṃ ekatas anāgata ttā indriya vibhaṅge suttanta bhājanīyam
translated: because it is a further section and a distinguished section of the three planes of reference, which are without detailed explanation. In the Suttas the twenty-two faculties are not dealt with together, so the Abhidhamma deals with them in the Faculties chapter.

original: natthi. “Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā sambhavantī”tiādinā paṭiccasamuppāde tassa tassa
analyzed: natthi avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā sambhavanti iti ādinā paṭiccasamuppāde tassa tassa
translated: “No, friend.” “With ignorance as condition, volitional formations come to be” .🔽

original: paccayadhammassa paccayuppannadhammānaṃ paccayabhāvo uddiṭṭho, uddiṭṭhadhammānañca
analyzed: paccaya dhammassa paccaya uppanna dhammānam paccaya bhāvaḥ uddiṭṭhaḥ uddiṭṭha dhammānam ca
translated: There is none. “With ignorance as condition there are volitional formations” and so on: the conditionality of the various states that are conditioned is stated in the dependent origination. And the profitable, etc.,

original: kusalādibhāvo pucchitvā vissajjetabbo, na cettha “avijjāsaṅkhārā”ti evaṃ vutto uddeso🔽atthīti pañhapucchakaṃ natthi. Suttante pañca sikkhāpadāni uddiṭṭhāni pāṇātipātā🔽veramaṇītiādīni. Sā pana veramaṇī yadi sabhāvakiccādivasena vibhajīyeyya, “ārati
analyzed: kusala ādi bhāvaḥ pucchitvā vissajjetabbaḥ na ca ittha avijjā saṅkhārā ti evam vuttaḥ uddesaḥ  atthi iti pañha pucchakam na atthi suttante pañca sikkhāpadāni uddiṭṭhāni pāṇātipātā  veramaṇī itiādīni sā pana veramaṇī yadi ārati
translated: nature of the states stated there should be explained in answer to the question. But there is no question here in the form, “Are ignorance and formations profitable, etc.?”

original: viratī”tiādinā abhidhammabhājanīyameva hoti. Athāpi cittuppādavasena vibhajīyeyya,🔽tathāpi abhidhammabhājanīyameva hoti. Añño pana veramaṇīnaṃ vibhajitabbappakāro natthi,
analyzed: virati iti ādinā abhidhamma bhājanīyam eva hoti atha api cittuppāda vasena  tathā api abhidhamma bhājanīyam eva hoti aññaḥ pana veramaṇīnam vibhajitabba ppakāraḥ natthi
translated: So there is no question. In the sutta the five training precepts are stated thus: “Abstinence from killing breathing things” and so on. But that abstinence, if it were to be analysed according to the meaning of the terms, according to the action, etc., would be only a subject for the Abhidhamma, since it would be a matter of “non-delight, non-contention, abstinence, avoidance, abstention, non-transgression, restraint, practice of restraint, restraint, fulfilment of virtue, fulfilment of duty, non-doing, non-making, non-transgressing, non-committing, non-offending, non-repeating, non-committing again” .🔽And if it were to be analysed according to the arising of consciousness, it would be only a subject for the Abhidhamma. But there is no other way of analysing abstinence that could be called a subject for the Suttanta.

original: yena pakārena suttantabhājanīyaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā. Tasmā sikkhāpadavibhaṅge suttantabhājanīyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: yena pakārena suttanta bhājanīyam vattabbam siyā tasmā sikkhāpada vibhaṅge suttanta bhājanīyam na atthi
translated: So there is no subject for the Suttanta in the analysis of the training precepts.

original: Vacanatthato abhidhamme ñāte paricchedato ñāpetuṃ āha “pakaraṇaparicchedato”tiādi.🔽Katipayāva pañhavārā avasesāti dhammahadayavibhaṅge anāgatā hutvā mahādhammahadaye
analyzed: vacana atthataḥ abhidhamme ñāte paricchedataḥ ñāpetum āha pakaraṇa paricchedato tiādi  katipayā ava pañha vārāḥ dhamma hadaya vibhaṅge anāgatāḥ hutvā mahā dhamma hadaye
translated: When the meaning of the words in the Abhidhamma is known, he says “By the method of the exposition of the text” in order to show the method of exposition by way of the divisions.🔽The remaining few questions are those that are not included in the Dhamm- ahadaya Vibhanga but are included in the Maha-Dhammasangani.

original: āgatā dhammahadayavibhaṅgavacanavasena avasesā katipayāva pañhavārāti attho. Ettheva
analyzed: āgatā dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga vacana vasena avasesā katipayā ava pañha vārā ti atthaḥ ettha iva
translated: The meaning is: the remaining few questions are those that are not included in the Dhamm- ahadaya Vibhanga but are included in the Maha-Dhammasangani.

original: saṅgahitāti “apubbaṃ natthī”ti vuttaṃ. Appamattikāva tanti avasesāti dhammahadayavibhaṅge🔽anāgantvā mahādhammahadaye āgatatantito yadi pathavīādīnaṃ vitthārakathā mahādhātukathā
analyzed: saṅgahitā ti apubbam na atthi iti vuttam appamattikā ava tanti avasesā ti dhamma hadaya vibhaṅge  an āgantvā mahā dhamma hadaye āgata tantitaḥ yadi vitthāra kathā mahā dhātu kathā
translated: They are included there. Therefore it is said: “There is nothing new.”🔽The meaning is: the remaining few questions are those that are not included in the Dhamm- ahadaya Vibhanga but are included in the Maha-Dhammasangani.

original: rūpakaṇḍadhātuvibhaṅgādīsu, atha dhātukathāya vitthārakathā dhātukathāya anāgantvā
analyzed: rūpa kaṇḍa dhātu vibhaṅga ādīsu atha dhātu kathāya vitthāra kathā dhātu kathāya an āgantvā
translated: If the detailed explanation of earth, etc., is the Maha-Dhatu Katha, it is included in the Rupi- kanda, the Dhatu Vibhanga, etc.🔽If the detailed explanation of the Dhatu Katha is the Maha-Dhatu Katha, it is included in the Maha-Dhatu Katha and not in the Dhatu Katha.

original: mahādhātukathāya āgatatanti appamattikāvāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: mahā dhātu kathāya āgata tanti appamattikā vā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is: it is of little importance.

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “sāvakabhāsitattā chaḍḍetha na”nti, taṃ buddhabhāsitabhāvadassanena
analyzed: yam pana vuttam sāvaka bhāsita ttā chaḍḍetha tam buddha bhāsita bhāva dassanena
translated: But it was said: “Do not reject it because it was spoken by a disciple.”

original: paṭisedhetuṃ “sammāsambuddho hī”tiādimāha. Catūsu pañhesūti “upalabbhati nupalabbhatī”ti
analyzed: paṭisedhetum sammāsambuddhaḥ hi iti ādim āha catūsu pañhesu upalabbhati na upalabbhati iti
translated: In the four fivefold questions, when the admission “It is found” or “It is not found”

original: paṭiññāya gahitāya paṭikkhepagahaṇatthaṃ “yo saccikaṭṭho”ti vuttaṃ saccikaṭṭhaṃ nissayaṃ🔽katvā upādāya pavattā dvepi pañcakā eko pañho, “sabbatthā”ti sarīraṃ sabbaṃ vā desaṃ
analyzed: paṭiññāya gahitāya paṭikkhepa gahaṇa attham yaḥ saccikaṭṭhaḥ ti vuttam saccikaṭṭham nissayam  katvā upādāya pavattā dve pi pañcakā ekaḥ pañho sabbattha ati sarīram sabbam vā desam
translated: has been made, the words “What is the true nature of what is found” are said for the purpose of making him grasp the denial.🔽The two sets of five, which occur with the true nature of what is found and what is not found as the basis,🔽are one question. That which occurs with the body or the whole region as the basis is one question.

original: upādāya pavattā eko, “sabbadā”ti kālamupādāya eko, “sabbesū”ti yadi khandhāyatanādayo
analyzed: upādāya pavattā ekaḥ sabbadā ti kālam upādāya ekaḥ sabbesu iti yadi khandha āyatana ādayo
translated: That which occurs with time as the basis is one question. If the aggregates, bases, etc., are meant by “all,”

original: gahitā, te upādāya pavattā, atha pana “yo saccikaṭṭho sabbattha sabbadā”ti etehi🔽na koci saccikaṭṭho deso kālo vā aggahito atthi, te pana sāmaññavasena gahetvā anuyogo
analyzed: gahitā te upādāya pavattā atha pana yaḥ saccikaṭṭhaḥ sabbattha sabba dāti etehi  na koci saccikaṭṭhaḥ desaḥ kālaḥ vā aggahitaḥ atthi te pana sāmañña vasena gahetvā anuyogaḥ
translated: they are included in the question “What is the true nature of what is found everywhere and at all times.”🔽But if no particular true nature of what is found is meant by “the true nature of what is found everywhere and at all times,”

original: kato, na bhedavasenāti bhedavasena gahetvā anuyuñjituṃ “sabbesū”ti vuttā saccikaṭṭhadesakālappadese
analyzed: kataḥ na bheda vasena ati bheda vasena gahetvā anuyuñjitum sabbesu iti vuttā saccikaṭṭha desa kāla ppadese
translated: then the interrogation is conducted by taking that as a general term, not by taking it as a particular.🔽So “all” is said in order to interrogate by taking it as a particular, thus: “What is the true nature of what is found in all the regions, at all times, and in all the individual existences?”

original: upādāya ca pavattā ekoti etesu catūsu. Dvinnaṃ pañcakānanti ettha “puggalo upalabbhati…pe…🔽micchā”ti ekaṃ, “puggalo nupalabbhati…pe… micchā”ti ekaṃ, “tvaṃ ce pana maññasi…pe…
analyzed: upādāya ca pavattā ekaḥ ti etesu catūsu dvinnam pañcakānam ti ettha puggalaḥ  micchāti ekam puggalaḥ micchāti ekam tvam ce pana maññasipe
translated: Herein, “The person is found … is wrong” is one,🔽“The person is not found … is wrong” is one, “But if you think … is wrong” is one,

original: idaṃ te micchā”ti ekaṃ, “ese ce dunniggahite…pe… idaṃ te micchā”ti ekaṃ, “na hevaṃ
analyzed: idam te micchāti ekam ese ce idam te micchāti ekam na ha evam
translated: “If it is misapprehended … is wrong” is one, “It should not be apprehended thus … well done, the explanation is finished” is one.

original: niggahetabbe, tena hi yaṃ niggaṇhāsi…pe… sukatā paṭipādanā”ti ekanti evaṃ niggahakaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: niggahetabbe tena hi yam suka tā paṭipādanā ati ekam ti evam niggaha karaṇam
translated: So this is the way of apprehending,

original: paṭikammakaraṇaṃ, niggahassa suniggahabhāvaṃ icchato paṭiññāṭhapanena paṭikammaveṭhanaṃ,
analyzed: paṭikamma karaṇam niggahassa su niggaha bhāvam icchataḥ paṭiññā ṭhapanena paṭikamma veṭhanam
translated: the way of countering, the way of countering a counter by a denial of the proposition when one wants to show that the apprehension is well apprehended,

original: paṭikammassa duppaṭikammabhāvaṃ icchato taṃnidassanena niggahassa dunniggahabhāvadassanena
analyzed: paṭikammassa duppaṭikamma bhāvam icchato tad nidassanena niggahassa dunniggaha bhāva dassanena
translated: the way of showing that the counter is badly countered by showing that the apprehension is badly apprehended when one wants to show that the counter is well countered,

original: niggahanibbeṭhanaṃ, aniggahabhāvāropanādinā chedoti ayaṃ eko pañcako, yo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: niggaha nibbeṭhanam a niggaha bhāva āropana ādinā chedo ti ayam ekaḥ pañcakaḥ yo
translated: and the way of cutting off by superimposition of the state of not being apprehended, etc., when one wants to show that the apprehension is not apprehended. This is the first set of five.

original: anulomapañcakapaṭikammacatukkaniggahacatukkaupanayanacatukkanigamanacatukka nāmehi
analyzed: anuloma pañcaka paṭikamma catukka niggaha catukka upanayana catukka nigamana catukka nāmehi
translated: In the commentary it is called the set of five in forward order, the set of four in counter order, the set of four in apprehension, the set of four in superimposition, and the set of four in conclusion.

original: sakavādipubbapakkhe anulomapaccanīkapañcakoti vutto, paravādipubbapakkhe ca evameva
analyzed: sakavādi pubbapakkhe anuloma paccanīka pañcako ti vutto paravādi pubbapakkhe ca evam eva
translated: In the first proposition of the proponent’s case, the five terms in the affirmative are called the “five terms in the affirmative and the reverse” , and in the first proposition of the opponent’s case, the five terms in the reverse are called the “five terms in the reverse and the affirmative” .

original: paccanīyānulomapañcakoti vutto. Evaṃ dve pañcakā veditabbā. Evaṃ sesapañhesupīti
analyzed: paccanīya anuloma pañcako ti vutto evam dve pañcakāḥ veditabbāḥ evam sesa pañhesu pi iti
translated: Thus two sets of five terms should be understood. And so too in the remaining propositions.

original: aṭṭha pañcakā aṭṭhamukhā vādayuttīti vuttā. Yuttīti upāyo, vādassa yutti vādayutti,
analyzed: aṭṭha pañcakā aṭṭhamukhā vādayuttī iti vuttā yuttī iti upāyaḥ vādassa yutti vādayutti
translated: Thus the eight sets of five terms are called the “eight-faced debate-guide” . “ Guide” is a means; the guide for a debate is a debate-guide,

original: vādappavattanassa upāyoti attho.
analyzed: vāda ppavattanassa upāyaḥ ti attho
translated: the means for the occurrence of a debate.

original: Anulomapaccanīkapañcake ādiniggahaṃ dassetvā paccanīyānulomapañcake ca ādiniggahameva🔽dassetvā mātikaṃ dīpetuṃ “sā panesā”tiādimāha. Puggaloti attā satto jīvo. Upalabbhatīti🔽paññāya upagantvā labbhati. Saccikaṭṭhaparamaṭṭhenāti māyāmarīciādayo viya nābhūtākārena,
analyzed: anuloma paccanīka pañcake ādi niggaham dassetvā paccanīya anuloma pañcake ca ādi niggaham eva  dassetvā mātikam dīpetum sā pana isā ti ādim āha puggalaḥ ti attā sattaḥ jīvaḥ upalabbhati iti  paññāya upagantvā labbhati saccikaṭṭha paramaṭṭhena ati māyā marīci ādayaḥ viya na abhūta ākārena
translated: Having shown the first terms in the five terms in the affirmative and the reverse and in the five terms in the reverse and the affirmative, he said “This, however, is the method” in order to show the method by pointing out the Schedule.🔽“Person” : self, being, soul. “Is found” : is reached by going up to it with understanding. “In the ultimate sense” : not as something that has not been and become in the way it is apprehended, like a mirage, a phantom, etc.,

original: anussavādīhi gahetabbā viya na anuttamatthabhāvena, atha kho bhūtena uttamatthabhāvena
analyzed: anussava ādīhi gahetabbāḥ viya na anuttama attha bhāvena atha kho bhūtena uttama ttha bhāvena
translated: not as a highest meaning that can be apprehended by those who rely on hearsay, but rather as something that has been and become in the ultimate, highest sense,

original: upalabbhatīti pucchati. Itaro tādisaṃ icchanto paṭijānāti. Puna yo saccikaṭṭhaparamaṭṭhena
analyzed: upalabbhati iti pucchati itaro tādisam icchantaḥ paṭijānāti puna yo saccikaṭṭha paramaṭṭhena
translated: he asks, “Is it found?” The other, wishing to be like that, admits it. Again, he who is

original: upalabbhati, so saccikaṭṭhaparamaṭṭhato añño tadādhāro, aññatra vā tehi, tesaṃ vā
analyzed: upalabbhati so saccikaṭṭha paramaṭṭhato aññaḥ tad ādhāraḥ aññatra vā tehi tesam vā
translated: He asks whether it is found. The other, wanting to make it out to be such, admits it. Then the other presses him further, saying: “If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.

original: ādhārabhūto, anañño vā tato ruppanādisabhāvato sappaccayādisabhāvato vā upalabbhamāno🔽āpajjatīti anuyuñjati “yo saccikaṭṭho…pe… paramaṭṭhenā”ti. Itaro puggalassa rūpādīhi
analyzed: ādhāra bhūtaḥ anaññaḥ vā tatas ruppana ādi sabhāvataḥ sappaccaya ādi sabhāvataḥ vā upalabbhamānaḥ  āpajjati iti anuyuñjati yaḥ paramaṭṭhena ati itaro puggalassa rūpa ādīhi
translated: “If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.🔽“If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.

original: aññattaṃ anaññattañca anicchanto “na heva”nti paṭikkhipati. Puna sakavādī paṭiññāya🔽ekattāpannaṃ appaṭikkhipitabbaṃ paṭikkhipatīti katvā niggahaṃ āropento āha “ājānāhi🔽niggaha”nti. “Puggalo nupalabbhatī”ti puṭṭho sakavādī puggaladiṭṭhiṃ paṭisedhento
analyzed: aññattam an aññattam ca an icchantaḥ na hevanti paṭikkhipati puna saka vādī paṭiññāya  ekatta āpannam appaṭikkhipitabbam paṭikkhipati iti katvā niggaham āropentaḥ āha ājānāhi  niggahanti puggalaḥ na upalabbhati iti puṭṭhaḥ saka vādī puggala diṭṭhim paṭisedhento
translated: “If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.🔽“If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.🔽“If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.

original: “āmantā”ti paṭijānāti. Puna itaro yo saccikaṭṭhena nupalabbhati puggalo, so saccikaṭṭhaparamaṭṭhato
analyzed: āmantā ati paṭijānāti puna itaraḥ yaḥ saccikaṭṭhena na upalabbhati puggalo saḥ saccikaṭṭha paramaṭṭhataḥ
translated: “If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or it is the support of that, or it is not that, or it is not different from that, or it is not not different from that.🔽“If it is found in the ultimate sense as real and ultimate, then it is different from what is its support, or it is not different from it, or

original: añño vā anañño vā nupalabbhatīti āpajjati aññassa pakārassa abhāvāti anuyuñjati “yo
analyzed: aññaḥ vā anaññaḥ vā na upalabbhati iti āpajjati aññassa pakārassa abhāvā ati anuyuñjati yaḥ
translated: he falls into the view that it is neither the same nor different, because there is no other kind of difference.

original: saccikaṭṭho…pe… paramaṭṭhenā”ti. Yasmā pana puggalo sabbena sabbaṃ nupalabbhati,
analyzed: paramaṭṭhena ati yasmā pana puggalaḥ sabbena sabbam na upalabbhati
translated: When pressed further, he says, “The person is not found as real in the ultimate sense.”🔽But since the person is not found at all anywhere,

original: tasmā tassa aññattānaññattānuyogo ananuyogo puggalaladdhiṃ paṭisedhentassa anāpajjanatoti
analyzed: tasmā tassa aññatta anaññatta anuyogaḥ ananuyogaḥ puggala laddhim paṭisedhentassa an āpajjanato ti
translated: the pursuit of the question of its sameness or difference is not a pursuit for one who denies the existence of a person.

original: “na heva”nti paṭikkhipati. Itaro paṭiññāya āpajjanalesameva passanto aviparītaṃ atthaṃ
analyzed: na hevanti paṭikkhipati itaraḥ paṭiññāya āpajjana lesam eva passantaḥ aviparītam attham
translated: “No,” he replies, rejecting the pursuit. The other, seeing only the possibility of a pursuit in terms of the question of the person’s existence,

original: asambujjhantoyeva niggahaṃ āropeti “ājānāhi niggaha”nti.
analyzed: a sambujjhantaḥ yā iva niggaham āropeti ājānāhi niggahan ti
translated: and not seeing the correct meaning, makes his own refutation: “Understand the refutation.”

original: Itīti yaṃ disvā mātikā ṭhapitā, evaṃ desitattāti adhippāyo. Yathā kinti yena pakārena
analyzed: iti iti yam disvā mātikā ṭhapitā evam desita ttā ati adhippāyaḥ yathā kinti yena pakārena
translated: “Thus”: the meaning is that the mātikā was set up after seeing thus, after being taught thus.🔽“In what way?” The meaning is: in what way did it come to be called “spoken by the Buddha”?

original: buddhabhāsitaṃ nāma jātaṃ, taṃ nidassanaṃ kinti attho. Yatonidānanti yaṃkāraṇā chaajjhattikabāhirāyatanādinidānanti
analyzed: buddha bhāsitam nāma jātam tam nidassanam kim ti atthaḥ yatonidānam ti yaṃkāraṇā cha ajjhattika bāhira āyatana ādi nidānam ti
translated: “From which source”: the meaning is: from which cause, from the source of the six internal and external bases, etc.

original: attho. Papañcasaññāsaṅkhāti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhipapañcasampayuttā saññākoṭṭhāsā. Samudācarantīti
analyzed: attho papañca saññā saṅkhāti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi papañca sampayuttā saññā koṭṭhāsā samudācaranti iti
translated: “The proliferation of perceptions”: the meaning is: the groups of perceptions associated with the proliferation of craving, conceit, and views. “Occurring”:

original: ajjhācaranti. Ettha ceti etesu āyatanādīsu taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīhi abhinanditabbaṃ abhivaditabbaṃ
analyzed: ajjhācaranti ettha ca iti etesu āyatana ādīsu taṇhā māna diṭṭhīhi abhinanditabbam abhivaditabbam
translated: and clung to in these bases, etc., then there is nothing.🔽But is there not? Why is it said, “If there is nothing”?

original: ajjhositabbañca natthi ce. Nanu natthiyeva, kasmā “natthi ce”ti vuttanti? Saccaṃ
analyzed: ajjhositabbam ca natthi ce nanu natthiyā iva kasmā natthi ceti vuttanti saccam
translated: It is true that there is nothing,

original: natthi, appahīnābhinandanābhivadanajjhosānānaṃ pana puthujjanānaṃ abhinanditabbādippakārāni
analyzed: natthi appahīna abhinandana abhivadana ajjhosānānam pana puthujjanānam abhinanditabba ādi ppakārāni
translated: but for worldlings who have not abandoned delight, approval, and clinging, the bases, etc., are such that they can be delighted in, etc.

original: āyatanādīni hontīti tesaṃ na sakkā “natthī”ti vattuṃ, pahīnābhinandanādīnaṃ pana
analyzed: āyatana ādīni honti iti tesam na sakkā natthi iti vattum pahīna abhinandana ādīnam pana
translated: Therefore it cannot be said of them that they are nothing. But for those who have abandoned delight, etc.,

original: sabbathā natthīti “natthi ce”ti vuttaṃ. Esevantoti abhinandanādīnaṃ natthibhāvakaro
analyzed: sabbathā natthi iti natthi ca iti vuttam esevanto ti abhinandana ādīnam natthi bhāva karo
translated: they are in every way nothing. Thus it is said, “If there is nothing.”

original: maggo tappaṭippassaddhibhūtaṃ phalaṃ vā rāgānusayādīnaṃ anto avasānaṃ, appavattīti attho.
analyzed: maggaḥ tad paṭippassaddhi bhūtam phalam vā rāga anusaya ādīnam antaḥ avasānam appavatti iti attho
translated: This is the end: the path that brings about the non-existence of delight, etc., or the fruit that is the state of their cessation is the end, the culmination, the non-occurrence of the underlying tendencies of lust, etc.

original: Jānaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇena jānitabbaṃ jānāti. Na hi padesañāṇavā jānitabbaṃ
analyzed: jānam jānāti iti sabbaññuta ññāṇena jānitabbam jānāti na hi padesa ñāṇavā jānitabbam
translated: Knowing, he knows: he knows what is to be known by means of the knowledge of omniscience. For what is to be known is not known by means of limited knowledge.

original: sabbaṃ jānātīti. Passaṃ passatīti dibbacakkhupaññācakkhudhammacakkhubuddhacakkhusamantacakkhusaṅkhātehi🔽pañcahi cakkhūhi passitabbaṃ passati. Atha vā jānaṃ jānātīti yathā aññe savipallāsā🔽kāmarūpapariññāvādino jānantāpi vipallāsavasena jānanti, na evaṃ bhagavā, bhagavā🔽pana pahīnavipallāsattā jānanto jānātiyeva, diṭṭhidassanassa ca abhāvā passanto passatiyevāti
analyzed: sabbam jānāti iti passam passati iti dibba cakkhu paññā cakkhu dhamma cakkhu buddha cakkhu samanta cakkhu saṅkhātehi  pañcahi cakkhūhi passitabbam passati atha vā jānam jānāti iti yathā aññe sa vipallāsā  kāmarūpa pariññā vādinaḥ vipallāsa vasena jānanti na evam bhagavā bhagavā  pana pahīna vipallāsa ttā jānantaḥ jānātiyā iva diṭṭhi dassanassa ca abhāvā passantaḥ passatiyā iva ati
translated: “He knows all.”🔽“He sees what is to be seen”: he sees what is to be seen with the five eyes, namely, the divine eye, the wisdom eye, the Dhamma eye, the Buddha eye, and the universal eye.🔽Or alternatively, “he knows what is to be known” means that while others who claim to know the full understanding of sensual desire and form know through perversion, the Exalted One knows without perversion,🔽because he has abandoned perversion. “He sees what is to be seen” means that because he has no view of seeing, he sees what is to be seen.🔽

original: attho. Cakkhubhūtoti paññācakkhumayattā sattesu ca taduppādanato lokassa cakkhubhūto.🔽Ñāṇabhūtoti etassa ca evameva attho daṭṭhabbo. Dhammā bodhipakkhiyā. Brahmā maggo,🔽tehi uppannattā lokassa ca taduppādanato tabbhūto. Vattāti catusaccadhamme vadatīti
analyzed: atthaḥ cakkhu bhūtaḥ ti paññā cakkhu maya ttā sattesu ca tad uppādanato lokassa cakkhu bhūtaḥ 🔽ñāṇa bhūto ti etassa ca evam eva atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo dhammā bodhi pakkhiyā brahmā maggo 🔽tehi uppanna ttā lokassa ca tad uppādanataḥ tad bhūtaḥ vattā ati catu sacca dhamme vadati iti
translated: He knows all. He sees what is to be seen by the five eyes, namely, the divine eye, the wisdom eye, the Dhamma eye, the Buddha eye, and the universal eye. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is to be known by the five eyes. Or else, he knows what is

original: vattā. Pavattāti ciraṃ saccappaṭivedhaṃ pavattento vadatīti pavattā. Atthassa ninnetāti
analyzed: vattā pavattā ati ciram sacca paṭivedham pavattentaḥ vadati iti pavattā atthassa ninnetā ati
translated: “He is a speaker” : he speaks for a long time, causing the penetration of the truth. “He is a proclaimer” : he proclaims, he speaks. “He is a demonstrator” :

original: atthaṃ uddharitvā dassetā, paramatthaṃ vā nibbānaṃ pāpayitā. Amatassa dātāti amatasacchikiriyaṃ🔽sattesu uppādento amataṃ dadātīti amatassa dātā. Bodhipakkhiyadhammānaṃ tadāyattabhāvato
analyzed: attham uddharitvā dassetā paramattham vā nibbānam pāpayitā amatassa dātā ati amata sacchikiriyam  sattesu uppādentaḥ amatam dadāti iti amatassa dātā bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam tad āyatta bhāvato
translated: he demonstrates, he shows the meaning, or he leads to the ultimate meaning, Nibbāna. “He is a giver of the deathless” :🔽he gives the deathless, causing beings to attain the deathless, the realization of the deathless. “He is the Lord of the Dhamma” :

original: dhammassāmī. Suvaṇṇāliṅganti suvaṇṇamayaṃ āliṅgaṃ khuddakamudiṅgaṃ. Supupphitasatapattapadumamiva
analyzed: dhammassāmī suvaṇṇa āliṅganti suvaṇṇa mayam āliṅgam khuddaka mudiṅgam su pupphita sata patta padumam iva
translated: because the factors of enlightenment are included in it. “A golden chain” : a small golden chain. “Like a golden lotus with a hundred petals in full bloom” :

original: sassirikaṃ sasobhaṃ supupphitasatapattasassirikaṃ.🔽Anumoditakālato paṭṭhāya…pe… buddhabhāsitaṃ nāma jātanti etena anumodanā buddhabhāsitabhāvassa🔽kāraṇanti ayamattho vutto viya dissati, evañca sati kathāvatthussa buddhabhāsitabhāvo
analyzed: sassirikam sasobham su pupphita sata patta sassirikam  anumodita kālataḥ buddha bhāsitam nāma jātan ti etena anumodanā buddha bhāsita bhāvassa  kāraṇam ti ayam atthaḥ vuttaḥ viya dissati evam ca sati kathā vatthussa buddha bhāsita bhāvaḥ
translated: beautiful, lovely, like a golden lotus with a hundred petals in full bloom.

original: na siyā ananumoditattā, tasmā evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo – “mahākaccāyano evaṃ vibhajissatī”ti
analyzed: na siyā an anumodita ttā tasmai evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo mahākaccāyanaḥ evam vibhajissati iti
translated: “From the time of his rejoicing” : from the time of his rejoicing, etc. “It has become the word of the Buddha” : by this it seems as if the meaning expressed is that the rejoicing is the cause of the discourse’s becoming the word of the Buddha. But if this were so, then the discourse would not be the word of the Buddha, since it was not rejoiced in by the Buddha. Therefore the meaning should be understood in the following way: “Mahākaccāyana will analyze it in this way.”

original: disvā bhagavā mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho, tatheva ca thero bhagavatā dinnanayena
analyzed: disvā bhagavā mātikam nikkhipitvā vihāram paviṭṭhaḥ tathā iva ca theraḥ bhagavatā dinna nayena
translated: and after seeing it, the Blessed One put down the bowl and entered the dwelling. The Elder also, in the same way, by the method given by the Blessed One,

original: ṭhapitamātikāya vibhajīti buddhabhāsitaṃ nāma jātaṃ, taṃ pana anumodanāya pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapita mātikāya vibhajīti buddhabhāsitam nāma jātam tam pana anumodanāya pākaṭam
translated: divided the Schedule as set out. Thus it came to be called “spoken by the Buddha.” But it became clear through the expression of appreciation.

original: jātanti etamatthaṃ sandhāya “evaṃ satthārā…pe… nāma jāta”nti vuttanti.
analyzed: jātanti etam attham sandhāya evam nāma jātanti vuttanti
translated: It is in reference to this meaning that it is said: “So the Master … came to be called the Schedule.”

original: Idāni pāḷiyā sannivesaṃ dassetuṃ “tattha dhammasaṅgaṇīpakaraṇe”tiādimāha. Kāmāvacarakusalato
analyzed: idāni pāḷiyā sannivesam dassetum tattha dhammasaṅgaṇī pakaraṇa iti ādim āha kāmāvacara kusalato
translated: Now, in order to point out the arrangement in the text, he said “Herein, in the Vibhaṅga of the Dhamma-saṅgaṇi” .

original: aṭṭhāti kāmāvacarakusale cattāro khandhe gahetvā tato aṭṭha cittāni uddharati. Paṭhamā🔽vibhattītipi vadanti. Ekūnanavuti cittānīti yattha etāni cittāni vibhattāni, te pāḷippadesā
analyzed: aṭṭha ati kāmāvacara kusale cattāraḥ khandhe gahetvā tatas aṭṭha cittāni uddharati paṭhamā  vadanti ekūnanavuti cittāni iti yattha etāni cittāni vibhattāni te pāḷippadesā
translated: Eight from the profitable of the sense sphere: having taken the four aggregates in the sense-sphere profitable, he extracts eight kinds of consciousness from it.🔽The first🔽is called the “analysis” . The ninety-nine kinds of consciousness: the passages in the text where these kinds of consciousness are analysed

original: “ekūnanavuti cittānī”ti vuttā. Tesañca samudāyo cittavibhatti, tasmā upapannametaṃ
analyzed: ekūnanavuti cittāni iti vuttā tesam ca samudāyaḥ citta vibhatti tasmai upapannam etam
translated: are called “the ninety-nine kinds of consciousness.” And the collection of them is the “analysis of consciousness.” So it is proper to say🔽“the ninety-nine kinds of consciousness are the analysis of consciousness.”

original: “ekūnanavuti cittāni cittavibhattī”ti. Mātikañca uddisitvā tattha ekekaṃ padaṃ uddharitvā
analyzed: ekūnanavuti cittāni citta vibhattī iti mātikam ca uddisitvā tattha ekekam padam uddharitvā
translated: And after announcing the Schedule, he extracts each clause from it

original: yasmā cittāni vibhattāni, tasmā mātikāpi cittavibhattiantogadhāyevāti cittuppādakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: cittāni vibhattāni tasmā mātikā api citta vibhatti anta gadhāya iva ati citta uppāda kaṇḍam
translated: And since the thoughts are classified, the mātikā is included in the classification of thoughts.

original: mātikāpadabhājanīyavasena duvidhanti idampi vacanaṃ yujjati.
analyzed: mātikā pada bhājanīya vasena idam api vacanam yujjati
translated: So the statement “The section on the arising of thoughts is twofold as mātikā and as padabhājaniya” is appropriate.🔽“From the root”: the brief statement by way of the roots of the wholesome, etc., beginning with “There are three roots of the wholesome.”

original: Mūlatoti “tīṇi kusalamūlānī”tiādinā kusalādīnaṃ mūlavasena saṅkhipitvā vacanaṃ. “Vedanākkhandho”tiādinā
analyzed: mūlataḥ iti tīṇi kusala mūlāni iti ādinā kusala ādīnam mūla vasena saṅkhipitvā vacanam vedanā kkhandha iti ādinā
translated: By way of aggregates: “The aggregate of feeling.”🔽By way of doors: “Bodily action.”

original: khandhato. “Kāyakamma”ntiādinā dvārato. “Sukhabhūmiyaṃ kāmāvacare”tiādinā bhūmito.
analyzed: khandhataḥ kāya kammanti ādinā dvārataḥ sukha bhūmi yam kāmāvacarā iti ādinā bhūmitaḥ
translated: By way of planes: “In the plane of pleasure, in the sense-sphere.”

original: Atthoti hetuphalaṃ. Dhammoti hetu. “Tīṇi kusalamūlāni tīṇi akusalamūlānī”tiādinā🔽hetuvasena saṅgaho dhammato nikkhepo. “Taṃsampayutto, taṃsamuṭṭhānā tadekaṭṭhā ca
analyzed: attho ti hetu phalam dhammo ti hetu tīṇi kusala mūlāni tīṇi akusala mūlāni itiādinā  hetu vasena saṅgahaḥ dhammataḥ nikkhepaḥ tad sampayuttaḥ tad samuṭṭhānā tad ekaṭṭhā ca
translated: “Meaning” is cause and fruit. “Idea” is cause. The inclusion by way of cause, beginning with “Three roots of the wholesome, three roots of the unwholesome,” is the definition by way of idea.

original: kilesā”tiādinā hetuphalavasena saṅgaho atthato nikkhepo. Atha vā dhammoti bhāsito.
analyzed: kilesa ati ādinā hetu phala vasena saṅgahaḥ atthataḥ nikkhepaḥ atha vā dhammaḥ ti bhāsito
translated: The inclusion by way of cause and fruit, beginning with “The defilements associated with that, arisen from that, and having that as their object,” is the definition by way of meaning. Or else: “idea” is what is stated;

original: Atthoti bhāsitattho. “Tayo kusalahetū”ti dhammo. “Tattha katame tayo kusalahetū alobho”tiādi
analyzed: attho ti bhāsita ttho tayo kusala hetū ti dhammo tattha katame tayo kusala hetū alobho tiādi
translated: “meaning” is the meaning of what is stated. “Three roots of the wholesome” is the idea. “What are the three roots of the wholesome? Non-greed” and so on is the meaning.

original: attho, so ca dhammo. “Tattha katamo alobho”tiādi atthoti evaṃ atthadhammavasena nikkhepo
analyzed: attho so ca dhammo tattha katamaḥ alobhaḥ tiādi attho ti evam attha dhamma vasena nikkhepaḥ
translated: and the meaning is the state of being free from greed, etc., and the state of being a root, etc.🔽The meaning should be known thus as the meaning and the states.

original: veditabbo. Nāmatoti “tīṇi kusalamūlānī”ti vuttadhammānaṃ alobhotiādināmavasena. Liṅgatoti
analyzed: veditabbaḥ nāmato ti tīṇi kusala mūlāni iti vutta dhammānam alobho ti ādi nāma vasena liṅgato ti
translated: As to name: the name of the states stated as “three profitable roots” is “free from greed,” etc.🔽As to gender: the meaning should be known as “free from greed,” etc., by the method of the masculine, etc.,

original: uddiṭṭhassa ekasseva dhammassa “alobho alubbhanā alubbhitatta”nti purisādiliṅgavasena nikkhepo.
analyzed: uddiṭṭhassa ekassa iva dhammassa alobhaḥ alubbhanā a lubbhita ttanti purisa ādi liṅga vasena nikkhepaḥ
translated: of the single state stated.🔽As to number: as to the occurrence of the number.🔽They bring to completion: they make the same, they fulfil.

original: Gaṇanacāranti gaṇanappavattiṃ. Samānentīti samānaṃ karonti pūrenti, tathā samānetabbanti
analyzed: gaṇana cāranti gaṇana pavattim samānenti iti samānam karonti pūrenti tathā samānetabbanti
translated: As to what should be brought to completion:

original: etthāpi. “Vijjābhāgino avijjābhāgino”ti evamādīsu ettha viññātesu ābhidhammikattherā
analyzed: ettha api vijjā bhāginaḥ avijjā bhāginaḥ ti evamādīsu ettha viññātesu ābhidhammika therā
translated: herein, when the Elder Abhidhamma teachers have known the states stated as “those partaking of understanding, those partaking of ignorance,”

original: suttantaṃ suṇantā cintentā ca suttantesu “vijjābhāgino”tiādīsu āgatesu atthassa viññātattā
analyzed: suttantam suṇantā cintentā ca suttantesu vijjā bhāgino ti ādīsu āgatesu atthassa viññāta ttā
translated: they do not tire when they hear the Suttas and reflect on them, because they have known the meaning of the words “those partaking of understanding,” etc., in the Suttas.

original: na kilamantīti etamatthaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “ābhidhammikattherānaṃ…pe… akilamatthaṃ ṭhapitā”ti.
analyzed: na kilamanti iti etam attham sandhāya vuttam ābhidhammika thera anaṃpe a kilamattham ṭhapitā ati
translated: With reference to this meaning it is said: “The Elder Abhidhamma teachers … were established in non-tiring.”

original: Anamataggoti aññātaggo. Khandhantaranti khandhanānattaṃ, khandhameva vā. Gahetuṃ
analyzed: anamataggo ti aññātaggo khandhantaram ti khandha nānattam khandham eva vā gahetum
translated: “Without a beginning” : without a known beginning. “The various groups” : the various kinds of aggregates or simply the aggregates. “Delicate” : hard to grasp,

original: asakkuṇeyyattā saṇhaṃ, sukhumāya paññāya gahetabbato sukhumañca dhammaṃ saṇhasukhumadhammaṃ.🔽Balavatā ñāṇavegena pavattattā balavato ñāṇavegassa nimittabhāvato ca balavaṃ. Gambhīrameva
analyzed: a sakkuṇeyya ttā saṇham sukhumāya paññāya gahetabbataḥ sukhumam ca dhammam saṇha sukhuma dhammam  balavatā ñāṇa vegena pavatta ttā balavataḥ ñāṇa vegassa nimitta bhāvataḥ ca balavam gambhīram eva
translated: “subtle” : to be grasped by subtle understanding.🔽“Powerful” : it is the cause of a powerful current of knowledge, which flows with great force.🔽“Deep” : it is deep itself or it has gone deep, or it has deep goings.

original: gambhīragataṃ, gambhīrāni vā gatāni gamanāni etassa santīti gambhīragataṃ. Yathānupubbanti
analyzed: gambhīra gatam gambhīrāni vā gatāni gamanāni etassa santi iti gambhīra gatam yathānupubbanti
translated: “In due course” : in due order.

original: yathānupubbena. Nikhilenāti niravasesena desitaṃ, pañcakhilarahitena vā bhagavatā🔽desitaṃ. Rūpagataṃvāti hatthagataṃ rūpaṃ viya cakkhunā. “Paṭivedhañāṇena samantapaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: yathā anupubbena nikhilena ati niravasesena desitam pañca khila rahitena vā bhagavatā  desitam rūpa gatam vā ati hattha gatam rūpam viya cakkhunā paṭivedha ñāṇena samanta paṭṭhānam
translated: “In full” : taught without remainder or taught by the Blessed One, who is free from the five hindrances.🔽“As though it were placed in the palm of the hand” : as though visible form were in the hand. “He who sees the successive order of the world by means of the knowledge of penetration, he exists, not he who does not” .

original: yo passati, so attheva, no natthī”ti attānaṃ sandhāya thero vadatīti.
analyzed: yaḥ passati saḥ atthā iva no natthi iti attānam sandhāya theraḥ vadati iti
translated: The Elder is referring to himself.

original: Khuddakavatthuvibhaṅge āgatesu ekādhikesu aṭṭhasu kilesasatesu aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni
analyzed: khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅge āgatesu eka adhikesu aṭṭhasu kilesa satesu aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: The eighty-eight hundred defilements mentioned in the Khandhakas of the Vinaya are included in the eighty-four hundred kinds of craving.

original: apanetvā sesā dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo ca uppannānuppannabhāvena diguṇitāni diyaḍḍhakilesasahassāni
analyzed: apanetvā sesāḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ ca uppanna anuppanna bhāvena di guṇitāni
translated: and the rest, the sixty-two views, are reckoned as two thousand five hundred and sixty-four defilements by counting them as past, future, and present.

original: dasādhikāni honti, appakaṃ pana ūnamadhikaṃ vā na gaṇanūpagaṃ hotīti “diyaḍḍhakilesasahassa”nti
analyzed: dasa adhikāni honti appakam pana ūnam adhikam vā na gaṇana upagam hoti iti
translated: But the small number that is less or more is not reckoned. That is why it is said, “two thousand five hundred and sixty-four defilements.”

original: vuttaṃ. Itaresaṃ atītādibhāvāmasanā aggahaṇaṃ khepane daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam itaresam atīta ādi bhāva āmasanā aggahaṇam khepane daṭṭhabbam
translated: The non-grasping of the others as past, etc., should be regarded as an ellipsis.

original: Mecakapaṭāti nīlanibhā paṭā. Cittasamuṭṭhānā vaṇṇadhātūti cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: mecaka paṭā ati nīla nibhā paṭā citta samuṭṭhānā vaṇṇa dhātū ti citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhānā
translated: “Blue-black cloth” is cloth of a blue-blackish colour. “The visible-data element originated by consciousness”: the meaning to be understood is “the visible-data element originated by temperature with consciousness as its condition.”

original: vaṇṇadhātūti attho gahetabbo. Kasmā? Na hi cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ rūpaṃ bahi nigacchatīti,
analyzed: vaṇṇa dhātū ti atthaḥ gahetabbo kasmā na hi citta samuṭṭhānam rūpam bahi nigacchati iti
translated: For materiality originated by consciousness does not go outside .

original: cittasamuṭṭhānarūpaparamparāya āgatattā pana evaṃ vuttaṃ. Atha vā cittasamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhāna rūpa paramparāya āgata ttā pana evam vuttam atha vā citta samuṭṭhānā
translated: But it is said thus because it has come by way of a continuity of materiality originated by consciousness. Or alternatively,

original: vaṇṇadhātūti ettha paccayautusaddānaṃ lopaṃ katvā soyeva pubbe vutto attho suvaṇṇatā
analyzed: vaṇṇa dhātū ti ettha paccaya otu saddānam lopam katvā saḥ yā iva pubbe vuttaḥ atthaḥ su vaṇṇa tā
translated: “the visible-data element originated by consciousness” is a locution in which the words “with temperature as condition” are omitted, like the locution “sweetness of sugar” .

original: sussaratā viya. Ettha hi “sussaratā”ti upādinnakādhikāre āgataṃ, na ca saddo upādinnako
analyzed: sussaratā viya ettha hi sussaratā ati upādinnaka adhikāre āgatam na ca saddaḥ upādinnakaḥ
translated: For here “sweetness” is a locution that occurs in the chapter on the “up-going” . But the word “sweetness” is not “up-going.”

original: atthi, tasmā upādinnakarūpaoṭṭhatāluādinissayattā evaṃ vuttanti, evametthāpi cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ🔽sandhāya “cittasamuṭṭhānā vaṇṇadhātū”ti vadati.
analyzed: atthi tasmai evam vuttam ti evam ettha api citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam  sandhāya citta samuṭṭhānā vaṇṇa dhātū iti vadati
translated: So too in the case of the materiality originated by temperature, which is a condition for consciousness.

original: Kāyasakkhinti paccakkhaṃ. Dantāvaraṇanti oṭṭhadvayaṃ. Mukhādānanti mukhavivaraṃ.
analyzed: kāyasakkhinti paccakkham danta āvaraṇanti oṭṭha dvayam mukhādānanti mukha vivaram
translated: ‘One who has experienced it with the body’ means one who has experienced it with the eye. ‘The covering of the teeth’ means the two lips. ‘The mouth’ means the mouth cavity.

original: Siliṭṭhanti saṃgataṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ. Sare nimittaṃ gahetvāti “dhammo eso vuccatī”ti
analyzed: siliṭṭhanti saṃgatam su saṇṭhitam sare nimittam gahetvā ati dhammo eso vuccati iti
translated: ‘Well-knit’ means well-knit together. ‘Having taken the sign from the flesh’ means having taken the sign by means of the flesh-mode of mindfulness thus ‘This is called the flesh-mode’

original: dhammassaravasena nimittaṃ gahetvā, na kilesānubyañjanavasena. Ekappahārenāti ettha
analyzed: dhammassara vasena nimittam gahetvā na kilesa anubyañjana vasena eka ppahārena ati ettha
translated: and not by means of the defilement-mode. ‘In one period’ :🔽herein,

original: pahāroti divasassa tatiyo bhāgo vuccati. Evaṃ santeti pubbe vuttamaggahetvā vācanāmaggassa
analyzed: pahāro ti divasassa tatiyaḥ bhāgaḥ vuccati evam santā iti pubbe vutta magga hetvā vācanā maggassa
translated: ‘period’ is said to be the third part of the day. ‘If it is so’ : taking the method stated previously, the method of recitation

original: therappabhavattavacanameva gahetvā tena purimavacanañca paṭikkhipanto codeti.
analyzed: thera ppabha vatta vacanam eva gahetvā tena purima vacanam ca paṭikkhipanto codeti
translated: is the method of the Elder. Taking only the statement of the Elder’s origin, he accuses the other by rejecting the previous statement.

original: Tenetametassāti vinayassa. Attatthaparatthādibhedeti yo taṃ suttaṃ sajjhāyati suṇāti
analyzed: tena itam etassa ati vinayassa atta ttha para ttha ādi bhede iti yaḥ tam suttam sajjhāyati suṇāti
translated: ‘Therefore this’ : of the Discipline. ‘The difference in one’s own benefit, another’s benefit, etc.’ : he who recites the Thread, listens to it,

original: vāceti cinteti deseti, suttena saṅgahito sīlādiattho tassapi hoti, tena parassa sādhetabbato
analyzed: vācā iti cintā iti dese ti suttena saṅgahitaḥ sīla ādi attho tassa api hoti tena parassa sādhetabbataḥ
translated: He speaks, he thinks, he teaches, and the meaning of virtue, etc., included in the sutta is his too, because it is to be accomplished by him.

original: parassapi hotīti tadubhayaṃ taṃ suttaṃ sūceti dīpeti. Tathā diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthe
analyzed: parassa api hoti iti tat ubhayam tam suttam sūceti dīpeti tathā diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika tthe
translated: And it is the other’s too, so that sutta shows, illuminates, both of them. Likewise the meaning of what is concerned with this present existence and with the existence of the next world,

original: lokiyalokuttarattheti evamādibhede atthe ādisaddena saṅgaṇhāti. Atthasaddo cāyaṃ🔽hitapariyāyavacanaṃ, na bhāsitatthavacanaṃ. Yadi siyā, suttaṃ attanopi bhāsitatthaṃ
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara ttha iti evamādi bhede atthe ādi saddena saṅgaṇhāti attha saddaḥ ca ayam  hita pariyāya vacanam na bhāsita attha vacanam yadi siyā suttam bhāsita ttham
translated: and the meaning of what is concerned with the worlds of the mundane and supramundane spheres, and so on. The word “meaning” includes all this.🔽And this word “meaning” is a synonym for welfare, not a synonym for the meaning of what is said. If it were, it would be possible to say that the sutta shows the meaning of what is said by oneself and by another.

original: sūceti parasuttassapīti ayamattho siyā, suttena ca yo attho pakāsito, so tasseva
analyzed: sūcā iti para suttassa api iti ayam attho siyā suttena ca yaḥ attho pakāsito saḥ tassa eva
translated: But the meaning that is revealed by the sutta is his alone,

original: hotīti na tena parattho sūcito hoti, tena ca sūcetabbassa paratthassa nivattetabbassa
analyzed: hoti iti na tena paratthaḥ sūcitaḥ hoti tena ca sūcetabbassa paratthassa nivattetabbassa
translated: so the meaning of another is not indicated by it. And because there is no meaning of another to be indicated and to be rejected,

original: abhāvā attaggahaṇaṃ na kattabbaṃ, attatthaparatthavinimuttassa bhāsitatthassa abhāvā
analyzed: abhāvā atta ggahaṇam na kattabbam atta ttha para ttha vinimuttassa bhāsita tthassa abhāvā
translated: there is no need to include the word “self.” And because there is no meaning of what is said that is not included in the meaning for oneself and for another,

original: ādiggahaṇañca na kattabbaṃ, tasmā yathāvuttassa atthassa sutte asambhavato suttādhārassa
analyzed: ādi gahaṇam ca na kattabbam tasmā yathā vuttassa atthassa sutte asambhavataḥ sutta ādhārassa
translated: there is no need to include the word “other.” So since the meaning stated is not possible in the sutta,

original: puggalassa vasena attatthaparatthā vuttā.
analyzed: puggalassa vasena atta attha para tthā vuttā
translated: The benefit for oneself and the benefit for others are stated according to the person.

original: Atha vā suttaṃ anapekkhitvā ye attatthādayopi atthappabhedā vuttā niddese “attattho
analyzed: atha vā suttam an apekkhitvā ye attattha ādayaḥ api attha ppabhedāḥ vuttā niddese
translated: Or else, without regard to the sutta, the benefit for oneself, etc., which are stated as the different kinds of benefit in the Niddesa, are indicated by the sutta. “The benefit for oneself,

original: parattho ubhayattho diṭṭhadhammiko attho samparāyiko attho uttāno attho gambhīro
analyzed: paratthaḥ ubhayatthaḥ diṭṭhadhammikaḥ attho samparāyikaḥ attho uttānaḥ atthaḥ gambhīro
translated: the benefit for others, the benefit for both, the benefit visible here and now, the benefit in the life to come, the benefit of the profitable, the benefit of the sublime,

original: attho guḷho attho paṭicchanno attho neyyo attho nīto attho anavajjo attho nikkileso🔽attho vodāno attho paramattho attho”ti, te suttaṃ sūcetīti attho. Atha vā “attanā
analyzed: atthaḥ guḷhaḥ atthaḥ paṭicchannaḥ atthaḥ neyyaḥ atthaḥ nītaḥ atthaḥ anavajjaḥ atthaḥ nikkilesaḥ  attho vodānaḥ attho paramattho attho ti te suttam sūceti iti attho atha vā attanā
translated: the benefit of the deep, the benefit of the hidden, the benefit of the undiscovered, the benefit of the discovered, the benefit of the blameless, the benefit of the uncorrupted,

original: ca appiccho hotī”ti attatthaṃ, “appicchakathañca paresaṃ kattā hotī”ti paratthaṃ🔽sūcetīti. Evaṃ “attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hotī”tiādisuttāni yojetabbāni. Vinayābhidhammehi
analyzed: ca appicchaḥ hoti iti atta attham appiccha katham ca paresam kattā hoti iti parattham  sūceti iti evam attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti iti ādi suttāni yojetabbāni vinaya abhidhammehi
translated: the benefit of the purified, the benefit of the ultimate” . Or else, “he himself is contented” is the benefit for oneself; “he is one who speaks to others about contentment” is the benefit for others.🔽Thus the suttas beginning with “He himself is abstainer from killing living beings” should be construed.

original: ca visesetvā suttasaddassa attho vattabbo, tasmā veneyyajjhāsayavasappavattāya desanāya
analyzed: ca visesetvā sutta saddassa atthaḥ vattabbaḥ tasmā veneyya jjhāsa yavasa ppavattāya desanāya
translated: And the meaning of the word sutta should be stated by distinguishing it from the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma. Therefore, since the teaching occurs in accordance with the dispositions of those who are trainable,

original: attahitaparahitādīni sātisayaṃ pakāsitāni honti, na āṇādhammasabhāvavasappavattāyāti
analyzed: atta hita para hita ādīni sa atisayam pakāsitāni honti na āṇā dhamma sabhāva vasa ppavattāya ati
translated: and the benefit for oneself, the benefit for others, etc., are made clear in excess, not in the mere form of a command.

original: idameva “atthānaṃ sūcanato sutta”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam eva atthānam sūcanato suttan ti vuttam
translated: This is why it is said: “Because it shows the meaning it is a sutta.”

original: Sutte ca āṇādhammasabhāvā veneyyajjhāsayaṃ anuvattanti, na vinayābhidhammesu viya
analyzed: sutte ca āṇā dhamma sabhāvāḥ veneyya ajjhāsayam anuvattanti na vinaya abhidhammesu viya
translated: And in the case of a sutta, the mere form of a command follows the inclination of those requiring training, not as in the case of the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma,

original: veneyyajjhāsayo āṇādhammasabhāve anuvattati, tasmā veneyyānaṃ ekantahitapaṭilābhasaṃvattanikā
analyzed: veneyya ajjhāsayo āṇā dhamma sabhāve anuvattati tasmā veneyyānam ekanta hita paṭilābha saṃvattanikā
translated: where the mere form of a command follows the inclination of those requiring training. That is why the teaching of the sutta-collection is conducive to the attainment of the highest benefit for those requiring training.🔽This is why it is said: “The meanings are well stated here” , etc. It bears fruit: it ripens.

original: suttantadesanā hotīti “suvuttā cettha atthā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pasavatīti phalati. “Suttāṇā”ti🔽etassa atthaṃ pakāsetuṃ “suṭṭhu ca ne tāyatī”ti vuttaṃ. Attatthaparatthādividhānesu
analyzed: suttanta desanā hoti iti su vuttā ca ittha attha atiādi vuttam pasavati iti phalati suttāṇā ti  etassa attham pakāsetum suṭṭhu ca vuttam atta ttha para ttha ādi vidhānesu
translated: In order to explain the meaning of “suttas” it is said: “It leads them on well” .🔽And the measure of a sutta and its inclusion of the various kinds of benefit for oneself, benefit for others, and so on, should be construed as follows.

original: ca suttassa pamāṇabhāvo tesañca saṅgāhakattaṃ yojetabbaṃ, tadatthappakāsane padhānattā
analyzed: ca suttassa pamāṇa bhāvaḥ tesam ca saṅgāhaka ttam yojetabbam tad attha ppakāsane padhāna ttā
translated: Because it is pre-eminent in revealing that meaning, the sutta is distinguished from the others.

original: suttassa itarehi visesanañca. Etanti “atthānaṃ sūcanato”tiādikaṃ atthavacanaṃ. Etassāti suttassa.
analyzed: suttassa itarehi visesanam ca etat ti atthānam sūcanato ti ādikam attha vacanam etassa ati suttassa
translated: The word “here” refers to the statement of meaning beginning with “Because it shows the meaning it is a sutta.” The word “this” refers to the sutta.

original: Abhikkamantīti ettha abhi-saddo kamanassa vuddhibhāvaṃ atirekattaṃ dīpeti. Abhikkantenāti
analyzed: abhikkamanti iti ettha abhi saddo kamanassa vuddhi bhāvam atireka ttam dīpeti abhikkantena ati
translated: The prefix abhi in abhikkamanti shows the increase and excess of the act of coming.

original: ca ettha kantiyā adhikattaṃ visesabhāvanti yuttaṃ kiriyāvisesakattā upasaggassa.
analyzed: ca ettha kantiyāḥ adhika ttam visesa bhāvanti yuttam kiriyā visesaka ttā upasaggassa
translated: And in abhikkantanti it shows the excess of the affection.

original: Abhiññātā, abhirājā, abhivinayeti ettha lakkhaṇapūjitaparicchinnesu rattiādīsu abhi-saddo
analyzed: abhiññātā abhirājā abhivinaya iti ettha lakkhaṇa pūjita paricchinnesu ratti ādīsu abhisaddaḥ
translated: The prefix abhi in abhiññātā, abhirājā, abhivinaye shows the night, etc., as characterized, worshipped, and limited.

original: vattatīti kathametaṃ yujjeyyāti? Lakkhaṇakaraṇañāṇapūjanaparicchedakiriyādīpanato
analyzed: vattati iti katham etam yujjeyya iti lakkhaṇa karaṇa ñāṇa pūjana pariccheda kiriyā dīpanato
translated: How can this be right? Because it shows the act of characterizing, the act of worshipping, the act of limiting, etc.,

original: tāhi ca kiriyāhi rattirājavinayānaṃ yuttattā. Bhāvanāpharaṇavuddhīhi vuddhimanto.🔽Ārammaṇādīhīti ārammaṇasampayuttakammadvārapaṭipadādīhi. Avisiṭṭhanti aññamaññavisiṭṭhesu
analyzed: tāhi ca kiriyāhi bhāvanā pharaṇa vuddhīhi vuddhimantaḥ  ārammaṇa ādīhi iti ārammaṇa sampayutta kamma dvāra paṭipad ādīhi avisiṭṭhanti aññamañña visiṭṭhesu
translated: and because the night, the king, and the discipline are appropriate to those acts.🔽They are endowed with increase by the increase of development.🔽By objects, etc., : by objects, associated states, doors of action, way of practice, etc.

original: vinayasuttantābhidhammesu avisiṭṭhaṃ samānaṃ piṭakasaddanti attho. Yathāvuttenevāti
analyzed: vinaya suttanta abhidhammesu avisiṭṭham samānam piṭaka saddanti atthaḥ yathā vuttena eva ati
translated: Not limited: the meaning is that it is not limited to the Vinaya, Suttanta, and Abhidhamma, which are limited to each other.🔽By the very method stated:

original: “evaṃ duvidhatthenā”tiādinā nayena.
analyzed: evam duvidhatthena ati ādinā nayena
translated: by the method stated thus “In these two ways.”

original: Kathetabbānaṃ atthānaṃ desakāyattena āṇādividhinā atisajjanaṃ pabodhanaṃ desanā.🔽Sāsitabbapuggalagatena yathāparādhādinā sāsitabbabhāvena anusāsanaṃ vinayanaṃ sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: kathetabbānam atthānam desaka āyattena āṇa ādi vidhinā atisajjanam pabodhanam desanā  sāsitabba puggala gatena yathā aparādha ādinā sāsitabba bhāvena anusāsanam vinayanam sāsanam
translated: Teaching is the arousing of understanding by the method of command, etc., in the sense of the suitability of the time for the matter to be taught.🔽Discipline is the training by way of the person to be trained, in the sense of the state of being trainable according to the offence, etc. The Dispensation is the teaching.🔽Discussion is the making of speech-contact by teaching the matter to be taught, such as restraint and non-restraint.

original: Kathetabbassa saṃvarāsaṃvarādino atthassa kathanaṃ vacanapaṭibaddhakaraṇaṃ kathā.🔽Bheda-saddo visuṃ visuṃ yojetabbo “desanābhedaṃ sāsanabhedaṃ kathābhedañca yathārahaṃ
analyzed: kathetabbassa saṃvara asaṃvara ādino atthassa kathanam vacana paṭibaddha karaṇam kathā  bheda saddaḥ visum visum yojetabbaḥ desanā bhedam sāsana bhedam kathā bhedam ca yathāraham
translated: The word “distinction” should be construed with each of the three terms: “the distinction of teaching, the distinction of the Dispensation, and the distinction of discussion.”🔽“I shall illuminate” means I shall reveal.

original: paridīpaye”ti. Bhedanti nānattaṃ, nānākaraṇanti attho. Sikkhā ca pahānāni ca gambhīrabhāvo🔽ca sikkhāpahānagambhīrabhāvaṃ, tañca paridīpaye. Yanti pariyattiādiṃ. Yathāti upārambhādihetu🔽pariyāpuṇanādippakārehi.
analyzed: paridīpaya iti bhedanti nānattam nānākaraṇanti attho sikkhā ca pahānāni ca gambhīra bhāvaḥ  ca sikkhā apahāna gambhīra bhāvam tat ca paridīpaye yanti pariyatti ādim yathā ati upārambha ādi hetu  pariyāpuṇanā ādi pakārehi
translated: The distinction of training and the distinction of abandoning and the distinction of profundity are the distinction of training, abandoning and profundity.🔽“And that” refers to the three. “I shall reveal” means I shall reveal the three.🔽“In the three” means in the three Piṭakas. “The meaning of the text” is the meaning of the text of the three Piṭakas. “The teaching of the text” is the teaching of the text of the three Piṭakas. “The penetration of the meaning of the text” is the penetration of the meaning of the text of the three Piṭakas.

original: Tīsupi cetesu ete dhammatthadesanāpaṭivedhāti ettha tantiattho tantidesanā tantiatthapaṭivedho
analyzed: tīsu pi ca itesu ete dhamma attha desanā paṭivedhā ti ettha tanti atthaḥ tanti desanā tanti attha paṭivedho
translated: “The meaning of the Dhamma” is the meaning of the Dhamma of the three Piṭakas. “The teaching of the Dhamma” is the teaching of the Dhamma of the three Piṭakas. “The penetration of the teaching of the Dhamma” is the penetration of the teaching of the Dhamma of the three Piṭakas.

original: ca tantivisayā hontīti vinayapiṭakādīnaṃ atthadesanāpaṭivedhādhārabhāvo yutto, piṭakāni
analyzed: ca tanti visayāḥ honti iti vinaya piṭaka ādīnam attha desanā paṭivedha ādhāra bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ piṭakāni
translated: and the three Piṭakas are their domain. So it is proper to say that the three Piṭakas are the foundation for the discovery of the meaning of the three Baskets, namely, the Vinaya Piṭaka, etc.,

original: pana tantiyoyevāti dhammādhārabhāvo kathaṃ yujjeyyāti? Tantisamudāyassa avayavatantiyā
analyzed: pana dhamma ādhāra bhāvo katham yujjeyya ati tanti samudāyassa avayava tantiyā
translated: but how can it be proper to say that the three Piṭakas are the foundation for ideas, etc., since the three Piṭakas are only the Threads?🔽Because the Threads are the foundation for the Thread-collection,

original: ādhārabhāvato, dhammādīnañca dukkhogāhabhāvato tehi vinayādayo gambhīrāti vinayādīnañca🔽catubbidho gambhīrabhāvo vutto, tasmā “dhammādayo eva dukkhogāhattā gambhīrā, na
analyzed: ādhāra bhāvataḥ dhamma ādīnam ca dukkha ugāha bhāvataḥ tehi vinaya ādayaḥ gambhīrā ati vinaya ādīnam ca  catubbidhaḥ gambhīra bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ tasmā dhamma ādayo eva dukkha ogāhattā gambhīrāḥ na
translated: and because the Vinaya, etc., are profound owing to the ideas, etc., being hard to grasp.🔽So it is said that the fourfold profundity of the Vinaya, etc.,

original: vinayādayo”ti na codetabbametaṃ. Tattha paṭivedhassa dukkarabhāvato dhammatthānaṃ,🔽desanāñāṇassa dukkarabhāvato desanāya ca dukkhogāhabhāvo veditabbo. Paṭivedhassa🔽pana uppādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā tabbisayañāṇuppattiyā ca dukkarabhāvato dukkhogāhatā veditabbā.
analyzed: vinaya ādayaḥ ti na codetabbam etam tattha paṭivedhassa dukkara bhāvataḥ dhammatthānam  desanā ñāṇassa dukkara bhāvataḥ desanāya ca dukkha ugāha bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ paṭivedhassa  pana uppādetum a sakkuṇeyya ttā tad visaya ñāṇa uppattiyā ca dukkara bhāvataḥ dukkha ugāha tā veditabbā
translated: is owing to the ideas, etc., being hard to grasp, not owing to the Vinaya, etc., being hard to grasp. Herein, the ideas are the foundation because penetration is hard;🔽and the teaching is hard to grasp because the knowledge of teaching is hard.🔽But the ideas are hard to grasp because the occurrence of the knowledge whose domain is penetration is hard owing to the impossibility of producing penetration.

original: Hetumhi ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidāti etena vacanatthena dhammassa hetubhāvo kathaṃ
analyzed: hetumhi ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā ti etena vacana atthena dhammassa hetu bhāvaḥ katham
translated: Knowledge of the cause is the discrimination of ideas:

original: ñātabboti? “Dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti etassa samāsapadassa avayavapadatthaṃ dassentena🔽“hetumhi ñāṇa”nti vuttattā. “Dhamme paṭisambhidā”ti ettha hi “dhamme”ti etassa atthaṃ
analyzed: ñātabbaḥ ti dhamma paṭisambhidā ti etassa samāsa padassa avayava pada attham dassentena  hetumhi ñāṇam ti vutta ttā dhamme paṭisambhidā ti ettha hi dhamma iti etassa attham
translated: What is to be known?🔽The meaning of the words of the compound is shown by the words “Knowledge of ideas” .🔽For the meaning of “ideas” in “Understanding of ideas” is shown by the words “in the cause” ,

original: dassentena “hetumhī”ti vuttaṃ, “paṭisambhidā”ti etassa ca atthaṃ dassentena “ñāṇa”nti,
analyzed: dassentena hetumhi iti vuttam paṭisambhidā ti etassa ca attham dassentena ñāṇam ti
translated: and the meaning of “understanding” is shown by the words “knowledge” .

original: tasmā hetudhammasaddā ekatthā ñāṇapaṭisambhidāsaddā cāti imamatthaṃ dassentena sādhito
analyzed: tasmā hetu dhamma saddāḥ ekatthāḥ ñāṇa paṭisambhidā saddāḥ ca ati imam attham dassentena sādhitaḥ
translated: So the words “cause” and “idea” have the same meaning, and the words “understanding” and “knowledge” have the same meaning.🔽The meaning of the words “in the cause” is established in this way.

original: dhammassa hetubhāvo. Atthassa hetuphalabhāvo ca evameva daṭṭhabbo. Yathādhammanti
analyzed: dhammassa hetu bhāvaḥ atthassa hetu phala bhāvaḥ ca evam eva daṭṭhabbaḥ yathādhammanti
translated: And the meaning of the words “in the fruit” should be understood in the same way.🔽As to ideas: here the word “ideas” includes both the cause and the fruit of the ideas beginning with ignorance and formations.

original: ettha dhamma-saddo hetuṃ hetuphalañca sabbaṃ gaṇhāti. Sabhāvavācako hesa, na pariyattihetubhāvavācako,
analyzed: ettha dhamma saddaḥ hetum hetu phalam ca sabbam gaṇhāti sa bhāva vācakaḥ ha esa na pariyatti hetu bhāva vācakaḥ
translated: For it is a word that denotes individual essence, not a word that denotes the cause and fruit of the scriptures.

original: tasmā yathādhammanti yo yo avijjāsaṅkhārādidhammo, tasmiṃ tasminti attho. Dhammābhilāpoti
analyzed: tasmai yathādhammam ti yaḥ yaḥ avijjā saṅkhāra ādi dhammo tasmin tasmin ti atthaḥ dhamma abhilāpo ti
translated: So the meaning is “in each case according to the idea,” that is, in each case according to the idea of ignorance, formations, and so on.🔽As to the expression of ideas:

original: atthabyañjanako aviparītābhilāpo. Etena “tatra dhammaniruttābhilāpe ñāṇaṃ niruttipaṭisambhidā”ti🔽ettha vuttadhammaniruttiṃ dasseti. Anulomādivasena vā kathananti etena tassā dhammaniruttiyā
analyzed: attha byañjanakaḥ aviparīta abhilāpaḥ etena tatra dhamma nirutta abhilāpe ñāṇam nirutti paṭisambhidā ati  ettha vutta dhamma niruttim dasseti anuloma ādi vasena vā kathanan ti etena tassā dhamma niruttiyā
translated: and the expression of the meaning is the unperverted statement. By this he shows the expression of the Dhamma stated in the passage: “Understanding of the expression of the Dhamma there is discernment of language” .

original: abhilāpaṃ kathanaṃ tassa vacanassa pavattanaṃ dasseti. Adhippāyoti etena “desanāti🔽paññattī”ti etaṃ vacanaṃ dhammaniruttābhilāpaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na tabbinimuttaṃ
analyzed: abhilāpam kathanam tassa vacanassa pavattanam dasseti adhippāyaḥ ti etena desanā ti  paññatti iti etam vacanam dhamma nirutta abhilāpam sandhāya vuttam na tat vinimuttam
translated: Or else, by “the manner of expression, etc.,” he shows the expression of that Dhamma-expression, its utterance, the occurrence of that statement. By “the purport” he shows that the statement “The teaching is the designation”

original: paññattiṃ sandhāyāti dasseti.
analyzed: paññattim sandhāya ati dasseti
translated: is made with reference to the expression of the Dhamma-expression, not with reference to the designation that is its own meaning.

original: So ca lokiyalokuttaroti evaṃ vuttaṃ abhisamayaṃ yena pakārena abhisameti, yañca abhisameti,🔽yo ca tassa sabhāvo, tehi pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ “visayato asammohato ca atthādianurūpaṃ dhammādīsu
analyzed: saḥ ca lokiya lokuttaraḥ ti evam vuttam abhisamayam yena pakārena abhisameti yat ca abhisameti  yaḥ ca tassa sabhāvaḥ tehi pākaṭam kātum visayataḥ asammohataḥ ca attha ādi anurūpam dhamma ādīsu
translated: And the penetration stated as “that, too, is mundane and supramundane” he makes clear by the mode in which it is penetrated and by what is penetrated,🔽and by its own nature. And he says: “The understanding of ideas, etc., in accordance with their meaning, etc., by way of their province and by way of non-delusion,”

original: avabodho”ti āha. Tattha hi visayato atthādianurūpaṃ dhammādīsu avabodho avijjādidhammasaṅkhārādiatthatadubhayapaññāpanārammaṇo
analyzed: avabodho ti āha tattha hi visayataḥ attha ādi anurūpam dhamma ādīsu avabodhaḥ avijjā ādi dhamma saṅkhāra ādi attha tad ubhaya paññāpana ārammaṇaḥ
translated: for here the understanding of ideas, etc., in accordance with their meaning, etc., by way of their province is the condition for the ideas beginning with ignorance, etc., and for the meanings beginning with determinations, etc., and is the object for the designation of both.

original: lokiyo abhisamayo. Asammohato atthādianurūpaṃ dhammādīsu avabodho nibbānārammaṇo
analyzed: lokiyaḥ abhisamayaḥ asammohataḥ attha ādi anurūpam dhamma ādīsu avabodhaḥ nibbāna ārammaṇaḥ
translated: The mundane direct-knowledge is the understanding of the meaning of the truths, etc., in accordance with their meaning, which is accompanied by doubt, and which has Nibbāna as its object.

original: maggasampayutto yathāvuttadhammatthapaññattīsu sammohaviddhaṃsano lokuttaro abhisamayoti.🔽Abhisamayato aññampi paṭivedhatthaṃ dassetuṃ “tesaṃ tesaṃ vā”tiādimāha. “Paṭivedhanaṃ
analyzed: magga sampayuttaḥ yathāvutta dhammattha paññattīsu sammoha viddhaṃsanaḥ lokuttaraḥ abhisamayaḥ ti  abhisamayataḥ aññam pi paṭivedha attham dassetum tesam tesam vā ti ādim āha paṭivedhanam
translated: The supramundane direct-knowledge is the understanding of the truths, etc., in accordance with their meaning, which is accompanied by non-doubt, and which has Nibbāna as its object.🔽In order to show that penetration also has the meaning of “penetrating” other than the meaning of “direct-knowledge,” he says, “Or else, penetration is the penetration of the meaning of the truths, etc.”

original: paṭivedho”ti iminā hi vacanatthena abhisamayo, paṭivijjhīyatīti paṭivedhoti iminā
analyzed: paṭivedhaḥ ti iminā hi vacana atthena abhisamayaḥ paṭivijjhīyati iti paṭivedhaḥ ti iminā
translated: For penetration is the meaning of the word “direct-knowledge” .

original: taṃtaṃrūpādidhammānaṃ aviparītasabhāvo ca paṭivedhoti yujjati.
analyzed: tad taṃ rūpa ādi dhammānam aviparīta sabhāvo ca paṭivedho ti yujjati
translated: And it is proper to say that penetration is the unperverted individual essence of the various dhammas such as form, etc., since it is penetrated .

original: Yathāvuttehi dhammādīhi piṭakānaṃ gambhīrabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “idāni yasmā etesu piṭakesū”tiādimāha.🔽Yo cetthāti etesu taṃtaṃpiṭakagatesu dhammādīsu yo paṭivedho etesu ca piṭakesu tesaṃ
analyzed: yathā vuttehi dhamma ādīhi piṭakānam gambhīra bhāvam dassetuṃ idāni yasmai etesu piṭakesu iti ādim āha  yaḥ ca itthā ati etesu taṃ taṃ piṭaka gatesu dhamma ādīsu yaḥ paṭivedhaḥ etesu ca piṭakesu tesam
translated: In order to show the profundity of the Piṭakas by means of the truths, etc., as stated, he says, “Now, since in these Piṭakas.”

original: tesaṃ dhammānaṃ yo aviparītasabhāvoti yojetabbo. Dukkhogāhatā ca vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: tesam dhammānam yaḥ aviparīta sabhāvaḥ ti yojetabbaḥ dukkha ugāha tā ca vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: The penetration of the truths, etc., in the various Piṭakas, and the unperverted individual essence of the various dhammas in the various Piṭakas, should be construed here. The oppression by suffering should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Ayaṃ panettha viseso “aviparītasabhāvasaṅkhāto paṭivedho dubbiññeyyatāya eva dukkhogāho”ti.
analyzed: ayam pana ittha visesaḥ aviparīta sabhāva saṅkhātaḥ paṭivedhaḥ dubbiññeyya tāya eva dukkhogāho ti
translated: But the difference here is that penetration, which is called “the true nature,” is hard to enter upon because of its difficulty to understand.

original: Yanti pariyattiduggahaṇaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Atthanti bhāsitatthaṃ payojanatthañca.🔽Na upaparikkhantīti na vicārenti. Na nijjhānaṃ khamantīti nijjhānapaññaṃ na khamanti,
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam atthanti bhāsita attham payojana attham ca  na upaparikkhanti iti na vicārenti na nijjhānam khamanti iti nijjhāna paññam na khamanti
translated: “Yanti” is said with reference to the difficulty of grasping the scriptures. “Attha” is the meaning of what is said and the purpose of what is said.

original: nijjhāyitvā paññāya disvā rocetvā na gahetabbā hontīti adhippāyo. Itīti evaṃ etāya
analyzed: nijjhāyitvā paññāya disvā rocetvā na gahetabbāḥ honti iti adhippāyaḥ iti iti evam etāya
translated: “Do not investigate” : they do not examine. “Do not accept” : they do not accept after having examined with wisdom, after having seen, after having understood. The intention is that they are not to be grasped. “Itī” : in this way, by this scripture.

original: pariyattiyā vādappamokkhānisaṃsā attano upari parehi āropitavādassa niggahassa pamokkhappayojanā🔽hutvā dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇanti. Vādappamokkhoti vā nindāpamokkho. Yassa catthāyāti yassa🔽ca sīlādiparipūraṇassa anupādāvimokkhassa vā atthāya. Dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇantīti ñāyena
analyzed: pariyattiyāḥ vāda ppamokkha anisaṃsāḥ attanaḥ upari parehi āropita vādassa niggahassa pamokkha ppayojanā  hutvā dhammam pariyāpuṇanti vāda ppamokkho ti vā nindā apamokkho yassa catthāya ati yassa  ca sīla ādi paripūraṇassa an upādā vimokkhassa vā atthāya dhammam pariyāpuṇanti iti ñāyena
translated: The purpose of the scriptures is the escape from the debate that others bring up against oneself.🔽They learn the Dhamma with the purpose of the escape from the debate. Or else, “escape from the debate” is escape from blame. “Yassa ca atthāya” : for the purpose of which

original: pariyāpuṇantīti adhippāyo. Assāti assa dhammassa. Nānubhontīti na vindanti. Tesaṃ
analyzed: pariyāpuṇanti iti adhippāyaḥ assa ati assa dhammassa na anubhonti iti na vindanti tesam
translated: fulfillment of virtue, etc., or of the liberation by nongrasping. “They learn the Dhamma” : they learn by the method. The intention is that they learn by the method. “Assa” : of that Dhamma. “Do not experience” : do not find.

original: te dhammā duggahitattā upārambhamānadappamakkhapalāsādihetubhāvena dīgharattaṃ ahitāya
