analyzed: te dhammā duggahita ttāḥ upārambha māna dappa makkha palāsa ādi hetu bhāvena dīgharattam ahitāya
translated: being a cause for censure, contempt, and conceit.

original: dukkhāya saṃvattanti. Bhaṇḍāgāre niyutto bhaṇḍāgāriko, bhaṇḍāgāriko viyāti bhaṇḍāgāriko,
analyzed: dukkhāya saṃvattanti bhaṇḍāgāre niyuttaḥ bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ viyāti bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ
translated: The one appointed to the storehouse is the storehouse-keeper. He is like a storehouse-keeper, thus he is the storehouse-keeper.🔽He is the guardian of the treasure of the Dhamma.

original: dhammaratanānupālako. Aññaṃ atthaṃ anapekkhitvā bhaṇḍāgārikasseva sato pariyatti
analyzed: dhamma ratana anupālakaḥ aññam attham an apekkhitvā bhaṇḍāgārikassa iva sataḥ pariyatti
translated: The storehouse-keeper’s learning is the learning of one who, without regard for any other purpose,

original: bhaṇḍāgārikapariyatti.
analyzed: bhaṇḍāgārika pariyatti
translated: is intent only on the storehouse-keeper’s work.

original: Tāsaṃyevāti avadhāraṇaṃ pāpuṇitabbānaṃ chaḷabhiññācatupaṭisambhidānaṃ vinaye pabhedavacanābhāvaṃ🔽sandhāya vuttaṃ. Verañjakaṇḍe hi tisso vijjāva vibhattāti. Dutiye tāsaṃyevāti avadhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tāsam yeva ati avadhāraṇam pāpuṇitabbānam chaṭ abhiññā catu paṭisambhidānam vinaye pabheda vacana abhāvam  sandhāya vuttam verañja kaṇḍe hi tissaḥ vijjāva vibhattā ati dutiye tāsam yeva ati avadhāraṇam
translated: “Of those alone”: the word “alone” is said with reference to the six kinds of direct knowledge and the four discriminations, which are to be attained.🔽For in the Verañjā Khandha it is said: “The three knowledges are analyzed.”🔽In the second case, the word “alone” is said with reference to the four discriminations, not with reference to the three knowledges.

original: catasso paṭisambhidā apekkhitvā kataṃ, na tisso vijjā. Tā hi chasu abhiññāsu antogadhāti
analyzed: catasso paṭisambhidāḥ apekkhitvā katam na tissaḥ vijjā tāḥ hi chasu abhiññāsu antogadhāti
translated: For the latter are included in the six kinds of direct knowledge.🔽They are analyzed in the Suttas.🔽“Having known, he combines” is the construction.

original: sutte vibhattāyevāti. Ñatvā saṅgayhamānanti yojanā. Tesanti tesaṃ piṭakānaṃ. Sabbampīti
analyzed: sutte vibhattāya iva ati ñatvā saṅgayhamānam iti yojanā tesam ti tesam piṭakānam sabbam pi iti
translated: “Those” refers to those three Piṭakas.🔽“All”:

original: sabbampi buddhavacanaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam pi buddha vacanam
translated: all the Buddha’s word.

original: Atthānulomanāmato anulomiko. Anulomikattaṃyeva vibhāvetuṃ “kasmā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: attha anuloma nāmataḥ anulomikaḥ anulomika ttam yeva vibhāvetum kasmā pana atiādi vuttam
translated: It is called “in conformity with the meaning” because it is in conformity with the meaning. In order to make this clear, the question “But why is it called the Abhidhamma Pitaka?” is asked.

original: Ekanikāyampīti ekasamūhampi. Poṇikā ca cikkhallikā ca khattiyā, tesaṃ nivāso poṇikanikāyo
analyzed: eka nikāyam pi iti eka samūham pi poṇikā ca cikkhallikā ca khattiyā tesam nivāso poṇika nikāyo
translated: “A single group” means a single collection. The “stiff” and “stiff-necked” nobles had a “stiff-necked group”

original: cikkhallikanikāyo ca. Evaṃ dhammakkhandhato caturāsīti dhammakkhandhasahassānīti
analyzed: cikkhallika nikāyaḥ ca evam dhammakkhandhato caturāsīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti
translated: and a “stiff group.” Thus there are eighty-four thousand groups of states.

original: buddhavacanapiṭakādīni niṭṭhāpetvā anekacchariyapātubhāvapaṭimaṇḍitāya saṅgītiyā
analyzed: buddha vacana piṭaka ādīni niṭṭhāpetvā aneka chariya pātubhāva paṭimaṇḍitāya saṅgītiyā
translated: Having thus completed the Buddha’s Word consisting of the three Piṭakas, etc., the author now begins the section on the recital, which is adorned with the manifestation of many miracles, with the words “Thus all this,” etc.

original: paṭhamabuddhavacanādiko sabbo vuttappabhedo aññopi uddānasaṅgahādibhedo saṅgītiyā🔽ñāyatīti etassa dassanatthaṃ “evametaṃ sabbampī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Ayaṃ abhidhammo piṭakato
analyzed: paṭhama buddha vacana ādikaḥ sabbaḥ vutta ppabhedaḥ aññaḥ api uddāna saṅgaha ādi bhedaḥ saṅgītiyā  ñāyati iti etassa dassana attham evam etam sabbam pi itiādi āraddham ayam abhidhammaḥ piṭakataḥ
translated: The fact that the whole of the Buddha’s Word, with its various divisions beginning with the first utterance, is known through the recital,🔽and also the fact that the Abhidhamma is the middle portion of the Buddha’s Word and that the Tathāgata was originally an Abhidhammika,

original: abhidhammapiṭakantiādinā piṭakādibhāvadassaneneva majjhimabuddhavacanabhāvo tathāgatassa🔽ca ādito ābhidhammikabhāvo dassitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭakam ti ādinā piṭaka ādi bhāva dassanena iva majjhima buddha vacana bhāvaḥ tathāgatassa 🔽ca āditaḥ ābhidhammika bhāvaḥ dassito ti veditabbo
translated: are shown by the words “Thus all this is known through the recital” and by the words “The Abhidhamma is the middle portion of the Buddha’s Word,” etc., which show the Abhidhamma’s position as the third Piṭaka, etc.

original: Ettha siyā “yadi tathāgatabhāsitabhāvo abhidhammassa siddho siyā, majjhimabuddhavacanabhāvo
analyzed: ettha siyā yadi tathāgata bhāsita bhāvaḥ abhidhammassa siddhaḥ siyā majjhima buddha vacana bhāvaḥ
translated: Here it may be asked: “If the status of the Abhidhamma as spoken by the Tathāgata were established, then the status of the Majjhima as Buddha-word

original: ca siddho bhaveyya, so eva ca na siddho”ti tassa vinayādīhi buddhabhāsitabhāvaṃ sādhetuṃ
analyzed: ca siddhaḥ bhaveyya saḥ eva ca na siddhaḥ ti tassa vinaya ādīhi buddha bhāsita bhāvam sādhetum
translated: would also be established, and that is not established.” In order to establish the status of the Vinaya, etc., as spoken by the Buddha, he shows the subject matter

original: vatthuṃ dassento “taṃ dhārayantesu bhikkhūsū”tiādimāha. Sabbasāmayikaparisāyāti sabbanikāyikaparisāya
analyzed: vatthum dassentaḥ tam dhārayantesu bhikkhūsu iti ādim āha sabba sāmayika parisāya iti sabba nikāyika parisāya
translated: with the words “among the bhikkhus who were memorizing it.” In the assembly of all the elders: in the assembly of all the nikāyas.

original: pañcapi nikāye pariyāpuṇantiyā. Na uggahitanti sakalassa vinayapiṭakassa anuggahitattā
analyzed: pañca api nikāye pariyāpuṇantiyā na sakalassa vinaya piṭakassa an uggahita ttā
translated: They memorized the five nikāyas. They had not learned: he says this because the entire Vinaya Piṭaka had not been learned.🔽They had learned only the Vinaya: he says this because they had learned the two Vibhaṅgas.

original: āha. Vinayamattaṃ uggahitanti vibhaṅgadvayassa uggahitattā āha. Vinayaṃ avivaṇṇetukāmatāya
analyzed: āha vinaya mattam uggahitanti vibhaṅga dvayassa uggahita ttā āha vinayam a vivaṇṇetu kāma tāya
translated: Because he did not want to explain the Vinaya,🔽there is no offense for him in saying, “Memorize the Abhidhamma.”

original: “abhidhammaṃ pariyāpuṇassū”ti bhaṇantassa anāpattiṃ, abhidhamme anokāsakataṃ bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: abhidhammam pariyāpuṇassu iti bhaṇantassa anāpattim abhidhamme anokāsakatam bhikkhum
translated: When they asked a question of a bhikkhu who had not studied the Abhidhamma,

original: pañhaṃ pucchantiyā pācittiyañca vadantena bhagavatā abhidhammassa buddhabhāsitabhāvo
analyzed: pañham pucchantiyā pācittiyam ca vadantena bhagavatā abhidhammassa buddha bhāsita bhāvo
translated: and when the Blessed One said that there was an offense of expiation for that, the status of the Abhidhamma as spoken by the Buddha was established.

original: dīpito buddhabhāsitehi suttādīhisaha vacanato, bāhirakabhāsitesu ca īdisassa vacanassa abhāvā.
analyzed: dīpitaḥ buddha bhāsitehi sutta ādīhi saha vacanataḥ bāhiraka bhāsitesu ca īdisassa vacanassa abhāvā
translated: and it is shown by the words of the Buddha’s own utterance, the Suttas, etc., and not by any such utterance of outsiders.

original: Itopi balavataraṃ ābhidhammikassa sādhukāradānena vicikicchāvicchedassa katattā.
analyzed: itas api balavataram ābhidhammikassa sādhukāra dānena vicikicchā vicchedassa kata ttā
translated: And this is more powerful than the other because the other’s doubt is cut by the other’s giving approval to the Abhidhamma.

original: Kammato aññaṃ kammaṃ kammantaraṃ, taṃ kāmāvacarādiṃ rūpāvacarādibhāvena, kaṇhavipākādiṃ
analyzed: kammataḥ aññam kammam kammantaram tam kāmāvacara ādim rūpāvacara ādi bhāvena kaṇha vipāka ādim
translated: “Another action” is an action different from the one under discussion. He “distorts” it by explaining the action of the sense sphere, etc., as that of the fine-material sphere, etc.,

original: sukkavipākādibhāvena kathento āloḷeti.
analyzed: sukka vipāka ādi bhāvena kathentaḥ āloḍeti
translated: and the action with a happy destiny, etc., as that with a miserable destiny, etc.

original: Jinacakketi jinasāsane. Visaṃvādetīti vippalambheti. Bhedakaravatthūsu ekasminti
analyzed: jina cakka iti jina sāsane visaṃvāda iti iti vippalambha iti bheda kara vatthūsu ekasmin ti
translated: “The Wheel of the Victor” is the Dispensation of the Victor. “He misrepresents” : he misleads. “In one of the grounds for schism” :

original: “bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpetī”ti ekasmiṃ
analyzed: bhāsitam lapitam tathāgatena a bhāsitam a lapitam tathāgatena ati dīpeti iti ekasmin
translated: “He shows that what was spoken by the Tathāgata was not spoken by him, and what was not spoken by the Tathāgata was spoken by him” .🔽In one of the grounds for schism it appears. The same method of explanation applies to the rest.

original: sandissati. Uttaripi evaṃ vattabbo…pe… na aññesaṃ visayo…pe… nidānakiccaṃ nāma natthīti
analyzed: evam vattabba upe na aññesam visaya upe nidāna kiccam nāma natthi iti
translated: … not the province of others. … there is no such thing as the function of a source.

original: apākaṭānaṃ kāladesadesakaparisānaṃ pākaṭabhāvakaraṇatthaṃ tadupadesasahitena nidānena
analyzed: apākaṭānam kāla desa desaka parisānam pākaṭa bhāva karaṇa ttham tad upadesa sahitena nidānena
translated: In order to make known the obscure times, places, countries, and assemblies, he teaches the source together with the occasion.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, aññesaṃ avisayattā desako pākaṭo, okkantikālādīnaṃ pākaṭattā kālo ca,
analyzed: bhavitabbam aññesam avisaya ttā desako pākaṭaḥ okkanti kāla ādīnam pākaṭa ttā kālo ca
translated: since the place is evident because it is not the domain of others, the teacher is evident, the time is evident because the time of descent and so on is evident,

original: devaloke desitabhāvassa pākaṭattā desaparisā ca pākaṭāti kiṃ nidānakiccaṃ siyāti.🔽Yattha khandhādayo nippadesena vibhattā, so abhidhammo nāma, tasmā tassa nidānena🔽khandhādīnaṃ nippadesatopi paṭividdhaṭṭhānena bhavitabbanti adhippāyena thero “mahābodhinidāno
analyzed: deva loke desita bhāvassa pākaṭa ttā desa parisā ca pākaṭā ati kim nidāna kiccam siyā ti  yattha khandha ādayaḥ nippadesena vibhattā saḥ abhidhammaḥ nāma tasmā tassa nidānena  khandha ādīnam nippadesataḥ pi paṭividdha ṭṭhānena bhavitabban ti adhippāyena theraḥ mahā bodhi nidāno
translated: and the place and the assembly are evident because the fact that it was taught in the deva world is evident, then what is the purpose of the introduction?🔽The intention is this: since the aggregates, etc., are expounded without specification in the Abhidhamma,🔽it is necessary that they be known by means of the place of penetration, namely, by means of the aggregates, etc., themselves.

original: abhidhammo”ti dasseti. “So evaṃ pajānāmi sammādiṭṭhipaccayāpi vedayita”ntiādinā nayena
analyzed: abhidhammaḥ ti dasseti saḥ evam pajānāmi sammādiṭṭhi paccayā api vedayita nti ādinā nayena
translated: The Elder thus shows that the Abhidhamma has the Great Enlightenment as its introduction.🔽He dwelt investigating feeling by way of the aggregates, etc., with the aggregates, etc., as its meaning,

original: paccayādīhi vedanaṃ upaparikkhanto khandhādipadesānaṃ vedanākkhandhādīnaṃ vasena🔽vihāsi. Dhammeti kusalādiaraṇante.
analyzed: paccaya ādīhi vedanam upaparikkhanto khandha ādi padesānam vedanā khandha ādīnam vasena  vihāsi dhamma iti
translated: in the way beginning: “I understand feeling to be with conditions, and I understand the arising of feeling” ,🔽and so on. By the Dhamma is meant the profitable, etc., in the sense of the ultimate stage .

original: Dhammaṃ parivattentoti sāṭṭhakathaṃ pāḷiṃ parivattento etaṃ paravādīcodanaṃ patvā
analyzed: dhammam parivattento ti sa aṭṭhakatham pāḷim parivattento etam paravādī codanam patvā
translated: Turning the Dhamma: turning the text together with the commentary. Having come to this challenge from the opponents,

original: “ayaṃ paravādī”tiādimāha. Amhādisesu nidānaṃ jānantesu paṭisaraṇesu vijjamānesu appaṭisaraṇo🔽araññe kandanto viya nidānasabbhāve sakkhibhūtesupi amhesu vijjamānesu asakkhikaṃ
analyzed: ayam paravādī iti ādim āha amhādisesu nidānam jānantesu paṭisaraṇesu vijjamānesu appaṭisaraṇaḥ  araññe kandantaḥ viya nidāna sabbhāve sakkhi bhūtesu pi amhesu vijjamānesu asakkhikam
translated: “This is the opponent’s view,” he says. When we know the source and there are others who know it too, he is like one who weeps in the forest, having no one to turn to.

original: aḍḍaṃ karonto viya hoti, nidānassa atthibhāvampi na jānāti, nanu etaṃ nidānanti kathento🔽evamāha. Ekamevāti desanānidānameva ajjhāsayānurūpena desitattā. Dve nidānānīti adhigantabbadesetabbadhammānurūpena
analyzed: aḍḍam karontaḥ viya hoti nidānassa atthi bhāvam pi na jānāti nanu etam nidānam ti kathento  evam āha ekam eva ati desanā nidānam eva ajjhāsayā anurūpena desita ttā dve nidānāni iti adhigantabba desetabba dhamma anurūpena
translated: When we are present as witnesses to the source, he is like one who makes a false claim, having no one to turn to. He does not even know that the source exists. When he says, “This is the source,”🔽he says this. “Only one”: because it is taught in accordance with the intention, there is only the source of the teaching. “Two sources”: because it is taught in accordance with the Dhamma that is to be understood and the place where it is to be understood,

original: desitattā. Abhidhammādhigamassa mūlaṃ adhigamaṃ nidetīti adhigamanidānaṃ. Bodhiabhinīhārasaddhāyāti
analyzed: desita ttā abhidhamma adhigamassa mūlam adhigamam nideti iti adhigama nidānam bodhi abhinīhāra saddhāya ati
translated: there are two sources. “The source of understanding”: it leads to the understanding of the Abhidhamma, thus it is the source of understanding. “By the faith of the aspiration for enlightenment”:

original: yāya saddhāya dīpaṅkaradasabalassa santike bodhiyā cittaṃ abhinīhari paṇidhānaṃ akāsi.🔽Sumedhakathāvaṇṇanā🔽Caturo ca asaṅkhiyeti uddhaṃ ārohanavasena atikkamitvā amaraṃ nāma nagaraṃ ahosīti
analyzed: yāya saddhāya dīpaṅkara dasa balassa santike bodhiyā cittam abhinīhari paṇidhānam akāsi 🔽sumedha kathā vaṇṇanā 🔽caturaḥ ca uddham ārohana vasena atikkamitvā amaram nāma nagaram ahosi iti
translated: by the faith by which he aspired for enlightenment in the presence of the Ten-Powered One Dīpaṅkara and made the aspiration.

original: vacanasesayojanā kātabbā. Dasahīti hatthiassarathabherīsaṅkhamudiṅgavīṇāgītasammatāḷehi
analyzed: vacana sesa yojanā kātabbā dasahi iti
translated: The rest of the words should be construed as follows: “With ten sounds” means with the ten sounds of elephants, horses, chariots, kettledrums, conches, mudiṅgas, lutes, songs, cymbals, and “Eat, drink, and enjoy yourselves.”

original: “asnātha pivatha khādathā”ti dasamena saddena. Te pana ekadesena dassetuṃ “hatthisadda”ntiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Hatthisaddanti karaṇatthe upayogo daṭṭhabbo. Bherīsaṅkharathānañca saddehi
analyzed: a snātha pivatha khādatha ati dasamena saddena te pana eka desena dassetum hatthi sadda ntiādi  vuttam hatthi saddam ti karaṇa atthe upayogaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ bherī saṅkha rathānam ca saddehi
translated: But in order to show them separately, it is said “the sound of elephants,” etc.🔽The word “sound” should be understood in the instrumental case.🔽And the words “not separated from the sound of kettledrums, chariots, and conches” should be construed as “resounding with the sound of kettledrums, chariots, and conches.”

original: avivittanti vā ghositanti vā yojetabbaṃ. Hatthisaddanti vā hatthisaddavantaṃ nagaraṃ.
analyzed: avivittam ti vā ghositam ti vā yojetabbam hatthi saddanti vā hatthi saddavantam nagaram
translated: Or “the sound of elephants” means a city that has the sound of elephants.

original: Khādatha pivatha cevāti iti-saddo ñātatthattā appayutto daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: khādatha pivatha ca iva ati iti saddaḥ ñāta tthattā appayuttaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The word “eat, drink, and enjoy yourselves” should be understood as not connected with the word “iti” because it has a known meaning.

original: Sabbaṅgasampannaṃ uyyānapokkharaṇīādisampannattā. Lakkhaṇeti itthilakkhaṇe purisalakkhaṇe
analyzed: sabba aṅga sampannam uyyāna pokkharaṇī ādi sampanna ttā lakkhaṇe ti itthi lakkhaṇe purisa lakkhaṇe
translated: “All the parts” means it is endowed with all the parts, such as parks, lotus ponds, etc. “Characteristics” means the characteristics of women and men.

original: ca. Itihāseti porāṇe. Sadhammeti attano tevijjadhamme ca yaññavidhiādike ca. Pāraminti
analyzed: ca itihāse iti porāṇe sadhamme iti attano tevijja dhamme ca yañña vidhi ādike ca
translated: “History” means ancient [stories]. “One’s own doctrine” means one’s own doctrine of the three Vedas, and the rituals of sacrifices, etc. “Perfection” means

original: pārañāṇaṃ pārādhigamaṃ gato. Cintesahanti cintesiṃ ahaṃ sumedhabhūtoti satthā vadati.
analyzed: pāra ñāṇam pāra adhigamam gataḥ aham sumedha bhūto ti satthā vadati
translated: one who has attained the knowledge of perfection, the perfection of wisdom. “I thought” means the Teacher says “I, being wise, thought.”

original: Atthi hehitīti so vijjamāno bhavissati. Na hetuyeti abhavituṃ. Evamevāti evamevaṃ.
analyzed: atthi hehiti iti so vijjamānaḥ bhavissati na hetuyā iti a bhavitum evam eva ati evam evam
translated: ‘Is there anything to be desired?’ means ‘Is there anything that exists?’ ‘Is there not?’ means ‘Is there anything that does not exist?’ ‘Just so’ means ‘just in the same way.’

original: Na gavesatīti na gantuṃ esati na icchati nānugacchati vā. Dhoveti dhovante. Serīti🔽sāyattiko. Sayaṃvasīti savaso. Mahācorasamo viyāti kāyasārāgavasena duccaritānesanehi
analyzed: na gavesati iti na gantum esati na icchati na anugacchati vā dhova iti dhovante  sāyattikaḥ sayaṃvasī iti savasaḥ mahā cora samaḥ viyāti kāya sā rāga vasena duccarita anesanehi
translated: ‘Does not seek’ means ‘does not go to seek,’ ‘does not wish,’ ‘does not follow.’ ‘Washes’ means ‘washes away.’ ‘Bent’ means

original: kusalabhaṇḍacchedanā. Nāthāti nāthavanto. Pañcadosavivajjitanti evamādikassa attho
analyzed: kusala bhaṇḍa chedanāḥ nāthā ati nāthavanto pañca dosa vivajjitanti evamādikassa attho
translated: ‘bent down.’ ‘Self-dependent’ means ‘having self-power.’ ‘Like a great thief’ means ‘like one who cuts off the goods of merit by means of the defilements of the body.’ ‘Master’ means ‘having a master.’ ‘Avoiding the five’ means the meaning of this is written in some books of the commentaries.

original: kesuci aṭṭhakathāpotthakesu likhitoti katvā na vakkhāma.🔽Sāsaneti ettha tāpasasāsanaṃ jhānābhiññā ca. Vasībhūtassa sato. Mayi evaṃbhūte dīpaṅkaro
analyzed: kesuci aṭṭhakathā potthakesu likhito ti katvā na vakkhāma  sāsana iti ettha tāpasa sāsanam jhāna abhiññā ca vasībhūtassa sataḥ mayi evaṃbhūte dīpaṅkaro
translated: We will not say it.

original: jino uppajji. Sodheti jano. Añjasaṃ vaṭumāyananti pariyāyavacanehi maggameva vadati.
analyzed: jinaḥ uppajji sodha iti janaḥ añjasam pariyāya vacanehi maggam eva vadati
translated: ‘In the Dispensation’ means the Dispensation of the Ascetic, and also the jhānas and the higher knowledges. ‘Of one who has become powerful’ means ‘of one who has become powerful in the Dispensation of the Ascetic, and also in the jhānas and the higher knowledges.’ ‘When I was such-like’ means ‘when I was such-like in the Dispensation of the Ascetic, and also in the jhānas and the higher knowledges.’ ‘The Conqueror Dīpaṅkara arose’ means ‘the Conqueror Dīpaṅkara arose in the world.’ ‘The people purified’ means ‘the people purified themselves.’ ‘Along the straight path’ means ‘along the path of direct-comprehension.’

original: Mā naṃ akkamitthāti ettha nanti padapūraṇamatte nipāto. Ghātiyāmahanti ettha ca a-iti
analyzed: mā nam akkamittha ati ettha na nti pada pūraṇa matte nipātaḥ ettha ca ai ti
translated: ‘Do not tread on it’ means ‘do not tread on it.’ ‘We will kill’ means ‘we will kill.’

original: ca haṃ-iti ca nipātā, ahaṃ-iti vā eko nipāto sānunāsiko kato. Āhutīnanti dakkhiṇāhutīnaṃ.
analyzed: ca haṃ iti ca nipātāḥ ahaṃ iti vai ekaḥ nipātaḥ sa anunāsikaḥ kataḥ āhutīnam ti dakkhiṇa āhutīnam
translated: The offerings are the offerings of alms.

original: Manti mama, maṃ vā abrvi.
analyzed: manti mama mam vai abrvi
translated: The word manti is from the root √man, to think, and is a contraction of mama or maṃ.

original: Kappe atikkamitvā vuttepi bodhimhi mātādisaṃkittane saṅgaṇhituṃ “bodhi tassa bhagavato”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kappe atikkamitvā vutte api bodhimhi mātā ādi saṃkittane saṅgaṇhitum bodhi tassa bhagavataḥ iti ādim āha
translated: Even though it is said, “Having passed through the aeons,” in the description of the mother, etc., of the Buddha, he includes them with the words “The enlightenment of that Fortunate One.”

original: Sukhenāti uttamena sukhena. Asamoti tāpasehi asamo. Abhiññāsukhatopi visiṭṭhaṃ īdisaṃ🔽buddhattabyākaraṇajaṃ sukhaṃ alabhiṃ. Yāti yāni nimittāni. Ābhujatīti āvattati. Abhiravantīti
analyzed: sukhena ati uttamena sukhena asamaḥ ti tāpasehi asamaḥ abhiññā sukhataḥ pi visiṭṭham īdisam  buddha tta byākaraṇa jam sukham alabhim yāti yāni nimittāni ābhujati iti āvattati abhiravanti iti
translated: With ease: with the highest ease. Unequalled: not equalled by ascetics. Such happiness, which is superior even to the happiness of direct-knowledge,

original: saddaṃ karonti. Chuddhāti nikkhantā. Nuddhaṃsatīti na uddhaṃ gacchati. Ubhayanti
analyzed: saddam karonti chuddhā ati nikkhantā na uddhaṃsati iti na uddham gacchati ubhayanti
translated: I obtained, which arose from the prediction to Buddhahood. The signs: the signs which are the omens. They appeared: they turned up. They resounded: they made a sound. They were released: they came out. They did not go up: they did not go upwards. Both:

original: ubhayavacanaṃ. Dhuvasassatanti ekantasassataṃ, aviparītamevāti attho. Āpannasattānanti
analyzed: ubhaya vacanam dhuva sassatam ti ekanta sassatam aviparītam eva ati atthaḥ āpannasattānam ti
translated: is a word for both. Eternal and permanent: eternal and permanent in the absolute sense, is the meaning. Pregnant women:

original: gabbhinīnaṃ. Yāvatādasa disā, tattha. Dhammadhātuyāti dhammadhātuyaṃ, sabbesu dhammesu vicināmīti attho.
analyzed: gabbhinīnam yāvatā dasa disā tattha dhammadhātuyā ati dhammadhātuyam sabbesu dhammesu vicināmi iti attho
translated: women who are pregnant. In the ten directions: in the ten directions. In the element of Dhamma: in the element of Dhamma, the meaning is: I examine all dhammas.

original: Yassa sampuṇṇo, taṃ vamateva udakaṃ nissesaṃ. Eteti ekissāpi dānapāramitāya anekappakāratāya
analyzed: yassa sampuṇṇaḥ tam vamatā iva udakam nissesam eta iti ekissa api dāna pāramitāya aneka ppakāra tāya
translated: The plural is used in the phrase “these perfections” because each perfection has many aspects.

original: bahuvacananiddeso kato. Paṭilaggitaṃ rakkhatīti vacanaseso, bhummatthe vā upayogo.
analyzed: bahuvacana niddeso kataḥ paṭilaggitam rakkhati iti vacana sesaḥ bhumma tthe vā upayogaḥ
translated: The phrase “he guards the path he has begun” is a verbal expression, or it is used in the sense of a basis.

original: Catūsu bhūmīsūti pātimokkhādīsu saṃvarabhūmīsu. Advejjhamānasoti kadāci khamanaṃ
analyzed: catūsu bhūmīsu iti pātimokkha ādīsu saṃvara bhūmīsu advejjhamānaso ti kadāci khamanam
translated: “In the four grounds” means in the grounds of restraint beginning with the Pāṭimokkha.

original: kadāci akkhamanaṃ, kassaci khamanaṃ kassaci akkhamananti evaṃ dvedhābhāvaṃ anāpannamānaso
analyzed: kadāci akkhamanam kassaci khamanam kassaci akkhamanan ti evam dvedhā bhāvam an āpanna mānasaḥ
translated: “With a mind free from doubt” means with a mind that has not fallen into the twofold state of sometimes being forgiving and sometimes not being forgiving, sometimes forgiving one person and not forgiving another.

original: hutvā. Saccassa vīthi nāma diṭṭhādi ca adiṭṭhādi ca yathābhūtaṃva vatthu. Adhiṭṭhānanti
analyzed: hutvā saccassa vīthi nāma diṭṭha ādi ca a diṭṭha ādi ca vatthu adhiṭṭhānanti
translated: “The path of truth” is the subject matter that is stated as it actually is, such as “seen,” “heard,” etc. “Resolution”

original: kusalasamādānādhiṭṭhānaṃ, samādinnesu kusalesu acalatā adhiṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Pathaviyā
analyzed: kusala samādāna adhiṭṭhānam samādinnesu kusalesu acala tā adhiṭṭhānam nāma pathaviyā
translated: means the resolution to undertake the wholesome. The state of not wavering from the wholesome that has been undertaken is called “resolution.” “Equanimity towards the earth”

original: upekkhanaṃ nāma vikārānāpatti. Aññatrāti aññaṃ. Sabhāvarasalakkhaṇeti ettha bhāvoti
analyzed: upekkhanam nāma vikāra anāpatti aññatra ati aññam sa bhāva rasa lakkhaṇā iti ettha bhāvaḥ ti
translated: means not to fall into alteration. “Except” means “other than.” “The individual essence, the taste, the characteristic” : here “essence”

original: aviparītatā vijjamānatā, saha bhāvena sabhāvo, aviparīto attano bodhiparipācanakiccasaṅkhāto
analyzed: a viparīta tā vijjamāna tā saha bhāvena sa bhāvaḥ aviparītaḥ attanaḥ bodhi paripācana kicca saṅkhāto
translated: means non-deceptiveness, existence. That which is together with the essence is the individual essence. The individual essence is the characteristic of the wholesome that has been undertaken.

original: raso, anavajjavatthupariccāgādisaṅkhātaṃ lakkhaṇañca sabhāvarasalakkhaṇaṃ, tato sammasato.
analyzed: rasaḥ anavajja vatthu pariccāga ādi saṅkhātam lakkhaṇam ca sabhāva rasa lakkhaṇam tatas sammasato
translated: and the taste of the Dhamma, which is the characteristic of the object of blameless giving, etc., and the individual essence of the taste of the Dhamma.

original: Dhammatejenāti ñāṇatejena. Calatāti calatāya kampanatāya. Sesīti sayi. Mā bhāthāti
analyzed: dhamma tejena ati ñāṇa tejena cala tā ati cala tāya kampana tāya sesi iti sayi mā bhātha ati
translated: “By the power of the Dhamma”: by the power of knowledge. “They would tremble”: they would tremble with fear, they would shake. “The rest”: the rest of the bhikkhus. “Let them not be afraid”:

original: mā bhāyittha. Sabbītiyoti sabbā ītiyo upaddavā taṃ vivajjantu.
analyzed: mā bhāyittha sabbītiyā iti sabbāḥ ītiyaḥ upaddavā tam vivajjantu
translated: let them not be afraid. “All fears”: all fears, all calamities.

original: Sumedhakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sumedha kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the story of Sumedha is finished.

original: Pavacchatīti deti. Yogenāti upāyena. Samiṃsūti sannipatiṃsu. Appattamānasāti appattaarahattā
analyzed: pavacchati iti dā iti yogena ati upāyena appatta mānasā ati appatta arahattā
translated: “To give” means to bestow. “By means of a means”: by means of a method. “They assembled”: they gathered together. “Their minds were not yet fully satisfied”: because they had not yet attained arahatship,

original: bhikkhū garahitā bhavanti. Rittāti suññā antarahitā. Sālakalyāṇī nāma eko rukkho.
analyzed: bhikkhū gara hitāḥ bhavanti rittā ati suññā antarahitā sālakalyāṇī nāma ekaḥ rukkho
translated: the bhikkhus were reproached. “Empty”: devoid, lacking. “Sālakalyāṇī”: this is the name of a tree.

original: Buddhacakkavattikāleyeva kira ekāheneva uppajjati.
analyzed: buddha cakkavatti kāleya iva kira eka ahena iva uppajjati
translated: It is said that it appears only during the time of a Buddha, and then only for one day.

original: Liṅgasampattīti purisaliṅgatā. Hetūti tihetukapaṭisandhitā. Guṇasampattīti abhiññāsamāpattilābhitā.
analyzed: liṅga sampatti iti purisa liṅga tā hetu uti ti hetuka paṭisandhi tā guṇa sampatti iti abhiññā samāpatti lābhi tā
translated: “The attainment of the male sex”: the state of being a man. “The cause”: rebirth-linking with three roots. “The attainment of the special qualities”: the attainment of the supernormal powers and meditative attainments.

original: Adhikāroti buddhānaṃ sakkārakaraṇaṃ. Chandatāti buddhattappattiyaṃ chandasamāyogo.
analyzed: adhikāraḥ ti buddhānam sakkāra karaṇam chanda tā ati chanda samāyogaḥ
translated: “The opportunity”: the opportunity to render service to the Buddhas. “The will”: the will and effort to attain Buddhahood.

original: Sabbaṅgasampannāti aṭṭhaṅgāni samodhānetvā katapaṇidhānā. Pakkhikāti pīṭhasappikā.
analyzed: sabba aṅga sampannā ti aṭṭhaṅgāni samodhānetvā kata paṇidhānā pakkhikā ati pīṭhasappikā
translated: “Complete in all limbs” : who have made their resolution with the eight factors complete. “Flock-followers” : those who follow a teacher.

original: Paṇḍakāti ubhayaliṅgarahitā. Bodhisattā ca brahmalokūpapattipaṭhamakappikesu kālesu🔽ubhayaliṅgarahitā honti, na pana paṇḍakapariyāpannāti etamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “pariyāpannā🔽na bhavantī”ti vuttaṃ, yathāvuttesu vā dosesu sabbesu pariyāpannā na bhavanti, bodhisattesu🔽vā pariyāpannā tadantogadhā, paricchinnasaṃsārattā vā pariyāpannā bodhisattā ubhatobyañjanapaṇḍakā
analyzed: paṇḍakā ati ubhaya liṅga rahitā bodhisattā ca brahma loka upapatti paṭhama kappikesu kālesu  ubhaya liṅga rahitāḥ honti na pana paṇḍaka pariyāpannā ti etam attham dassetum pariyāpannā  na bhavanti iti vuttam yathā vuttesu vā dosesu sabbesu pariyāpannāḥ na bhavanti bodhisattesu  vā pariyāpannā tad antogadhā paricchinna saṃsārattā vā pariyāpannāḥ bodhisattā ubhatas byañjana paṇḍakā
translated: “Eunuchs” : those lacking both sexual organs. Bodhisattas, when they are in the first stage of life in the Brahma-world,

original: na bhavantīti attho. Sabbattha suddhagocarā yasmā, tasmā micchādiṭṭhiṃ na sevanti.🔽Micchādiṭṭhinti natthikāhetukākiriyadiṭṭhiṃ. Bhavābhaveti khuddake ceva mahante ca
analyzed: na bhavanti iti sabbattha suddha gocarāḥ yasmā tasmā micchādiṭṭhim na sevanti  micchādiṭṭhim ti natthika ahetuka akiriya diṭṭhim bhava abhava iti khuddake ca iva mahante ca
translated: are lacking both sexual organs, but they are not included among the eunuchs. In order to show this, it is said, “are not included among the eunuchs.” Or, in the above-mentioned faults, they are not included in all of them. Or, the bodhisattas are included in the eunuchs, because they are included in the category of eunuchs, or because they are included in the cycle of existence, but they are not eunuchs lacking both sexual organs. The meaning is: because they are pure in all respects, they do not follow wrong views.

original: bhave. Bhojaputteti luddake. Lagananti saṅgo. Aññathāti līnatā. Gāmaṇḍalāti gāmadārakā.
analyzed: bhave bhoja putta iti luddake saṅgaḥ aññathā ati līna tā
translated: “Wrong views” : the view of annihilation, of causelessness, and of non-action. “Existence and non-existence” : small and great existences. “Hunters” : killers. “Attachment” : clinging. “Otherwise” : depression. “Village boys” : village youths.

original: Rūpanti vippakāraṃ. Ayaṃ tāva nidānakathā yāya abhidhammassa buddhabhāsitatāsiddhīti
analyzed: vippakāram ayam tāva nidāna kathā yāya abhidhammassa buddha bhāsita tā siddhi iti
translated: “Form” is the alteration. This is the introductory story, by which the fact that the Abhidhamma was spoken by the Buddha is established.

original: atthayojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: attha yojanā kātabbā
translated: The explanation of the meaning should be done.

original: Nidānakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nidāna kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the introductory story is finished.

original: 1. Cittuppādakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: cittuppāda kaṇḍam
translated: The section on the arising of consciousness

original: Tikamātikāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tikamātikā pada vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the three-line summary

original: Idāni paṭiññātakathaṃ kātuṃ “idāni iti me…pe… kathanokāso sampatto”tiādimāha. Ito paṭṭhāyāti kusaladhammapadato paṭṭhāya.
analyzed: idāni paṭiññāta katham kātum idāni iti mepe kathana ukāso sampatto ti ādim āha itas paṭṭhāya ati kusala dhamma padataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: Now, in order to give an answer, he says “Now, this is the occasion for me to explain how the Abhidhamma was spoken by the Buddha.” From here on means from the term “wholesome states.”

original: 1. Sabbapadehi laddhanāmoti tīsupi padesu vedanāsaddassa vijjamānattā tena laddhanāmo
analyzed: sabba padehi laddha nāmaḥ ti tīsu pi padesu vedanā saddassa vijjamāna ttā tena laddha nāmaḥ
translated: The name obtained from all the terms means that because the word “feeling” exists in all three sections, it obtains its name from that.

original: sabbapadehi laddhanāmo hoti. Nanu sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā dhammāti cattāri padāni,
analyzed: sabba padehi laddha nāmaḥ hoti nanu sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttāḥ dhammā ti cattāri padāni
translated: It is called “obtained from all the terms.” Aren’t there four terms for “the states associated with pleasant feeling,”

original: evaṃ sesesupīti dvādasetāni padāni, na tīṇīti vedanāsaddassa padattayāvayavattaṃ
analyzed: evam sesesu pi iti dvādasa etāni padāni na tīṇi iti vedanā saddassa
translated: and so on for the other two? Thus there are twelve terms, not three. With reference to the fact that the word “feeling” is a part of the term

original: sandhāya “sabbapadehī”ti vucceyya, na yuttaṃ. “Vedanāyā”ti hi visuṃ padaṃ na kassaci
analyzed: sandhāya sabba padehi iti vucceyya na yuttam vedanāya ati hi visum padam na kassaci
translated: and a component, it would be said “from all the terms,” but that is not appropriate. For the term “feeling” is not a separate term for anyone.

original: padassa avayavo hoti, nāpi sukhādipadabhāvaṃ bhajatīti tena laddhanāmo kathaṃ sabbapadehi
analyzed: padassa avayavaḥ hoti nā api sukha ādi pada bhāvam bhajati iti tena laddha nāmaḥ katham sabba padehi
translated: and it is not a word in the sense of a word such as “pleasure,” etc., so how can it be called “that which has a name derived from all the words”?

original: laddhanāmo siyāti? Adhippetappakāratthagamakassa padasamudāyassa padattā. Pajjati🔽avabujjhīyati etenāti hi padaṃ, “sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā dhammā”ti etena ca padasamudāyena
analyzed: laddha nāmaḥ siyā ti adhippeta ppakāra attha gamakassa pada samudāyassa pada ttā pajjati  avabujjhīyati etena ati hi padam sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttāḥ dhammā ati etena ca pada samudāyena
translated: It is a word because it is a combination of words that conveys the meaning intended.🔽For a word is that by which something is made known , and by this combination of words

original: yathādhippeto attho samatto viññāyati, tasmā so padasamudāyo “pada”nti vuccati. Evaṃ
analyzed: yathā adhippeto attho samattaḥ viññāyati tasmā so pada samudāyaḥ padanti vuccati evam
translated: the meaning intended is made known completely, thus that combination of words is called a “word.” So too

original: itarepi veditabbā. Tasmā tesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ samudāyānaṃ avayavena laddhanāmo sabbapadehi laddhanāmoti yutto.🔽Ganthato ca atthato cāti ettha hetupadasahetukapadādīhi sambandhattā ganthato ca
analyzed: itarā api veditabbā tasmā tesam tiṇṇam samudāyānam avayavena laddha nāmo sabba padehi laddha nāmo ti yuttaḥ  ganthato ca atthato ca ati ettha hetu pada sahetuka pada ādīhi sambandha ttā ganthato ca
translated: the other two should be understood. So it is proper to say that it has a name derived from the component part of the three combinations and that it has a name derived from all the words.🔽As to syntactical-connexion and as to meaning: here the syntactical-connexion should be understood as the mutual connexion as to meaning of the words with cause and with effect, etc.,

original: hetuatthasahetukatthādīhi sambandhattā atthato ca aññamaññasambandho veditabbo. Sahetukahetusampayuttadukā
analyzed: hetu attha sahetuka ttha ādīhi sambandha ttā atthataḥ ca aññamañña sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ sa hetuka hetu sampayutta dukā
translated: and as to syntactical-connexion of the words with cause and with effect, etc.,

original: hi hetuduke hetūhi sambandhattā hetudukasambandhā, hetusahetukaduko hetudukasahetukadukasambandho
analyzed: hi hetu duke hetūhi hetu duka sambandhā hetu sahetuka dukaḥ hetu duka sahetuka duka sambandhaḥ
translated: Because of the connection with the grounds of the reason, the grounds of the reason are connected with the grounds of the reason. The grounds of the reason and the grounds of the non-reason are connected with the grounds of the reason and the grounds of the non-reason.

original: ubhayekapadavasena. Tathā hetuhetusampayuttaduko hetudukahetusampayuttadukasambandho,
analyzed: ubhaya eka pada vasena tathā hetu hetu sampayutta dukaḥ hetu duka hetu sampayutta duka sambandhaḥ
translated: By the method of the two terms both ways. Likewise, the grounds of the reason and the grounds of the associated with the reason are connected with the grounds of the reason and the grounds of the associated with the reason.

original: nahetusahetukaduko ekadvipadavasena hetudukasahetukadukasambandhoti. Kaṇṇikā viyāti
analyzed: eka dvipada vasena hetu duka sahetuka duka sambandhā iti kaṇṇikā viyāti
translated: The grounds of the non-reason and the grounds of the non-reason and the associated are connected with the grounds of the reason and the grounds of the non-reason and the associated by the method of the one term and the two terms. Like a garland.

original: pupphamayakaṇṇikā viya. Ghaṭā viyāti pupphahatthakādīsu pupphādīnaṃ samūho viya.
analyzed: puppha maya kaṇṇikāḥ viya ghaṭāḥ viya ati puppha hatthaka ādīsu puppha ādīnam samūhaḥ viya
translated: Like a flower-basket. Like a vase. Like the collection of flowers, etc., in flower-hands, etc.

original: Kaṇṇikāghaṭādīsu hi pupphādīni vaṇṭādīhi aññamaññasambandhāni hontīti tathāsambandhatā🔽etesaṃ dukānaṃ vuttā. Dukasāmaññatoti aññehi hetudukādīhi dukavasena samānabhāvā.
analyzed: kaṇṇikā ghaṭa ādīsu hi puppha ādīni vaṇṭa ādīhi aññamañña sambandhāni honti iti tathā sambandha tā  etesam dukānam vuttā duka sāmaññato ti aññehi hetu duka ādīhi duka vasena samāna bhāvā
translated: For in a garland, a vase, etc., the flowers, etc., are connected with each other by means of stalks, etc. Thus the connection🔽of these grounds is stated. By the similarity of the grounds: they have the same nature as the grounds by means of the grounds of the reason, etc., other than the grounds of the reason, etc.

original: Aññehīti sārammaṇadukādīhi. Asaṅgahito padeso yesaṃ atthi, te sappadesā. Yesaṃ pana
analyzed: aññehi iti sa ārammaṇa duka ādīhi asaṅgahitaḥ padesaḥ yesam atthi te sappadesāḥ yesam pana
translated: By others: by the grounds of object, etc. Those that have a part that is not included are with a part. But those that

original: natthi, te nippadesā.
analyzed: na atthi te nippadesā
translated: do not have a part are without a part.

original: “Kacci nu bhoto kusala”nti evaṃ pucchitamevatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā pucchituṃ “kacci
analyzed: kacci nu bhoto kusalanti evam pucchita evattham pākaṭam katvā pucchitum kacci
translated: “Are you well?” is said to make clear the meaning of the question “Are you comfortable?”

original: bhoto anāmaya”nti vuttaṃ, tasmā kusalasaddo anāmayattho hoti. Bāhitikasutte bhagavato
analyzed: bhoto anāmayam ti vuttam tasmā kusala saddo anāmaya atthaḥ hoti bāhitika sutte bhagavato
translated: Therefore the word “comfortable” has the meaning of “healthy.” In the Bāhitikasutta, the Dhamma treasurer,

original: kāyasamācārādayo vaṇṇentena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena “yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro
analyzed: kāya samācāra ādayaḥ vaṇṇentena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena yaḥ kho mahā rāja kāya samācāraḥ
translated: praising the Blessed One’s bodily conduct, etc., said: “Great king, whatever bodily conduct is blameless,

original: anavajjo”ti kusalo kāyasamācāro vutto. Na hi bhagavato sukhavipākaṃ kammaṃ atthīti
analyzed: anavajjaḥ iti kusalaḥ kāya samācāraḥ vuttaḥ na hi bhagavato sukha vipākam kammaṃ atthi iti
translated: is comfortable bodily conduct.” For the Blessed One has no kamma that ripens in pleasure.

original: sabbasāvajjarahitā kāyasamācārādayo kusalāti vuttā. Kusalesu dhammesūti ca bodhipakkhiyadhammā
analyzed: sabba sāvajja rahitā kāya samācāra ādayo kusalā ati vuttā kusalesu dhammesu iti ca bodhi pakkhiya dhammā
translated: Therefore, bodily conduct, etc., free from all that is reprehensible, are called “comfortable.” And the states that are wholesome

original: “kusalā”ti vuttā. Te ca vipassanāmaggaphalasampayuttā na ekantena sukhavipākāyevāti🔽anavajjattho kusalasaddo. Aṅgapaccaṅgānanti kusalasaddayogena bhummatthe sāmivacanaṃ,
analyzed: kusalā ati vuttā te ca vipassanā magga phala sampayuttāḥ na ekantena sukha vipākāya eva ati  anavajja atthaḥ kusala saddaḥ kusala sadda yogena bhumma tthe sāmivacanam
translated: are called “comfortable.” And these, being associated with insight, the path, and fruition, are not exclusively ripening of pleasure.🔽Therefore the word “comfortable” has the meaning of “blameless.” The words “limbs and secondary limbs” are a genitive depending on “states” in the sense of a possessor.

original: aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ vā nāmakiriyāpayojanādīsūti attho. Naccagītassāti ca sāmivacanaṃ
analyzed: aṅga paccaṅgānam vā nāma kiriyā apayojana ādīsu uti atthaḥ nacca gītassa ati ca sāmi vacanam
translated: The meaning is: the purpose, etc., of the naming of the limbs and secondary limbs. The words “dancing and singing” are a genitive depending on “limbs and secondary limbs” in the sense of an object.

original: bhummatthe, naccagītassa visesesūti vā yojetabbaṃ. Kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samādānahetu
analyzed: bhummatthe nacca gītassa visesesu iti vā yojetabbam kusalānam dhammānam samādāna hetu
translated: Or else the words “in the sense of the earth” and “in the sense of the particular kinds of dancing and singing” should be construed with “in the sense of skill” .

original: evamidaṃ puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatīti puññavipākanibbattakakammaṃ “kusala”nti vuttaṃ. Dhammā
analyzed: evam idam puññam pavaḍḍhati iti puñña vipāka nibbattaka kammam kusalanti vuttam dhammā
translated: “Because of undertaking profitable things” : the profitable action that produces the resultant of merit is called “profitable” .🔽“Things” : the meaning is that they are mere things, void of self or anything pertaining to a self.

original: hontīti suññadhammattā sabhāvamattā hontīti attho. Evaṃ dhammesu dhammānupassīti
analyzed: honti iti suñña dhamma ttā sabhāvamattāḥ honti iti attho evam dhammesu dhamma anupassī iti
translated: So too in the case of “contemplating things in things” .

original: etthāpi suññatattho dhammasaddo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ettha api suññata tthaḥ dhamma saddo daṭṭhabbo
translated: Here too the word “things” should be regarded as having the meaning of voidness.

original: Salayanti…pe… viddhaṃsentīti ettha purimassa purimassa pacchimaṃ pacchimaṃ atthavacanaṃ.
analyzed: ettha purimassa purimassa pacchimam pacchimam attha vacanaṃ
translated: “They shake” , etc.: the meaning of the latter terms should be understood as an elaboration of the meaning of the former terms.

original: Atha vā salanassa atthadīpanāni calanādīni tīṇi tadaṅgappahānādīhi yojetabbāni. Appahīnabhāvena
analyzed: atha vā salanassa attha dīpanāni calana ādīni tīṇi tad aṅga ppahāna ādīhi yojetabbāni appahīna bhāvena
translated: Or alternatively, the three terms “shaking,” etc., can be taken as the explanation of the term “profitable” .🔽Unprofitable things lie in the sense of lying in a continuum by way of non-abandonment,

original: santāne sayamānā akusalā dhammā rāgādiasucisampayogato nānāvidhadukkhahetuto ca kucchitena
analyzed: santāne sayamānāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ rāga ādi asuci sampayogataḥ nānāvidha dukkha hetuto ca kucchitena
translated: in the sense of lying in a foul form by way of association with the impurities of lust, etc., and by way of being a cause for the various kinds of suffering.

original: ākārena sayanti. Ñāṇavippayuttānampi ñāṇaṃ upanissayapaccayo hotīti sabbepi kusalā
analyzed: ākārena sayanti ñāṇa vippayuttānam pi ñāṇam upanissaya paccayaḥ hoti iti sabbe pi kusalā
translated: Knowledge is a decisive-support condition even for those things that are unaccompanied by knowledge. Therefore all profitable things

original: dhammā kusena ñāṇena pavattetabbāti kusalā. Uppannaṃsānuppannaṃsabhāgesu saṅgahitattā
analyzed: dhammā kusena ñāṇena pavattetabbā ati kusalāḥ uppanna ṃsa anuppanna ṃsa bhāgesu saṅgahita ttā
translated: They are profitable because they are to be brought about by profitable knowledge.

original: ubhayabhāgagataṃ saṃkilesapakkhaṃ pahānānuppādanehi lunanti sammappadhānadvayaṃ viya.
analyzed: ubhaya bhāga gatam saṃkilesa pakkham pahāna anuppādanehi lunanti sammappadhāna dvayam viya
translated: They are called states because they bear their own individual essences, like beings, and because they are cut off from both ends, like the middle of a bamboo, by the abandoning and non-arising of the states of defilement belonging to the past and future respectively, as the middle of a bamboo is cut off by the cutting off of the top and the roots.

original: Sattādigāhakānaṃ cittānaṃ gocarā sattādayo viya paññāya upaparikkhiyamānā na nissabhāvā,
analyzed: satta ādi gāhakānam cittānam gocarā satta ādayaḥ viya paññāya upaparikkhiyamānāḥ na nissabhāvā
translated: When they are investigated by understanding, they are not non-existent, like beings, etc., which are the domain of the seven kinds of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness.🔽But they bear their own individual essences, and so they are called states.

original: kintu attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhammā. Na ca dhāriyamānasabhāvā añño dhammo nāma
analyzed: kintu attano sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhammā na ca dhāriyamāna sabhāvā aññaḥ dhammo nāma
translated: And there is no other state than one that bears its own individual essence.

original: atthi. Na hi ruppanādīhi aññe rūpādayo, kakkhaḷādīhi ca aññe pathavīādayo dhammā
analyzed: atthi na hi ruppana ādīhi aññe rūpa ādayo kakkhaḷa ādīhi ca aññe pathavī ādayo dhammā
translated: For there are no materialities, etc., apart from the properties of assuming, etc., nor are there earth, etc., apart from the properties of hardness, etc.

original: vijjantīti. Aññathā pana avabodhetuṃ na sakkāti nāmavasena viññātāviññāte sabhāvadhamme🔽aññe viya katvā “attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentī”ti vuttaṃ. Sappaccayadhammesu visesaṃ dassento
analyzed: vijjanti iti aññathā pana avabodhetum na sakkā ati nāma vasena viññāta aviññāte sabhāva dhamme  aññe viya katvā attanaḥ sabhāvam dhārenti iti vuttam sappaccaya dhammesu visesam dassento
translated: But it is said thus in order to show that they can be known only by the name, not otherwise.

original: “dhārīyanti vā paccayehī”ti āha. Dhārīyantīti upadhārīyanti, lakkhīyantīti attho.
analyzed: dhārīyanti vā paccayehi iti āha dhārīyanti iti upadhārīyanti lakkhīyanti iti atthaḥ
translated: And in order to show the difference between states that have conditions and those that have not, he said, “Or they are borne by conditions.” They are borne means they are borne along, the meaning is that they are characterized.

original: Akusalāti kusalapaṭisedhanamattaṃ kusalābhāvamattavacanaṃ tadaññamattavacanaṃ vā
analyzed: akusalā ati kusala paṭisedhana mattam kusala abhāva matta vacanam tad añña matta vacanam vā
translated: “Unprofitable” is a mere denial of profitable, a mere statement of the absence of profitable, or a mere statement of what is other than profitable.

original: etaṃ na hoti, kintu tappaṭipakkhavacananti dassetuṃ “mittapaṭipakkhā amittā viyā”tiādi
analyzed: etam na hoti kintu tad paṭipakkha vacananti dassetum mitta paṭipakkhāḥ amittāḥ viya itiādi
translated: This is not so, but rather it is a statement of the opposite of that. In order to show this, “Enemies are the opposite of friends” is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Tappaṭipakkhavacanatā ca abyākatatatiyarāsivacanena viññāyati. Yadi hi kusalābhāvamattavacanaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tad paṭipakkha vacana tā ca abyākata tatiya rāsi vacanena viññāyati yadi hi kusala abhāva matta vacanam
translated: And the fact that it is a statement of the opposite is known from the statement of the third category, namely, the indeterminate. For if the word “unprofitable” were a mere statement of the absence of profitable,

original: akusalasaddo, tena na koci dhammo vuttoti abyākatavacaneneva ca tatiyo rāsi vutto🔽na siyā, kusalā ceva dhammā abyākatā cāti dukovāyaṃ āpajjati, na tiko, evañca sati
analyzed: akusala saddo tena na koci dhammaḥ vuttaḥ ti abyākata vacanena iva ca tatiyaḥ rāsi vutto  na siyā kusalā ca iva dhammā abyākatā ca ati āpajjati na tikaḥ evam ca sati
translated: no state of being would be stated by it. And then the third category would be stated only by the statement of the indeterminate,🔽and the dilemma would be twofold, namely, “profitable states and indeterminate states,” not threefold. And if that were so,

original: akusalavacanena na koci attho. Atha siyā, “anabyākatā”ti ca vattabbaṃ siyā kusalānaṃ
analyzed: akusala vacanena na koci atthaḥ atha siyā anabyākatā ati ca vattabbam siyā kusalānam
translated: the word “unprofitable” would not state anything. But it might be said that it should be stated as “indeterminate” because the absence of profitable and the absence of indeterminate are possible, like the absence of enemies.

original: viya abyākatānañca abhāvamattasambhavā, tasmā abhāvamattavacane abyākatabhāvamattaṃ
analyzed: abyākatā anañca abhāva matta sambhavā tasmai abhāva matta vacane abyākata bhāva mattam
translated: So unprofitable is not any category, since it is a mere statement of the absence of profitable, like the absence of indeterminate.

original: viya kusalābhāvamattaṃ akusalaṃ na koci rāsīti “abyākatā”ti tatiyo rāsi na siyā.
analyzed: viya kusala abhāva mattam akusalam na koci rāsi iti tatiyaḥ rāsi na siyā
translated: “Indeterminate” would not be the third category.

original: Tatiyarāsibhāvena ca abyākatā vuttāti akusalo ca eko rāsīti viññāyati. Tasmā nābhāvavacanatā,🔽sabhāvadhāraṇādiatthena dhammasaddena samānādhikaraṇabhāvato ca akusalasaddassa kusalābhāvamattavacanatā
analyzed: tatiya rāsi bhāvena ca abyākatā vuttā ati akusalaḥ ca ekaḥ rāsi iti viññāyati tasmā na abhāva vacana tā  sabhāva dhāraṇa ādi atthena dhamma saddena samāna adhikaraṇa bhāvato ca akusala saddassa kusala abhāva matta vacana tā
translated: And since the indeterminate is stated as a third aggregate, it is evident that the unprofitable is one aggregate.🔽So the word “unprofitable” does not mean mere non-existence,

original: na hoti, nāpi tadaññamattavacanatā tatiyarāsivacanato eva. Yadi hi kusalehi aññe
analyzed: na hoti nā api tad aññamattavacanatā tatiya rāsi vacanataḥ eva yadi hi kusalehi aññe
translated: nor does it mean mere other-than-that, because of the words “third aggregate.” For if it meant “other than the profitable”

original: akusalā cetasikehi aññe acetasikā viya, kusalākusalavacanehi sabbesaṃ dhammānaṃ saṅgahitattā🔽asaṅgahitassa tatiyarāsissa abhāvā cetasikaduko viya ayañca duko vattabbo siyā “kusalā
analyzed: akusalā cetasikehi aññe acetasikāḥ viya kusala akusala vacanehi sabbesam dhammānam saṅgahita ttā  asaṅgahitassa tatiya rāsissa abhāvā cetasika dukaḥ viya ayam ca dukaḥ vattabbo siyā kusalā
translated: like “other than the mental” means “not mental,” then since all states would be included by the words “profitable” and “unprofitable,”

original: dhammā akusalā dhammā”ti, na “abyākatā”ti tatiyo rāsi vattabbo, vutto ca so, tasmā
analyzed: dhammā akusalā dhammā ati na abyākatā ti tatiyaḥ rāsi vattabbaḥ vuttaḥ ca saḥ tasmā
translated: there would be no third aggregate not included, and so this dyad would have to be stated like the dyad “mental and non-mental” as “profitable states, unprofitable states,” not as “indeterminate states” as a third aggregate, and yet it is stated as such. So the word “unprofitable” does not mean mere other-than-that.

original: na tadaññamattavacanaṃ akusalasaddo, pārisesena tappaṭipakkhesu a-kārassa payogadassanato
analyzed: na tad aññamatta vacanam akusala saddaḥ pārisesena tad paṭipakkhesu akārassa payoga dassanato
translated: And because the letter a is used in the sense of negation in the words “non-greed” , etc.,

original: loke “amittā”ti sāsane “alobho”ti idhāpi tappaṭipakkhavacanatā akusalasaddassa siddhā,
analyzed: loke amittā ati sāsane alobho ti idha api tad paṭipakkha vacana tā akusala saddassa siddhā
translated: In the world “enemies” are called “adversaries” and in the Dispensation “non-greed” is so called. Here too the word “unprofitable” is established as the opposite of that.

original: tattha niruḷhattā ca na itaravacanatā, tappaṭipakkhabhāvo ca viruddhasabhāvattā tappaheyyabhāvato🔽ca veditabbo, na kusalavināsanato. Na hi kusalā akusalehi pahātabbā, mahābalavatāya
analyzed: tattha niruḷha ttā ca na itara vacana tā tad paṭipakkha bhāvo ca viruddha sabhāva ttā tad paheyya bhāvato  ca veditabbaḥ na kusala vināsanataḥ na hi kusalāḥ akusalehi pahātabbāḥ mahā balavatāya
translated: And because it is well known as such, it is not the opposite of that. And its being the opposite of that should be understood as being due to its being of a contrary nature and to its being what is to be abandoned by that .

original: pana kusalāyeva payoganipphāditā sadānusayite akusale tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedavasena pajahantīti.
analyzed: pana kusalāya iva payoga nipphāditā sadā anusayite akusale tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda vasena pajahanti iti
translated: It is not because it is to be abandoned by the profitable, for the unprofitable is not to be abandoned by the profitable. But rather it is because of the great strength of the profitable that it abandons the unprofitable, which is always latent, by suppression and by cutting off the associated taints, which are produced by the profitable’s own effort.

original: Na byākatāti akathitā. Kathaṃ panete akathitā honti, nanu “sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā”tiādīhi
analyzed: na byākatā ati a kathitā katham pana ete a kathitāḥ honti nanu sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā ati ādīhi
translated: Not stated: not mentioned. But how are they not mentioned? Are they not mentioned in the three terms of the triad, “Associated with pleasant feeling,” etc.,

original: tikadukapadehi cakkhuviññāṇādivacanehi phassādivacanehi ca kathitāti? No na kathitā,
analyzed: tika duka padehi cakkhu viññāṇa ādi vacanehi phassa ādi vacanehi ca kathitā ati no na kathitā
translated: and in the terms for the eye-consciousness, etc., and for contact, etc.? They are not unmentioned.🔽But those terms are not intended here, and so they are not mentioned and are not included. For the terms “associated with pleasant feeling,” etc.,

original: tāni pana vacanāni idha anadhippetāni avuttattā ananuvattanato. Na hi “sukhāya vedanāya
analyzed: tāni pana vacanāni idha anadhippetāni a vutta ttā an anuvattanataḥ na hi sukhāya vedanāya
translated: are not mentioned here.

original: sampayuttā dhammā”tiādiṃ vatvā “abyākatā”ti vuttaṃ, tasmā na tāni idha anuvattantīti🔽tabbacanīyabhāvena akathitatā na hoti, kusalākusalavacanāni pana idha vuttattā anuvattantīti🔽tabbacanīyabhāvena akathitatā ñāyatīti “kusalākusalabhāvena akathitāti attho”ti āha.
analyzed: sampayuttāḥ dhammā tiādim vatvā abyākatā iti vuttam tasmā na tāni idha anuvattanti iti  tad bacanīya bhāvena a kathita tā na hoti kusala akusala vacanāni pana idha vutta ttā anuvattanti iti  tad bacanīya bhāvena akathita tā ñāyati iti kusala akusala bhāvena akathitā ati atthaḥ iti āha
translated: and so on, and then “indeterminate” is said. Therefore they are not repeated here.🔽So it is not because they are not mentioned by being mentioned that they are not mentioned. But because the terms “wholesome” and “unwholesome” are mentioned here, they are repeated.🔽So it is because they are not mentioned by being mentioned that they are not mentioned.

original: Na byākatāti vā avipākā, abyākatavacaneneva ca avipākatthā ñāyanti. Na hi bhagavato
analyzed: na vā avipākāḥ abyākata vacanena iva ca avipāka atthāḥ ñāyanti na hi bhagavataḥ
translated: Or “not declared” means “not having result.” And the meaning of “not having result” is understood by the very words “indeterminate.” For the Blessed One’s

original: vacanaṃ ñāpakasādhanīyaṃ, āsayānusayacariyādikusalena bhagavatā yesaṃ avabodhanatthaṃ
analyzed: vacanam ñāpaka sādhanīyam āsaya anusaya cariyā ādi kusalena bhagavatā avabodhana attham
translated: words do not need to be proved by a reason. When the Dhamma is spoken by the Blessed One, who is skilled in the dispositions, proclivities, modes, etc., of beings,

original: dhammā vuttā tesaṃ vacanānantaraṃ tadatthapaṭivedhato, pacchimehi pana yathā tesaṃ🔽avabodhanatthaṃ bhagavatā taṃ taṃ vacanaṃ vuttaṃ, yathā ca tehi tadattho paṭividdho,
analyzed: dhammā vuttā tesam vacana anantaram tad attha paṭivedhato pacchimehi pana yathā tesam  avabodhana attham bhagavatā tam tam vacanam vuttam yathā ca tehi tad atthaḥ paṭividdhaḥ
translated: the meaning is understood immediately after the words. But for those who come later,🔽the meaning can be understood by studying under a teacher and listening to the explanation of the words spoken by the Blessed One for the purpose of understanding.

original: taṃ sabbaṃ ācariye payirupāsitvā sutvā veditabbaṃ hoti, tasmā kāraṇaṃ avatvā “kusalākusalabhāvena
analyzed: tam sabbam ācariye payirupāsitvā sutvā veditabbam hoti tasmai kāraṇam avatvā kusala akusala bhāvena
translated: Therefore, without giving a reason, the author says, “The meaning is that they are not mentioned as wholesome or unwholesome.”

original: akathitāti attho”ti āha. Yo ca vadeyya “akusalavipākabhāvena akathitattā, kusalā
analyzed: a kathitā ati atthā iti āha yaḥ ca vadeyya akusala vipāka bhāvena a kathita ttā kusalā
translated: the meaning is ‘not stated.’ ”🔽And if anyone should say, “Because of the non-statedness of the unwholesome result, they fall into the wholesome and indeterminate,

original: abyākatāti āpajjanti, kusalavipākabhāvena akathitattā akusalāpī”ti, sopi “aññāpakasādhanīyavacano
analyzed: abyākatā ati āpajjanti kusala vipāka bhāvena a kathita ttā akusalā api iti saḥ api aññāpaka sādhanīya vacanaḥ
translated: and because of the non-statedness of the wholesome result, they fall into the unwholesome,” he should be told, “The Blessed One’s word is to be established by a proof other than that,

original: bhagavā”ti nivāretabbo anuvattamānavacanavacanīyabhāvena akathitassa ca abyākatabhāvato.
analyzed: bhagavā ati nivāretabbaḥ anuvattamāna vacana vacanīya bhāvena a kathitassa ca abyākata bhāvato
translated: because of the statedness of the non-stated by the statedness of the word and by the non-statedness of the indeterminate.”

original: Na hi avipākavacanaṃ vuttaṃ kusalavacanañca avuttaṃ, yato avipākavacanassa adhikatabhāvo
analyzed: na hi avipāka vacanam vuttam kusala vacanam ca a vuttam yatas avipāka vacanassa adhikata bhāvo
translated: For no statement of non-result has been made, nor has any statement of the wholesome been omitted,🔽so that the statement of non-result could be more authoritative than the statement of the wholesome,

original: kusalassa ca tabbacanīyabhāvena akathitabhāvo siyā, tasmā na kusalānaṃ abyākatatā,
analyzed: kusalassa ca tad bacanīya bhāvena a kathita bhāvaḥ siyā tasmā na kusalānam a byākata tā
translated: and the non-statedness of the latter could be due to its being stated. Therefore the wholesome is not indeterminate.

original: evaṃ akusalānañca anabyākatabhāve yojanā kātabbā.🔽Atha vā vi-saddo virodhavacano, ā-saddo abhimukhabhāvappakāsano, tasmā attano paccayehi
analyzed: evam anabyākata bhāve yojanā kātabbā  atha vā visaddaḥ virodha vacanaḥ āsaddaḥ abhimukha bhāva ppakāsano tasmai attano paccayehi
translated: And the same method of explanation applies to the unwholesome.🔽Or alternatively, the prefix vi- in the word vibhūtaṃ signifies opposition, and the prefix ā- signifies presence. So the word means “opposed to its conditions”

original: aññamaññavirodhābhimukhā katā, lakkhaṇavirodhato vināsakavināsitabbato cāti byākatā,
analyzed: añña mañña virodha abhimukhā katā lakkhaṇa virodhataḥ ca ati byākatā
translated: because of the opposition of one to the other and because of the presence of the opposition of characteristics, as that which destroys and that which is destroyed.

original: kusalākusalā. Na byākatāti abyākatā. Te hi lakkhaṇato kusalākusalā viya viruddhā🔽na honti. Na hi avipākatā dukkhavipākatā viya sukhavipākatāya sukhavipākatā viya🔽ca dukkhavipākatāya sukhadukkhavipākatāhi virujjhatīti nāpi te kiñci pajahanti, na🔽ca te kenaci pahātabbāti ayamettha attanomati.
analyzed: kusala akusalāḥ na byākatā ati abyākatā te hi lakkhaṇato kusala akusalāḥ viya viruddhā  na honti na hi avipāka tā dukkha vipāka tā viya sukha vipāka tāya sukha vipāka tā viya  ca dukkha vipāka tāya sukha dukkha vipāka tāhi virujjhati iti na api te kiñci pajahanti na  ca te kenacid pahātabbā ati ayam ettha attanomati
translated: They are neither profitable nor unprofitable.🔽They are not opposed to profitable and unprofitable states as the characteristics of these are.🔽For the non-resultant is not opposed to the pleasant-resultant as the painful-resultant is, nor is the pleasant-resultant opposed to the painful-resultant as the pleasant-resultant is, nor is the pleasant-and-painful-resultant opposed to the pleasant-resultant and the painful-resultant.🔽And they do not abandon anything, nor are they abandoned by anything. This is the opinion here.

original: Anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇāti ettha natthi etesaṃ avajjanti anavajjā, garahitabbabhāvarahitā🔽niddosāti attho. Tena nesaṃ agarahitabbabhāvaṃ dasseti, na gārayhavirahamattaṃ. Aññepi🔽atthi niddosā abyākatāti anavajjavacanamattena tesampi kusalatāpattidosaṃ disvā taṃ🔽pariharituṃ sukhavipākavacanaṃ āha. Avajjapaṭipakkhā vā idha anavajjāti vuttā, na
analyzed: anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇā ti ettha na atthi etesam avajjanti anavajjā 🔽niddosā ti attho tena nesam a garahitabba bhāvam dasseti na gārayha viraha mattam aññe pi 🔽atthi niddosā abyākatā ti anavajja vacana mattena tesam pi kusala tā āpatti dosam disvā tam 🔽pariharitum sukha vipāka vacanam āha avajja paṭipakkhā vā idha anavajjā ati vuttā na
translated: They are neither profitable nor unprofitable. They are indeterminate. For they are not opposed in characteristic to profitable and unprofitable states as are the unprofitable and profitable. For non-resultantness is not opposed to resultantness as is profitable to unprofitable, nor is profitable resultantness opposed to unprofitable resultantness as is unprofitable to profitable. So they are not abandoned by either of the two kinds of path. And they are not to be abandoned by anything, since they are not subject to defilement. This is the opinion here. They have the characteristic of being blameless and having pleasant result. Herein, they are blameless since there is no blame in them. They are free from blame, is the meaning. So he shows that they are not to be blamed. He does not show that they are merely free from blame. For there are other indeterminate states that are free from blame. So seeing the danger in their being reckoned as profitable because of the mere fact that they are blameless, he says “having pleasant result” in order to avoid that. Or alternatively, what is opposed to blame is here called “blameless” .

original: bāhitikasutte viya paṭippassaddhāvajjā virahitāvajjamattā vā, tasmā anavajjavacanena🔽avajjavināsanabhāvo dassito. Abyākatehi pana visiṭṭhaṃ kusalākusalānaṃ sādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bāhitika sutte viya paṭippassaddha avajjāḥ vā tasmai anavajja vacanena  avajja vināsana bhāvaḥ dassitaḥ abyākatehi pana visiṭṭham kusala akusalānam sādhāraṇam
translated: and the word “blameless” shows the destruction of blame, as in the Bāhitikasutta .🔽But the word “conducive to pleasure” is said in order to show the distinction in the characteristic of having a resultant in the case of the profitable and the unprofitable, which is shared by both the profitable and the unprofitable,🔽since the profitable is distinguished from the unprofitable and the indeterminate by that characteristic.

original: savipākatālakkhaṇanti tasmiṃ lakkhaṇe visesadassanattaṃ sukhavipākavacanaṃ avoca.
analyzed: sa vipāka tā lakkhaṇam ti tasmim lakkhaṇe visesa dassana ttam sukha vipāka vacanam avoca
translated: For the distinction of the profitable from the unprofitable and the indeterminate is already established by the former words.

original: Siddho hi purimeneva akusalābyākatehi kusalānaṃ visesoti. Sukho vipāko etesanti sukhavipākā.
analyzed: siddhaḥ hi purimena iva akusala abyākatehi kusalānam visesaḥ ti sukhaḥ vipākaḥ sukha vipākā
translated: They have pleasure as their outcome, thus they are “conducive to pleasure” .

original: Tena kusalākusalānaṃ sāmaññe vipākadhammabhāve sukhavipākavipaccanasabhāvaṃ dasseti,🔽na tesaṃ sukhavipākasabbhāvameva. Anavajjā ca te sukhavipākā cāti anavajjasukhavipākā.
analyzed: tena kusala akusalānam sāmaññe vipāka dhamma bhāve sukha vipāka vipaccana sabhāvam dasseti  na tesam sukha vipāka sabbhāvam eva anavajjā ca te sukha vipākā ca ati anavajja sukha vipākā
translated: By this he shows that the profitable and the unprofitable are alike in having an outcome that is a state with a resultant,🔽but he does not show that they are alike in having pleasure as their outcome.🔽They are blameless and have pleasure as their outcome, thus they are “blameless and have pleasure as their outcome” .

original: Kusalā lakkhīyanti etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ, anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇaṃ etesanti anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇā.
analyzed: kusalāḥ lakkhīyanti etena ati lakkhaṇam anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇam etesan ti anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇā
translated: It is characterized by being blameless and having pleasure as its outcome, thus it is the “characteristic of being blameless and having pleasure as its outcome” .

original: Nanu te eva kusalā anavajjasukhavipākā, kathaṃ te sayameva attano lakkhaṇaṃ hontīti?
analyzed: nanu te eva kusalāḥ anavajja sukha vipākā katham te sayam eva attanaḥ lakkhaṇam honti iti
translated: Are not these same profitable things blameless and of pleasant feeling? How then do they become their own characteristics?

original: Viññātāviññātasaddatthabhāvena lakkhaṇalakkhitabbabhāvayuttito. Kusalasaddatthavasena
analyzed: viññāta a viññāta saddattha bhāvena lakkhaṇa lakkhitabba bhāva yuttitaḥ kusala saddattha vasena
translated: They are so called because of the meaning of “known” and “unknown” and of “good” and “useful,”🔽and because of the meaning of “profitable” and “good,”🔽and because of the meaning of “blameless” and “of pleasant feeling,”

original: hi aviññātā kusalā lakkhitabbā honti, anavajjasukhavipākasaddatthabhāvena viññātā
analyzed: hi aviññātā kusalā lakkhitabbā honti anavajja sukha vipāka saddattha bhāvena viññātā
translated: and because of the appropriateness of the characteristic and the characterized,🔽and because of the meaning of “is characterized” .

original: lakkhaṇanti yuttametaṃ. Atha vā lakkhīyatīti lakkhaṇaṃ, sabhāvo. Anavajjasukhavipākā
analyzed: lakkhaṇanti yuttam etam atha vā lakkhīyati iti lakkhaṇam sa bhāvaḥ anavajja sukha vipākā
translated: Or alternatively, it is characterized , thus it is a characteristic ; the individual essence is meant. They are blameless and of pleasant feeling,

original: ca te lakkhaṇañcāti anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇā, anavajjasukhavipākā hutvā lakkhiyamānā
analyzed: ca te lakkhaṇam ca ati anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇā anavajja sukha vipākā hutvā lakkhiyamānā
translated: and they are a characteristic , thus they are blameless-and-pleasant-feeling-characteristic . Being blameless and of pleasant feeling,

original: sabhāvā kusalā nāmāti attho.
analyzed: sabhāvā kusalā nāma ati attho
translated: they are characterized as having the individual essence called “profitable.”

original: Atha vā anavajjavacanena anavajjattaṃ āha, sukhavipākavacanena sukhavipākattaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: atha vā anavajja vacanena āha sukha vipāka vacanena tasmā
translated: Or alternatively, by the word “blameless” he stated blamelessness, and by the word “of pleasant feeling” he stated pleasant feeling. Thus

original: anavajjañca sukhavipāko ca anavajjasukhavipākaṃ, taṃ lakkhaṇaṃ etesaṃ karaṇatthe
analyzed: anavajjam ca sukha vipāko ca anavajja sukha vipākam tam lakkhaṇam etesam karaṇa tthe
translated: blameless and of pleasant feeling is blameless-and-pleasant-feeling. That is a characteristic of these . The meaning is that they are characterized as having the individual essence called “profitable” because of the meaning of “blameless” and “of pleasant feeling.”🔽Or alternatively, the word “blameless” states the state of being blameless, and the word “of pleasant feeling” states the state of being of pleasant feeling. Thus🔽blameless and of pleasant feeling is blameless-and-pleasant-feeling. That is a characteristic of these . The meaning is that they are characterized as having the individual essence called “profitable” because of the meaning of “blameless” and “of pleasant feeling.”

original: ca kammatthe ca lakkhaṇasadde sabhāvabhūtanti anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇā, anavajjasukhavipākasabhāvena🔽lakkhiyamānā taṃsabhāvavanto ca kusalāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha anavajjavacanena pavattisukhataṃ
analyzed: ca kammatthe ca lakkhaṇa sadde anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇāḥ anavajja sukha vipāka sabhāvena  lakkhiyamānā taṃsa bhāvavanto ca kusalā ti vuttam hoti tattha anavajja vacanena
translated: and in the sense of what is to be done and in the sense of a sound that is a characteristic, it is what has the nature of that, that is to say, it has the characteristic of resultant pleasant feeling that is blameless, and it is what has the nature of that, that is to say, the nature of resultant pleasant feeling that is blameless.🔽What is meant is that it is profitable. Herein, by the word “blameless” he shows the pleasantness of occurrence of the profitable,

original: kusalānaṃ dasseti, sukhavipākavacanena vipākasukhataṃ. Purimañhi attano pavattisabhāvavasena
analyzed: kusalānam dasseti sukha vipāka vacanena vipāka sukhatam puriman hi attanaḥ pavatti sabhāva vasena
translated: and by the word “resultant” he shows the pleasantness of its ripening. For the former is called a characteristic in the sense of the nature of its own occurrence,

original: lakkhaṇatāvacanaṃ, pacchimaṃ kālantare vipākuppādanasamatthatāyāti. Tathā purimena
analyzed: lakkhaṇa tā vacanam pacchimam kāla antare vipāka uppādana samattha tāya ati tathā purimena
translated: while the latter is called a characteristic in the sense of the ability to produce a ripening in a future existence.

original: kusalānaṃ attasuddhiṃ dasseti, pacchimena visuddhavipākataṃ. Purimena ca kusalaṃ
analyzed: kusalānam atta suddhim dasseti pacchimena visuddha vipākatam purimena ca kusalam
translated: And by the former he shows the profitable’s own-advantage, and by the latter he shows its advantage to others.

original: akusalasabhāvato nivatteti, pacchimena abyākatasabhāvato savipākattadīpakattā pacchimassa.
analyzed: akusala sabhāvataḥ nivatteti pacchimena abyākata sabhāvataḥ sa vipāka tta dīpaka ttā pacchimassa
translated: And by the former he turns the profitable away from the nature of the unprofitable, and by the latter he shows that it has ripening since it has the nature of the indeterminate.

original: Purimena vā vajjapaṭipakkhabhāvadassanato kiccaṭṭhena rasena akusalaviddhaṃsanarasataṃ
analyzed: purimena vā vajja paṭipakkha bhāva dassanataḥ kicca ṭṭhena rasena
translated: Or by the former he shows that it is the opposite of what is blameworthy, and by the latter he shows that it has the taste of the profitable in the sense of function, since the taste of the profitable is the opposite of the taste of the unprofitable.

original: dīpeti, pacchimena sampattiatthena iṭṭhavipākarasataṃ. Purimena ca upaṭṭhānākāraṭṭhena
analyzed: dīpeti pacchimena sampatti atthena purimena ca upaṭṭhāna ākāra ṭṭhena
translated: and by the second, the fact that it has a desirable ripening. And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge is shown,🔽since it is a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge through being a footing for the kinds of direct-knowledge object. And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object.

original: paccupaṭṭhānena vodānapaccupaṭṭhānataṃ dasseti, pacchimena phalatthena sukhavipākapaccupaṭṭhānataṃ.🔽Purimena ca yonisomanasikāraṃ kusalānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ vibhāveti. Tato hi te anavajjā
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhānena vodāna paccupaṭṭhāna tam dasseti pacchimena phala atthena sukha vipāka paccupaṭṭhāna tam  purimena ca yoni soma nasikāram kusalānam padaṭṭhānam vibhāveti tatas hi te anavajjāḥ
translated: And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the profitable is shown, since it is a footing for the profitable through being a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge.🔽And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object.

original: jātāti. Pacchimena kusalānaṃ aññesaṃ padaṭṭhānabhāvaṃ dasseti. Te hi sukhavipākassa
analyzed: jātā iti pacchimena kusalānam aññesam padaṭṭhāna bhāvam dasseti te hi sukha vipākassa
translated: And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the profitable is shown, since it is a footing for the profitable through being a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge.🔽And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object.

original: kāraṇaṃ hontīti. Ettha ca sukhavipākasadde sukhasaddo iṭṭhapariyāyavacananti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Iṭṭhacatukkhandhavipākā hi kusalā, na sukhavedanāvipākāva. Saṅkhāradukkhopasamasukhavipākatāya
analyzed: kāraṇam honti iti ettha ca sukha vipāka sadde sukha saddaḥ iṭṭha pariyāya vacanan ti daṭṭhabbaḥ  iṭṭha catu khandha vipākāḥ hi kusalā na sukha vedanā vipākāḥ ava saṅkhāra dukkha upasama sukha vipāka tāya
translated: And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the profitable is shown, since it is a footing for the profitable through being a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge.🔽And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object.🔽And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the profitable is shown, since it is a footing for the profitable through being a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge.

original: ca sambhavo eva natthi. Na hi taṃvipākoti. Yadi pana vipākasaddo phalapariyāyavacanaṃ,
analyzed: ca sambhavaḥ eva natthi na hi tad vipākaḥ ti yadi pana vipāka saddo phala pariyāya vacanam
translated: And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object.

original: nissandavipākena iṭṭharūpenāpi sukhavipākatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: nissanda vipākena iṭṭha rūpena api sukha vipāka tā yojetabbā
translated: And by the first, the way in which it is a footing for the profitable is shown, since it is a footing for the profitable through being a footing for the kinds of direct knowledge.🔽And by the second, the way in which it is a footing for the kinds of concentration is shown, since it is a footing for the kinds of concentration through being a footing for the kinds of concentration object

original: Sāvajjadukkhavipākalakkhaṇāti ettha ca vuttavidhianusārena attho ca yojanā ca yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: sāvajja dukkha vipāka lakkhaṇā ti ettha ca vutta vidhi anusārena atthaḥ ca yojanā ca yathāsambhavam
translated: As to the characteristic of blameableness and painful result: the meaning and the application should be understood here in the way already stated.

original: veditabbā. Vipākārahatā kusalākusalānaṃ lakkhaṇabhāvena vuttā, tabbhāvena akathitā
analyzed: veditabbā vipāka arahatā kusala akusalānam lakkhaṇa bhāvena vuttā tad bhāvena a kathitā
translated: And the unprofitable and the unprofitable result, etc., should be understood in the way stated in the case of the profitable and the profitable result, etc., and the meaning and the application should be construed accordingly.

original: abyākatā avipākārahasabhāvā hontīti āha “avipākalakkhaṇā abyākatā”ti. Yatheva hi
analyzed: abyākatāḥ a vipāka araha sabhāvāḥ honti iti āha avipāka lakkhaṇā abyākatā ati yathā iva hi
translated: The profitable and the unprofitable are called “having the characteristic of result” because they are stated as the characteristic of result of profitable and unprofitable kamma respectively, and the indeterminate is called “having the characteristic of no-result” because it is not stated as the characteristic of result of either kind of kamma.

original: sukhadukkhavipākārahā sukhadukkhavipākāti evaṃlakkhaṇatā kusalākusalānaṃ vuttā, evamidhāpi🔽avipākārahā avipākāti evaṃlakkhaṇatā abyākatānaṃ vuttā. Tasmā “ahosi kammaṃ nāhosi
analyzed: sukha dukkha vipāka arahā sukha dukkha vipākā ati evaṃlakkhaṇa tā kusala akusalānam vuttā evam idha api  avipāka arahā avipākā ati evaṃlakkhaṇa tā abyākatānam vuttā tasmai ahosi kammam na ahosi
translated: Just as the profitable and the unprofitable are stated as having the characteristic of having a result that is pleasure, etc., and a result that is pain, etc., respectively,🔽so the indeterminate is stated as having the characteristic of having no such result.

original: kammavipāko na bhavissati kammavipāko natthi kammavipāko, atthi kammaṃ natthi kammavipāko
analyzed: kamma vipākaḥ na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ na atthi kamma vipākaḥ atthi kammam na atthi kamma vipāko
translated: So the profitable and the unprofitable do not become indeterminate by becoming “there was kamma but there was no result of kamma, there will be no result of kamma, there is no result of kamma; there is kamma but there is no result of kamma;

original: na bhavissati kammavipāko, bhavissati kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko”ti evaṃpakārānaṃ🔽kusalākusalānaṃ kusalākusalabhāvānāpatti abyākatabhāvāpatti vā na hoti. Na hi te
analyzed: na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ bhavissati kammam na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ ti evaṃpakārānam 🔽kusala akusalānam kusala akusala bhāva anāpatti abyākata bhāva āpatti vā na hoti na hi te
translated: there will be kamma but there will be no result of kamma, there is kamma but there is no result of kamma.”🔽For they do not become indeterminate.

original: sukhadukkhavipākārahā na honti vipākadhammattā, avipākārahā vā na honti avipākadhammattābhāvāti.
analyzed: sukha dukkha vipāka ārahāḥ na honti vipāka dhamma ttā avipāka ārahāḥ vā na honti avipāka dhamma ttā bhāvāti
translated: they are not not-result-yielding because they are not non-result-state dhammas.

original: Kusalāti vā dhammāti vātiādīnīti kusaladhammapadāni dve, akusaladhammapadāni dve,
analyzed: kusalā ati vā dhammā ati vā atiādīni iti kusala dhamma padāni dve akusala dhamma padāni dve
