original: kusalāti katvā tāyapi pucchāya virodho āpajjati, vuccati ca tathā sā pucchāti na nānatthatā yujjati.
analyzed: kusalā ati katvā pucchāya virodhaḥ āpajjati vuccati ca tathā sā pucchā ati na nānattha tā yujjati
translated: and if he were to take them as profitable, he would be contradicting the question, and yet the question is said to be asked in that way. So it is not proper to take it as having a single meaning.

original: Aparo nayoti “kusalā dhammā”tiādīnaṃ dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ ekatthattameva tiṇṇaṃ dhammasaddānaṃ🔽ekatthanānatthattehi codeti. Tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ ekattātiādimhi yathā tīhi inda-saddehi🔽vuccamānānaṃ indatthānaṃ indabhāvena ekattā tato anaññesaṃ sakkapurindadasahassakkhasaddatthānaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayo ti kusalāḥ dhammā ati ādīnam dvinnam dvinnam ekatthattam eva tiṇṇam dhamma saddānam  ekattha nānatthattehi codeti tiṇṇam dhammānam ekatta ati ādimhi yathā tīhi inda saddehi  vuccamānānam inda tthānam inda bhāvena eka ttā tatas anaññesam sakka purinda da sahassakkha sadda tthānam
translated: Another method: he reproves the three terms “states,” “profitable,” and “unprofitable” for having a single meaning and for having a different meaning in the two pairs “profitable states” and “profitable ideas,” “unprofitable states” and “unprofitable ideas.”🔽In the passage beginning “The singleness of the three ideas” he says that just as the meanings of the three terms “Inda,” “lord,” and “a thousand” are single in the sense of being the same as each other🔽because of the singleness of the meaning of “Inda” in the three expressions “Inda’s abode,” “Inda’s city,” and “Inda’s mountain,” so too the meanings of the three terms “states,” “profitable,” and “unprofitable” are single in the sense of being the same as each other

original: ekattaṃ, evaṃ tiṇṇaṃ dhamma-saddatthānaṃ dhammabhāvena ekattā tato anaññesaṃ kusalākusalābyākata-saddatthānaṃ
analyzed: ekattam evam tiṇṇam dhamma sadda tthānam dhamma bhāvena ekattā tatas anaññesam kusala akusala abyākata sadda tthānam
translated: because of the singleness of the meaning of “states” in the three expressions “profitable states,” “unprofitable states,” and “indeterminate states.”

original: ekattaṃ āpajjatīti attho. Dhammo nāma bhāvoti sabhāvadhāraṇādinā atthena dhammoti
analyzed: ekattam āpajjati iti atthaḥ dhammaḥ nāma bhāvaḥ ti sa bhāva dhāraṇa ādinā atthena dhammo ti
translated: The meaning of the word “idea” is an “idea” in the sense of a state,

original: vutto, so ca sabhāvasseva hoti, nāsabhāvassāti iminā adhippāyena vadati. Hotu bhāvo,
analyzed: vutto so ca sabhāvassa iva hoti na asabhāvassa ati iminā adhippāyena vadati hotu bhāvaḥ
translated: and that is only of a state, not of a non-state. This is the intention. Let it be a state.

original: tato kinti? Yadi tiṇṇaṃ dhammasaddānaṃ nānatthatā, tīsu dhammesu yo koci eko dhammo
analyzed: tatas kim ti yadi tiṇṇam dhamma saddānam nānattha tā tīsu dhammesu yaḥ koci ekaḥ dhammo
translated: Then what? If there is a difference in meaning of the three terms “state,” “non-state,” and “non-existent,” then one of the three states

original: bhāvo, tato anaññaṃ kusalaṃ akusalaṃ abyākataṃ vā ekekameva bhāvo. Bhāvabhūtā pana
analyzed: bhāvaḥ tatas anaññam kusalam akusalam abyākatam vā ekekam eva bhāvaḥ bhāva bhūtā pana
translated: is a state, and what is not that is a non-state, and what is not that is a non-existent. But the states that are

original: dhammā aññe dve abhāvā hontīti tehi anaññe kusalādīsu dve ye keci abhāvā. Yopi ca🔽so eko dhammo bhāvoti gahito, sopi samānarūpesu tīsu dhammasaddesu ayameva bhāvattho🔽hotīti niyamassa abhāvā aññassa bhāvatthatte sati abhāvo hotīti tato anaññassapi
analyzed: dhammā aññe dve abhāvā honti iti tehi anaññe kusala ādīsu dve ye abhāvā ca  saḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ bhāvaḥ ti gahitaḥ saḥ api samāna rūpesu tīsu dhamma saddesu ayam eva bhāva tthaḥ  hoti iti niyamassa abhāvāḥ aññassa bhāvatthatte sati abhāvaḥ hoti iti tatas anaññassa api
translated: are two non-states. And of the two non-states in the case of the profitable, etc., any one is a non-state. And the one state that is taken as a state

original: abhāvattaṃ āpannanti kusalādīnaṃ sabbesampi abhāvattāpatti hoti. Na hi indassa amanussatte🔽tato anaññesaṃ sakkādīnaṃ manussattaṃ atthīti.
analyzed: abhāva ttam āpannanti kusala ādīnam sabbesam pi abhāva tta āpatti hoti na hi indassa a manussatte  tatas anaññesam sakka ādīnam manussa ttam atthi iti
translated: is also in the three terms “state,” etc., which are the same in form, only a state in meaning. So there is no rule. And when there is a state in one, there is a non-state in the other two. So there is the fault that all the profitable, etc., become non-states. For when Indra is a non-human being, there is no other Sakka, etc., who are human beings.

original: Nanu evamapi ekassa bhāvattaṃ vinā aññesaṃ abhāvattaṃ na sakkā vattuṃ, tattha ca
analyzed: nanu evam api ekassa bhāvattam vinā aññesam abhāvattam na sakkā vattum tattha ca
translated: But surely in that case too it is not possible to say that there is a state in one and a non-state in the other. And in that case too

original: ekeneva bhāvena bhavitabbanti niyamābhāvato tiṇṇampi bhāvatte siddhe tehi anaññesaṃ
analyzed: ekena iva bhāvena bhavitabbanti niyama abhāvato tiṇṇam pi bhāva tte siddhe tehi anaññesam
translated: Since there is no rule that one must exist in one mode only, it is established that all three exist in each of the modes.

original: kusalādīnampi bhāvattaṃ siddhaṃ hotīti? Na hoti tiṇṇaṃ dhamma-saddānaṃ nānatthabhāvassa
analyzed: kusala ādīnam pi bhāva ttam siddham hoti iti na hoti tiṇṇam dhamma saddānam nānattha bhāvassa
translated: because there is no rule that they must exist in one mode only, the existence of all three is established. So is the existence of the profitable, etc., also established? No, because the existence of the three terms of the expression is admitted as having different meanings.

original: anuññātattā. Na hi tiṇṇaṃ bhāvatte nānatthatā atthi, anuññātā ca sā tayāti. Nanu
analyzed: anuññāta ttā na hi tiṇṇam bhāvatte nānattha tā atthi anuññātā ca sā tayā ati nanu
translated: For there is no difference in the existence of the three terms, and that is admitted by us as three.

original: tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ abhāvattepi nānatthatā na siyāti? Mā hotu nānatthatā, tava pana🔽nānatthataṃ paṭijānantassa “eso doso”ti vadāmi, na pana mayā nānatthatā ekatthatā
analyzed: tiṇṇam dhammānam abhāvatte pi nānattha tā na siyāti mā hotu nānattha tā tava pana  nānattha tam paṭijānantassa eso doso ti vadāmi na pana mayā nānattha tā ekattha tā
translated: But even if there were no existence of the three ideas, would there not be difference? Let there be no difference. But I say that the fault is yours

original: vā anuññātāti kuto me virodho siyāti. Atha vā abhāvattaṃ āpannehi dhammehi anaññe🔽kusalādayopi abhāvā eva siyunti idaṃ vacanaṃ aniyamena ye keci dve dhammā abhāvattaṃ
analyzed: vā anuññātā ati kutas me virodhaḥ siyāti atha vā abhāvattam āpannehi dhammehi anaññe  kusala ādayaḥ api abhāvāḥ eva siyunti idam vacanam aniyamena ye keci dve dhammāḥ
translated: who admit difference, not mine who admit neither difference nor non-difference. So how can there be any contradiction for me?

original: āpannā, tehi anaññesaṃ kusalādīsu yesaṃ kesañci dvinnaṃ kusalādīnaṃ abhāvattāpattiṃ
analyzed: āpannā tehi anaññesam kusala ādīsu yesam kesañci dvinnam kusala ādīnam abhāva tta āpattim
translated: Or alternatively, if the ideas that have reached non-existence were not different from the profitable, etc., then the profitable, etc., would be non-existent too. This statement is not definite. For any two ideas that have reached non-existence are not different from any other two ideas that have reached non-existence, whether profitable, etc., or not.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ ekassa bhāvattā. Yampi vuttaṃ “tehi ca añño kusalaparopi abhāvo siyā”ti,
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam ekassa bhāvattā yat pi vuttam tehi ca aññaḥ kusala paraḥ api abhāvaḥ siyāti
translated: and it was said with reference to the fact that there is the state of one only. And as for what was said, namely, that “there might be the non-existence of any other profitable state apart from those” ,

original: taṃ aniyamadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ, na sabbesaṃ abhāvasādhanatthaṃ. Ayañhi tattha attho
analyzed: tat aniyama dassana ttham vuttam na sabbesam abhāva sādhana ttham ayam hi tattha attho
translated: that was said with reference to the non-restriction of the term “profitable” to the profitable only, not with reference to the establishment of the non-existence of all. For this is the meaning here:

original: akusalaparassa vā abyākataparassa vā dhammassa bhāvatte sati tehi añño kusalaparopi abhāvo siyāti.
analyzed: akusala parassa vā abyākata parassa vā dhammassa bhāvatte sati tehi aññaḥ kusala paraḥ api abhāvo siyāti
translated: if there were the state of the unprofitable or the state of the indeterminate, there might be the non-existence of any other profitable state apart from those.

original: Sabbametaṃ akāraṇanti ettha kāraṇaṃ nāma yutti. Kusalakusalasaddānaṃ viya ekantaekatthataṃ,
analyzed: sabbam etat akāraṇam ti ettha kāraṇam nāma yutti kusala kusala saddānam viya ekanta ekattha tam
translated: All this is not a reason. Herein, a reason is a ground. After distinguishing the meaning of the words “profitable” and “profitable state” as being exclusively the same,

original: kusalarūpacakkhuma-saddānaṃ viya ekantanānatthatañca vikappetvā yāyaṃ punarutti chakkacatukkāpatti
analyzed: kusala rūpa cakkhuma saddānam viya ekanta nānattha tat ca vikappetvā yā ayam punarutti chakka catukka āpatti
translated: and the meaning of the words “profitable visible-data” and “eye” as being exclusively different, the re-statement that was made in the way beginning “The assumption of the four-foldness of the eye”

original: asambandhavirodhābhāvāpatti dosāropanayutti vuttā, sabbā sā ayutti, tathā ekatthanānatthatābhāvatoti
analyzed: asambandha virodha abhāva āpatti dosa āropana yutti vuttā sabbā sā ayutti tathā eka attha nānattha tā bhāvato ti
translated: is not a reason, since it is a groundless contradiction, a groundless ascription of a defect. What is meant is that it is not a reason because there is no such thing as the meaning being exclusively the same or different.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Yā yā anumati yathānumati anumatiyā anumatiyā vohārasiddhito. Anumatiyā
analyzed: vuttam hoti yā yā anumati yathā anumati anumatiyā anumatiyā vohāra siddhitaḥ anumatiyā
translated: The assumption is the assumption of the meaning of the words “profitable” and “profitable state” as being exclusively the same, and the assumption of the meaning of the words “profitable visible-data” and “eye” as being exclusively different.

original: anurūpaṃ vā yathānumati, yathā anumati pavattā, tathā tadanurūpaṃ vohārasiddhitoti
analyzed: anurūpam vā yathā anumati yathā anumati tathā tat anurūpam vohāra siddhitaḥ uti
translated: or in accordance with the usage, in accordance with the usage as it occurs, in accordance with that, by the establishment of usage.

original: attho. Anumati hi visesanavisesitabbābhāvato accantamabhinnesu katthaci kiriyāguṇādipariggahavisesena
analyzed: atthaḥ anumati hi visesana visesitabba abhāvataḥ accantam abhinnesu katthaci kiriyā guṇa ādi pariggaha visesena
translated: For the usage is in accordance with that, because it occurs in order to explain the meaning of the word that is not clear in some cases by the distinction of the action, quality, etc.,🔽which is to be distinguished by the distinction, because of the absence of the distinction of the distinguished in the very much mixed up.🔽In some cases it occurs in order to explain the meaning of the word that is not clear in the very much distinguished,

original: avivaṭasaddatthavivaraṇatthaṃ pavattā yathā “sakko indo purindado”ti. Katthaci accantaṃ
analyzed: pavattā yathā sakkaḥ indo katthaci
translated: as in “Sakka, the lord of Indra, the lord of men.” In some cases it occurs in order to explain the meaning of the word that is not clear in the very much mixed up,

original: bhinnesu yathā “dhavo khadiro palāso ca ānīyantū”ti. Katthaci visesanavisesitabbabhāvato🔽bhedābhedavantesu seyyathāpi “nīluppalaṃ paṇḍitapuriso”ti, tāya tāya anumatiyā tadanurūpañca
analyzed: bhinnesu yathā dhavaḥ khadiraḥ palāsaḥ ca ānīyantu uti katthaci visesana visesitabba bhāvato  bheda abhedavantesu sā iyyathā api nīluppalam paṇḍita purisaḥ ti tāya tāya anumatiyā tad anurūpam ca
translated: as in “Bring the dhavo, the khadiro, and the palāso.” In some cases it occurs in order to explain the meaning of the word that is not clear in those that have distinction and are to be distinguished,

original: te te vohārā siddhā. Tasmā ihāpi kusaladhamma-saddānaṃ visesanavisesitabbabhāvato
analyzed: te te vohārā siddhā tasmai iha api kusala dhamma saddānam visesana visesitabba bhāvato
translated: as in “The blue lotus, the wise man.” By that and that usage, those and those usages are established. Therefore here also, because of the absence of the distinction of the distinguished in the words of the wholesome states,

original: visesatthasāmaññatthapariggahena samāne atthe bhedābhedayutte pavatti anumatāti tāya
analyzed: visesa attha sāmañña ttha pariggahena samāne atthe bheda abheda yutte pavatti anumatā ati tāya
translated: the occurrence is usage, because of the distinction of the meaning of the distinction and the meaning of the commonality in the same meaning, because of the suitability of the distinction and the non-distinction.

original: tāya anumatiyā tadanurūpañca siddho eso vohāro. Tasmā vuttaṃ “sabbametaṃ akāraṇa”nti.
analyzed: tāya anumatiyā tad anurūpam ca siddhaḥ esaḥ vohāro tasmā vuttam sabbam etam akāraṇam ti
translated: And by that permission the usage is established in conformity with it. That is why it was said above, “All this is not a reason.”

original: Attano attano atthavisesaṃ tassa dīpentīti attanā pariggahitaṃ attanā vuccamānaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ attanaḥ attha visesam tassa dīpenti iti attanā pariggahitam attanā vuccamānam
translated: They show the special meaning of each one for itself: they show the meaning of the word “Dhamma” as the meaning of what is to be learned, etc., by themselves, that is, as what is taken up by themselves, as what is spoken of by themselves,

original: anavajjasukhavipākādikusalādibhāvaṃ dhamma-saddassa dīpenti tadatthassa tabbhāvadīpanavasenāti
analyzed: anavajja sukha vipāka ādi kusala ādi bhāvam dhamma saddassa dīpenti tad atthassa tad bhāva dīpana vasena ati
translated: and they show the meaning of the word “Dhamma” as the meaning of what has a blameless fruition, etc., and as the meaning of what is profitable, etc., by themselves, that is, by themselves showing the state of being that meaning.🔽This is the purport. For the word “Dhamma” is not itself profitable, etc.

original: adhippāyo. Na hi dhamma-saddo kusalādibhāvo hotīti. Imināvāti “dhamma-saddo pariyattiādīsu
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ na hi dhamma saddo kusala ādi bhāvaḥ hoti iti dhamma saddo pariyatti ādīsu
translated: This is the reason: “The word ‘Dhamma’ is found in the sense of what is to be learnt, etc.,

original: dissatī”tiādinā “attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentī”tiādinā ca nayena. So hi sabbattha samāno,
analyzed: dissati itiādinā attanaḥ sabhāvam dhārenti itiādinā ca nayena so hi sabbattha samānaḥ
translated: and in the sense of the individual essence, etc.,” and so on. For that word is the same in all these instances,

original: na kusala-saddo ārogyādīsu dissatīti “kucchite salayantī”tiādiko, so ca visesanayo🔽“ito paraṃ visesamattameva vakkhāmā”ti etena apanītoti daṭṭhabbo. Na hi kusalādivisesaṃ
analyzed: na kusala saddo ārogya ādīsu dissati iti so ca visesa nayo  itas param visesa mattam eva vakkhāma ati etena apanītaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ na hi kusala ādi visesam
translated: but the word “profitable” is not found in the sense of health, etc., as in the passage “They cause to be brought to perfection what is profitable” , etc.,🔽and that is a distinguishing reason.

original: gahetvā pavattā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttātiādayo visesāti.
analyzed: gahetvā pavattā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā ati ādayaḥ visesā ti
translated: And it should be regarded as excluded by the words “We shall explain only the distinctions from here onward” . For the distinctions beginning with “Associated with pleasant feeling” are not the distinctions of the word “Dhamma” as profitable, etc.,

original: 2. Sukhassa ca pahānāti ettha sukhindriyaṃ “sukha”nti vuttaṃ, tañca sukhavedanāva
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānāti ettha sukha indriyam sukhanti vuttam tat ca sukha vedanā va
translated: “And the abandoning of pleasure” : here the pleasure faculty is called “pleasure” . And that is only the feeling of pleasure.

original: hotīti “sukhavedanāyaṃ dissatī”ti vuttaṃ, na pana “tisso imā, bhikkhave, vedanā sukhā🔽vedanā”tievamādīsu sukha-saddo viya sukhavedanāsaddena samānatthattā. Ayañhi sukhindriyattho🔽sukha-saddo kāyasukhanaṃ kāyānuggahaṃ sātavisesaṃ gahetvā pavatto, na pana sukhā
analyzed: hoti iti sukha vedanā ayam dissati iti vuttam na pana tissaḥ imāḥ bhikkhave vedanā sukhā  vedanā ati evamādīsu sukha saddaḥ viya sukha vedanā saddena samāna attha ttā ayam hi sukha indriya tthaḥ  sukha saddaḥ kāya sukhanam kāya anuggaham sāta visesam gahetvā pavattaḥ na pana sukhā
translated: Therefore it is said, “It is seen in the feeling of pleasure” , but not because it has the same meaning as the word “pleasure” as in such passages as “Bhikkhus, these three feelings are pleasant” .🔽For this word “pleasure” in the sense of the pleasure faculty occurs in the sense of a special kind of satisfaction that is a benefit to the body, not in the sense of the feeling of pleasure as in such passages as “Whatever feeling is felt, whether pleasant” .

original: vedanā “yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vedeti sukhaṃ vā, yo sukhaṃ dukkhato”tievamādīsu sukha-saddo
analyzed: vedanā yam kiñci vedanam vedeti sukham vā yaḥ sukham dukkhato ti evamādīsu sukha saddaḥ
translated: But the word “pleasure” in such passages as “If he feels a pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘It is impermanent; there is no holding to it; there is no delight in it” occurs in the sense of the feeling of pleasure, taking the similarity of pleasantness .

original: viya sātasāmaññaṃ gahetvā pavattoti. Yasmiṃ sati sukhahetūnaṃ pavatti, taṃ sukhamūlaṃ.🔽Buddhuppāde ca kāmasamatikkamādike virāge ca sati sukhahetūnaṃ puññapassaddhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: viya sāta sāmaññam gahetvā yasmin sati sukha hetūnam tam sukha mūlam  buddhuppāde ca kāma samatikkama ādike virāge ca sati sukha hetūnam puñña passaddhi ādīnam
translated: When there is that , there is the occurrence of the causes of pleasure. That is the root of pleasure.🔽And when there is the arising of a Buddha, the surmounting of sense desires, etc., and the fading away of greed, etc., there is the occurrence of the causes of pleasure, namely, merit, tranquillity, etc. That is why it is said, “The root of pleasure is pleasure” .

original: pavatti hotīti taṃ “sukhamūlaṃ sukha”nti vuttaṃ. Sukhassa ca ārammaṇattā “rūpaṃ sukha”nti
analyzed: pavatti hoti iti tam sukha mūlam sukhanti vuttam sukhassa ca ārammaṇa ttā rūpam sukhanti
translated: And because it is the object of pleasure, material form is called “pleasure” .

original: vuttaṃ. Puññānīti yadidaṃ vacanaṃ, taṃ sukhassa ca adhivacanaṃ iṭṭhavipākassa adhivacanaṃ
analyzed: vuttam puññāni iti yat idam vacanam tam sukhassa ca adhivacanam iṭṭha vipākassa adhivacanam
translated: “Merit” is a term for pleasure, for a desirable ripening.🔽The meaning is that it is the source of that, since it ripens as desirable.

original: tadatthassa iṭṭhavipākavipaccanatoti attho. Sukhapaccayānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tad atthassa iṭṭha vipāka vipaccanato ti attho sukha paccayānam rūpa ādīnam iṭṭhānam ṭhānam
translated: The “pleasures” are the desirable forms, etc., that are conditions for pleasure.

original: okāso saggā nandanañcāti “sukhā saggā sukhaṃ nandana”nti vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammeti imasmiṃ🔽attabhāve. Sukhavihārāti paṭhamajjhānavihārādī. Nīvaraṇādibyābādharahitattā “abyābajjhā”ti
analyzed: okāsaḥ saggā nandanam ca ati sukhā saggā sukham nandananti vuttam diṭṭhadhamma iti imasmiṃ  atta bhāve sukha vihārā ati paṭhama jhāna vihāra ādī nīvaraṇa ādi byābādha rahita ttā a byābajjhā ati
translated: The “delight” is heaven. So it is said: “Pleasure is heaven, delight is heaven.”🔽“In this very life”: in this very individual existence.🔽“Pleasant abidings”: the abidings in the first jhāna, etc. They are called “unadulterated” because they are free from the defilements such as sensual desire, etc.,

original: vuttā. Sabbasaṅkhāradukkhanibbāpanato taṃnirodhattā vā “nibbānaṃ sukha”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Ādi-saddena “adukkhamasukhaṃ santaṃ, sukhamicceva bhāsita”nti adukkhamasukhe. “Dvepi
analyzed: vuttā sabba saṅkhāra dukkha nibbāpanataḥ tad nirodha ttā vā nibbānam sukhan ti vuttam  ādi saddena adukkham asukham santam sukham icca iva bhāsitanti adukkham asukhe dve pi
translated: and because they are the cessation of those. Or they are the cessation of those, and they are pleasure because they are the cessation of those.🔽The word “etc.” includes the “neither-painful-nor-pleasant” in the passage: “The peaceful neither-painful-nor-pleasant state is said to be pleasure” ,

original: mayā, ānanda, vedanā vuttā pariyāyena sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā”ti sukhopekkhāsu🔽ca iṭṭhāsūti evamādīsu pavatti saṅgahitā.
analyzed: mayā ānanda vedanā vuttā pariyāyena sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā ati sukha upekkhāsu 🔽ca iṭṭhāsu iti evamādīsu pavatti saṅgahitā
translated: and the desirable in the passages: “Two kinds of feeling have been taught by me, Ānanda, as desirable when felt” ,🔽and “The desirable is of two kinds, Ānanda” .

original: Dukkhavatthūti dukkhassa okāso. Attano paccayehi uppajjamānampi hi taṃ dukkhaṃ jātiādīsu🔽vijjamānesu tabbatthukaṃ hutvā uppajjati. Dukkhapaccayeti dukkhahetumhi, dukkhassa
analyzed: dukkha vatthu iti dukkhassa okāsaḥ attanaḥ paccayehi uppajjamānam pi hi tam dukkham jāti ādīsu  vijjamānesu tabbatthukam hutvā uppajjati dukkha paccaye iti dukkha hetumhi dukkhassa
translated: “Basis for suffering” is the occasion for suffering. For although suffering arises through its own conditions, it arises with those conditions as its ground when they are present in such things as birth.🔽“In the cause of suffering” means in the cause of suffering, in the producer of suffering, is the meaning.

original: janaketi attho. Dukkhapaccayaṭṭhāneti dukkhajanakakammassa sahāyabhūtānaṃ aniṭṭharūpādipaccayānaṃ
analyzed: janaka iti atthaḥ dukkha paccaya ṭṭhāne ti dukkha janaka kammassa sahāya bhūtānam aniṭṭha rūpa ādi paccayānam
translated: “In the place of the cause of suffering” means in the place of the conditions that are not desirable, such as visible forms, etc., which are the companions of the action that produces suffering.

original: ṭhāne. Paccayasaddo hi janake janakasahāye ca pavattatīti. Ādi-saddena “yadaniccaṃ
analyzed: ṭhāne paccaya saddaḥ hi janake janaka sahāye ca pavattati iti ādi saddena yat aniccam
translated: For the word “cause” is used for the producer and for the companion of the producer.

original: taṃ dukkha”ntiādinā saṅkhāradukkhādīsu pavatti daṭṭhabbā. Sampayutte vatthuñca karajakāyaṃ🔽sukhayati laddhassāde anuggahite karotīti sukhā. Sukhāti vedanāsaddamapekkhitvā sukhabhāvamattassa
analyzed: tam dukkham ti ādinā saṅkhāra dukkha ādīsu pavatti daṭṭhabbā sampayutte vatthum ca karaja kāyam  sukhayati laddha ssāde anuggahite karoti iti sukhā sukhā ati vedanā saddam apekkhitvā sukha bhāva mattassa
translated: The word “etc.” should be understood to include the occurrence of the expression “What is impermanent is suffering” in the case of the suffering of formations, etc.🔽The body that is born of kamma is pleasant, it makes happy, it causes to be assisted by the pleasure that has been obtained, thus it is pleasant .

original: appakāsanena napuṃsakaliṅgatā na katā. Sabhāvato saṅkappato ca yaṃ iṭṭhaṃ, tadanubhavanaṃ
analyzed: appakāsanena napuṃsaka liṅga tā na katā sabhāvato saṅkappato ca yam iṭṭham tad anubhavanam
translated: The neuter gender of sukha is not used because the mere state of pleasantness is not intended, with reference to the word “feeling” .

original: iṭṭhākārānubhavanaṃ vā iṭṭhānubhavanaṃ.
analyzed: iṭṭha ākāra anubhavanam vā iṭṭha anubhavanam
translated: What is desirable in the sense of its essential original nature and in the sense of its being an object of choice is the experience of the desirable , or the experience of the aspect of the desirable, thus it is the experience of the desirable .

original: Samanti avisamaṃ. Samā ekībhāvūpagatā viya yuttā, samaṃ vā saha yuttāti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: samanti avisamam samā ekībhāva upagatā viya yuttā samam vā saha yuttā iti yojetabbam
translated: “Even” : without unevenness. They are even, yoked together as it were, or they are yoked together with evenness.

original: Ekuppādāti eko samāno uppādo etesanti ekuppādā, samānapaccayehi sahuppattikāti attho.
analyzed: eka uppādā ti ekaḥ samānaḥ uppādaḥ etesanti eka uppādā samāna paccayehi sahuppattikā ti attho
translated: “Having a single arising” : they have a single arising in common, thus they have a single arising. The meaning is that they arise together with the same conditions.

original: Sahuppattikānaṃ rūpārūpānañca aññamaññasampayuttatā āpajjeyyāti “ekanirodhā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: sahuppattikānam rūpa arūpānam ca aññamañña sampayutta tā āpajjeyya ati eka nirodhā iti vuttam
translated: “Having a single cessation” is said because it would follow that material and immaterial states that arise together would be conjoined.

original: ye samānuppādā samānanirodhā ca, te sampayuttāti rūpārūpānaṃ aññamaññasampayogo nivārito
analyzed: ye samāna uppādā samāna nirodhā ca te sampayuttā ati rūpa arūpānam aññamañña sampayogaḥ nivāritaḥ
translated: Those that have a single arising, a single cessation, and a single basis are conjoined. Thus the conjoining of material and immaterial states is excluded.

original: hoti. Evamapi avinibbhogarūpānaṃ aññamaññasampayuttatā āpajjeyyāti “ekavatthukā”ti
analyzed: hoti evam api a vinibbhoga rūpānam aññamañña sampayutta tā āpajjeyya ati eka vatthukā ati
translated: Even so, it would follow that undifferentiated materiality would be conjoined. Thus “having a single basis” is said.

original: vuttaṃ, ye ekuppādā ekanirodhā ekavatthukā ca, te sampayuttāti. Evamapi avinibbhogarūpesu🔽ekaṃ mahābhūtaṃ sesamahābhūtopādārūpānaṃ nissayapaccayo hotīti tena tāni ekavatthukānīti,
analyzed: vuttam ye eka uppādāḥ eka nirodhāḥ eka vatthukā ca te sampayuttā ati evam api a vinibbhoga rūpesu  ekam mahābhūtam sesa mahābhūta upādā rūpānam nissaya paccayaḥ hoti iti tena tāni eka vatthukāni iti
translated: Those that have a single arising, a single cessation, and a single basis are conjoined. Even so, it would follow that among the undifferentiated materialities🔽a great element is the support condition for the other great elements and for the materiality derived by clinging to them. Thus they have a single basis.

original: cakkhādinissayabhūtāni vā bhūtāni ekaṃ vatthu etesu sannissitanti ekavatthukānīti
analyzed: cakkha ādi nissaya bhūtāni vā bhūtāni ekam vatthu etesu sannissitanti eka vatthukāni iti
translated: Or the great elements that are the support for the eye, etc., have a single basis in the sense that they are supported by it. Thus they have a single basis.

original: kappentassa tesaṃ sampayuttatāpatti siyāti tannivāraṇatthaṃ “ekārammaṇā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: kappentassa tesam sampayutta tā āpatti siyāti tad nivāraṇa attham eka ārammaṇā iti vuttam
translated: The purpose of the words “with a single object” is to prevent it being said that they are associated when they are merely present together in one who is making a single cognitive series.

original: ye ekuppādā…pe… ekārammaṇā ca honti, te sampayuttāti. Paṭilomato vā ekārammaṇāti🔽vutte ekavīthiyañca pañcaviññāṇasampaṭicchanānaṃ nānāvīthiyaṃ parasantāne ca ekasmiṃ
analyzed: ye eka uppāda ape eka ārammaṇā ca honti te sampayuttā ati paṭilomataḥ vā eka ārammaṇā ati  vutte eka vīthiyam ca pañca viññāṇa sampaṭicchanānam nānā vīthiyam para santāne ca ekasmin
translated: Those that have a single arising, a single domain, and a single object are associated.

original: ārammaṇe uppajjamānānaṃ bhinnavatthukānaṃ sampayuttatā āpajjeyyāti “ekavatthukā”ti🔽vuttaṃ, ye ekavatthukā hutvā ekārammaṇā, te sampayuttāti. Evamapi sampaṭicchanasantīraṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇe uppajjamānānam bhinna vatthukānam sampayutta tā āpajjeyya ati eka vatthukā ati  vuttam ye eka vatthukāḥ hutvā eka ārammaṇā te sampayuttā ati evam api sampaṭicchana santīraṇa ādīnam
translated: Or alternatively, when it is said “with a single object,” it might be thought that the five-sense-door adverting and the receiving that arise in a single cognitive series, and those that arise in a different cognitive series in another’s mental continuity, are associated, since they occur with a single object.🔽So the words “with a single domain” are stated in order to prevent it being said that they are associated. Those that have a single domain, a single object, and a single cessation are associated.

original: sampayuttatā āpajjeyyāti “ekanirodhā”ti vuttaṃ, ye ekanirodhā hutvā ekavatthukā ekārammaṇā,
analyzed: sampayutta tā āpajjeyya ati eka nirodhā iti vuttam ye eka nirodhā hutvā eka vatthukāḥ eka ārammaṇā
translated: But it might be thought that adverting, receiving, etc., are associated. So the words “with a single cessation” are stated in order to prevent it being said that they are associated. Those that have a single cessation, a single domain, and a single object are associated.

original: te sampayuttāti. Kiṃ pana nānuppādāpi evaṃ tividhalakkhaṇā honti, atha ekuppādā evāti
analyzed: te sampayuttā ati kim pana na anuppādā api evam tividha lakkhaṇāḥ honti atha eka uppādāḥ eva ati
translated: But are they only threefold in this way when they have a single arising, or are they so when they have no arising?

original: vicāraṇāya ekuppādā eva evaṃ tividhalakkhaṇā hontīti dassanatthaṃ “ekuppādā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vicāraṇāya eka uppādāḥ eva evam tividha lakkhaṇāḥ honti iti dassana ttham eka uppādā ti vuttam
translated: The words “with a single arising” are stated in order to show that they are only threefold in this way when they have a single arising.

original: 3. Vipakkabhāvamāpannānaṃ arūpadhammānanti yathā sālibījādīnaṃ phalāni taṃsadisāni
analyzed: vipakka bhāvam āpannānam yathā sāli bīja ādīnam phalāni
translated: “Of resultant immaterial dhammas”: just as the fruits of rice, etc., are called “ripened” because they are produced similar to their seeds,

original: nibbattāni vipakkāni nāma honti, vipākaniruttiñca labhanti, na mūlaṅkurapattakhandhanāḷāni,🔽evaṃ kusalākusalānaṃ phalāni arūpadhammabhāvena sārammaṇabhāvena sukkakaṇhādibhāvena
analyzed: nibbattāni vipakkāni nāma honti vipāka niruttiñca labhanti na mūla aṅkura patta khandha nāḷāni  evam kusala akusalānam phalāni arūpa dhamma bhāvena sa ārammaṇa bhāvena sukka kaṇha ādi bhāvena
translated: and they acquire the designation “resultant,” but not the root, sprout, stalk, or leaves,

original: ca taṃsadisāni vipakkabhāvamāpannānīti vipākaniruttiṃ labhanti, na rūpadhammā kammanibbattāpi🔽kammāsadisāti dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Jātijarāsabhāvāti jāyanajīraṇasabhāvā. Vipākapakatikāti
analyzed: ca tad sadisāni vipakka bhāvam āpannāni iti vipāka niruttim labhanti na rūpa dhammā kamma nibbattā api  kamma asadisā ti dassetum vuttam jāti jarā sabhāvā ti jāyana jīraṇa sabhāvā vipāka pakatikā ati
translated: so too, the fruits of profitable and unprofitable kamma are called “ripened” and acquire the designation “resultant” because they are similar to their kamma in being immaterial dhammas, in having an object, and in being either fair or foul, but not material dhammas produced by kamma,

original: vipaccanapakatikā. Vipaccanasabhāvatā ca anupacchinnāvijjātaṇhāmānasantāne sabyāpāratā,
analyzed: vipaccana pakatikā vipaccana sabhāva tā ca an upacchinna a vijjāta ṇhā māna santāne sa byāpāra tā
translated: which are similar to kamma in being material. The words “because they have the nature of being born and ageing” are said to show that they have the nature of being born and ageing. “Have the nature of result”: have the nature of ripening. And the nature of ripening is the state of being accompanied by the unsevered continuity of ignorance, craving, and conceit.

original: tena abhiññādikusalānaṃ bhāvanāyapahātabbādiakusalānañca vipākānuppādanepi vipākadhammatā
analyzed: tena abhiññā ādi kusalānam vipāka an uppādane pi vipāka dhamma tā
translated: Therefore, even though the resultants of profitable and unprofitable kamma are not produced by the profitable and unprofitable kamma that should be abandoned by the path of seeing, etc., and by the path of development, etc., respectively, they have the nature of being dhammas that are the result of kamma.

original: siddhā hoti. Vipakkabhāvanti cettha bhāva-saddena sabhāvo eva vutto. Taṃ yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: siddhā hoti vipakka bhāvanti ca ittha bhāva saddena sabhāvaḥ eva vuttaḥ tam yathā vuttam
translated: is accomplished. And here the word “development” is said to refer to the individual essence.

original: vipakkasabhāvaṃ dutiyassa vuttaṃ vipaccanasabhāvañca gahetvā “ubhayasabhāvapaṭikkhepavasenā”ti āha.
analyzed: vipakka sabhāvam dutiyassa vuttam vipaccana sabhāvam ca gahetvā ubhaya sabhāva paṭikkhepa vasena āti āha
translated: He said “by the exclusion of the individual essence of both” because it takes the individual essence of the opposite of what has been said, which is the individual essence of the developed, and the individual essence of the opposite of the second, which is the individual essence of the undeveloped.

original: 4. Upetena ādinnā upādinnā. Kiṃ pana taṃ upetaṃ, kena ca upetaṃ, kathañca upetaṃ,
analyzed: upetena ādinnā upādinnā kim pana tam upetam kena ca upetam kathañca upetam
translated: What is clung to by what, and how is it clung to, and what is it that is clung to?

original: ke ca tena ādinnāti? Sati ca lokuttarānaṃ kesañci ārammaṇabhāve tannivattanatthaṃ🔽upetasaddasambandhinā upaya-saddena vuccamānāhi catubbidhupādānabhūtāhi taṇhādiṭṭhīhi🔽upetaṃ, tehi ca ārammaṇakaraṇavasena upetaṃ, na samannāgamavasena. Sati ca sabbatebhūmakadhammānaṃ
analyzed: ke ca tena sati ca ārammaṇa bhāve tad nivattana attham  upeta sadda sambandhinā upaya saddena vuccamānāhi catubbidha upādāna bhūtāhi taṇhā diṭṭhīhi  upetam tehi ca ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena upetam na samannāgama vasena sati ca
translated: And in order to refute the possibility of some supramundane states being objects,🔽it is said to be “clung to” by craving and views, which are the four kinds of clinging associated with the word “clung to” by the word “clinging” in the sense of “clinging to” them as objects, not in the sense of “endowment with.”🔽And in order to refute the possibility of all mundane states being objects of clinging,

original: upādānārammaṇatte yehi vipākakaṭattārūpāni amhehi nibbattattā amhākaṃ etāni phalānīti
analyzed: upādāna ārammaṇa tte yehi vipāka kaṭattā rūpāni amhehi nibbatta ttā amhākam etāni phalāni iti
translated: it is said to be “clung to” by the craving called “clinging to sense pleasures” and by the views called “clinging to views,” which are the two kinds of clinging associated with the word “clung to” by the word “clinging” in the sense of “clinging to” them as objects, not in the sense of “endowment with.”

original: gaṇhantehi viya ādinnāni, tāni tebhūmakakammāni kammabhāvena ekattaṃ upanetvā upetanti🔽idha gahitāni. Tehi ca nibbattāni vipākakaṭattārūpāni upādinnā dhammāti sabbametaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhantehi viya ādinnāni tāni tebhūmaka kammāni kamma bhāvena ekattam upanetvā upetanti  idha gahitāni tehi ca nibbattāni vipāka kaṭattā rūpāni upādinnāḥ dhammā ati sabbam etam
translated: They are “taken” as if they were taken by those who take them, and they are “brought together” by being brought together in the single state of being kamma-process,🔽and they are “included” here. And the materiality of the resultant kinds produced by them is “included” too.

original: dassetuṃ “ārammaṇakaraṇavasenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayañca atthanayo yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbo,🔽na vacanānupubbenāti. Etthāha – yadi ārammaṇakaraṇavasena taṇhādiṭṭhīhi upetena ādinnā🔽upādinnā, sabbatebhūmakadhammā ca taṇhādīnaṃ ārammaṇā honti, na ca upetasaddo kamme
analyzed: dassetum ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena atiādi vuttam ayam ca attha nayaḥ yathāsambhavam yojetabbaḥ  na vacana anupubbena āti ettha āha yadi ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena taṇhā diṭṭhīhi upetena ādinnā  upādinnā sabba tebhūmaka dhammā ca taṇhā ādīnam ārammaṇāḥ honti na ca upeta saddo kamme
translated: All this is stated in order to show that it is included in the three planes. And this method of explanation should be applied in each instance according to circumstances.🔽But it should not be done in the order in which the words are stated.

original: eva niruḷho, tena kammasseva gahaṇe kāraṇaṃ natthi, tasmā sabbatebhūmakadhammapaccayuppannānaṃ
analyzed: eva niruḷhaḥ tena kammassa iva gahaṇe kāraṇam na atthi tasmā
translated: Here it may be objected: “If what is ‘taken’ by craving and views by being ‘brought together’ through making them its object is ‘included,’ then all states in the three planes are objects of craving, etc., and the word ‘brought together’ is not restricted to kamma only. So there is no reason to take it as kamma only. Consequently it follows that formations, etc., which are the fruit of ignorance, etc., are ‘included’ because they are the states that arise with those as their condition.

original: avijjādihetūhi nibbattānaṃ saṅkhārādiphalānaṃ upādinnattaṃ āpajjati tesampi tehiphalabhāvena
analyzed: avijjā ādi hetūhi nibbattānam saṅkhāra ādi phalānam upādinna ttam āpajjati tesam pi
translated: And it follows that ignorance, etc., are ‘included’ because they are the states that arise with those as their fruit.

original: gahitattā. Upa-saddena ca upetatāmattaṃ jotitaṃ, na ārammaṇakaraṇaṃ samannāgamanivattakaṃ,
analyzed: gahita ttā upasaddena ca upeta tā mattam jotitam na ārammaṇa karaṇam samannāgama nivattakam
translated: because it is already included. And by the prefix upa- the state of being approached is indicated, not the state of being made an object, the state of being associated with, the state of being turned towards.

original: ādinna-saddena ca gahitatāmattaṃ vuttaṃ, na kammasamuṭṭhānatāviseso. Tasmā sabbapaccayuppannānaṃ🔽upādinnattaṃ āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati bodhaneyyajjhāsayavasena desanāpavattito. Yesañhi🔽bodhanatthaṃ “upādinnā”ti etaṃ vuttaṃ, te teneva vacanena yathāvuttappakāre dhamme
analyzed: ādinna saddena ca gahita tā mattam vuttam na kamma samuṭṭhāna tā viseso tasmā sabba paccaya uppannānam  upādinna ttam āpajjati iti na āpajjati bodhaneyya ajjhāsaya vasena desanā pavattitaḥ yesam hi  bodhana attham upādinnā ti etam vuttam te tena iva vacanena yathā vutta ppakāre dhamme
translated: And by the prefix ā- the state of being seized is indicated, not the state of being a special kind of kamma-originated . Therefore it is not the case that all conascent states🔽are conascent states because they are conascent with materiality.🔽Because the teaching is given according to the inclination of those to be taught. For those who are taught

original: bujjhiṃsu, etarahi pana tāvatā bujjhituṃ asakkontena sutvā tadattho veditabboti esā
analyzed: bujjhiṃsu etarahi pana tāvatā bujjhitum a sakkontena sutvā tad atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti esā
translated: by the word “conascent” understand the states of the kind already stated by that word. But now, since it is not possible to understand by that word, the meaning must be understood by hearing the explanation of the meaning.

original: atthavibhāvanā katā “kammunā”ti.🔽Ayaṃ pana aparo attho daṭṭhabbo – upa-saddo upetaṃ dīpeti. Ayañhi upa-saddo samāse
analyzed: attha vibhāvanā katā kammunā ati  ayam pana aparaḥ atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ upasaddaḥ upetam dīpeti ayam hi upasaddaḥ samāse
translated: This is the elucidation of the meaning.🔽But there is another meaning to be seen here. The prefix upa- signifies what is approached. For this prefix upa-

original: payujjamāno “atimālā”tiādīsu ati-saddo viya atikkamanaṃ sasādhanaṃ upagamanaṃ sasādhanaṃ
analyzed: payujjamānaḥ ati mālā ati ādīsu ati saddaḥ viya atikkamanam sa sādhanam upagamanam sa sādhanam
translated: when used in compounds signifies what is approached together with the means of approaching, as in ati-mala “excessive defilement” , etc., where the prefix ati- signifies what is exceeded together with the means of exceeding.

original: vadati, upagamanañca upādānaupayo, tena upagataṃ upetaṃ. Kiṃ pana tanti? Yaṃ asati
analyzed: vadati upagamanam ca tena upagatam upetam kim pana asati
translated: and the going for and the going to are the means and the object of the means, and so what is gone for and gone to is the means and the object of the means. But what is the Thread?

original: upādāne na hoti, taṃ “upādānapaccayā bhavo”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ tebhūmakakammaṃ paccayabhāvena
analyzed: upādāne na hoti tam upādāna paccayā evam vuttam tebhūmaka kammam paccaya bhāvena
translated: and the “approached” is the approaching and the approach. But what is that? It is the kamma of the three planes of existence stated thus, “With the condition of clinging, becoming,” which does not occur if there is no clinging.

original: purimajātuppannena upādānena upagatattā “upeta”nti vuccati. Na hi koci anupaggamma
analyzed: purima jātuppannena upādānena upagata ttā upetanti vuccati na hi koci an upaggamma
translated: It is called “approached” because it is approached by the clinging arisen in the previous birth. For no one does kamma without approaching it and desiring it.

original: anicchanto kammaṃ karotīti. Tena upetena kammunā punabbhavassa ādānaṃ hoti. Kammunā
analyzed: an icchantaḥ kammam karoti iti tena upetena kammunā punabbhavassa ādānam hoti kammunā
translated: With that approached kamma there is the taking up of renewed existence.

original: hi sāsavena sattā ādiyanti punabbhavaṃ, tasmā ādātabbabhāvena pākaṭo punabbhavo.
analyzed: hi sa āsavena sattāḥ ādiyanti punabbhavam tasmai ādātabba bhāvena pākaṭaḥ punabbhavaḥ
translated: For it is by kamma that beings take up renewed existence, since they are defiled by kamma. Therefore renewed existence is evident as what is to be taken up.

original: So ca upapattibhavo tebhūmakavipākakaṭattārūpasaṅgaho “bhavapaccayā jātī”ti ettha
analyzed: saḥ ca upapatti bhavo tebhūmaka vipāka kaṭattā rūpa saṅgahaḥ bhava paccayā jāti iti ettha
translated: And that renewed existence, which is included in the three planes of existence as the result of kamma and as materiality originated by kamma, is included in the word “birth” in the passage, “With becoming as condition, birth” .

original: jātivacane samavaruddhoti upādinnavacanena upapattibhavo vuccati, upapattibhavo ca
analyzed: jāti vacane samavaruddhaḥ ti upādinna vacanena upapatti bhavaḥ vuccati upapatti bhavo ca
translated: And the word “birth” includes the renewed existence that is included in the word “clinging” .🔽And the renewed existence included in the word “birth” is included in the three planes of existence as the result of kamma and as materiality originated by kamma. This is stated in the chapter on elements .

original: tebhūmakavipākakaṭattārūpānīti dhātukathāyaṃ pakāsitametaṃ. Tasmā upetena ādinnāti
analyzed: tebhūmaka vipāka kaṭattā rūpāni iti dhātu kathā ayam pakāsitam etam tasmai upetena
translated: Therefore it is said that with the approached kamma there is the taking up of renewed existence.

original: te eva dhammā vuccantīti siddho ayamatthoti. Upādinna-saddassa atthaṃ vatvā taṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: te eva dhammā vuccanti iti siddhaḥ ayam atthaḥ ti upādinna saddassa attham vatvā tam vissajjetvā
translated: Having stated the meaning of the word “subject to clinging,” he now answers the question

original: upādāniya-saddassa visuṃ upādinnasaddānapekkhaṃ atthaṃ vattuṃ “ārammaṇabhāvaṃ upagantvā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: upādāniya saddassa visum upādinna sadda anapekkham attham vattum ārammaṇa bhāvam upagantvā iti ādim āha
translated: and then, in order to state the meaning of the word “clinging” separately from the word “subject to clinging,” he says, “having become the object.”

original: Tasmā eva avisesetvā “upādānassa ārammaṇapaccayabhūtānametaṃ adhivacana”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai eva avisesetvā upādānassa ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtānam etam adhivacanan ti vuttam
translated: Therefore, without distinguishing, he says, “This is a designation for those that are a condition, by way of object condition, for clinging.”

original: Taṃ pana upādāniyaṃ upādinnaṃ anupādinnanti duvidhaṃ. Tasmā taṃ visesanena dassento
analyzed: tam pana upādāniyam upādinnam anupādinnanti duvidham tasmā tam visesanena dassento
translated: But that “subject to clinging” is twofold: subject to clinging and not subject to clinging. Therefore, in order to show that distinction,

original: “upādinnā ca te upādāniyā cā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: upādinnā ca te upādāniyā ca ati ādim āha
translated: he says, “They are subject to clinging and are also a condition for clinging.”

original: 5. Saṃkilesoti dasa kilesavatthūni vuccanti. Saṃkiliṭṭhāti tehi vibādhitā upatāpitā
analyzed: saṃkileso ti dasa kilesa vatthūni vuccanti saṃkiliṭṭhā ti tehi vibādhitā upatāpitā
translated: “Defilement” is the ten bases of defilement. “Defiled” means afflicted and oppressed by them.

original: ca. Te pana yasmā saṃkilesasampayuttā ekuppādādīhi ninnānattā ekībhāvamiva gatā visādīhi
analyzed: ca te pana yasmā saṃkilesa sampayuttāḥ eka uppāda ādīhi ninnānattāḥ ekībhāvam iva gatāḥ visa ādīhi
translated: But since they are associated with defilement, they are not different in origination, etc., and so they are as if unified, like ghee, etc., that is clarified. They are defiled, stained, afflicted, and oppressed,

original: viya sappiādayo vidūsitā malīnā vibādhitā upatāpitā ca nāma honti, tasmā āha “saṃkilesena
analyzed: sappi ādayaḥ vidūsitāḥ malīnāḥ vibādhitāḥ upatāpitāḥ ca nāma honti tasmai āha saṃkilesena
translated: therefore he says, “by defilement they are defiled.”

original: samannāgatā saṃkiliṭṭhā”ti. Saṃkilesaṃ arahantīti saṃkilesassa ārammaṇabhāvena taṃ🔽laddhuṃ arahantīti attho. Ārammaṇabhāvānatikkamanatoti etena saṃkilesānatikkamanameva
analyzed: samannāgatā saṃkiliṭṭhā ati saṃkilesam arahanti iti saṃkilesassa ārammaṇa bhāvena taṃ  laddhum arahanti iti atthaḥ ārammaṇa bhāva anatikkamanato ti etena saṃkilesa anatikkamanam eva
translated: and they are defiled when they are associated with these. The meaning is: they are fit to be the object of defilement.

original: dasseti, vatthayugikasuṅkasālikasaddānaṃ viya saṃkilesika-saddassa pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: dassa iti vattha yugika suṅka sālika saddānam viya saṃkilesika saddassa pavatti veditabbā
translated: By the words “because of the surmounting of the object” he shows the surmounting of defilement. The word “defiled” should be understood as a bahubbīhi compound, like the words “a bundle of sugar-cane” and “a bundle of reeds.”

original: 6. Saha vitakkena hontīti vacanaseso yojetabbo avuccamānassapi bhavati-atthassa viññāyamānattā.
analyzed: saha vitakkena honti iti vacana sesaḥ yojetabbaḥ a vuccamānassa api bhavati atthassa viññāyamāna ttā
translated: The words “accompanied by applied thought” should be supplied. For the meaning is understood even though it is not stated.

original: Mattāti pamāṇavācakaṃ ekaṃ padanti gahetvā “vicārova mattā etesa”nti attho vutto.🔽Aññattha avippayogīsu vitakkavicāresu vicārova etesaṃ mattā, tato uddhaṃ vitakkena
analyzed: mattā iti pamāṇa vācakam ekam padam ti gahetvā vicāraḥ uva mattā etesan ti atthaḥ vutto  aññattha a vippayogīsu vitakka vicāresu vicāraḥ u vā etesam mattā tatas uddham vitakkena
translated: Taking the word “matta” as a measure word, the meaning is stated as “the measure of these is applied thought.”

original: sampayogaṃ na gacchantīti attho. Ayamaparo attho – matta-saddo visesanivattiattho.
analyzed: sampayogam na gacchanti iti atthaḥ ayam aparaḥ atthaḥ matta saddaḥ visesa nivatti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: applied thought is the measure of these, i.e., the measure of the jhānas, because they are not associated with applied thought beyond that. Another meaning: the word “matta” is a word for a distinction.

original: Savitakkasavicārā dhammā hi vitakkavisiṭṭhena vicārena savicārā, ete pana vicāramattena
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicārāḥ dhammāḥ hi vitakka visiṭṭhena vicārena sa vicārāḥ ete pana vicāra mattena
translated: For states accompanied by applied thought are accompanied by applied thought distinguished by applied thought. But these are accompanied by the measure of applied thought.

original: vitakkasaṅkhātavisesarahitena, tasmā “vicāramattā”ti vuccanti, vicāramattavantoti🔽attho. Vicāramattavacanena avitakkatte siddhe avitakkānaṃ aññesampi atthibhāvajotanatthaṃ
analyzed: vitakka saṅkhāta visesa rahitena tasmā vicāra mattā ati vuccanti vicāra mattavantaḥ ti  atthaḥ vicāra matta vacanena avitakka tte siddhe avitakkānam aññesam pi atthi bhāva jotana attham
translated: and they are called “accompanied by sustained thought only” because they are devoid of the special quality called “applied thought.” The meaning is that they are possessed of sustained thought only.🔽The words “accompanied by sustained thought only” establish their being without applied thought. The words “without applied thought” are stated in order to show that they exist in other cases too.🔽For there are states without applied thought and accompanied by sustained thought only, and there are states without sustained thought.

original: avitakkavacanaṃ. Avitakkā hi vicāramattā ca santi avicārā cāti nivattetabbā gahetabbā
analyzed: avitakka vacanam avitakkāḥ hi vicāra mattāḥ ca santi avicārāḥ ca ati nivattetabbā gahetabbā
translated: So they would have to be either excluded or included. But if they were not mentioned, they would not be shown to be either to be excluded or to be included.

original: ca honti, tesu avuccamānesu nivattetabbagahetabbassa adassitattā vicāramattāvaavitakkāti🔽āpajjeyyāti. Visesanavisesitabbabhāvo pana yathākāmaṃ hotīti sāmaññena avitakkabhāvena
analyzed: ca honti tesu a vuccamānesu nivattetabba gahetabbassa a dassita ttā vicāra mattā ava avitakkā ati  āpajjeyya ati visesana visesitabba bhāvaḥ pana yathākāmam hoti iti sāmaññena a vitakka bhāvena
translated: So they are mentioned in order to avoid the mistake that they are accompanied by sustained thought only and without applied thought.

original: saha vicāramattatāya dhammavisesanabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “avitakkavicāramattā”ti padānukkamo kato.🔽Atha vā savicārā duvidhā savitakkā avitakkā ca, tesu avitakke nivattetuṃ ādipadaṃ
analyzed: saha vicāra matta tāya dhamma visesana bhāvam dassetum a vitakka vicāra mattā ati pada anukkamo kato  atha vā sa vicārā duvidhā sa vitakkā avitakkā ca tesu avitakke nivattetum ādi padam
translated: But the distinction of what is distinguished and what distinguishes it is as desired. So in order to show that the states distinguished by the absence of applied thought are distinguished by sustained thought only, the order of the terms is given thus: “without applied thought, accompanied by sustained thought only.”🔽Or alternatively, those accompanied by sustained thought are of two kinds, namely, with applied thought and without applied thought. In order to exclude those with applied thought, the first term is stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Avicārā ca duvidhā savitakkā avitakkā ca, tesu savitakke nivattetuṃ tatiyapadaṃ
analyzed: vuttam avicārā ca duvidhā sa vitakkā avitakkā ca tesu sa vitakke nivattetum tatiya padam
translated: And those without sustained thought are of two kinds, namely, with applied thought and without applied thought. In order to exclude those with applied thought, the third term is stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Ye pana dvīhipi nivattitā avitakkā savitakkā ca savicārā avicārā ca, tesu
analyzed: vuttam ye pana dvīhi pi nivattitāḥ avitakkā sa vitakkā ca sa vicārā avicārā ca tesu
translated: and so on. But in the case of those who have turned away from both, who are without thinking and with only the second, and who are without thinking and with only the third,

original: aññataradassanaṃ vā kattabbaṃ siyā ubhayadassanaṃ vā. Ubhayadassane kariyamāne yadi🔽“savitakkasavicārā”ti vucceyya, ādipadatthatāva āpajjati. Atha “avitakkaavicārā”ti
analyzed: aññatara dassanam vā kattabbam siyā ubhaya dassanam vā ubhaya dassane kariyamāne yadi  sa vitakka sa vicārā ati vucceyya ādi pada attha tā ava āpajjati atha avitakka avicārā ti
translated: either only one of the two should be mentioned or both should be mentioned. If only the first is mentioned,🔽then the first term is left out of count. If only the second is mentioned,

original: vucceyya, antapadatthatā. Atha pana “avitakkasavicārā savitakkaavicārā”ti vucceyya,
analyzed: vucceyya anta pada ttha tā atha pana avitakka sa vicārā sa vitakka avicārā ati vucceyya
translated: then the last term is left out of count. But if both are mentioned thus, ‘Without thinking, with only the second, with only the third,’

original: ajjhattabahiddhānaṃ viya atthantarābhāvo vā saṅkaradoso vā ekasseva savitakkāvitakkatāsavicārāvicāratāvirodho🔽vā āpajjeyya, tasmā aññataradassanena itarampi pakāsetuṃ avitakkavacanena dvippakāresu
analyzed: ajjhatta bahiddhānam viya atthantara abhāvaḥ vā saṅkara dosaḥ vā ekassa iva sa vitakka avitakka tā sa vicāra avicāra tā virodho  vā āpajjeyya tasmai aññatara dassanena itaram pi pakāsetum a vitakka vacanena dvippakāresu
translated: then either the meaning is contradictory, like ‘internal-external,’ or there is the fault of confusion, or there is the contradiction of the same being both with thinking and without thinking, with exploring and without exploring.

original: vattabbesu savitakkaavicāre nivattetvā avitakkasavicāre dassento āha “avitakkavicāramattā”ti.
analyzed: vattabbesu sa vitakka avicāre nivattetvā avitakka sa vicāre dassentaḥ āha avitakka vicāra mattā ati
translated: So in order to show the other by showing one, he said ‘without thinking and with only the second’ in order to turn aside the two that should be mentioned, namely, ‘with thinking and with exploring’ and ‘without thinking and without exploring,’ from among the four that are possible when the word ‘without thinking’ is used.

original: Atha vā vitakkābhāvena ete vicāramattā, na vicārato aññassa kassaci dhammassa abhāvāti
analyzed: atha vā vitakka abhāvena ete vicāra mattāḥ na vicārataḥ aññassa kassaci dhammassa abhāvāti
translated: Or alternatively, these are “contemplations of only happiness” because of the absence of applied thought, and because of the presence of only sustained thought, and because of the absence of any other state.

original: dassetuṃ avitakkavacanena vicāramattā visesitā.
analyzed: dassetum a vitakka vacanena vicāra mattā visesitā
translated: So they are distinguished by the words “without applied thought” in order to show this.

original: 7. Upekkhatīti vedayamānāpi majjhattavedanā sukhākāre dukkhākāre ca udāsinā hotīti
analyzed: upekkhati iti vedayamānā api majjhatta vedanā sukha ākāre dukkha ākāre ca udāsinā hoti iti
translated: “She looks on with equanimity”: the meaning is that, while experiencing, she is neutral, not reacting with disliking or liking towards the aspects of pleasure and pain.

original: attho. Atha vā upetā yuttā sukhadukkhānaṃ aviruddhā ikkhā anubhavanaṃ upekkhā. Visesadassanavasenāti🔽nānattadassanavasena. Yadi hi pītisahagatā eva sukhasahagatā siyuṃ, “pītisahagatā”ti🔽eteneva siddhattā “sukhasahagatā”ti idaṃ na vattabbaṃ siyā, “sukhasahagatā”ti vā
analyzed: atthaḥ atha vā upetā yuttā sukha dukkhānam a viruddhā ikkhā anubhavanam upekkhā visesa dassana vasena ati  nānatta dassana vasena yadi hi pīti sahagatā eva sukha sahagatā siyum pīti sahagatā ati  etena iva siddha ttā sukha sahagatā ati idam na vattabbam siyā sukha sahagatā ati vā
translated: Or alternatively, equanimity is looking on, that is, experiencing, in a way that is not opposed to pleasure and pain, that is, in a way that is not incompatible with them.

original: vuccamāne “pītisahagatā”ti na vattabbaṃ, tato tikaṃ pūrentena dukkhasahagatapadaṃ
analyzed: vuccamāne pīti sahagatā ti na vattabbam tatas tikam pūrentena dukkha sahagata padam
translated: By the method of distinguishing: by the method of showing the difference. For if they were only associated with happiness and with pleasure, then since that would be established by the words “associated with happiness,” there would be no need to say “associated with pleasure.” Or if they were associated with pleasure, then since that would be established by the words “associated with pleasure,” there would be no need to say “associated with happiness.” Then, in order to complete the triad, the words “associated with pain” would have to be stated.

original: vattabbaṃ siyā, evañca sati “vedanāttiko evāya”nti vuttavacanaṃ āpajjati, tasmā “pītisahagatā”ti
analyzed: vattabbam siyā evam ca sati vedanā attikaḥ eva āyanti vutta vacanam āpajjati tasmā pīti sahagatā ti
translated: And if that were so, then the words “It is only the feeling triad that is intended” would be contradicted. Therefore, since it is necessary to say all three, it must be admitted that they are associated with happiness, etc., too.

original: vatvā “sukhasahagatā”ti vadanto pītivippayuttampi sukhaṃ atthīti tatiyajjhānakāyaviññāṇasampayuttaṃ
analyzed: vatvā sukha sahagatā ti vadanto pīti vippayuttam pi sukham atthi iti tatiya jhāna kāya viññāṇa sampayuttam
translated: and by saying “accompanied by happiness” he shows that there is also happiness not accompanied by joy, namely, that associated with the third jhāna consciousness.

original: sukhaṃ sappītikasukhato bhinnaṃ katvā dassetīti adhippāyo. Atha vā pītisukhānaṃ dubbiññeyyanānattānaṃ
analyzed: sukham sappītika sukhataḥ bhinnam katvā dasseti iti adhippāyaḥ atha vā pīti sukhānam dubbiññeyya nānattānam
translated: His intention is that he shows that the happiness associated with the third jhāna consciousness is different from the happiness accompanied by joy. Or alternatively, this triad is stated in order to show the difference between the two kinds of happiness and joy, which are difficult to distinguish.

original: nānattadassanatthaṃ ayaṃ tiko vutto. “Pītisahagatā”ti ettha hi sukhekadeso saṅgahito,🔽na pīti. “Sukhasahagatā”ti ettha pīti saṅgahitā, na sukhaṃ. Pītivippayuttasukhasahagatā
analyzed: nānatta dassana tham ayam tikaḥ vutto pīti sahagatā ti ettha hi sukha ekadeso saṅgahito  na pīti sukha sahagatā ti ettha pīti saṅgahitā na sukham pīti vippayutta sukha sahagatā
translated: For in the phrase “accompanied by joy” a portion of happiness is included, but not joy;🔽in the phrase “accompanied by happiness” joy is included, but not happiness;

original: ca purimena asaṅgahitā pacchimena saṅgahitāti siddho pītisukhānaṃ visesoti.🔽8. Nibbānaṃ dassanatoti nibbānārammaṇataṃ sandhāyāha. Atha vā dhammacakkhu punappunaṃ
analyzed: ca purimena asaṅgahitā pacchimena saṅgahitā ati siddhaḥ pīti sukhānam visesaḥ ti  nibbānam dassanataḥ ti nibbāna ārammaṇatam sandhāya āha atha vā dhamma cakkhu punappunam
translated: and that which is accompanied by happiness but not by joy is not included in the first phrase but is included in the second. So the difference between the two kinds of happiness and joy is established.🔽Because it shows Nibbāna: he says this with reference to Nibbāna as object. Or alternatively, the “eye of Dhamma” is called “seeing” because it arises again and again, and it has not reached the state of development.

original: nibbattanena bhāvanābhāvaṃ appattaṃ dassanaṃ nāma, dhammacakkhu ca pariññādikiccakaraṇena
analyzed: nibbattanena bhāvanā bhāvam appattam dassanam nāma dhammacakkhu ca pariññā ādi kicca karaṇena
translated: And the eye of Dhamma performs the functions of full-understanding, etc.,

original: catusaccadhammadassanaṃ tadatisayo, tasmā natthettha gotrabhussa dassanabhāvāpattīti.
analyzed: catu sacca dhamma dassanam tad atisayo tasmā nattha ittha gotrabhussa dassana bhāva āpatti iti
translated: The seeing of the four noble truths is the surpassing of that, and so there is no occasion for the arrival of the state of being seen by the noble-path understanding here.

original: Ubhayapaṭikkhepavasenāti dvīhi padehi vuttadhammapaṭikkhepavasena, na pahāyakapaṭikkhepavasena.🔽Tathā hi sati dassanabhāvanāhi añño samucchedavasena pahāyako atthi, tena pahātabbā
analyzed: ubhaya paṭikkhepa vasena ati dvīhi padehi vutta dhamma paṭikkhepa vasena na pahāyaka paṭikkhepa vasena  tathā hi sati dassana bhāvanāhi aññaḥ samuccheda vasena pahāyakaḥ atthi tena pahātabbā
translated: By the rejection of both: by the rejection of the states spoken of by the two terms, not by the rejection of the abandoning.🔽For if it were so, then there would be another abandoning by cutting off apart from seeing and developing, and that would have to be admitted as something to be abandoned by seeing or by developing,

original: neva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbāti ayamattho āpajjati, na ca añño pahāyako atthi
analyzed: na iva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbā ati ayam atthaḥ āpajjati na ca aññaḥ pahāyakaḥ atthi
translated: and yet there is no other abandoning,

original: aññehi vikkhambhitānañca punappavattisabbhāvā, nāpi pahātabbā tatiyapadena saṅgayhanti,
analyzed: aññehi vikkhambhitānam ca punappavatti sabbhāvāḥ na api pahātabbā tatiya padena saṅgayhanti
translated: and what has been suppressed by others does not occur again, and so it is not included by the third term as something to be abandoned.🔽But it is not to be abandoned at all. So the term “to be abandoned” should be construed separately with each term.

original: kintu appahātabbā evāti. Tasmā pahātabbapadaṃ paccekaṃ yojetvā neva dassanena pahātabbā
analyzed: kintu appahātabbāḥ eva ati tasmā pahātabba padam paccekam yojetvā na iva dassanena pahātabbā
translated: They are not to be abandoned by seeing,

original: na bhāvanāya pahātabbāti dassanena bhāvanāya pahātabbehi aññe gahitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: na bhāvanāya pahātabbā ati dassanena bhāvanāya pahātabbehi aññe gahitā ati veditabbā
translated: they are not to be abandoned by developing. They are to be understood as being different from those to be abandoned by seeing and by developing.

original: 9. Evamatthaṃ aggahetvāti atthāyuttito ca saddāyuttito ca aggahetabbataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: evam attham aggahetvā ti attha āyuttitaḥ ca sadda āyuttitaḥ ca aggahetabba tam dasseti
translated: Without taking the meaning thus: he shows that it should not be taken either according to the meaning or according to the letter.

original: Dassanabhāvanāhi appahātabbahetumattesu hi gayhamānesu ahetukā asaṅgahitāti yathādhippetassa🔽atthassa aparipuṇṇattā atthāyutti, pahātabbasaddassa niccasāpekkhatte ca sati na
analyzed: dassana bhāvanāhi appahātabba hetumattesu hi gayhamānesu ahetukā asaṅgahitā ati yathā adhippetassa  atthassa a paripuṇṇa ttā pahātabba saddassa ca sati na
translated: For if only the causes to be abandoned by seeing and by cultivation are taken, then the word “without cause” is not included, and so🔽the meaning intended is not complete. And if the word “to be abandoned” is taken as requiring a constant complement, then the compound

original: sambandhīsaddato pahāyakato aññaṃ paṭisedhaṃ apekkhamānassa hetusaddena samāso upapajjatīti
analyzed: sambandhī saddataḥ pahāyakato aññam paṭisedham apekkhamānassa hetu saddena samāsaḥ upapajjati iti
translated: cannot be made with the word “cause,” since it requires a negative complement other than the complement of the word “to be abandoned.”

original: saddāyutti ca veditabbā. Evamattho gahetabboti pahātabba-saddaṃ paṭisedhena ayojetvā
analyzed: ca veditabbā evam atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ iti pahātabba saddam paṭisedhena a yojetvā
translated: So the verbal expression should be understood as a verbal expression of meaning. The meaning should be taken thus: the word “to be abandoned” is construed with the negative,

original: yesaṃ aññapadatthe samāso, tabbisesanaṃ atthīti idaṃ paṭisedhena yojetvā dassanabhāvanāhi🔽pahātabbo hetu etesaṃ nevatthīti attho gahetabboti vuttaṃ hoti. Evañca sati yathādhippetattho
analyzed: yesam añña padatthe samāsaḥ tad visesanam atthi iti idam paṭisedhena yojetvā dassana bhāvanāhi  pahātabbaḥ hetu etesam na iva atthi iti atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ iti vuttam hoti evam ca sati yathā adhippeta tthaḥ
translated: and then the compound is resolved into its components in the form “those that have no cause to be abandoned by seeing and by cultivation.”🔽The meaning is that there is no such cause. And when this is so, then the whole of the intended meaning is included,

original: sabbo saṅgahitoti. Atthāyutti mā hotu, saddo pana idhāpi na yutto. Ekantayogīnaṃ
analyzed: sabbo saṅgahito ti attha ayutti mā hotu saddo pana idha api na yuttaḥ ekanta yogīnam
translated: so let there be no verbal expression of meaning. But the verbal expression is not appropriate here either. For the compound is appropriate

original: atthi-saddameva hi apekkhamānānaṃ ubhinnaṃ pahātabbahetu-saddānaṃ samāso yutto, na
analyzed: atthi saddam eva hi apekkhamānānam ubhinnam pahātabba hetu saddānam samāsaḥ yuttaḥ na
translated: only for those who require the word “there is” as a constant complement, not for those who require a negative complement.

original: paṭisedhaṃ apekkhamānānanti, tasmā gahetabbatthadassanamattaṃ etaṃ kataṃ, saddo pana🔽yathā yujjati, tathā yojetabbo. Evaṃ pana yujjati – pahātabbo hetu etesaṃ atthīti🔽pahātabbahetukā. Kena pahātabboti? Dassanena bhāvanāya ca. Tayidaṃ pahātabbahetukapadaṃ
analyzed: paṭisedham tasmā gahetabba attha dassana mattam etam katam saddaḥ pana  yathā yujjati tathā yojetabbaḥ evam pana yujjati pahātabbaḥ hetu etesam atthi iti  pahātabba hetukā kena pahātabbā uti dassanena bhāvanāya ca tayā idam pahātabba hetuka padam
translated: So this is merely a statement of the meaning to be taken. But the word🔽can be construed as follows: they have a cause to be abandoned,🔽therefore they are “with a cause to be abandoned.” By what are they to be abandoned? By seeing and by developing. So this phrase “with a cause to be abandoned”

original: dassanabhāvanāpadehi visuṃ visuṃ yojetvā tehi yuttena ye dassanena pahātabbahetukā🔽neva honti, bhāvanāya pahātabbahetukā ca na hontīti paṭisedhañca visuṃ visuṃ yojetvā
analyzed: dassana bhāvanā padehi visum visum yojetvā tehi yuttena ye dassanena pahātabba hetukā  na iva honti bhāvanāya pahātabba hetukā ca na honti iti paṭisedham ca visum visum yojetvā
translated: is construed separately with the phrases “by seeing” and “by developing.”

original: te neva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbahetukāti vuccanti. Nevavipākanavipākadhammadhammavacanaṃ
analyzed: te na iva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabba hetukā ati vuccanti na iva vipāka na vipāka dhamma dhamma vacanam
translated: Those that are not to be abandoned by seeing and are not to be abandoned by developing are called “not with a cause to be abandoned by seeing and not with a cause to be abandoned by developing.”

original: viya hi purimapadadvayasaṅgahitadhammapaṭisedhanena tadaññadhammanidassanametaṃ hoti,
analyzed: viya hi purima pada dvaya saṅgahita dhamma paṭisedhanena tad añña dhamma nidassanam etam hoti
translated: For this is a statement of other dhammas by way of the denial of dhammas included in the first two phrases, like the statement “not an outcome, not having an outcome as its essence,”🔽not a statement of the absence of a cause like the phrase “without a cause.” And when it is construed in this way,

original: na ahetukapadaṃ viya hetuvirahappakāsanenāti. Evañca katvā dve paṭisedhā yuttā honti.
analyzed: na ahetuka padam viya hetu viraha ppakāsanena ati evam ca katvā dve paṭisedhāḥ yuttāḥ honti
translated: the two denials are appropriate.

original: Hetuyeva hi tesaṃ natthi, yo dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbo siyāti purimasmiñhi atthe
analyzed: hetuyā iva hi tesam na atthi yaḥ dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbaḥ siyāti purimasmin hi atthe
translated: For they have no cause that could be abandoned by means of seeing and development. For in the first case

original: hetūnaṃ dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbatā paṭikkhittā, paṭikkhepo ca pahātabbāsaṅkāsabbhāve
analyzed: hetūnam dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabba tā paṭikkhittā paṭikkhepaḥ ca pahātabba asaṅka asabbhāve
translated: the abandoning of causes by means of seeing and development is denied. And the denial is of the possibility of their being abandoned.

original: hoti, pahātabbāsaṅkā ca hetumhi sati siyā, tesaṃ pana ahetukānaṃ hetuyeva natthi,🔽yo dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbo siyā, tadabhāvā pahātabbāsaṅkā natthīti taṃnivāraṇattho🔽paṭikkhepo na sambhavati, tasmā “nevadassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbo hetu etesa”nti
analyzed: hoti pahātabba āsaṅkā ca hetumhi sati siyā tesam pana ahetukānam hetuyā iva natthi  yaḥ dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbaḥ siyā tad abhāvā pahātabba āsaṅkā natthi iti tad nivāraṇa attho  paṭikkhepaḥ na sambhavati tasmā na iva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbaḥ hetu etesan ti
translated: And the possibility of their being abandoned is only if there is a cause. But these have no cause at all🔽that could be abandoned by means of seeing and development.🔽And because there is no such cause, there is no possibility of their being abandoned. So the denial🔽is not possible in the sense of the exclusion of that possibility. Therefore the meaning is that the words “They have no cause that can be abandoned by means of seeing or development”

original: evaṃ ahetukānaṃ gahaṇaṃ na bhaveyyāti attho. Atha vā itarathā hi ahetukānaṃ aggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: evam ahetukānam gahaṇam na bhaveyya ati atthaḥ atha vā itarathā hi ahetukānam aggahaṇam
translated: would not include the rootless. Or alternatively, the meaning is that otherwise, if the words were taken in the first way, the rootless would not be included.

original: bhaveyyāti atthassa pākaṭattā na kāraṇasādhanīyo esoti gahetabbatthasseva kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhaveyya ti atthassa pākaṭa ttā na kāraṇa sādhanīyaḥ esaḥ ti gahetabba atthassa iva kāraṇam
translated: And since the meaning is clear, the reason need not be stated. So the reason is given by one who wants to include the rootless,🔽saying, “For they have no cause at all.”

original: vadanto “hetuyeva hi tesaṃ natthī”tiādimāha. Tesañhi nevadassanena na bhāvanāyapahātabbahetukapadavacanīyānaṃ
analyzed: vadantaḥ hetuyā iva hi tesam natthi iti ādim āha tesam hi na iva dassanena na
translated: For the words “They have no cause that can be abandoned by means of seeing or development”

original: yo dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbo siyā, so evaṃpakāro hetu natthi. Te hi anekappakārā
analyzed: yaḥ dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbaḥ siyā saḥ evaṃpakāraḥ hetu natthi te hi aneka ppakārā
translated: There is no such cause to be abandoned by means of seeing and development. For they are of many kinds🔽as having a cause and as having no cause. Therefore the meaning to be understood is this:

original: sahetukā ahetukā cāti, tasmā nevadassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbo hetu etesaṃ atthīti🔽ayamattho gahetabboti attho.🔽10. Taṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvāti idaṃ catukiccasādhanavasena ārammaṇakaraṇaṃ sandhāya vuttanti
analyzed: sa hetukā ahetukā ca ati tasmā na iva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbaḥ hetu etesam atthi iti  ayam attho gahetabbaḥ ti atthaḥ  tam ārammaṇam katvā iti idam catu kicca sādhana vasena ārammaṇa karaṇam sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: ‘They have no cause to be abandoned by means of seeing and development.’

original: veditabbaṃ. Aññathā gotrabhuphalapaccavekkhaṇādīnampi apacayagāmitā āpajjeyyāti.
analyzed: veditabbam aññathā gotra bhu phala paccavekkhaṇa ādīnam pi apacaya gāmi tā āpajjeyya iti
translated: ‘Taking that as object’: this should be understood as referring to the taking of it as object in the way already stated, that is, by accomplishing the fourfold task. Otherwise the state of change-of-lineage, fruition attainment, reviewing of Nibbāna, and so on, would also become subject to diminution.

original: Atha vā hetubhāvena apacayaṃ nibbānaṃ gacchantīti apacayagāmino. Nibbānassa hi anibbattaniyattepi
analyzed: atha vā hetu bhāvena apacayam nibbānam gacchanti iti apacaya gāminaḥ nibbānassa hi a nibbatta niyatte pi
translated: Or alternatively, they go to Nibbāna, which is diminution, by means of a cause, thus they are subject to diminution ;

original: samudayappahānasamudayanirodhānaṃ adhigamaadhigantabbabhāvato hetuhetuphalabhāvo
analyzed: samudaya ppahāna samudaya nirodhānam adhigama adhigantabba bhāvataḥ hetu hetu phala bhāvaḥ
translated: for although Nibbāna is not subject to production, still the state of being a cause and the state of being a result are appropriate to the path and Nibbāna respectively in the sense of what is reached and what reaches,

original: magganibbānānaṃ yujjati. Yathāha “dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā
analyzed: magga nibbānānam yujjati yathā āha dukkha nirodhe ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā dukkha nirodha gāminiyā
translated: as is said: ‘Knowledge of the cessation of suffering is the discrimination of meaning. The path leading to the cessation of suffering is the discrimination of language’ .

original: paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti. Atthoti hi hetuphalaṃ. Dhammoti hetūti. Purimapacchimānaṃ
analyzed: paṭipadāya ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā ti atthaḥ iti hi hetu phalam dhammaḥ iti hetu uti purima pacchimānam
translated: Knowledge of the way is the discrimination of language. “Meaning” is cause and fruit. “Language” is cause.

original: purime sasampayuttā vuttā, pacchime kevalā. Purime viya pana pacchime atthepi ariyamaggasīsena🔽sabbalokuttarakusalacittuppādā gahetabbā. Dutiye atthavikappe “ācayaṃ gāmino”ti vattabbe🔽anunāsikalopo katoti daṭṭhabbo. Ācinantīti vā ācayā, ācayā hutvā gacchanti pavattantītipi attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽11. Satta pana sekkhā sikkhanasīlāti sekkhā, tesaṃ imeti sekkhā, aññāsādhāraṇā maggaphalattayadhammā.
analyzed: purime sa sampayuttā vuttā pacchime kevalā purime viya pana pacchime atthe pi ariya magga sīsena  sabba lokuttara kusala cittuppādāḥ gahetabbāḥ dutiye attha vikappe ācayam gāminaḥ ti vattabbe  anunāsika lopo kato ti daṭṭhabbo ācinanti iti vā ācayāḥ ācayāḥ hutvā gacchanti pavattanti iti pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  satta pana sekkhā sikkhana sīlā ati sekkhā tesam ime ti sekkhāḥ añña asādhāraṇāḥ magga phala ttaya dhammā
translated: The first is stated with its associated states, the second by itself. But in the second, as in the first, the meaning is the noble path.

original: Sayameva sikkhantīti sikkhanasīlānametaṃ nidassanaṃ. Ye hi dhammā sikkhanti, te sikkhanasīlā🔽hontīti. Akkharattho pana sikkhā etesaṃ sīlanti sekkhāti. Na sekkhāti yattha sekkhabhāvāsaṅkā
analyzed: sayam eva sikkhanti iti sikkhana sīlānam etam nidassanam ye hi dhammā sikkhanti te sikkhana sīlā 🔽honti iti akkhara atthaḥ pana sikkhā etesam sīlanti sekkhā ati na sekkhā ati yattha sekkha bhāva āsaṅkā
translated: The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path. The meaning is the noble path.

original: atthi, tatthāyaṃ paṭisedhoti lokiyanibbānesu asekkhabhāvānāpatti daṭṭhabbā. Sīlasamādhipaññāsaṅkhātā
analyzed: atthi tattha ayam paṭisedhaḥ ti lokiya nibbānesu asekkha bhāva anāpatti daṭṭhabbā sīla samādhi paññā saṅkhātā
translated: “There is, and this is the denial of it”: the non-occurrence of the state of a learner in the mundane and supramundane cessations should be regarded as the denial of it.

original: hi sikkhā attano paṭipakkhakilesehi vippamuttā parisuddhā upakkilesānaṃ ārammaṇabhāvampi
analyzed: hi sikkhā attanaḥ paṭipakkha kilesehi vippamuttā parisuddhā upakkilesānam ārammaṇa bhāvam pi
translated: For the training consisting of virtue, concentration, and understanding,🔽which is purified from the defilements that are its opposites, is fit to be called “training” since it does not even take as its object the secondary defilements that are its associates.

original: anupagamanato etā sikkhāti vattuṃ yuttā aṭṭhasu maggaphalesu vijjanti, tasmā catumaggaheṭṭhimaphalattayadhammā🔽viya arahattaphaladhammāpi tāsu sikkhāsu jātāti ca, taṃsikkhāsamaṅgino arahato itaresaṃ
analyzed: an upagamanataḥ etā sikkhā ati vattum yuttāḥ aṭṭhasu magga phalesu vijjanti tasmā catu magga heṭṭhima phala ttaya dhammā  viya arahatta phala dhammā api tāsu sikkhāsu jātā ati ca tad sikkhā samaṅginaḥ arahataḥ itaresam
translated: It exists in the eight paths and fruits. Therefore, like the three states of the fourth path and the last fruit,🔽the states of the Arahant fruit are born in the training. And because the states of the training exist in the Arahant who possesses the training,

original: viya sekkhatte sati sekkhassa eteti ca, sikkhā sīlaṃ etesanti ca sekkhāti āsaṅkitabbā
analyzed: viya sekkhatte sati sekkhassa ete iti ca sikkhā sīlam etesan ti ca sekkhā ati āsaṅkitabbā
translated: as they do not in others, and because the training is virtue in them, they are called “learners.”

original: siyunti tadāsaṅkānivattanatthaṃ “asekkhā”ti yathāvuttasekkhabhāvapaṭisedho kato.
analyzed: siyum ti tad āsaṅkā nivattana attham asekkhā ti yathāvutta sekkha bhāva paṭisedho kato
translated: They should be understood as such. But in order to deny the state of a learner as stated, the words “who are not learners” are used,

original: Arahattaphale hi pavattamānā sikkhā pariniṭṭhitasikkhākiccattā na sikkhākiccaṃ karonti,
analyzed: arahatta phale hi pavattamānā sikkhā pariniṭṭhita sikkhā kicca ttā na sikkhā kiccam karonti
translated: for the training that occurs in the Arahant fruit does not perform the function of training because the function of training is completed.

original: kevalaṃ sikkhāphalabhāveneva pavattanti, tasmā tā na sikkhāvacanaṃ arahanti, nāpi
analyzed: kevalam sikkhā phala bhāvena iva pavattanti tasmā tāḥ na sikkhā vacanam arahanti na api
translated: They occur only as fruits of training. Therefore they do not merit the name of training.

original: taṃsamaṅgino sekkhavacanaṃ, na ca taṃsampayuttā sikkhanasīlāti sikkhāsu jātātiādiatthehi
analyzed: tad samaṅginaḥ sekkha vacanam na ca tad sampayuttā sikkhana sīlā ati sikkhāsu jātā ati ādi atthehi
translated: Nor do those who possess them merit the name of “in training” . And the virtue associated with them is not the virtue of training. So the states of the jhānas, etc., are not “in training” in the sense of being born in the training, and so on.

original: aggaphaladhammā sekkhā na honti, heṭṭhimaphalesu pana sikkhā sakadāgāmimaggavipassanādīnaṃ
analyzed: agga phala dhammā sekkhāḥ na honti heṭṭhima phalesu pana sikkhā sakadāgāmi magga vipassanā ādīnam
translated: But they are “in training” in the sense of being the highest fruit of training. But the training in the lower fruits, such as the path of once-return, etc.,

original: upanissayabhāvato sikkhākiccaṃ karontīti sikkhāvacanaṃ arahanti, taṃsamaṅgino ca
analyzed: upanissaya bhāvataḥ sikkhā kiccam karonti iti sikkhā vacanam arahanti tad samaṅgino ca
translated: performs the function of training by being a condition for insight. So it merits the name of training. And those who possess it merit the name of “in training” .

original: sekkhavacanaṃ, taṃsampayuttā ca sikkhanasīlavuttīti tattha dhammā yathāvuttehi atthehi sekkhā honti eva.🔽Sekkhāti vā apariyositasikkhā dassitā. Anantarameva “asekkhā”ti vacanaṃ pariyositasikkhānaṃ
