analyzed: sekkha vacanam tad sampayuttā ca sikkhana sīla vutti iti tattha dhammā yathā vuttehi atthehi sekkhāḥ honti eva  sekkhā ati vā a pariyosita sikkhā dassitā anantaram eva asekkhā iti vacanam pariyosita sikkhānam
translated: And the virtue associated with it is called the virtue of training. So the states of the jhānas, etc., are “in training” in the senses stated.🔽Or “in training” shows that the training is not finished. And the next word “finished” shows that the training is finished.

original: dassananti na lokiyanibbānānaṃ asekkhatāpatti. Vuddhippattā vā sekkhāti etasmiṃ atthe
analyzed: dassananti na lokiya nibbānānam asekkha tā āpatti vuddhi pattā vā sekkhā ti etasmin atthe
translated: So the supramundane jhānas, etc., do not become “finished” in the sense of the mundane jhānas, etc., and of Nibbāna.

original: sekkhadhammesu eva kesañci vuddhippattānaṃ asekkhatā āpajjati, tena arahattamaggadhammā
analyzed: sekkha dhammesu eva kesañci vuddhi ppattānam asekkha tā āpajjati tena arahatta magga dhammā
translated: and some who have reached growth in the states of a learner attain the state of a non-learner, therefore the states of the path to arahatship are called the “states of growth”.🔽

original: vuddhippattā ca yathāvuttehi ca atthehi sekkhāti katvā asekkhā āpannāti? Na, taṃsadisesu
analyzed: vuddhi pattā ca yathāvuttehi ca atthehi sekkhā ati katvā asekkhā āpannā ati na tad sadisesu
translated: But in the case of some who have reached fulfilment in the states of those still subject to training, the state of those no longer subject to training is entered upon. So is it because those states of the path to arahatship have reached fulfilment that they are called those no longer subject to training because they have entered upon the state of arahatship?🔽No, because they are similar to those that are.

original: tabbohārā. Arahattamaggato hi ninnānākaraṇaṃ arahattaphalaṃ ṭhapetvā pariññādikiccakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tad bohārāḥ arahatta maggataḥ hi ninnānākaraṇam arahatta phalam ṭhapetvā pariññā ādi kicca karaṇam
translated: For the fruition of arahatship has no distinction from the path to arahatship except for the fact that it is the result of that path and that it is the state of one who has done what had to be done.

original: vipākabhāvañca, tasmā te eva sekkhā dhammā arahattaphalabhāvaṃ āpannāti sakkā vattuṃ,
analyzed: vipāka bhāvam ca tasmā te eva sekkhāḥ dhammāḥ arahatta phala bhāvam āpannāḥ ati sakkā vattum
translated: So it may be said that those states of those still subject to training have reached fulfilment in the state of fruition of arahatship.

original: kusalasukhato ca vipākasukhaṃ santataratāya paṇītataranti vuddhippattā ca te dhammā
analyzed: kusala sukhataḥ ca vipāka sukham santataratāya paṇītataranti vuddhi pattā ca te dhammā
translated: And because the pleasure of fruition is more tranquil and more sublime than the pleasure of profitable action, they have reached fulfilment in pleasure.

original: hontīti asekkhāti vuccantīti.
analyzed: honti iti asekkhā ati vuccanti iti
translated: So they are called those no longer subject to training.🔽They are limited because they are not capable of suppressing defilements, etc.,

original: 12. Kilesavikkhambhanāsamatthatādīhi parittā. “Kilesa…pe… tāyā”ti atthattayampi kusalesu
translated: The three meanings beginning with “because of the suppression of defilements” apply to the profitable only,🔽but the long continuity applies to the resultant and the functional.

original: yujjati, vipākakiriyesu dīghasantānatāva. Pamāṇakarehi vā oḷārikehi kāmataṇhādīhi
analyzed: vipāka kiriyesu pamāṇa karehi vā oḷārikehi kāma taṇhā ādīhi
translated: Or alternatively, they are limited because of the limitedness of the defilements that they suppress, which are gross greed, hatred, and delusion, and so on.

original: paricchinnā parittā. Tehi aparicchinnattā sukhumehi rūpataṇhādīhi paricchinnā pamāṇamahattaṃ
analyzed: paricchinnā parittā tehi aparicchinna ttā sukhumehi rūpa taṇhā ādīhi paricchinnā pamāṇa mahattaṃ
translated: They are limited because they are limited by the craving for materiality, etc., which is subtle and not limited.🔽They are exalted because they have gone to the greatness of measurelessness.

original: gatāti mahaggatā. Aparicchinnā appamāṇā.
analyzed: gatā ati mahaggatā aparicchinnā appamāṇā
translated: They are immeasurable because they are not limited.

original: 14. Atappakaṭṭhenāti divasampi paccavekkhiyamānā lokuttaradhammā tittiṃ na janenti samāpajjiyamānāpi phaladhammāti.
analyzed: a tappakaṭṭhena ati divasam pi paccavekkhiyamānāḥ lokuttara dhammā tittim na janenti samāpajjiyamānā api phala dhammā ti
translated: They are called “not to be fathomed” because even if one were to reflect on supramundane states for a whole day, one would not reach their end and be satisfied.

original: 15. Mātughātādīsu pavattamānāpi hitasukhaṃ icchantāva pavattantīti te dhammā hitasukhāvahā🔽me bhavissantīti āsīsitā honti, tathā asubhāsukhāniccānattesu subhādivipariyāsadaḷhatāya🔽ānantariyakammaniyatamicchādiṭṭhīsu pavatti hotīti te dhammā asubhādīsu subhādiviparītappavattikā🔽honti. Micchāsabhāvāti musāsabhāvā. Anekesu ānantariyesu katesu yaṃ tattha balavaṃ,
analyzed: mātughāta ādīsu pavattamānā api hita sukham icchantā ava pavattanti iti te dhammā hita sukha āvahā  me bhavissanti iti āsīsitāḥ honti tathā asubha asukha anicca ānattesu subha ādi vipariyāsa daḷha tāya  ānantariya kamma niyatam icchā diṭṭhīsu pavatti hoti iti te dhammā asubha ādīsu subha ādi viparīta ppavattikā  honti micchā sabhāvā ati musā sabhāvā anekesu ānantariyesu katesu yam tattha balavam
translated: They are called “conducive to welfare and happiness” because they occur wishing for welfare and happiness even when they occur in such states as the killing of one’s mother.🔽They are called “conducive to the perception of what is undesirable” because they occur in the opposite way to the perception of what is desirable, etc., in such states as foulness, pain, impermanence, and not-self.🔽They are called “conducive to the perception of what is contrary” because they occur in the opposite way to the perception of what is not contrary, etc., in such states as the immediate action, the fixed action, and wrong view.🔽They are called “conducive to the perception of what is otherwise” because they occur in the opposite way to the perception of what is not otherwise, etc., in such states as a lie.

original: taṃ vipaccati, na itarānīti ekantavipākajanakatāya niyatatā na sakkā vattunti “vipākadāne
analyzed: tam vipaccati na itarāni iti ekanta vipāka janaka tāya niyata tā na sakkā vattunti vipāka dāne
translated: When many immediate actions have been done, the strongest ripens first, not the others. Therefore it cannot be said that they are fixed in the sense of always producing their results.

original: satī”tiādimāha. Tattha khandhabhedānantaranti cutianantaraṃ. Cuti hi maraṇaniddese🔽“khandhānaṃ bhedo”ti vuttāti. Etena vacanena sati phaladāne cutianantaro eva, na🔽añño etesaṃ phalakāloti phalakālaniyameneva niyatatā vuttā hoti, na phaladānaniyamenāti
analyzed: sati itiādim āha tattha cuti anantaram hi maraṇa niddese  khandhānam bhedo ti vuttā ati etena vacanena sati phala dāne cuti anantaraḥ eva na  aññaḥ etesam phala kālo ti phala kāla niyamena iva niyata tā vuttā hoti na phala dāna niyamena ati
translated: Herein, immediately after the breakup of the aggregates is immediately after death. For death is called “the breakup of the aggregates” in the description of death in the way beginning, “With the breakup of the body, after death” .🔽So by this statement it is shown that their certainty is only in the time of the fruit’s ripening, not in the giving of the fruit, since the time of the fruit’s ripening is certain, not the giving of the fruit.

original: niyataphalakālānaṃ aññesampi upapajjavedanīyānaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyānampi niyatatā
analyzed: niyata phala kālānam aññesam pi upapajja vedanīyānam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyānam pi niyata tā
translated: So it follows that the certainty of those that are certain in the time of the fruit’s ripening, whether they are due to ripen in the next existence or in some subsequent existence, is not due to the certainty of the giving of the fruit.

original: āpajjati, tasmā vipākadhammadhammānaṃ paccayantaravikalatādīhi avipaccamānānampi🔽attano sabhāvena vipākadhammatā viya balavatā ānantariyena vipāke dinne avipaccamānānampi🔽ānantariyānaṃ phaladāne niyatasabhāvā ānantariyasabhāvā ca pavattīti attano sabhāvena
analyzed: āpajjati tasmā vipāka dhamma dhammānam paccaya antara vikala tā ādīhi a vipaccamānānam pi  attano sabhāvena vipāka dhamma tā viya balavatā ānantariyena vipāke dinne a vipaccamānānam pi  phala dāne niyata sabhāvā ānantariya sabhāvā ca pavatti iti sabhāvena
translated: Therefore, although results of unprofitable kamma that are states subject to the conditions of ripening do not ripen owing to deficiency in the conditions, etc.,🔽when the fruit is given by the powerful immediately-arising result of the heinous kamma, then the certainty of the giving of the fruit of the heinous kamma, whether or not it is ripening,🔽is due to its own individual essence, and the certainty of the heinous kamma is due to its own individual essence.

original: phaladānaniyameneva niyatatā ānantariyatā ca veditabbā. Avassañca niyatasabhāvā ānantariyasabhāvā
analyzed: phala dāna niyamena iva niyata tā ānantariya tā ca veditabbā avassan ca niyata sabhāvā ānantariya sabhāvā
translated: So the certainty and the heinous nature should be understood as due only to the certainty of the giving of the fruit. And the certainty of the giving of the fruit is due to the heinous nature.

original: ca tesaṃ pavattīti sampaṭicchitabbametaṃ aññassa balavato ānantariyassa abhāve cutianantaraṃ
analyzed: ca tesam pavatti iti sampaṭicchitabbam etam aññassa balavataḥ ānantariyassa abhāve cuti anantaram
translated: and it is to be admitted that they occur in this way, since there is no other strong action that would cause rebirth to take place immediately after death

original: ekantena phaladānato.🔽Nanu evaṃ aññesampi upapajjavedanīyānaṃ aññasmiṃ vipākadāyake asati cutianantarameva
analyzed: eka antena phala dānataḥ  nanu evam aññesam pi upapajja vedanīyānam aññasmin vipāka dāyake asati cuti anantaram eva
translated: because they necessarily give their result in the next existence.🔽But in the same way, do not other kamma-resultants that are to be experienced in some future existence also necessarily give their result in the next existence if there is no other kamma to give its result in the next existence,

original: ekantena phaladānato ānantariyasabhāvā niyatasabhāvā ca pavatti āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati🔽asamānajātikena cetopaṇidhivasena upaghātakena ca nivattetabbavipākattā anantarekantaphaladāyakattābhāvā,
analyzed: ekantena phala dānataḥ ānantariya sabhāvā niyata sabhāvā ca pavatti āpajjati iti na āpajjati  asamāna jātikena cetaḥ upaṇidhi vasena upaghātakena ca nivattetabba vipāka ttā anantara ekanta phala dāyaka ttā abhāvā
translated: and so do they not also come to have the nature of being next-after-death and the nature of being fixed? They do not,🔽because their result can be averted by kamma of a different kind, namely, by kamma that is a source of danger, and because they do not necessarily give their result in the next existence.

original: na pana ānantariyakānaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ dutiyajjhānādīni viya asamānajātikaṃ phalanivattakaṃ
analyzed: na pana ānantariyakānam paṭhama jhāna ādīnam dutiya jhāna ādīni viya asamāna jātikam phala nivattakam
translated: But there is no result of the kinds of kamma called “next-after-death” that can avert the result of the kinds called “next-after-death” as there is, for instance, a result of the kinds called “next-after-death” that can avert the result of the kinds called “in the next birth” and “in some subsequent birth.”

original: atthi sabbānantariyakānaṃ avīciphalattā, na ca heṭṭhupapattiṃ icchato sīlavato cetopaṇidhi🔽viya uparūpapattijanakakammaphalaṃ ānantariyakaphalaṃ nivattetuṃ samattho cetopaṇidhi
analyzed: atthi sabba ānantariyakānam avīci phala ttā na ca heṭṭhupapattim icchataḥ sīlavataḥ cetaḥ paṇidhi 🔽viya upara upapatti janaka kamma phalam ānantariyaka phalam nivattetum samatthaḥ cetas upaṇidhi
translated: And there is no resolve that can avert the result of the kinds of kamma called “next-after-death” as there is, for instance, a resolve that can avert the result of kamma that will cause rebirth in a lower world when one who is virtuous makes a resolve.

original: atthi anicchantasseva avīcipātanato, na ca ānantariyakopaghātakaṃ kiñci kammaṃ atthi,
analyzed: atthi an icchantassa iva avīci pātanataḥ na ca ānantariyaka upaghātakam kiñci kammaṃ atthi
translated: because there is no action that destroys the immediate,

original: tasmā tesaṃyeva anantarekantavipākajanakasabhāvā pavattīti.
analyzed: tasmā tesam yā iva anantara ekanta vipāka janaka sabhāvā pavatti iti
translated: so they occur with the nature of producing the next existence that is only the immediate’s result.

original: Anekāni ca ānantariyakāni katāni ekante vipāke sanniyatattā uparatāvipaccanasabhāvāsaṅkattā
analyzed: anekāni ca ānantariyakāni katāni ekante vipāke sanniyata ttā
translated: And many actions that are immediate are stopped because they are fixed to give only the immediate’s result. They are not accumulated because they have no nature of ripening.

original: nicchitāni sabhāvato niyatāneva. Cutianantaraṃ pana phalaṃ anantaraṃ nāma tasmiṃ
analyzed: nicchitāni sabhāvataḥ phalam anantaram nāma tasmin
translated: They are definitely only of the nature of the immediate. But the fruit that is next to the action is called “immediate” .

original: anantare niyuttāni tannibbattanena anantarakaraṇasīlāni anantarappayojanāni cāti🔽sabhāvato ānantariyakāneva ca honti. Tesu pana samānasabhāvesu ekena vipāke dinne
analyzed: anantare niyuttāni tad nibbattanena anantara karaṇa sīlāni anantara ppayojanāni ca ati  sabhāvataḥ ca honti tesu pana samāna sabhāvesu ekena vipāke dinne
translated: They are fixed to that immediate , and they have the nature of causing the immediate by producing it, and they have the immediate as their purpose.

original: itarāni attanā kattabbassa kiccassa teneva katattā na dutiyaṃ tatiyampi ca paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: itarāni attanā kattabbassa kiccassa tena iva kata ttā na dutiyam tatiyam pi ca paṭisandhim
translated: So they are only of the nature of the immediate. But when one of them has given its result, the others do not make a second or a third rebirth, because what they have to do has been done by that one.

original: karonti, na samatthatāvighātattāti natthi tesaṃ niyatānantariyatānivattīti. Na hi
analyzed: karonti na na samattha tā vighāta ttā ati natthi tesam niyata anantariya tā nivattī iti na hi
translated: They do not obstruct the completion. So there is no turning back of their fixedness as immediate.

original: samānasabhāvaṃ samānasabhāvassa samatthataṃ vihanatīti. Ekassa pana aññānipi upatthambhakāni
analyzed: samāna sabhāvam samāna sabhāvassa samattha tam vihanati iti ekassa pana aññāni pi upatthambhakāni
translated: and the state of being of the same kind as that of the other is the conditionality of the state of being of the same kind. But it should be regarded as the support of the other’s too.

original: hontīti daṭṭhabbānīti. Sammā sabhāvāti saccasabhāvā.
analyzed: honti iti daṭṭhabbāni iti sammā sabhāvā ati sacca sabhāvā
translated: The state of being of the same kind as that of the other is the state of being of the truth.🔽The four noble paths are called “paths” here because they have fulfilled their function as paths.

original: 16. Paripuṇṇamaggakiccattā cattāro ariyamaggāva idha “maggā”ti vuttā. Paccayaṭṭhenāti🔽maggapaccayaṭṭhena. Nikkhepakaṇḍepi hi ye maggapaccayaṃ labhanti, na pana sayaṃ maggapaccayabhāvaṃ
analyzed: paripuṇṇa magga kicca ttā cattāro ariya maggā va idha maggā ti vuttā paccaya ṭṭhena ati  magga paccaya ṭṭhena nikkhepa kaṇḍe pi hi ye magga paccayam labhanti na pana sayam magga paccaya bhāvam
translated: As conditions: because they are conditions for the path.

original: gacchanti, te maggahetukāti dassetuṃ “ariyamaggasamaṅgissa maggaṅgāni ṭhapetvā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Yo pana tattheva “ariyamaggasamaṅgissa alobho adoso amoho, ime dhammā maggahetū”ti
analyzed: gacchanti te magga hetukā ati dassetum ariya magga samaṅgissa maggaṅgāni ṭhapetvā atiādi  vuttam yaḥ pana tattha eva ariya magga samaṅgissa alobhaḥ adosaḥ amohaḥ ime dhammā magga hetū ti
translated: For in the “Section on Emergence” , too, those that get the name “conditions for the path” but are not themselves conditions for the path are shown to be causes of the path by the words “In one who possesses the noble path, the path factors, excepting the path itself, are causes of the path” .

original: ādinayo vutto, taṃ dassetuṃ “maggasampayuttā vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Ariyamaggasamaṅgissa
analyzed: ādi nayaḥ vuttaḥ tam dassetum magga sampayuttāḥ vā ti ādi vuttam ariya magga samaṅgissa
translated: But those that are shown there by the words “In one who possesses the noble path, non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion are causes of the path” are shown here by the words “Or they are associated with the path” .

original: sammādiṭṭhi maggo ceva hetu cā”tiādinā pana vuttanayaṃ dassetuṃ “sammādiṭṭhi saya”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi maggo ca iva hetu ca ātiādinā pana vutta nayam dassetum sammādiṭṭhi sayan tiādim āha
translated: And those that are shown there by the words “In one who possesses the noble path, right view is both the path and a cause of the path” are shown here by the words “Right view is itself” .

original: Tattha pana asaṅgahitasaṅgaṇhanavasena paṭipāṭiyā tayo nayā vuttā, hetubahutāvasena
analyzed: tattha pana asaṅgahita saṅgaṇhana vasena paṭipāṭiyā tayaḥ nayāḥ vuttāḥ hetu bahu tā vasena
translated: Herein, the three methods stated in the order are by way of inclusion and non-inclusion.

original: tatiyo nayo idha dutiyo vutto.🔽Abhibhavitvā pavattanaṭṭhenāti sahajātādhipatipi pubbābhisaṅkhāravasena jeṭṭhakabhāve🔽pavattamāno sahajāte attano vase anuvattayamāno te abhibhavitvā pavattati, ārammaṇādhipatipi🔽tadārammaṇe dhamme tatheva attānaṃ anuvattayamāno te dhamme abhibhavitvā ārammaṇabhāvena
analyzed: tatiyaḥ nayaḥ idha dutiyaḥ vutto  abhibhavitvā pavattana ṭṭhena ati sahajāta adhipati pi pubba abhisaṅkhāra vasena jeṭṭhaka bhāve  pavattamānaḥ sahajāte attanaḥ vase anuvattayamāno te abhibhavitvā pavattati ārammaṇa adhipati pi  tad ārammaṇe dhamme tathā iva attānam anuvattayamāno te dhamme abhibhavitvā ārammaṇa bhāvena
translated: The third method stated here as the second is by way of the multiplicity of causes.

original: pavattati, na paccuppannabhāvena, tasmā adhipatidvayampi saṅgahitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pavattati na paccuppanna bhāvena tasmai adhipati dvayam pi saṅgahitan ti veditabbam
translated: By the meaning of “having dominated and occurred”: the conascent-predominance, occurring in the state of seniority by the prior volition, occurs having dominated the conascent states, which are conforming to its own control. The object-predominance, too, occurring in the state of object-predominance, not in the state of presentness, occurs having dominated those states, which are conforming to itself in that object, not in the state of presentness. Therefore, it should be understood that both kinds of predominance are included.

original: “Maggo adhipati etesa”nti ayañca attho nikkhepakaṇḍe udāharaṇavasena āgataṃ atthanayaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ adhipati etesan ti ayam ca atthaḥ nikkhepa kaṇḍe udāharaṇa vasena āgatam attha nayam
translated: And this meaning “The path is the predominance of these” is stated by way of the meaning of the Thread-simile, which is stated in the Introduction by way of an example.

original: gahetvā vutto. Yasmā pana paṭṭhāne “maggādhipatiṃ dhammaṃ paṭicca maggādhipati dhammo
analyzed: gahetvā vuttaḥ yasmā pana paṭṭhāne magga adhipatim dhammam paṭicca magga adhipati dhammo
translated: But in the Paṭṭhāna, “A state with path-predominance has path-predominance states as its conascence-condition, etc. …

original: uppajjati nādhipatipaccayā, maggādhipatī khandhe paṭicca maggādhipati adhipatī”ti
analyzed: uppajjati na adhipati paccayā magga adhipatī khandhe paṭicca magga adhipati adhipati iti
translated: and “a path-predominance condition is a condition, as predominance condition, for the states associated therewith and for the path-concomitant formations” .

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā maggo adhipati maggādhipatīti ayampi attho pāḷiyaṃ sarūpekasesavasena
analyzed: vuttam tasmā maggaḥ adhipati magga adhipati iti ayam pi atthaḥ pāḷiyam sarūpa ekasesa vasena
translated: So the meaning of the path as predominance is included in the text by the words “predominance” and “predominance condition” in the literal sense,

original: samānasaddatthavasena vā saṅgahitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: vā saṅgahitaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: or it is included by the meaning of the words being the same.

original: 17. Anuppannāti etena sabbo uppannabhāvo paṭisiddho, na uppannadhammabhāvo evāti🔽tena uppannā vigatā atītāpi na saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā. Yadi hi saṅgahitā siyuṃ, “anuppanno
analyzed: anuppannā ti etena sabbaḥ uppanna bhāvaḥ paṭisiddhaḥ na uppanna dhamma bhāvaḥ eva ati  tena uppannā vigatā atītā api na saṅgahitā ati daṭṭhabbā yadi hi saṅgahitā siyum anuppannaḥ
translated: By “unarisen” all states of the arisen kind are excluded, but not the states of the non-arisen kind.

original: dhammo uppannassa dhammassa anantarapaccayena paccayo”tievamādi vucceyya, na tu vuttanti.
analyzed: dhammo uppannassa dhammassa anantara paccayena paccayaḥ ti evamādi vucceyya na tu vuttanti
translated: So it should be understood that past states are not included because they are arisen and have ceased. For if they were included, it would be said, “An unarisen state is a condition, as proximity condition, for an arisen state,” and so on, but it is not said.

original: Anāgatāni vipākakaṭattārūpāni atīte anāgate vā kamme purimanipphanne eva uppajjissanti,🔽nānipphanneti pariniṭṭhitakāraṇekadesāneva honti, tasmā tāni “avassaṃ uppajjissantīti
analyzed: anāgatāni vipāka kaṭattā rūpāni atīte anāgate vā kamme purima nipphanne eva uppajjissanti  na anipphannā iti pariniṭṭhita kāraṇa eka desān eva honti tasmā tāni avassam uppajjissanti iti
translated: The resultant materiality of the future is the materiality that will arise in a future kamma-process result.

original: uppādino dhammā”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: uppādinaḥ dhammā ti vuccanti
translated: It is only a part of the cause that is completed, so it is called “a state that is bound to arise” since it will certainly arise.

original: 18. Attano sabhāvanti kakkhaḷaphusanādisabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ sabhāvanti kakkhaḷa phusana ādi sabhāvam
translated: “His own being” is the being of the hard and solid, etc.,

original: 20. Evaṃ pavattamānāti evaṃ cakkhādibhāvena phusanādibhāvena ca ekasantatipariyāpannatāvasena🔽pavattamānā. Attānaṃ adhi ajjhattāti adhi-saddo samāsavisaye adhikāratthaṃ pavattiatthañca
analyzed: evam pavattamānā ti evam cakkha ādi bhāvena phusana ādi bhāvena ca eka santati pariyāpanna tā vasena  pavattamānā attānam adhi ajjhattā iti adhi saddaḥ samāsa visaye adhikāra attham pavatti attham ca
translated: Thus occurring: thus occurring in the continuity of aggregates as eye, etc., and as touching, etc.,

original: gahetvā pavattatīti attānaṃ adhikicca uddissa pavattā ajjhattā. Tenāti yassa jhānā🔽vuṭṭhahitvā ajjhattaṃ bahiddhā ajjhattabahiddhā ca suññataṃ āneñjañca manasikaroto
analyzed: gahetvā pavattati iti attānam adhikicca uddissa pavattā ajjhattā tena ati yassa jhānā  vuṭṭhahitvā ajjhattam bahiddhā ajjhatta bahiddhā ca suññatam āneñjam ca manasikaroto
translated: “In himself” : the word adhi is used in the sense of “dominance” in the compound adhi-ajjhatta, and in the sense of “occurrence” in the compound adhi-bahiddhā. Thus “in himself” means “occurring in oneself as the dominant, as the object.”

original: ajjhattasuññatādīsu cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati,
analyzed: ajjhatta suñña tā ādīsu cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na adhimuccati
translated: “That bhikkhu”: the bhikkhu who, after emerging from jhāna, gives attention to the void and the imperturbable internally, externally, and internally and externally, and whose mind does not enter into those voidnesses, etc., does not become settled in them, nor does it become serene, confident, and decided,

original: yo ca itiha tattha sampajāno, tena bhikkhunā. Tasmiṃyeva purimasmiṃ samādhinimitteti
analyzed: yaḥ ca iti ha tattha sampajāno tena bhikkhunā tasmin yeva purimasmin samādhi nimittā iti
translated: and who is thus “clearly comprehending it here” .🔽“In that same original object of concentration”: in the object of concentration of the first jhāna, etc.

original: paṭhamajjhānādisamādhinimitte. Ajjhattamevāti jhānagocare kasiṇādimhi. Cittaṃ saṇṭhapetabbanti
analyzed: paṭhamajjhāna ādi samādhi nimitte ajjhattam eva ati jhāna gocare kasiṇa ādimhi cittam saṇṭhapetabbanti
translated: “Internally”: in the kasiṇa, etc., which is the domain of jhāna.

original: paṭhamajjhānādicittaṃ saṇṭhapetabbaṃ. Ajjhattaratoti gocarajjhatte nibbāne rato,
analyzed: paṭhamajjhāna ādi cittam saṇṭhapetabbam ajjhatta rataḥ ti gocara jjhatte nibbāne rataḥ
translated: The first-jhāna consciousness, etc., should be steadied. He delights in his own mind: he delights in the mind’s own objective field, in Nibbāna,

original: samādhigocare kammaṭṭhāne vā rato. “Samāhito eko santusito tamāhu bhikkhu”nti gāthāseso.
analyzed: samādhi gocare kammaṭṭhāne vā rato samāhito eko santusito tam āhu bhikkhunti gāthā seso
translated: or he delights in the concentration subject or in the meditation subject. The rest of the stanza is: “He is called a monk who is concentrated, one in equipoise, contented, and happy” .

original: Ajjhattaṃ sampasādananti ettha jhānaṃ sakasantatipariyāpannattā “ajjhatta”nti vuttanti
analyzed: ajjhattam sampasādanan ti ettha jhānam saka santati pariyāpanna ttā ajjhattanti vuttanti
translated: As to “he is confident in himself”: the jhāna is called “in himself” because it is included in his own mental continuity.🔽The word “in himself” has the meaning of “in himself alone.” “In himself” is in his own mental continuity.

original: niyakajjhattattho ajjhatta-saddo hoti. Ajjhattanti sakasantatiniyakaṃ. Ajjhatte bhavā🔽ajjhattikāti niyakajjhattesupi abbhantarā cakkhādayo vuccanti. Ettha pana ajjhattika-saddo
analyzed: niyaka jjhatta atthaḥ ajjhatta saddaḥ hoti ajjhatta anti saka santati niyakam ajjhatte  ajjhattikā ti niyaka ajjhattesu pi abbhantarā cakkha ādayaḥ vuccanti ettha pana ajjhattika saddo
translated: What is in himself is “in himself alone.”🔽The eye, etc., are called “in himself” in the sense of “in himself alone.” But here the word “in himself”

original: cakkhādīsu pavattamāno dassito, na ajjhattasaddo, atthi ca ajjhattaajjhattikasaddānaṃ🔽bahiddhābāhira-saddānaṃ viya viseso. Ajjhattikasaddo hi saparasantānikesu sabbesu
analyzed: cakkha ādīsu pavattamānaḥ dassitaḥ na ajjhatta saddaḥ atthi ca ajjhatta ajjhattika saddānam  bahiddhā bāhira saddānam viya visesaḥ ajjhattika saddo hi sa para santānikesu sabbesu
translated: is used in the sense of the eye, etc., and not in the sense of “in himself alone.” And there is a distinction between the words “in himself” and “in himself alone,”🔽just as there is between the words “external” and “external in the ultimate sense” . For the word “in himself alone” is used of all the eye, etc., that are included in one’s own and another’s mental continuity,

original: cakkhādīsu rūpādīsu bāhira-saddo viya pavattati, ajjhatta-saddo pana sakasantānikesveva
analyzed: cakkha ādīsu rūpa ādīsu bāhira saddaḥ viya pavattati ajjhatta saddaḥ pana saka santānikesu eva
translated: just as the word “external” is used of visible data, etc.,

original: cakkhurūpādīsu tato aññesveva bahiddhā-saddo viya pavattatīti tasmā saddato atthato
analyzed: cakkhu rūpa ādīsu tatas aññesu eva bahiddhā saddaḥ viya pavattati iti tasmā saddataḥ atthato
translated: and the word “external” occurs in regard to the eye and visible forms, etc., as in regard to other things. Therefore, because of the dissimilarity in meaning,

original: ca asamānattā na idamettha udāharaṇaṃ yuttanti. Ayaṃ panettha adhippāyo daṭṭhabbo
analyzed: ca asamāna ttā na idam ettha udāharaṇam yuttam ti ayam pana ittha adhippāyaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: this is not a suitable example. But the intention here should be seen thus:

original: – ajjhatte bhavā ajjhattikāti ayañhi vacanattho. Yañca ajjhatte bhavaṃ, tena ajjhatteneva
analyzed: ajjhatte bhavā ajjhattikā iti ayam hi vacana tthaḥ yat ca ajjhatte bhavam tena ajjhattena iva
translated: “What is internal is internal.” This is the meaning of the words. And what is internal must be internal only;

original: bhavitabbaṃ, tena taṃvācakassa ajjhatta-saddassa ajjhattika-saddassa ca samānatthatā.
analyzed: bhavitabbam tena tad vācakassa ajjhatta saddassa ajjhattika saddassa ca samāna attha tā
translated: therefore the words “internal” and “internal things” have the same meaning.

original: Ubhinnampi saddānaṃ samānatthabhāvato ajjhattajjhatte pavattamāne ajjhattika-sadde
analyzed: ubhinnam pi saddānam samāna attha bhāvataḥ ajjhatta ajjhatte pavattamāne ajjhattika sadde
translated: Because the two words have the same meaning, when the word “internal” occurs in the sense of “internal and external,”

original: ajjhatta-saddo tattha pavattoti sakkā vattunti.🔽Ayaṃ kho panānanda, vihāroti vihārasuññatāsutte saṅgaṇikārāmatāya rūpādiratiyā ca
analyzed: ajjhatta saddo tattha pavatto ti sakkā vattunti  ayam kho pana ānanda vihāro ti vihāra suñña tā sutte saṅgaṇikā ārāma tāya rūpa ādi ratiyā ca
translated: it is proper to say that the word “internal” occurs there in the sense of “internal.”🔽“This, Ānanda, is a certain kind of abiding in emptiness”: in the Discourse on the Emptiness of Abiding , after pointing out the danger in delighting in society and in delighting in form, etc.,

original: ādīnavaṃ vatvā tappaṭipakkhavihāradassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Ajjhattaṃ suññatanti visayabhūtaṃ
analyzed: ādīnavam vatvā tad paṭipakkha vihāra dassana attham vuttam ajjhattam suññatam ti visaya bhūtam
translated: this is said in order to show the opposite kind of abiding.

original: issariyaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ suññataṃ, suññatāphalasamāpattinti attho. Cittissarā hi buddhā
analyzed: issariya ṭṭhāna bhūtam suññatam suñña tā phala samāpattinti attho cittissarāḥ hi buddhāḥ
translated: The attainment of the fruition of the void is the void that is the basis for lordship. The meaning is that it is the attainment of the fruition of the void.

original: bhagavanto dhammaṃ desentāpi yaṃ muhuttaṃ tuṇhī bhavitabbaṃ hoti, taṃ muhuttaṃ phalasamāpattiṃ🔽samāpajjanti, pageva aññasmiṃ kāle, tasmā sabbatthāpi issariyānaṃ bahulaṃ phalasamāpattiyaṃ
analyzed: bhagavantaḥ dhammaṃ desentā api yam muhuttam tuṇhī bhavitabbam hoti tam muhuttam phala samāpattim  samāpajjanti pagā iva aññasmin kāle tasmā sabbattha api issariyānam bahulam phala samāpattiyam
translated: For the Enlightened Ones, the Blessed Ones, when they are teaching the Dhamma, enter into the fruition attainment for the time being when they want to be silent for a while;

original: issariyassa pavattanato phalasamāpatti “issariyaṭṭhāna”nti vuttā. Arahattaphalādhigamena
analyzed: issariyassa pavattanataḥ phala samāpatti issariya ṭṭhānan ti vuttā arahatta phala adhigamena
translated: and all the more so at other times. Therefore, since lordship is usually exercised by them in the fruition attainment, it is said that the fruition attainment is the basis for lordship.

original: vā tathāgatānaṃ issariyaṃ nibbattaṃ taṃjanakeneva maggenāti taṃ tesaṃ issariyaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Visayo ca anaññatthabhāvova yathā “ākāse sakuṇā udake macchā”ti, buddhā ca aññattha
analyzed: vā tathāgatānam issariyam nibbattam taṃjanakena iva maggena ati tam tesam issariya ṭṭhānaṃ  visayo ca yathā ākāse sakuṇā udake buddhā ca aññattha
translated: Or alternatively, the lordship of the Perfect Ones arises with the attainment of the Arahant fruit, and it is generated by the path itself. So that is the basis for their lordship.

original: dissamānāpi vivekapabbhāratāya phalasamāpattininnāva, tena tassā tassā kiriyāya anantaraṃ
analyzed: dissamānā api viveka pabbhāratāya tena tassā tassā kiriyāya anantaram
translated: And the domain of the fruition attainment is not elsewhere, just as the domain of birds is in the air and that of fish in the water. And the Buddhas, though seen elsewhere, are inclined to seclusion, and they are intent on the fruition attainment. Therefore, immediately after each kind of activity,

original: phalasamāpattiyaṃyeva bhavantīti sā tesaṃ visayo, tabbisayatā ca saccakasuttena dīpetabbā.
analyzed: phala samāpattiyam yeva bhavanti iti sā tesam visayaḥ tad visaya tā ca saccaka suttena dīpetabbā
translated: They are the objective fields of the jhāna factors only in the fruition attainment. And their being the objective fields of the jhāna factors should be illustrated by the Saccaka Sutta .

original: 22. Yesaṃ daṭṭhabbabhāvo atthi, te sanidassanā. Cakkhuviññāṇagocarabhāvova daṭṭhabbabhāvo,
analyzed: yesam daṭṭhabba bhāvo atthi te sa nidassanā cakkhu viññāṇa gocara bhāvaḥ uva daṭṭhabba bhāvaḥ
translated: Those that have the state of being seen are the visible-data base. The state of being seen is the state of being the objective field of eye-consciousness.

original: tassa rūpāyatanā anaññattepi aññehi dhammehi rūpāyatanaṃ visesetuṃ aññaṃ viya katvā
analyzed: tassa rūpa āyatanā an aññatte pi aññehi dhammehi rūpa āyatanam visesetum aññam viya katvā
translated: Though it is not different from the visible-data base, still, in order to distinguish it from other states, it is as though it were different.

original: “saha nidassanenāti sanidassanā”ti vuttaṃ. Dhammasabhāvasāmaññena hi ekībhūtesu dhammesu
analyzed: saha nidassanena ati sa nidassanā iti vuttam dhamma sabhāva sāmaññena hi ekībhūtesu dhammesu
translated: So it is said, “With the state of being seen, thus it is visible-data base” . For when states are classed together according to their general nature,

original: yo nānattakaro sabhāvo, so añño viya katvā upacarituṃ yutto. Evañhi atthavisesāvabodho🔽hotīti. Sayañca nissayavasena ca sampattānaṃ asampattānañca paṭimukhabhāvo aññamaññapatanaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ nānatta karaḥ sabhāvaḥ saḥ aññaḥ viya katvā upacaritum yuttaḥ evam hi attha visesa avabodho  hoti iti sayam ca nissaya vasena ca sampattānam a sampattānam ca paṭimukha bhāvaḥ aññamañña patanam
translated: the state that causes the difference between them can be treated as though it were different. For then the particular meaning is understood.🔽The state of being mutually opposed to each other, of those that have reached and those that have not reached the eye, etc., by way of support, is the opposition by confrontation.

original: paṭihananabhāvo, yena byāpārādivikārapaccayantarasahitesu cakkhādīnaṃ visayesu vikāruppatti.
analyzed: paṭihanana bhāvaḥ yena byāpāra ādi vikāra paccaya antara sahitesu cakkha ādīnam visayesu vikāra uppatti
translated: It is the state of being mutually opposed to each other, of those that have reached and those that have not reached the eye, etc., by way of support, which is the cause for the arising of the alteration in the eye, etc., when they are accompanied by the conditions for alteration such as activity, etc.

original: Tikamātikāpadavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tikamātikā pada vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the three-aggregate schedule is ended.

original: Dukamātikāpadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duka mātikā pada vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the four-aggregate schedule

original: 1-6. Mūlaṭṭhenāti suppatiṭṭhitabhāvasādhanena mūlabhāvena, na paccayamattaṭṭhena
analyzed: mūla aṭṭhena ati suppatiṭṭhita bhāva sādhanena mūla bhāvena na paccaya matta ṭṭhena
translated: 1-6. As root-cause: as the state of being a root, that is, as the state of being a well-established cause, not as mere condition.

original: hetudhammā hetū dhammāti samāsāsamāsaniddesabhāvo dvinnaṃ pāṭhānaṃ viseso. Tathevāti
analyzed: hetu dhammāḥ hetū dhammā ati samāsa asamāsa niddesa bhāvaḥ dvinnam pāṭhānam viseso tathā iva ati
translated: The difference between the two statements is that the first is a compound and the second is not. “So too” means

original: sampayogatova. Sahetukānaṃ hetusampayuttabhāvato “sampayogato”ti vuttanti veditabbaṃ,
analyzed: sampayogataḥ va sa hetukānam hetu sampayutta bhāvato sampayogato ti vuttam ti veditabbam
translated: by association. It should be understood that the words “by association” are said because the associated states are associated with the cause,

original: na sahasaddassa sampayogatthattā. Saha-saddo pana ekapuñje uppādato yāva bhaṅgā sahetukānaṃ
analyzed: na saha saddassa sampayoga ttha ttā saha saddaḥ pana eka puñje uppādataḥ yāva bhaṅgā sa hetukānam
translated: not because the word “together” has the meaning of association. But the word “together” shows that the associated states arise together with the causes,

original: hetūhi samānadesagahaṇānaṃ hetuādisabbhāvaṃ dīpeti, sampayutta-saddo ekuppādādivasena
analyzed: hetūhi samāna desa gahaṇānam hetu ādi sabbhāvam dīpeti sampayutta saddaḥ eka uppāda ādi vasena
translated: and that they are included in the same aggregates, bases, and elements, and that they are included in the same groups, etc., until the moment of their dissolution. The word “associated” shows that they are united with the causes by the condition of arising together, etc.,

original: saha hetūhi ekībhāvupagamanaṃ, tato eva ca dvinnaṃ dukānaṃ nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ. Dhammanānattābhāvepi🔽hi padatthanānattena dukantaraṃ vuccati. Na hi hetudukasaṅgahitehi dhammehi aññe
analyzed: saha hetūhi ekībhāva upagamanam tatas eva ca dvinnam dukānam nānattam veditabbam dhamma nānatta abhāve pi  hi pada attha nānattena dukantaram vuccati na hi hetu duka saṅgahitehi dhammehi aññe
translated: and that the two statements are different. For although there is no difference in the diversity of states,

original: sahetukadukādīhi vuccanti, te eva pana sahetukāhetukādibhāvato sahetukadukādīhi vuttā.
analyzed: sa hetuka duka ādīhi vuccanti te eva pana sa hetuka ahetuka ādi bhāvataḥ sa hetuka duka ādīhi vuttā
translated: the two statements are called different because of the difference in the arrangement of the words. For the states included in the statement about the cause are not called by the statement about the associated states,🔽and vice versa.

original: Evaṃ sahetukadukasaṅgahitā eva hetusampayuttavippayuttabhāvato hetusampayuttadukena
analyzed: evam sa hetuka duka saṅgahitāḥ eva hetu sampayutta vippayutta bhāvataḥ hetu sampayutta dukena
translated: So they are called the dyad of associated with cause and not associated with cause because of the difference of being associated with and not associated with cause.

original: vuttā. Na hi dhammānaṃ avuttatāpekkhaṃ dukantaravacananti natthi punaruttidoso. Desetabbappakārajānanañhi
analyzed: vuttāḥ na hi dhammānam a vutta tā apekkham duka antara vacanan ti natthi punarutti dosaḥ desetabba ppakāra jānanam hi
translated: For there is no fault in repeating what has already been said, since the teaching of the Dhamma is not undertaken with a view to brevity,🔽but rather the teaching of the Dhamma is undertaken with a view to the manifestation of the diversity of the teaching, and the manifestation of the diversity of the teaching is undertaken with a view to the manifestation of the diversity of the knowledge of the teaching.

original: desanāvilāso tathā desanāñāṇañcāti. Tena dhammānaṃ tappakāratā vuttā hoti. Sakalekadesavasena🔽paṭhamadukaṃ dutiyatatiyehi saddhiṃ yojetvā catutthādayo tayo dukā vuttā. Sakalañhi
analyzed: desanā vilāso tathā desanā ñāṇam ca ati tena dhammānam tad pakāra tā vuttā hoti sakala ekadesa vasena  paṭhama dukam dutiya tatiyehi saddhim yojetvā catuttha ādayo tayo dukāḥ vuttā sakalam hi
translated: Therefore the diversity of the Dhamma is stated.🔽The first dyad is combined with the second and the third, and the remaining three dyads are stated.

original: paṭhamadukaṃ dutiyadukekadesena sahetukapadena tatiyadukekadesena hetusampayuttapadena🔽ca yojetvā yathākkamaṃ catutthapañcamadukā vuttā, tathā paṭhamadukekadesaṃ nahetupadaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama dukam dutiya duka ikadesena sa hetuka padena tatiya duka ikadesena hetu sampayutta padena  ca yojetvā yathākkamam catuttha pañcama dukā vuttā tathā paṭhama dukā ikadesam na hetu padam
translated: For the first dyad is combined with the second dyad by the word “with cause” and with the third dyad by the word “associated with cause,” and the fourth and fifth dyads are stated respectively.

original: sakalena dutiyadukena yojetvā chaṭṭhaduko vutto. Idampi sambhavatīti etena avuttampi
analyzed: sakalena dutiya dukena yojetvā chaṭṭha dukaḥ vuttaḥ idam pi sambhavati iti etena a vuttam pi
translated: Then the first dyad is combined with the whole of the second dyad by the word “without cause,” and the sixth dyad is stated.🔽This is possible. By this he shows that there is no fault in repeating what has already been said.

original: sambhavavasena dīpitanti dasseti. Sambhavo hi gahaṇassa kāraṇanti. Yathā hetusahetukāti
analyzed: sambhava vasena dīpitanti dasseti sambhavaḥ hi gahaṇassa kāraṇanti yathā hetu sahetukā ti
translated: He shows that they are demonstrated by way of generation, for generation is the cause of apprehension.

original: idaṃ sambhavatīti katvā gahitaṃ, evaṃ hetuahetukāti idampi sambhavatīti katvā gahetabbamevāti
analyzed: idam sambhavati iti katvā gahitam evam hetu ahetukā ati idam pi sambhavati iti katvā gahetabbam eva ati
translated: As to the words “with root-cause and with root-cause” , this is apprehended as “it is possible” . So too this “with root-cause and without root-cause” should be apprehended as “it is possible” .

original: evaṃ aññatthāpi yojetabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ paṭhamadukaṃ dutiyatatiyadukesu dutiyapadehi yojetvā “hetū ceva dhammā ahetukā🔽ca, ahetukā ceva dhammā na ca hetū, hetū ceva dhammā hetuvippayuttā ca, hetuvippayuttā
analyzed: evam aññattha api yojetabbam  evam paṭhama dukam dutiya tatiya dukesu dutiya padehi yojetvā hetū ca iva dhammā ahetukā  ca ahetukā ca iva dhammā na ca hetū hetū ca iva dhammā hetu vippayuttā ca hetu vippayuttā
translated: So too it should be construed in other instances.

original: ceva dhammā na ca hetū”ti ye dve dukā kātabbā, tesaṃ sambhavavaseneva saṅgahaṃ dassetvā🔽kho pana-padena aparesampi dukānaṃ saṅgahaṃ dassetuṃ “tatra yadeta”ntiādimāha. Tatrāti
analyzed: ca iva dhammā na ca hetu uti ye dve dukā kātabbā tesam sambhava vasena iva saṅgaham dassetvā  kho pana padena aparesam pi dukānam saṅgaham dassetum tatra yat etat iti ādim āha tatra ati
translated: So, having construed the first dyad with the second and third terms of the second dyad in the second and third triads, he shows the inclusion by way of generation of the two dyads that should be made thus “ dhammas with root-cause and dhammas without root-cause, dhammas without root-cause and dhammas not with root-cause, dhammas with root-cause and dhammas dissociated from root-cause, dhammas dissociated from root-cause and dhammas not with root-cause” .

original: pāḷiyaṃ. Ayaṃ atirekatthoti idāni yaṃ vakkhati, tamatthamāha. Tattha pana aññepi
analyzed: pāḷiyam ayam atireka atthaḥ ti idāni yam vakkhati tam attham āha tattha pana aññe pi
translated: Having shown the inclusion by way of generation, he says “Therein, that which is” , etc., in order to show the inclusion of the other dyads by means of the word “also” . Therein = in the text. This is the additional meaning = he states the meaning that he is about to say. But there also = in the text.

original: aññathāpīti etesaṃ visuṃ pavattiyā dve dukā dassitā, saha pavattiyā pana ayampi duko
analyzed: aññathā api iti etesam visum pavattiyā dve dukā dassitā saha pavattiyā pana ayam pi duko
translated: “In another way” shows two dyads in the separate occurrence of these, but in their joint occurrence there is this dyad:

original: veditabbo “hetū ceva dhammā hetusampayuttāpi hetuvippayuttāpī”ti, etesu pana pañcasu🔽dukesu dutiyadukena tatiyaduko viya, catutthadukena pañcamaduko viya ca chaṭṭhadukena
analyzed: veditabbaḥ hetū ca iva dhammā hetu sampayuttāḥ api hetu vippayuttāḥ api iti etesu pana pañcasu  dukesu dutiya dukena tatiya dukaḥ viya catuttha dukena pañcama dukaḥ viya ca chaṭṭha dukena
translated: The other way is that two dyads are shown for their separate occurrence. But for their joint occurrence, this dyad should be understood thus: “Ideas that are causes are associated with causes and dissociated from causes.” But of these five dyads,

original: ninnānatthattā “na hetu kho pana dhammā hetusampayuttāpi hetuvippayuttāpī”ti ayaṃ🔽duko na vutto. Dassitaninnānatthanayo hi so purimadukehīti. Itaresu catūsu hetū ceva🔽ahetukadukena samānatthattā hetū ceva hetuvippayuttaduko, hetusahetukadukena samānatthattā🔽hetuhetusampayuttaduko ca nahetuhetusampayuttaduko viya na vattabbo. Tesu pana dvīsu
analyzed: ninna anattha ttā na hetu kho pana dhammā hetu sampayuttā api hetu vippayuttā api iti ayaṃ  dukaḥ na vuttaḥ hi so purima dukehi iti itaresu catūsu hetū ca iva  ahetuka dukena samāna attha ttā hetū ca iva hetu vippayutta dukaḥ hetu sahetuka dukena samāna attha ttā  hetu hetu sampayutta duko ca na hetu hetu sampayutta duko viya na vattabbo tesu pana dvīsu
translated: the sixth dyad is not stated thus: “Ideas that are not causes are associated with causes and dissociated from causes,”🔽because it has the same meaning as the second dyad and the third dyad, and the fourth dyad and the fifth dyad. For the method of difference in meaning is that it is stated in the first dyad.

original: pacchimaduke “hetū kho pana dhammā sahetukā”ti padaṃ catutthaduke paṭhamapadena ninnānākaraṇattā
analyzed: pacchima duke hetū kho pana dhammā sa hetukā ati padam catuttha duke paṭhama padena ninnānākaraṇa ttā
translated: And of the remaining four dyads, the dyad “Ideas that are causes are dissociated from causes” should not be stated because it has the same meaning as the dyad “Ideas that are not causes are associated with causes and dissociated from causes,”🔽and the dyad “Ideas that are causes are associated with causes” should not be stated because it has the same meaning as the dyad “Ideas that are causes are associated with causes and dissociated from causes.”🔽But of these last two dyads, the phrase “Ideas that are causes are associated with causes” should not be stated in the first phrase of the fourth dyad because it has the same meaning as the phrase “Ideas that are causes are associated with causes and dissociated from causes.”

original: na vattabbaṃ, “hetū kho pana dhammā ahetukā”ti padaṃ “hetū ceva dhammā ahetukā”ti
analyzed: na vattabbam hetū kho pana dhammāḥ ahetukā ati padam hetū ca iva dhammāḥ ahetukā ati
translated: “States that are causes are not without causes” is not to be said.

original: etena ninnānattā na vattabbaṃ. Avasiṭṭhe pana ekasmiṃ duke “ahetukā ceva dhammā na
analyzed: etena ninnānattā na vattabbam avasiṭṭhe pana ekasmin duke ahetukāḥ ca iva dhammāḥ na
translated: Because of the difference in the words, it is not to be said. But when only one dyad is left, “States that are not causes are not without causes” is not to be said.

original: ca hetū”ti padaṃ chaṭṭhaduke dutiyapadena ekatthattā na vattabbaṃ. Idāni “hetū ceva🔽dhammā ahetukā cā”ti idamevekaṃ padaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ, na ca ekena padena duko hotīti
analyzed: ca hetū iti padam chaṭṭha duke dutiya padena ekattha ttā na vattabbam idāni hetū ca iva  dhammā ahetukā ca ati idam eva ekam padam avasiṭṭham na ca ekena padena dukaḥ hoti iti
translated: Because of the sameness of meaning with the second phrase in the sixth dyad. Now, only the phrase “States that are causes are without causes” is left, and a dyad is not made with a single phrase.

original: tañca na vuttanti. Catutthaduke dutiyapadena pana samānatthassa chaṭṭhaduke paṭhamapadassa
analyzed: tat ca na vuttanti catuttha duke dutiya padena pana samāna atthassa chaṭṭha duke paṭhama padassa
translated: And that is not said. But the statement of the first phrase in the sixth dyad, which has the same meaning as the second phrase in the fourth dyad,

original: vacanaṃ dukapūraṇatthaṃ, etena vā gatidassanena sabbassa sambhavantassa saṅgaho katoti🔽daṭṭhabbo. Tathā hi sabbo sambhavaduko paṭhamaduke dutiyatatiyadukapakkhepena dassito,
analyzed: vacanam duka pūraṇa attham etena vā gati dassanena sabbassa sambhavantassa saṅgahaḥ kato ti  daṭṭhabbo tathā hi sabbaḥ sambhava duko paṭhama duke dutiya tatiya duka pakkhepena dassito
translated: is for the purpose of completing the dyad. Or else, since the inclusion of all that can occur is made by the indication of the direction in this way,🔽it should be regarded thus. For all the dyads that can occur are shown in the first dyad by the method of the second and third dyads,

original: tesu ca paṭhamadukapakkhepenāti.
analyzed: tesu ca paṭhama duka pakkhepena ati
translated: and in those the second dyad is shown by the method of the first dyad.

original: 7-13. Samānakālena asamānakālena kālavimuttena ca paccayena nipphannānaṃ paccayāyattānaṃ🔽paccayabhāvamattena tesaṃ paccayānaṃ atthitaṃ dīpetuṃ sappaccayavacanaṃ, na sahetukavacanaṃ
analyzed: samāna kālena asamāna kālena kāla vimuttena ca paccayena nipphannānam paccaya āyattānam  paccaya bhāva mattena tesam paccayānam atthitam dīpetum sappaccaya vacanam na sa hetuka vacanam
translated: The statement “with conditions” is made to show the existence of those conditions by their mere state of being conditions, which have arisen through conditions that are sometimes simultaneous and sometimes not simultaneous and that are liberated from time.🔽It is not made to show that they are simultaneous like the statement “with cause” is,

original: viya samānakālānameva, nāpi sanidassanaṃ viya taṃsabhāvassa anatthantarabhūtassa.
analyzed: samāna kālānam eva na api sa nidassanam viya taṃsa bhāvassa anatthantara bhūtassa
translated: nor is it made to show that they are of the same nature as the statement “with object” is.

original: Saṅkhata-saddo pana sametehi nipphāditabhāvaṃ dīpetīti ayametesaṃ viseso dukantaravacane🔽kāraṇaṃ. Ettha ca appaccayā asaṅkhatāti bahuvacananiddeso avinicchitatthaparicchedadassanavasena🔽mātikāṭhapanato katoti veditabbo. Uddesena hi kusalādisabhāvānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthitāmattaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhata saddaḥ pana sametehi nipphādita bhāvam dīpeti iti ayam etesam visesaḥ duk antara vacane  kāraṇam ettha ca appaccayā asaṅkhatā ati bahuvacana niddesaḥ avinicchita attha pariccheda dassana vasena  mātikā ṭhapanataḥ kataḥ iti veditabbaḥ uddesena hi kusala ādi sabhāvānam dhammānam atthitā mattam
translated: But the word “formed” shows that they are produced by a combination. This is the difference between the two words in the sense of “other than.”🔽And here the plural form “conditions” and “unformed” should be understood as stated in the plural because the scope of the meaning is not specified.🔽For the method of exposition is stated in the Schedule thus: “By the statement of the headings the mere existence of profitable, etc., states is stated, not their scope. Therefore the exposition is stated in the plural by way of the unspecified plural.”

original: vuccati, na paricchedoti aparicchedena bahuvacanena uddeso vuttoti. Rūpanti rūpāyatanaṃ
analyzed: vuccati na paricchedo ti aparicchedena bahuvacanena uddesaḥ vutto ti rūpam ti rūpa āyatanam
translated: “Materiality” is the base consisting of materiality.

original: pathaviyādi vā. Purimasmiṃ atthavikappe rūpāyatanassa asaṅgahitatā āpajjatīti ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: pathaviyā ādi vā purimasmin attha vikappe rūpa āyatanassa asaṅgahita tā āpajjati iti ruppana lakkhaṇam
translated: Or else it is earth, etc., in the second case. In the first case, the visible-data base is not included, and so the meaning-interpretation stated is that the characteristic of being molested is the meaning of “materiality” .

original: vā rūpanti ayaṃ atthanayo vutto. Tattha rūpanti ruppanasabhāvo. Na lujjati na palujjatīti
analyzed: vā rūpanti ayam attha nayaḥ vutto tattha rūpanti ruppana sabhāvaḥ na lujjati na palujjati iti
translated: Herein, “materiality” is the state of being molested . It is not destroyed, not wasted away,

original: yo gahito tathā na hoti, so lokoti taṃgahaṇarahitānaṃ lokuttarānaṃ natthi lokatā.
analyzed: yaḥ gahito tathā na hoti so tad gahaṇa rahitānam lokuttarānam natthi loka tā
translated: that which is taken as that is not so, and so there is no world-status of supramundane states free from that taking.

original: Dukkhasaccaṃ vā loko, tattha teneva lokasabhāvena viditāti lokiyā.
analyzed: dukkha saccam vā tattha tena iva loka sabhāvena viditā ati lokiyā
translated: Or the truth of suffering is the world, and it is known by that as the world, thus it is mundane.

original: Evaṃ sante cakkhuviññāṇena vijānitabbassa rūpāyatanassa teneva navijānitabbassa saddāyatanādikassa
analyzed: evam sante cakkhu viññāṇena vijānitabbassa rūpa āyatanassa tena iva na vijānitabbassa sadda āyatana ādikassa
translated: If that is so, then the visible-data base, which is what should be known by eye-consciousness, and the sound base, etc., which are not what should be known by that,

original: ca nānattā dvinnampi padānaṃ atthanānattato duko hoti. Evaṃ pana duke vuccamāne dukabahutā
analyzed: ca nānattā dvinnam pi padānam attha nānattataḥ dukaḥ hoti evam pana duke vuccamāne duka bahu tā
translated: are different, and so the two terms differ in meaning, and so they make a dyad. But if they are called a dyad in this way, then there is an infinite number of dyads,

original: āpajjati, yattakāni viññāṇāni, tattakā dukā vuttā samattā ṭhapetvā sabbadhammārammaṇāni
analyzed: āpajjati yattakāni viññāṇāni tattakā dukā vuttā samattā ṭhapetvā sabba dhamma ārammaṇāni
translated: and so many dyads are mentioned as there are consciousnesses, and that is all, leaving aside those that have all states as their object.

original: viññāṇāni. Tesu ca dukassa pacchedo āpajjati, tathā ca sati “kenacī”ti padaṃ sabbaviññāṇasaṅgāhakaṃ🔽na siyā, niddesena ca viruddhaṃ idaṃ vacanaṃ. Yo ca tattha “ye te dhammā cakkhuviññeyyā,
analyzed: viññāṇāni tesu ca dukassa pacchedaḥ āpajjati tathā ca sati kenaci iti padam sabba viññāṇa saṅgāhakam  na siyā niddesena ca viruddham idam vacanam ca tattha ye te dhammā cakkhu viññeyyā
translated: and the consciousnesses. And if that were so, then the words “by any” would not include all consciousnesses.

original: na te dhammā sotaviññeyyāti ayaṃ duko na hotī”ti paṭisedho kato, so ca kathaṃ yujjeyya.
analyzed: na te dhammā sota viññeyyā ti ayam dukaḥ na hoti iti paṭisedho kato saḥ ca katham
translated: And this statement would be contradicted by the demonstration. And the denial “The dyad ‘Those ideas cognizable by the eye are not ideas cognizable by the ear’ does not exist” would be inappropriate.🔽For it is not proper for the Commentary to deny the text.

original: Na hi samatthā aṭṭhakathā pāḷiṃ paṭisedhetunti, na ca kenaci-saddassa tenevāti ayaṃ
analyzed: na hi samatthā aṭṭhakathā pāḷim paṭisedhetun ti na ca kenacid saddassa tena iva ati ayaṃ
translated: And the meaning of the word “by any” is not “by that same” .

original: padattho sambhavati, “kenacī”ti etassa ādipadassa aniyamitaṃ yaṃ kiñci ekaṃ padattho,
analyzed: padatthaḥ sambhavati kenaci iti etassa ādi padassa aniyamitam yam kiñci ekam padatthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the first word “by any” is “by some unspecified one” .

original: taṃ vatvā vuccamānassa “kenacī”ti dutiyapadassa yaṃ kiñci aparaṃ aniyamitaṃ padatthoti
analyzed: tam vatvā vuccamānassa kenaci iti dutiya padassa yam kiñci aparam aniyamitam
translated: And when it is being said that the meaning of the second word “by any” is “by some other unspecified one” ,

original: lokasiddhametaṃ, tatheva ca niddeso pavatto, na cettha viññātabbadhammabhedena dukabhedo
analyzed: loka siddham etam tathā iva ca niddeso pavattaḥ na ca ittha viññātabba dhamma bhedena duka bhedo
translated: this is a well-known fact in the world. And the demonstration proceeds in this way. But here the dyad is not divided up according to the different ideas that have to be known.

original: samatto āpajjati yattakā viññātabbā, tattakā dukāti, tasmā natthi dukabahutā. Na
analyzed: samattaḥ āpajjati yattakā viññātabbā tattakā dukā ati tasmā natthi duka bahu tā na
translated: The dyad is complete with as many as are to be cognized, and so there is no excess of dyads.

original: hi ekaṃyeva viññātabbaṃ kenaci viññeyyaṃ kenaci na viññeyyañca, kintu aparampi aparampīti
analyzed: hi ekam yeva viññātabbam kenaci viññeyyam kenaci na viññeyyam ca kintu aparam pi aparam pi iti
translated: For no single thing to be cognized is cognizable by one and not cognizable by another. But rather it is another and another.

original: sabbaviññātabbasaṅgahe duko samatto hoti, evañca sati “kenacī”ti padaṃ aniyamena
analyzed: sabba viññātabba saṅgahe duko samattaḥ hoti evam ca sati kenaci iti padam aniyamena
translated: So the dyad is complete with the inclusion of all that is to be cognized. And when that is so, the word “by one” is established as being without restriction,

original: sabbaviññāṇasaṅgāhakanti siddhaṃ hoti, viññāṇanānattena ca viññātabbaṃ bhinditvā
analyzed: sabba viññāṇa saṅgāhakanti siddham hoti viññāṇa nānattena ca viññātabbam bhinditvā
translated: as including all kinds of consciousness. And since the variety of consciousness is due to the variety of what is to be cognized,

original: ayaṃ duko vutto, na viññātabbānaṃ atthantaratāyāti. Etassa pana dukassa nikkheparāsiniddeso
analyzed: ayam dukaḥ vuttaḥ na viññātabbānam atthantara tāya ati etassa pana dukassa nikkhepa rāsi niddesaḥ
translated: this dyad is stated by dividing up what is to be cognized by means of the variety of consciousness, not by means of a difference in meaning of what is to be cognized.🔽The demonstration of the heap of the dyad’s outcome

original: dukasaṅgahitadhammekadesesu dukapadadvayappavattidassanavasena pavatto. Atthuddhāraniddeso
analyzed: duka saṅgahita dhamma ekadesesu duka pada dvaya ppavatti dassana vasena pavattaḥ atthuddhāra niddeso
translated: occurs by showing the occurrence of two instances of the word “dyad” in the case of the states included in the dyad. The demonstration of the extraction of the meaning

original: niravasesadukasaṅgahitadhammadassanavasenāti veditabbo.
analyzed: niravasesa duka saṅgahita dhamma dassana vasena ati veditabbo
translated: should be understood to occur by showing the states included in the dyad without remainder.

original: 14-19. Cakkhutopi…pe… manatopīti cakkhuviññāṇādivīthīsu tadanugatamanoviññāṇavīthīsu
analyzed: manataḥ pi iti cakkhu viññāṇa ādi vīthīsu tad anugata manaḥ viññāṇa vīthīsu
translated: As to “through the eye” … “through the mind”: in the streets of eye-consciousness, etc., and in the streets of mind-consciousness that accompanies them,

original: ca kiñcāpi kusalādīnampi pavatti atthi, kāmāsavādayo eva pana vaṇato yūsaṃ viya paggharaṇakaasucibhāvena
analyzed: ca kiñcā api kusala ādīnam pi atthi kāma āsava ādayaḥ eva pana vaṇataḥ yūsam viya paggharaṇaka asuci bhāvena
translated: and although there is occurrence of profitable, etc., ideas, it is only the cankers of sense desire, etc., that ooze out like the juice of a wound,

original: sandanti, tasmā te eva “āsavā”ti vuccanti. Tattha hi paggharaṇakaasucimhi niruḷho
analyzed: sandanti tasmā te eva āsavā ti vuccanti tattha hi paggharaṇaka asucimhi niruḷho
translated: and so they are called “cankers” . For the word “canker” is fixed by usage on what oozes out like a wound.

original: āsavasaddoti. Dhammato yāva gotrabhunti tato paraṃ maggaphalesu appavattito vuttaṃ.🔽Ete hi ārammaṇakaraṇavasena dhamme gacchantā tato paraṃ na gacchantīti. Nanu tato
analyzed: āsava saddaḥ ti dhammataḥ yāva gotrabhun ti tatas param magga phalesu appavattitaḥ vuttam  ete hi ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena dhamme gacchantā tato param na gacchanti iti nanu tato
translated: “As far as the state of change-of-lineage” : because of non-occurrence in the path and fruition.🔽For these ideas go to the ideas as object, but they do not go beyond them.

original: paraṃ bhavaṅgādīnipi gacchantīti ce? Na, tesampi pubbe ālambitesu lokiyadhammesu🔽sāsavabhāvena antogadhattā tato paratābhāvato. Ettha ca gotrabhuvacanena gotrabhuvodānaphalasamāpattipurecārikaparikammāni
analyzed: param bhavaṅga ādīni pi gacchanti iti ce na tesam pi pubbe ālambitesu lokiya dhammesu  sa āsava bhāvena tatas para tā bhāvataḥ ettha ca gotra bhuva canena gotra bhuvaḥ udāna phala samāpatti purecārika parikammāni
translated: But do they not go beyond them to the life-continuum, etc.? No; because the life-continuum, etc., are included in the category of ideas that are already reached previously as objects and are therefore not beyond them.🔽And here the words “state of change-of-lineage” should be understood to include the prenascence conditions for the fruition attainment, the fruition attainment, and the prenascence conditions for the first path.

original: vuttānīti veditabbāni, paṭhamamaggapurecārikameva vā gotrabhu avadhinidassanabhāvena
analyzed: vuttāni iti veditabbāni paṭhama magga purecārikam eva vā gotrabhu avadhi nidassana bhāvena
translated: Or alternatively, the state of change-of-lineage is the limit of the prenascence conditions for the first path, and it is stated as such in order to show the limit.

original: gahitaṃ, tato paraṃ maggaphalasamānatāya pana aññesu maggesu maggavīthiyaṃ phalasamāpattivīthiyaṃ
analyzed: gahitam tatas param magga phala samāna tāya pana aññesu maggesu magga vīthiyam phala samāpatti vīthiyam
translated: But after that, in the other paths, in the path phase and in the fruition attainment phase,

original: nirodhānantarañca pavattamānesu phalesu nibbāne ca pavatti nivāritā āsavānanti veditabbā.🔽Savantīti gacchanti. Duvidho hi avadhi abhividhivisayo anabhividhivisayo ca. Abhividhivisayaṃ🔽kiriyā byāpetvā pavattati “ābhavaggā bhagavato yaso gato”ti, itaraṃ bahi katvā “āpāṭaliputtā
analyzed: nirodha anantaram ca pavattamānesu phalesu nibbāne ca pavatti nivāritā āsavānanti veditabbā  savanti iti gacchanti duvidhaḥ hi avadhi abhividhi visayaḥ ca abhividhi visayam  kiriyā byāpetvā pavattati ābha vaggā bhagavataḥ yasaḥ gatā iti itaram bahis katvā āpāṭaliputtā
translated: and in the fruitions that occur next to cessation and in Nibbāna, the occurrence of defilements is prevented.

original: vuṭṭho devo”ti. Ayañca ā-kāro abhividhiattho idha gahitoti “antokaraṇattho”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Cirapārivāsiyaṭṭho ciraparivutthatā purāṇabhāvo. Ādi-saddena “purimā, bhikkhave,
analyzed: vuṭṭhaḥ devo ti ayam ca ākāraḥ abhividhi atthaḥ idha gahito ti antokaraṇa atthaḥ iti vuttam  cira pārivāsiya aṭṭhaḥ cira parivuttha tā purāṇa bhāvaḥ ādi saddena purimā bhikkhave
translated: They go: this is a word for a limit. For there are two kinds of limits, namely, that which is the sphere of the known and that which is not the sphere of the known. The first kind is that which occurs by encompassing the sphere of the known, as in “The Blessed One’s fame has gone to the world” . The second kind is that which occurs by excluding the sphere of the known, as in “The rain has stopped and the sky is clear” . But the letter a is here taken in the sense of the sphere of the known, and that is why it is said, “The meaning of the inside” .

original: koṭi na paññāyati bhavataṇhāyā”ti idaṃ suttaṃ saṅgahitaṃ. Avijjāsavabhavāsavānañca
analyzed: na paññāyati bhava taṇhāya ati idam suttam saṅgahitam avijja āsava bhava āsavānam ca
translated: The meaning of long continuance is the state of being long continued, the state of being ancient. The word “etc.” includes the sutta: “Bhikkhus, there is no determining the beginning of the round of rebirths for beings … caught up in birth, decay, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair” . And the words “the cankers of ignorance and of being” include the cankers of sensual desire, of becoming, of wrong view, and of ignorance.

original: ciraparivutthatāya dassitāya tabbhāvabhāvīnaṃ kāmāsavadiṭṭhāsavānañca ciraparivutthatā
analyzed: cira parivuttha tāya dassitāya tad bhāva bhāvīnam kāma āsava diṭṭha āsavānam ca cira parivuttha tā
translated: And by the showing of the long-standingness of the defilements, the showing of the long-standingness of the taints of sensual desire and of views is also effected.

original: dassitā hoti. Aññesupi yathāvutte dhamme okāsañca ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānesu mānādīsu
analyzed: dassitā hoti aññesu pi yathā vutte dhamme okāsam ca ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānesu māna ādīsu
translated: And in the case of the others, too, namely, conceit, etc., that occur taking as their object and as their proximate cause the states already mentioned,

original: vijjamānesu attattaniyādiggāhavasena abhibyāpanaṃ madakaraṇavasena āsavasadisatā
analyzed: vijjamānesu atta tta niyā diggāha vasena abhibyāpanam mada karaṇa vasena āsava sadisa tā
translated: the expression of them by the assumption of “I” and “mine” and so on, and their resemblance to taints in intoxicating,

original: ca etesaṃyeva, nāññesanti etesveva āsavasaddo niruḷho daṭṭhabbo. Āyataṃ vā savanti
analyzed: ca etesam yeva na aññesanti etesu eva āsava saddo niruḷhaḥ daṭṭhabbo āyatam vā savanti
translated: are the same. So the word “taint” should be understood to be established in the same way in them too.

original: phalantīti āsavā. Na hi kiñci saṃsāradukkhaṃ āsavehi vinā uppajjamānaṃ atthīti. Ārammaṇabhāvena
analyzed: phalanti iti āsavā na hi kiñci saṃsāra dukkham āsavehi vinā uppajjamānam atthi iti ārammaṇa bhāvena
translated: Or alternatively, they flow out in length , thus they are taints . For there is no suffering in the round of rebirths that arises without taints.

original: ye dhammā vaṇo viya āsave paggharanti, te asampayoge atabbhāvepi saha āsavehīti sāsavā, āsavavantoti attho.
analyzed: ye dhammāḥ vaṇaḥ viya āsave paggharanti te asampayoge a tabbhāve pi saha āsavehi iti sa āsavāḥ āsavavanto ti attho
translated: Those states that flow out with taints like a wound with pus, are “with taints” , in the sense of having taints, though they may not be associated with taints or have taints as their object.

original: Osānaduke “no āsavā kho panā”ti avatvā “āsavavippayuttā kho panā”ti vacanaṃ sāsavānaṃ
analyzed: osāna duke no āsavā kho pana ati avatvā āsava vippayuttā kho pana ati vacanam sa āsavānam
translated: In the last line of the verse, instead of saying “not taints” he says “not associated with taints” in order to show that the states with taints are not themselves taints.

original: sahetukānaṃ viya sampayuttehi taṃsahitatā na hotīti dassanatthaṃ. Evaṃ sesagocchakesupi
analyzed: sa hetukānam viya sampayuttehi tad sahita tā na hoti iti dassana attham evam sesa gocchakesu pi
translated: and the purpose of the clause is to show that they are not associated with the associated states as the states with roots are with the roots.

original: yathāsambhavaṃ vippayuttaggahaṇe payojanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Apica “no āsavā kho pana dhammā🔽sāsavā”ti idaṃ padaṃ catutthaduke dutiyapadena ninnānaṃ, na ca ekena duko hoti, tasmā
analyzed: yathāsambhavam vippayutta ggahaṇe payojanam daṭṭhabbam apica no āsavā kho pana dhammā  idam padam catuttha duke dutiya padena ninnānam na ca ekena dukaḥ tasmā
translated: The purpose of the inclusion of the dissociated should be understood in the other sections in the way appropriate to each case.

original: āsavavippayuttapadameva gahetvā osānadukayojanā ñāyāgatāti katā. Hetugocchake pana
analyzed: āsava vippayutta padam eva gahetvā osāna duka yojanā katā hetu gocchake pana
translated: Moreover, the clause “States that are not themselves cankers but are associated with cankers” is included in the fourth dyad by the second clause, “States that are associated with cankers,” and it is not included by the first dyad. Therefore the explanation of the last dyad is rightly given by taking only the clause “States that are dissociated from cankers.”

original: hetuvippayuttānaṃ sahetukatā natthīti te gahetvā dukayojanāya asakkuṇeyyattā nahetupadaṃ🔽gahetvā osānadukayojanā katā. Ye vā pana paṭhame duke dutiyassa pakkhepe eko, tatiyassa
analyzed: hetu vippayuttānam sa hetuka tā natthi iti te gahetvā duka yojanāya a sakkuṇeyya ttā na hetu padam  gahetvā osāna duka yojanā katā ye vā pana paṭhhame duke dutiyassa pakkhepe ekaḥ tatiyassa
translated: But in the case of the section on roots, since those dissociated from roots have no roots, they cannot be explained by the dyads by taking them. Therefore the explanation of the last dyad is given by taking the clause “States that are not roots.”

original: dve, paṭhamassa dutiye eko, tatiye dve, dutiyassa tatiye eko, dutiye ca tatiyassa
analyzed: dve paṭhamassa dutiye ekaḥ tatiye dve dutiyassa tatiye ekaḥ dutiye ca tatiyassa
translated: Or alternatively, in the first dyad one is included in the second pentad, two in the third, one in the second dyad of the second pentad, two in the third, one in the third dyad of the second pentad, and two in the third dyad of the first pentad.

original: ekoti aṭṭha dukā labbhanti, tesu tīhi itare ca nayato dassitāti veditabbā. Esa nayo sesagocchakesupi.
analyzed: ekaḥ iti aṭṭha dukāḥ labbhanti tesu tīhi itare ca nayataḥ dassitā ati veditabbā esa nayo sesa gocchakesu pi
translated: The eight dyads are obtained by one, and the rest are shown by the method in the dyads. This method applies to the other sections too.

original: 20-25. Kilesakammavipākavaṭṭānaṃ paccayabhāvena tattha saṃyojenti, satipi aññesaṃ🔽tappaccayabhāve na vinā saṃyojanāni tesaṃ tappaccayabhāvo atthi, orambhāgiyuddhambhāgiyasaṅgahitehi🔽ca taṃtaṃbhavanibbattakakammaniyamo bhavaniyamo ca hoti, na ca upacchinnasaṃyojanassa
analyzed: kilesa kamma vipāka vaṭṭānam paccaya bhāvena tattha saṃyojenti sati pi aññesam  tad paccaya bhāve na vinā saṃyojanāni tesam tad paccaya bhāvaḥ atthi orambhāgiya uddhambhāgiya saṅgahitehi  ca taṃ taṃ bhava nibbattaka kamma niyamaḥ bhava niyamaḥ ca hoti na ca upacchinna saṃyojanassa
translated: They connect there by way of condition for the defilements, kamma, and result. Even though others are conditions for them,🔽there is no conditionality for them without the fetters. And the determination of the kamma that generates the respective kinds of becoming and the determination of becoming are included in the lower and higher fetters.🔽But when the fetters are cut, the kammas do not generate becoming.

original: katānipi kammāni bhavaṃ nibbattentīti. Saṃyojetabbāti vā saṃyojaniyā, saṃyojane niyuttāti
analyzed: katāni api kammāni bhavam nibbattenti iti saṃyojetabbā ati vā saṃyojaniyā saṃyojane niyuttā ati
translated: Or they are called fetter-originated because they are to be fettered, or because they are bound to the fetters.

original: vā. Dūragatassapi ākaḍḍhanato nissarituṃ appadānavasena bandhanaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, ganthakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vā dūra gatassa api ākaḍḍhanataḥ nissaritum appadāna vasena bandhanam saṃyojanam gantha karaṇam
translated: A fetter is a bond in the sense of not letting go, of dragging back even one who has gone far, and of not allowing escape.

original: saṅkhalikacakkalakānaṃ viya paṭibaddhatākaraṇaṃ vā ganthanaṃ gantho, saṃsilisakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhalika cakkalakānam viya paṭibaddha tā karaṇam vā ganthanam gantho saṃsilisa karaṇam
translated: A tie is a binding in the sense of causing to be bound, like a rope, a chain, or a fetter, or in the sense of causing to be tied up, like a bundle of reeds.

original: yojanaṃ yogoti ayametesaṃ visesoti veditabbo. Dhammānaṃ sabhāvakiccavisesaññunā pana
analyzed: yojanam yogo ti ayam etesam visesaḥ ti veditabbaḥ dhammānam sabhāva kicca visesaññunā pana
translated: The difference between them should be understood as this.

original: bhagavatā sampayuttesu ārammaṇesu tappaccayesu ca tehi tehi nipphādiyamānaṃ taṃ taṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā sampayuttesu ārammaṇesu tad paccayesu ca tehi tehi nipphādiyamānam tam tam
translated: But the Blessed One, who knows the specific nature and function of states,🔽sees that the various functions are produced in the associated states and in the object conditions, etc.,

original: kiccavisesaṃ passantena te te dhammā tathā tathā āsavasaṃyojanaganthādivasena vuttāti
analyzed: kicca visesam passantena te te dhammā tathā tathā āsava saṃyojana gantha ādi vasena vuttā ati
translated: and he describes those states as “cankers,” “fetters,” “bonds,” and so on, in the various ways given in the texts.

original: “kimatthaṃ eteyeva dhammā evaṃ vuttā, kasmā ca vuttā eva puna vuttā”ti na codetabbametaṃ.🔽26-37. Ganthaniyāti ettha ayamañño attho “ganthakaraṇaṃ ganthanaṃ, ganthane niyuttāti🔽ganthaniyā, ganthayituṃ sakkuṇeyyā, ganthayituṃ arahantīti vā ganthaniyā”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: kimattham ete iva dhammā evam vuttā kasmā ca vuttāḥ eva puna vuttā ati na codetabbam etam  ganthaniyā ati ettha ayam aññaḥ atthaḥ gantha karaṇam ganthanam ganthane niyuttā ati  ganthaniyā ganthayitum sakkuṇeyyā ganthayitum arahanti iti vā ganthaniyā ati evam
translated: So it should not be asked: “Why are only these states described in these ways? Why are they described in these ways and no others?”🔽As to “subject to cankers”: the meaning here is this. “Cankering” is the act of causing a canker. Those subject to cankering are those engaged in cankering, those capable of cankering, those deserving to canker.

original: oghaniyādīsupi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenātikkamatīti etaṃ dhātvatthaṃ gahetvā oghaniyāti padasiddhi katā.
analyzed: ogha niyā ādīsu pi daṭṭhabbam tena atikkamati iti etam dhātvattham gahetvā ogha niyā ati
translated: So too with those “subject to floods,” and so on. The word “subject” is formed from the verbal root ti, “to cross,” and the verbal root is taken in the sense of “to go beyond.”

original: 50-54. Dhammasabhāvaṃ aggahetvā parato āmasantīti parāmāsā. Paratoti niccādito. Āmasantīti sabhāvapaṭisedhena parimajjanti.
analyzed: dhamma sabhāvam aggahetvā paratas āmasanti iti parāmāsā paratas ti nicca āditas āmasanti iti sabhāva paṭisedhena parimajjanti
translated: They are misapprehensions because they misapprehend what is other than the individual essence of dhammas. What is other than the individual essence is permanence, etc. They misapprehend it by misconstruing it through the individual essence.

original: 55-68. Sabhāvato vijjamānaṃ avijjamānaṃ vā vicittasaññāya saññitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ aggahetvā🔽appavattito ālambamānā dhammā sārammaṇā. Cintanaṃ gahaṇaṃ ārammaṇūpaladdhi. Cetasi
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ vijjamānam a vijjamānam vā vicitta saññāya saññitam ārammaṇam aggahetvā  appavattitaḥ ālambamānāḥ dhammā sa ārammaṇā cintanam gahaṇam ārammaṇa upaladdhi cetasi
translated: They are objects of consciousness because they are the objects of consciousness that occurs by apprehending as a single thing a single object consisting of a diversity of individual essences, whether existent or non-existent.🔽Thinking is the apprehending of an object, the experiencing of an object.🔽They are mental factors because they are bound up with the mind or because they are mixed up with the mind.

original: niyuttā, cetasā saṃsaṭṭhā vā cetasikā. Dubbiññeyyanānattatāya ekībhāvamivupagamanaṃ🔽nirantarabhāvupagamanaṃ. Yesaṃ rūpānaṃ cittaṃ sahajātapaccayo hoti, tesaṃ cittassa
analyzed: niyuttā cetasā saṃsaṭṭhā vā cetasikā dubbiññeyya nānatta tāya ekībhāvam iva upagamanam  nirantara bhāva upagamanam yesam rūpānam cittam sahajāta paccayaḥ hoti tesam cittassa
translated: The state of being a single thing is the state of being uninterrupted.

original: ca suviññeyyanānattanti nirantarabhāvānupagamanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ekato vattamānāpīti
analyzed: ca su viññeyya nānattam ti nirantara bhāva anupagamanam veditabbam ekatas vattamānā api iti
translated: It should be understood that the state of being uninterrupted is the state of being a single thing in the case of the consciousnesses that are conascent conditions for the material dhammas, and in the case of the material dhammas that are conascent conditions for the consciousnesses.

original: api-saddo ko pana vādo ekato avattamānāti etamatthaṃ dīpeti. Idamettha vicāretabbaṃ
analyzed: api saddaḥ kaḥ pana vādaḥ ekatas avattamānā ti etam attham dīpeti idam ettha vicāretabbam
translated: The words “even though they occur separately” indicate the meaning “how much less when they occur together.” Herein, this should be investigated:

original: – avinibbhogarūpānaṃ kiṃ aññamaññaṃ saṃsaṭṭhatā, udāhu visaṃsaṭṭhatāti? Visuṃ ārammaṇabhāvena
analyzed: avinibbhoga rūpānam kim aññam aññam saṃsaṭṭha tā udāhu visaṃsaṭṭha tā ati visum ārammaṇa bhāvena
translated: Are the kinds of materiality that are not-interdependently-originated mixed up with each other or not? They are not mixed up with each other, because their individual difference is easily discerned as object.

original: suviññeyyanānattattā na saṃsaṭṭhatā, nāpi visaṃsaṭṭhatā saṃsaṭṭhāti anāsaṅkanīyasabhāvattā.
analyzed: su viññeyya nānatta ttā na saṃsaṭṭha tā na api visaṃsaṭṭha tā saṃsaṭṭhāti an āsaṅkanīya sabhāva ttā
translated: Nor are they unmixed, because they are not of a kind to be suspected of being mixed up.

original: Catunnañhi khandhānaṃ aññamaññaṃ saṃsaṭṭhasabhāvattā rūpanibbānehipi so saṃsaṭṭhabhāvo🔽atthi natthīti siyā āsaṅkā, tasmā tesaṃ itarehi, itaresañca tehi visaṃsaṭṭhasabhāvatā
analyzed: catunnam hi khandhānam aññamaññam saṃsaṭṭha sabhāva ttā rūpa nibbānehi pi saḥ saṃsaṭṭha bhāvaḥ  atthi natthi iti siyā āsaṅkā tasmā tesam itarehi itaresam ca tehi visaṃsaṭṭha sabhāva tā
translated: For there might be the suspicion that the four aggregates are mixed up with materiality in the sense of being its opposite, since they are of a kind to be mixed up with each other.🔽So their being unmixed with the materiality and the materiality’s being unmixed with them is stated.🔽But there is no suspicion that the materiality is mixed up with materiality anywhere, so its being unmixed with materiality is not stated.

original: vuccati, na pana rūpānaṃ rūpehi katthaci saṃsaṭṭhatā atthīti tadāsaṅkābhāvato visaṃsaṭṭhatā🔽ca rūpānaṃ rūpehi na vuccatīti. Esa hi tesaṃ sabhāvoti. Cittasaṃsaṭṭhasamuṭṭhānādipadesu
analyzed: vuccati na pana rūpānam rūpehi katthaci saṃsaṭṭha tā atthi iti tad āsaṅka abhāvataḥ visaṃsaṭṭha tā  ca rūpānam rūpehi na vuccati iti esa hi tesam sabhāvaḥ ti citta saṃsaṭṭha samuṭṭhāna ādi padesu
translated: That is its individual essence.

original: saṃsaṭṭhasamuṭṭhānādisaddā cittasaddāpekkhāti paccekaṃ cittasaddasambandhattā cittasaṃsaṭṭhā
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭha samuṭṭhāna ādi saddā citta sadda apekkhā ati paccekam citta sadda sambandha ttā citta saṃsaṭṭhā
translated: In the words “arisen together with consciousness” and so on, the words “arisen together” and so on are construed with the word “consciousness” separately, so they are “mixed up with consciousness” in the sense of being associated with it.

original: ca te cittasamuṭṭhānā cāti paccekaṃ yojetvā attho vutto. Upādiyantevāti bhūtāni gaṇhanti
analyzed: ca te citta samuṭṭhānā ca ati paccekam yojetvā atthaḥ vuttaḥ upādiyante iva ati bhūtāni gaṇhanti
translated: and they are also originated by consciousness. The meaning is stated by taking each of them separately. They are clung-to because they are clung-to, that is, appropriated, by the elements.

original: eva, nissayanti evāti attho. Yathā bhūtāni upādiyanti gayhanti nissīyanti, na tathā
analyzed: eva nissayanti eva ati atthaḥ yathā bhūtāni upādiyanti gayhanti nissīyanti na tathā
translated: The meaning is that they are relied on. They are not clung-to in the way that the elements are clung-to, appropriated, and relied on,

original: etāni gayhanti nissīyanti, tasmā upādā. Atha vā bhūtāni amuñcitvā tesaṃ vaṇṇanibhādibhāvena gahetabbato upādā.
