translated: The definition of the doors by way of the kamma is this: the kamma defines the doors by way of the body, etc., as the doors of the body, etc., because it is the kamma that defines the bodily kamma, etc., as being the doors of the body, etc. Or alternatively, the kamma defines the doors by way of the body, etc., because the bodily kamma, etc., are discerned by the body, etc., even though they occur in the doors of the other two kamma-doors, since the nature of killing-living-beings, etc., is such that they are discerned by the body, etc., and because the nature of the kamma to be accomplished by the body, etc., is discerned even though it is expressed by the order, the gesture of the hand, etc. Therefore the kamma does not give the name of a door to another door even though it occurs in it, nor does the door give its own name to the kamma. But the kamma itself gives its own name to the door in which it occurs, and the door itself gives its own name to the kamma that occurs in it. Thus the definition of each by the other is established.

original: aññamaññavavatthānaṃ. Pubbe pana dvāresu anibaddhatā kammānaṃ dvārantaracaraṇameva🔽sandhāya vuttā, na etaṃ vavatthānanti.
analyzed: aññamañña vavatthānam pubbe pana dvāresu anibaddha tā kammānam dvāra antara caraṇam eva 🔽sandhāya vuttāḥ naḥ etam vavatthānanti
translated: But previously, when the kamma was not yet defined by way of the doors, it was said that the kamma occurs in the other door as well, referring only to the occurrence in the other door, not to the definition.

original: Tatthāti tesu dvārakammesu. Kāyakammassa uppajjanaṭṭhānanti taṃsahajātā viññattiyeva🔽vuccati. Kiñcāpi hi sā tassa kenaci pakārena paccayo na hoti, tathāpi kammassa visesikā
analyzed: tattha āti tesu dvāra kammesu kāya kammassa uppajjana ṭṭhānan ti tad sahajātā viññattiyā eva  vuccati kiñcā api hi sā tassa kenaci pakārena paccayaḥ na hoti tathā api kammassa visesikā
translated: Herein, as regards the two kinds of action, the source of bodily action is the intimation that is conascent with it.

original: viññatti taṃsahajātā hotīti tassa uppattiṭṭhānabhāvena vuttā yathāvuttaniyamena aññavisesanassa🔽kammassa visesanantare uppattiabhāvā. Kāyena pana katattāti kāyaviññattiṃ janetvā
analyzed: viññatti tad sahajātā hoti iti tassa uppatti ṭṭhāna bhāvena vuttā yathā vutta niyamena añña visesanassa  kammassa visesana ntare uppatti abhāvā kāyena pana kata ttā ti kāya viññattim janetvā
translated: Although that is not a condition for it in any way, still it is said to be the source of that action because it is the intimation that distinguishes the action, and it is conascent with it, since no other action that would distinguish it occurs in the way already stated.

original: tāya jīvitindriyupacchedādinipphādanato attano nipphattivasena “kāyena kataṃ kamma”nti
analyzed: tāya jīvitindriya upaccheda ādi nipphādanataḥ attanaḥ nipphatti vasena kāyena katam kammanti
translated: But as to “done by bodily intimation”: having generated the bodily intimation, it is called “action done by the body” in the sense of its own result, since it produces the severance of the life faculty, etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Kāraṇabhūto hi panettha kāyoti.🔽Aññamaññaṃ vavatthitāti ettha kammunā kāyo kāyakammadvāranti evaṃ vavatthito, na
analyzed: vuttam kāraṇa bhūtaḥ hi pana ittha kāyaḥ iti  aññam aññam vavatthitā ati ettha kammunā kāyaḥ kāya kamma dvāran ti evam vavatthitaḥ na
translated: For the body is the reason here.🔽As to “distinguished from each other”: here the body is distinguished as “bodily action” and “door of bodily action,” not as “body” alone,

original: kāyo icceva. Yathā sūcikammunā sūcikammakaraṇanti vavatthitā, na sūci icceva, tathā
analyzed: kāyaḥ iccā iva yathā sūci kammunā vavatthitā na sūci iccā iva tathā
translated: just as the needle is distinguished as “needlework” and “work done with a needle,” not as “needle” alone,

original: idampi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aññamaññaṃ vavatthitāti ca aññamaññaṃ visesitāti attho. Evaṃ santeti
analyzed: idam pi daṭṭhabbam aññamaññam vavatthitā ati ca aññamaññam visesitā ati attho evam santā iti
translated: If that is so,

original: yathāvuttaṃ vavatthānaniyamaṃ aggahetvā “dvāre caranti kammānī”tiādivacanameva gahetvā
analyzed: yathā vuttam vavatthāna niyamam aggahetvā dvāre caranti kammāni iti ādi vacanam eva gahetvā
translated: then, without taking the distinction and definition as stated, he accuses the Exalted One of contradicting the statement “The kamma is the door-moving” and so on.

original: codeti. Tattha evaṃ santeti kammānaṃ dvāracaraṇe aññamaññena ca vavatthāne nāmalābhe🔽visesane satīti attho.
analyzed: codeti tattha evam santā iti kammānam dvāra caraṇe aññamaññena ca vavatthāne nāma lābhe  visesane sati iti attho
translated: Herein, if that is so means if there is the obtaining of the name, the distinction, and the definition of the kamma as door-moving and as mutually exclusive.🔽The meaning is: if there is the distinction and definition of the kamma as door-moving and as mutually exclusive.

original: Kāyakammadvārakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāya kamma dvāra kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the section on bodily action as a door is ended.

original: Vacīkammadvārakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vacī kamma dvāra kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the section on verbal action as a door

original: Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatāti ettha subhāsitabhāsanasaṅkhātā apisuṇavācā,🔽dhammabhāsanasaṅkhāto asamphappalāpo, piyabhāsanasaṅkhātā apharusavācā, saccabhāsanasaṅkhāto
analyzed: catūhi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgatā ati ettha su bhāsita bhāsana saṅkhātā apisuṇa vācā  dhamma bhāsana saṅkhātaḥ a samphappalāpaḥ piya bhāsana saṅkhātā a pharusa vācā sacca bhāsana saṅkhātaḥ
translated: “Endowed with four factors”: here the intention that is the verbal action of speaking what is well spoken, which is called “non-malicious speech,”

original: amusāvādo cāti etā vācā tathāpavattā cetanā daṭṭhabbā. Sahasaddā panāti tassa vikārassa
analyzed: amusāvādaḥ ca ati etā vācā tathā pavattā cetanā daṭṭhabbā saha saddā pana ati tassa vikārassa
translated: the intention that is the verbal action of speaking the Dhamma, which is called “non-frivolous speech,” the intention that is the verbal action of speaking what is dear, which is called “non-harsh speech,” and the intention that is the verbal action of speaking the truth, which is called “truthful speech”—these verbal actions should be seen.

original: saddena saha sambhūtattā vuttaṃ. Cittānuparivattitāya pana so na yāva saddabhāvīti
analyzed: saddena saha sambhūta ttā vuttam citta anuparivatti tāya pana saḥ na yāva sadda bhāvī iti
translated: But together with the sound means that it is said thus because it is produced together with the sound of that transformation. But it does not last as long as the sound exists, because it turns with the mind.

original: daṭṭhabbo, vitakkavipphārasaddo na sotaviññeyyoti pavattena mahāaṭṭhakathāvādena🔽cittasamuṭṭhānasaddo vināpi viññattighaṭṭanena uppajjatīti āpajjati. “Yā tāya vācāya
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ vitakka vipphāra saddaḥ na sota viññeyyaḥ ti pavattena mahā aṭṭhakathā vādena  citta samuṭṭhāna saddaḥ vinā api viññatti ghaṭṭanena uppajjati iti āpajjati yā tāya vācāya
translated: and that the sound of the in-breath and out-breath is not cognizable by the ear,🔽then he would be landed in the absurdity that sound originated by consciousness arises without the impact of configurations.

original: viññattī”ti hi vacanato asotaviññeyyasaddena saha viññattiyā uppatti natthīti viññāyatīti.🔽Cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ saddāyatananti ettha ca na koci cittasamuṭṭhāno saddo asaṅgahito
analyzed: viñatti iti hi vacanataḥ a sota viññeyya saddena saha viññattiyāḥ uppatti natthi iti viññāyati iti  citta samuṭṭhānam sadda āyatanam ti ettha ca na koci citta samuṭṭhānaḥ saddaḥ asaṅgahitaḥ
translated: For it is clear from the words, “The intimation of that speech” , that there is no arising of intimation together with sound that is not cognizable by the ear.

original: nāma atthīti adhippāyena mahāaṭṭhakathāvādaṃ paṭisedheti. Chabbidhena rūpasaṅgahādīsu
analyzed: nāma atthi iti adhippāyena mahā aṭṭhakathā vādam paṭisedheti chabbidhena rūpa saṅgaha ādīsu
translated: And in the passage, “Sound as a mental datum originated by consciousness” , he rejects the view of the Great Commentary by the intention that there is no sound originated by consciousness that is not included there.

original: hi “sotaviññeyya”nti “diṭṭhaṃ suta”nti ettha “suta”nti ca na koci saddo na saṅgayhatīti.
analyzed: hi sota viññeyyanti diṭṭham sutanti ettha sutanti ca na koci saddaḥ na saṅgayhati iti
translated: For in the sixfold enumeration of the aggregate of material form, and in the passage, “Seen, heard, sensed, cognized” , there is no sound that is not included.

original: Mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana viññattisahajameva jivhātālucalanādikaravitakkasamuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam pana viññatti sahajam eva jivhā tālu calana ādi kara vitakka samuṭṭhitam
translated: But in the Great Commentary, the sound of the movement of the tongue and palate, etc., which is originated by applied thought and is conascent with intimation,

original: sukhumasaddaṃ “dibbasotena sutvā ādisatī”ti sutte paṭṭhāne ca oḷārikasaddaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: sukhuma saddam dibba sotena sutvā ādisati iti sutte paṭṭhāne ca oḷārika saddam sandhāya
translated: is called “subtle sound.” And in the sutta passage, “Having heard with the divine ear … he intimates it to others” , and in the commentary passage,🔽“Having heard with the divine ear … he intimates it to others,”

original: “sotaviññāṇassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo”ti vuttanti iminā adhippāyena asotaviññeyyatā
analyzed: sota viññāṇassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ti vuttan ti iminā adhippāyena a sota viññeyya tā
translated: “The sound is a condition, as object condition, for ear-consciousness” is said with the intention that it is not cognizable by the ear.

original: vuttā siyā. Saddo ca asotaviññeyyo cāti viruddhametanti pana paṭikkhepo veditabbo.
analyzed: vuttā siyā saddo ca a sota viññeyyaḥ ca ati viruddham etat ti pana paṭikkhepaḥ veditabbo
translated: But the refutation should be understood as follows: “It is contradictory to say that sound is not cognizable by the ear and that it is cognizable by the ear.”🔽The impact of intimation is the impact of intimation. Or it is intimation itself.

original: Viññattipaccayā ghaṭṭanā viññattighaṭṭanā. Viññatti eva vā. Ghaṭṭanākārappavattabhūtavikāro
analyzed: viññatti paccayā ghaṭṭanā viññatti ghaṭṭanā viññatti eva vā ghaṭṭana ākāra ppavatta bhūta vikāro
translated: For the modification of the primary elements that occurs in the mode of impact is called “impact.”

original: hi “ghaṭṭanā”ti vutto. Saṅghaṭṭanena saheva saddo uppajjati, na pubbāparabhāvena.
analyzed: hi ghaṭṭana ati vuttaḥ saṅghaṭṭanena saha iva saddaḥ uppajjati na pubba apara bhāvena
translated: The sound arises together with the impact, not in a prior or subsequent part.

original: Pathavīdhātuyāti idaṃ vāyodhātuyā viya cālanaṃ pathavīdhātuyā saṅghaṭṭanaṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: idam vāyodhātuyā cālanam pathavī dhātuyā saṅghaṭṭanam kiccam
translated: As to the earth element: this is said because the function of the earth element is conascence, unlike that of the air element, which is moving.

original: adhikanti katvā vuttaṃ, vikārassa ca tappaccayabhāvo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tabbikārānañhi
analyzed: adhikam ti katvā vuttam vikārassa ca tad paccaya bhāvaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: The state of being a condition for the modification should be understood in the way already stated.🔽For the primary elements that have been modified are a condition, as object condition, for each other.

original: bhūtānaṃ aññamaññassa paccayabhāvoti. Aññampi sabbaṃ vidhānaṃ kāyaviññattiyaṃ viya veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhūtānam aññam aññassa paccaya bhāvaḥ ti aññam pi sabbam vidhānam kāyaviññattiyam viya veditabbam
translated: And the rest of the explanation should be understood like that for bodily intimation.

original: Tisamuṭṭhānikakāyaṃ…pe… na labbhati. Na hi cālanaṃ upādinnaghaṭṭananti. Cālanañhi
analyzed: na labbhati na hi cālanam upādinna ghaṭṭanan ti cālanam hi
translated: The body that is the triple-originated kind … is not found. For the moving is not the impact of the clung-to.

original: desantaruppādanaparamparatā, ghaṭṭanaṃ paccayavisesena bhūtakalāpānaṃ āsannataruppādoti.🔽Upatthambhanakiccampi natthīti upatthambhanena vinā paṭhamacittasamuṭṭhānāpi ghaṭṭanākārena
analyzed: desantara uppādana parampara tā ghaṭṭanam paccaya visesena bhūta kalāpānam āsanna taru ppādaḥ ti  upatthambhana kiccam pi natthi iti upatthambhanena vinā paṭhama citta samuṭṭhānā api ghaṭṭana ākārena
translated: The succession of the arising of the distant is the succession of the arising of the near. The impact is the arising of the mass of primaries in proximity by means of the specific condition.🔽And there is no function of supporting: without supporting, the impact occurs in the mode of impulsion even with the first consciousness.

original: pavattatīti ghaṭṭanatthaṃ upatthambhanena payojanaṃ natthi, laddhāsevanena citteneva
analyzed: pavattati iti ghaṭṭana attham upatthambhanena payojanam natthi laddha āsevanena cittena iva
translated: So there is no need for supporting in order to impact, since the impact is strong enough with the consciousness that has obtained practice.

original: ghaṭṭanassa balavabhāvato cāti adhippāyo. Upatthambhanaṃ natthi atthīti vicāretvā gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ghaṭṭanassa balava bhāvataḥ ca ati adhippāyaḥ upatthambhanam natthi atthi iti vicāretvā gahetabbam
translated: The intention is this. The impact is not supported. It should be taken after considering whether there is or is not supporting.

original: Vacīkammadvārakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vacī kamma dvāra kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the section on the verbal doors is ended.

original: Manokammadvārakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: manaḥ kamma dvāra kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the mental door

original: Ayaṃ nāma cetanā kammaṃ na hotīti na vattabbāti idaṃ yassa dvāraṃ mano, taṃdassanatthaṃ
analyzed: ayam nāma cetanā kammam na hoti iti na vattabbā ati idam yassa dvāram manaḥ tad dassana attham
translated: The words “This or that volition is not to be spoken of as action” are said in order to show that the door of which the mind is the door.

original: vuttaṃ. Kappetīti “tvaṃ phusanaṃ karohi, tvaṃ vedayita”nti evaṃ kappentaṃ viya pavattatīti
analyzed: vuttam kappeti iti tvam phusanam karohi tvam vedayitanti evam kappentam viya pavattati iti
translated: The meaning is that it occurs as if it were appointing thus: “You do the touching, you do the feeling.”

original: attho. Pakappanañca tadeva. Kiṃ piṇḍaṃ karotīti āyūhanatthavasena pucchati. Phassādidhamme
analyzed: tat eva kim piṇḍam karoti iti āyūhana attha vasena pucchati phassa ādi dhamme
translated: And the appointing is that same volition. “What does it make into a unity?” He asks this in order to show the purpose of the accumulation.

original: hi avippakiṇṇe katvā sakiccesu pavattanaṃ āyūhanaṃ, tattheva byāpāraṇaṃ cetayanaṃ,
analyzed: hi a vippakiṇṇe katvā sa kiccesu pavattanam āyūhanam tattha iva byāpāraṇam cetayanam
translated: The act of directing oneself to one’s own duties after avoiding distraction is “accumulation.” The act of engaging in that is “aiding.”

original: tathākaraṇaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇanti. Tebhūmakasseva gahaṇaṃ lokuttarakammassa kammakkhayakarattā.
analyzed: tathā karaṇam tebhūmakassa iva gahaṇam lokuttara kammassa kamma kkhaya kara ttā
translated: The act of doing it in that way is “forming.” The reason for mentioning only the three planes is that it is the supramundane kamma that causes the destruction of kamma.

original: Manokammadvārakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: manaḥ kamma dvāra kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the section on mental action as door is ended.

original: Kammakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kamma kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on kamma

original: Cetayitvā kammaṃ karotīti ettha yasmā purimacetanāya cetayitvā sanniṭṭhānakammaṃ
analyzed: cetayitvā kammam karoti iti ettha yasmai purima cetanāya cetayitvā sanniṭṭhāna kammaṃ
translated: “Having intended, one performs kamma” . Since one performs the kamma of resolution after having intended with a previous intention,

original: karoti, tasmā cetanāpubbakaṃ kammaṃ taṃcetanāsabhāvamevāti cetanaṃ ahaṃ kammaṃ vadāmīti
analyzed: karoti tasmā cetanā pubbakam kammam cetanam aham kammam vadāmi iti
translated: the kamma is preceded by intention. It is of the nature of that intention, thus the meaning is that I declare intention to be kamma.

original: attho. Atha vā samānakālattepi kāraṇakiriyā pubbakālā viya vattuṃ yuttā, phalakiriyā
analyzed: atthaḥ atha vā samāna kāla tte pi kāraṇa kiriyā pubba kālāḥ viya vattum yuttā phala kiriyā
translated: Or else, even though they are of the same time, the act of the cause is suitable to be spoken of as if it were prior, and the act of the fruit

original: ca aparakālā viya. Yasmā ca cetanāya cetayitvā kāyavācāhi copanakiriyaṃ manasā ca
analyzed: ca yasmai ca cetanāya cetayitvā manasā ca
translated: as if it were subsequent. And since one performs the act of the body and speech after having intended with intention, and one performs the act of the mind such as covetousness,

original: abhijjhādikiriyaṃ karoti, tasmā tassā kiriyāya kārikaṃ cetanaṃ ahaṃ kammaṃ vadāmīti
analyzed: abhijjhā ādi kiriyam karoti tasmā tassā kiriyāya kārikam cetanam aham kammam vadāmi iti
translated: therefore I declare intention to be kamma, the doer of that act.

original: attho. Kāye vāti kāyaviññattisaṅkhāte kāye vā. Satīti dharamāne, anirodhite vā. Kāyasamuṭṭhāpikā🔽cetanā kāyasañcetanā. Ettha ca sukhadukkhuppādakena kammena bhavitabbaṃ, cetanā ca
analyzed: attho kāye vā ati kāya viññatti saṅkhāte kāye vā sati iti dharamāne a nirodhite vā kāya samuṭṭhāpikā  cetanā kāya sañcetanā ettha ca sukha dukkha uppādakena kammena bhavitabbam cetanā ca
translated: In the body: in the body called “bodily intimation” or in the body. Mindfulness: present, not ceased.🔽Bodily intimation: the volition that originates in the body. And here it is necessary that there be a kamma that produces pleasure and pain, and volition is said to produce pleasure and pain,

original: sukhadukkhuppādikā vuttāti tassā kammabhāvo siddho hoti. Sañcetaniyanti sañcetanasabhāvavantaṃ.
analyzed: sukha dukkha uppādikā vuttā ati tassā kamma bhāvo siddho hoti sañcetaniyanti sañcetana sabhāvavantam
translated: so its being kamma is established. Intentionally: possessing the nature of intention.

original: Samiddhittherena “sañcetaniyaṃ, āvuso…pe… manasā sukhaṃ so vedayatī”ti avibhajitvā🔽byākato. Sukhavedanīyantiādinā pana vibhajitvā byākātabbo so pañho, tasmā sammā byākato🔽nāma na hoti. Itaradvayepi eseva nayo. Yathā pana suttāni ṭhitāni, tathā copanakiriyānissayabhūtā
analyzed: manasā sukham saḥ vedayati iti a vibhajitvā  byākataḥ sukha vedanīya nti ādinā pana vibhajitvā byākātabbo so pañho tasmā sammā byākato  nāma na hoti itara dvaye pi esā iva nayaḥ yathā pana suttāni ṭhitāni tathā copana kiriyā nissaya bhūtā
translated: The Elder Samiddhi answered, “Intentionally, friend … he feels pleasure with the body,” without analyzing it.

original: kāyavācā abhijjhādikiriyānissayo ca manodvārāni, yāya pana cetanāya tehi kāyādīhi
analyzed: kāya vācā abhijjhā ādi kiriyā nissayo ca manaḥ dvārāni yāya pana cetanāya tehi kāya ādīhi
translated: But the question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition.” The question should be analyzed and answered thus: “The intention that produces pleasure is bodily volition. The intention that produces pain is bodily volition. The intention that produces neither pain nor pleasure is bodily volition

original: karaṇabhūtehi copanābhijjhādikiriyaṃ karonti vāsiādīhi viya chedanādiṃ, sā cetanā
analyzed: karaṇa bhūtehi copana abhijjhā ādi kiriyam karonti vāsi ādīhi chedana ādim sā cetanā
translated: And the state of being a means is like the state of being a knife, etc., for cutting, etc.,

original: kammanti dvārappavattiyampi kammadvārābhedanañca kammadvāravavatthānañca dissati,
analyzed: kammanti dvāra ppavattiyam pi kamma dvāra abhedanam ca kamma dvāra vavatthānañca dissati
translated: and the state of being a door is like the state of being an eye, etc., for visible data, etc.

original: evañca sati “kāyena ce kataṃ kamma”ntiādigāthāyo ativiya yujjanti.
analyzed: evam ca sati kāyena ce katam yujjanti
translated: And when that is so, the verses beginning, “By body, speech, and mind as well” , are very appropriate.

original: Lokuttaramaggo idha lokiyakammakathāyaṃ anadhippetopi bhajāpiyamāno tīṇi kammāni
analyzed: lokuttara maggo idha lokiya kamma kathā ayam anadhippetaḥ api tīṇi kammāni
translated: The supramundane path, though not intended here in the exposition of the kinds of kamma in the world, is included when the kinds of kamma are included, and it is included in the three kinds of kamma.

original: bhajati. Manena dussīlyanti kāyikavācasikavītikkamavajjaṃ sabbaṃ akusalaṃ saṅgaṇhāti,🔽micchādiṭṭhisaṅkappavāyāmasatisamādhiṃ vā. Tampi cetaṃ “manasā saṃvaro sādhū”ti vuttassa
analyzed: bhajati kāyika vācasika vītikkama vajjam sabbam akusalam saṅgaṇhāti  micchā diṭṭhi saṅkappa vāyāma sati samādhim vā tam pi ca itam manasā saṃvaro sādhu iti vuttassa
translated: And the words “and the unvirtuousness of mind” include all unprofitable kamma consisting in bodily and verbal transgression and in the taint of sensual desire, etc.,🔽and wrong view, thought, effort, mindfulness, and concentration.🔽And this is said as the opposite of the restraint of mind spoken of in the passage, “But the restraint of mind is good” ,

original: saṃvarassa paṭipakkhavasena vuttaṃ, na sīlavipattivasena. Na hi sā mānasikā atthīti
analyzed: saṃvarassa paṭipakkha vasena vuttam na sīla vipatti vasena na hi sā mānasikā atthi iti
translated: and not as a failure in virtue. For there is no mental kamma of failure in virtue.

original: maggasseva bhajāpanaṃ mahāvisayattā. Bojjhaṅgā hi manokammameva bhajeyyuṃ, na ca
analyzed: maggassa iva mahā visaya ttā bojjhaṅgāḥ hi manaḥ kammam eva bhajeyyum na ca
translated: The inclusion of the path is because of its great scope. For the enlightenment factors would only include mental kamma, and that is not enough.

original: na sakkā maggabhajāpaneneva tesaṃ bhajāpanaṃ viññātunti.
analyzed: na sakkā magga bhajāpanena iva tesam bhajāpanam viññātunti
translated: and it is not possible to know their performance by the mere performance of the path.

original: Kammapathaṃ appattānampi taṃtaṃdvāre saṃsandanaṃ avarodhanaṃ dvārantare kammantaruppattiyampi
analyzed: kamma patham appattānam pi taṃ taṃ dvāre saṃsandanam avarodhanam dvāra antare kamma antara uppattiyam pi
translated: And the performance of the act of opening a door, which is the connecting and obstructing of the various doors of kamma, even though it is not reached by the path of kamma,🔽is called the opening of the door of kamma. “Bhikkhus, there are three kinds of bodily volitions,

original: kammadvārābhedanañca dvārasaṃsandanaṃ nāma. “Tividhā, bhikkhave, kāyasañcetanā akusalaṃ
analyzed: kamma dvāra abhedanam ca dvāra saṃsandanam nāma tividhā bhikkhave kāya sañcetanā akusalam
translated: unprofitable, unprofitable kamma, and indeterminate.

original: kāyakamma”ntiādinā kammapathappattāva sanniṭṭhāpakacetanā kammanti vuttāti purimacetanā🔽sabbā kāyakammaṃ na hotīti vuttaṃ. Āṇāpetvā…pe… alabhantassāti āṇattehi amāritabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kāya kamma nti ādinā kamma patha ppattā ava sanniṭṭhāpaka cetanā kammanti vuttā ati purima cetanā  sabbā kāya kammam na hoti iti vuttam a labhantassa ati āṇattehi a mārita bhāvam
translated: So it is said that the volition that concludes the act is the kamma.🔽All volition is not bodily kamma.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ nāma hoti akammapathabhāvatoti adhippāyo. “Ime sattā🔽haññantū”ti pavattabyāpādavasena cetanāpakkhikā vā bhavanti kāyakammavohāralābhā.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam vacīduccaritam nāma hoti a kammapatha bhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ ime sattā  haññantu uti pavatta byāpāda vasena cetanā pakkhikāḥ vā bhavanti kāya kamma vohāra lābhā
translated: When he has had it announced … and they do not get it, the words “and they do not get it” are said with reference to the fact that the slaves are not dead. The intention is that there is verbal misconduct, but it is not reached by the path of kamma. “These beings🔽should be killed” is the kind of volition that occurs. It is called bodily kamma and verbal conduct.

original: Abbohārikā vā manokammavohāravirahā. Sasambhārapathavīādīsu āpādayo ettha nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: abbohārikāḥ vā manaḥ kamma vohāra virahāḥ sa sambhāra pathavī ādīsu āpa ādayaḥ ettha nidassanam
translated: Or it is called mental kamma because it is devoid of verbal conduct. The elements earth, water, fire, and air, together with the requisites, are the illustration here.

original: Kulumbassāti gabbhassa, kulasseva vā. Tissopi saṅgītiyo āruḷhatāya ananujānanato
analyzed: kulumbassa ati gabbhassa kulassa iva vā tissaḥ api saṅgītiyaḥ āruḷha tāya an anujānanato
translated: ‘Of Kulumba’s’ means of the embryo, or of the family itself. ‘Tissa’s’ is said because he did not allow the recitation to be undertaken.

original: “tava suttassā”ti vuttaṃ. Dasavidhā iddhi paṭisambhidāmagge iddhikathāya gahetabbā.
analyzed: tava suttassa ati vuttam dasavidhā iddhi paṭisambhidā magge iddhi kathāya gahetabbā
translated: The ten kinds of psychic power should be understood from the discussion of psychic power in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: Bhāvanāmayanti adhiṭṭhāniddhiṃ sandhāya vadati. Ghaṭabhedo viya parūpaghāto, udakavināso🔽viya iddhivināso ca hotīti upamā saṃsandati. Tava pañhoti bhāvanāmayāya parūpaghāto
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna iddhim sandhāya vadati ghaṭa bhedaḥ viya udaka vināsaḥ  viyaḥ iddhi vināso ca hoti iti upamā saṃsandati tava bhāvanā mayāya
translated: ‘Of the kind produced by development’ is said with reference to the psychic power of resolve. The simile of the breaking of the water-pot and the destruction of the psychic power like the destruction of the water are appropriate.🔽‘Your question’ is the meaning that is intended to be made known, that is, that is wished to be made known, namely, that there is destruction of the psychic power of the kind produced by development.

original: hotīti vutto ñāpetuṃ icchito attho. Āthabbaṇiddhi vijjāmayiddhi hoti. Sattame padeti
analyzed: hoti iti vuttaḥ ñāpetum icchitaḥ atthaḥ hoti sattame pade iti
translated: The psychic power of the kind produced by spells is psychic power produced by knowledge.

original: maṇḍalādito sattame pade.🔽Vacanantarena gametabbatthaṃ neyyatthaṃ, sayameva gamitabbatthaṃ nītatthaṃ. Kiriyato
analyzed: maṇḍala ādeḥ sattame pade  vacana ntarena gametabba attham neyya ttham sayam eva gamitabba attham nīta ttham
translated: ‘In the seventh step’ means in the seventh place from the circle.🔽The meaning that is to be understood by another statement is the indirect meaning; the meaning that is to be understood by oneself is the direct meaning.

original: samuṭṭhāti, udāhu akiriyatoti tenādhippetaṃ sampajānamusāvādaṃ sandhāya pucchati,
analyzed: samuṭṭhāti udāhu tena adhippetam sampajāna musāvādam sandhāya pucchati
translated: ‘Does it arise from action or from inaction?’ is what is intended. He asks with reference to the deliberate lie.

original: na uposathakkhandhake vuttaṃ. Tattha avuttameva hi so anariyavohāraṃ vuttanti gahetvā
analyzed: na uposatha khandhake vuttam tattha avuttam eva hi so anariya vohāram vuttan ti gahetvā
translated: It is not stated in the Khandhaka on the Uposatha. For what is not stated there he takes to be stated, and he misrepresents it.

original: voharatīti. Vācāgiranti vācāsaṅkhātaṃ giraṃ, vācānuccāraṇaṃ vā.
analyzed: voharati iti vācā giranti vācā a saṅkhātam giram vācā an uccāraṇam vā
translated: Speech-fault: speech-called-fault, or speech-utterance.

original: Khandasivādayo seṭṭhāti khandāti kumārā. Sivāti mahessarā, micchādiṭṭhiyā nidassanatthamidaṃ
analyzed: khanda siva ādayo seṭṭhā ati khandāti kumārā sivāti mahessarā micchādiṭṭhiyā nidassana attham idam
translated: The princes are called “khandas,” the great kings “sivas.” This is said

original: vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Natthikadiṭṭhādayo eva hi kammapathappattā kammanti. Cetanā
analyzed: vuttanti daṭṭhabbam natthika diṭṭha ādayaḥ eva hi kamma patha ppattā kammanti cetanā
translated: for the purpose of showing wrong view. For the views of non-existence, etc., are simply action that has reached the status of a path. Intention

original: panettha abbohārikāti kāyadvāre vacīdvāre ca samuṭṭhitāpi kāyakammaṃ vacīkammanti
analyzed: pana ittha abbohārikā ati kāya dvāre vacī dvāre ca samuṭṭhitā api kāya kammam vacī kammanti
translated: is not included here. Although it arises in the door of the body and in the door of speech, bodily action and verbal action

original: ca vohāraṃ na labhati abhijjhādippadhānattā. “Tividhā, bhikkhave, manosañcetanā akusalaṃ
analyzed: ca vohāram na labhati abhijjhā ādi ppadhāna ttā tividhā bhikkhave manaḥ sañcetanā akusalam
translated: are not obtained, because of the predominance of covetousness, etc. “Bhikkhus, there are three kinds of mental volitions that are unwholesome mental action” .

original: manokamma”nti pana vacanato sabhāveneva sā manokammaṃ, na abhijjhādipakkhikattāti
analyzed: mano kammanti pana vacanato sabhāvena iva sā mano kammam na abhijjhā ādi pakkhika ttā ti
translated: But because of the statement, it is mental action by its very nature, and not because of being a factor of covetousness, etc.

original: “abhijjhādipakkhikāvā”ti na vuttaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne kāyaṅgavācaṅgāni acopetvā
analyzed: abhijjhā ādi pakkhikā vā ti na vuttam imasmin pana ṭhāne kāyaṅga vācaṅgāni a copetvā
translated: Therefore it is not said that it is a factor of covetousness, etc. But in this place, without mentioning the bodily and verbal factors,

original: cintanakāle cetanāpi cetanāsampayuttadhammāpi manodvāre eva samuṭṭhahanti, tasmā
analyzed: cintana kāle cetanā api cetanā sampayutta dhammā api manaḥ dvāre eva samuṭṭhahanti tasmā
translated: At the time of thinking, volition and the states associated with volition arise only in the mind door. Therefore

original: cetanāya abbohārikabhāvo kathañci natthīti adhippāyo.🔽“Tividhā, bhikkhave, kāyasañcetanā kusalaṃ kāyakamma”ntiādivacanato pāṇātipātādipaṭipakkhabhūtā
analyzed: cetanāya abbohārika bhāvo kathañci natthi iti adhippāyaḥ  tividhā bhikkhave kāya sañcetanā kusalam kāya kamman ti ādi vacanato pāṇātipāta ādi paṭipakkha bhūtā
translated: the intention is that there is no way in which volition is not the most obvious.🔽“Bhikkhus, there are three kinds of bodily volitions, a profitable bodily action” .

original: tabbirativisiṭṭhā cetanāva pāṇātipātaviratiādikā hontīti “cetanāpakkhikā vā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: tad virati visiṭṭhā cetanā ava pāṇātipāta virati ādikāḥ honti iti cetanā pakkhikāḥ vā ti vuttam
translated: Therefore the volitions that are the opposite of killing living beings, etc., and that are the most excellent of all, are themselves the abstentions from killing living beings, etc. Thus it is said that they are “on the side of volition,”

original: na “viratipakkhikā”ti. Rakkhatīti avināsetvā katheti. Bhindatīti vināsetvā katheti.
analyzed: na virati pakkhikā ati rakkhati iti a vināsetvā kathā iti bhindati iti vināsetvā kathā iti
translated: not on the side of abstention. “He guards” : he makes by not destroying. “He breaks” : he makes by destroying.

original: Kammakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Cakkhuviññāṇadvāranti cakkhuviññāṇassa dvāraṃ. Cakkhu ca taṃ viññāṇadvārañcāti vā🔽cakkhuviññāṇadvāraṃ. Cakkhu viññāṇadvāranti vā asamāsaniddeso. Taṃ pana cakkhumeva.
analyzed: kamma kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  cakkhu viññāṇa dvāran ti cakkhu viññāṇassa dvāram cakkhu ca tam viññāṇa dvāram ca ati vā  cakkhu viññāṇa dvāram cakkhu viññāṇa dvāram ti vā asamāsa niddeso tam pana cakkhum eva
translated: The exposition of the section on action is ended.🔽Eye-consciousness door: the door for eye-consciousness. Or: it is the eye and it is a door for consciousness, thus it is an eye-consciousness door. Or: the eye is the consciousness door, this is a non-compounded designation. But that is only the eye.

original: Esa nayo sesesupi. “Cakkhunā saṃvaro sādhū”tiādikāya gāthāya pasādakāyacopanakāyasaṃvare
analyzed: esa nayo sesesu pi cakkhunā saṃvaro sādhu uti ādikāya gāthāya
translated: The same method applies in the case of the rest . “ Restraint by the eye is good” , etc., are verses about the restraint of the eye, etc., and the non-restraint of the eye, etc.

original: ekajjhaṃ katvā kāyena saṃvaro vutto, taṃ idha bhinditvā aṭṭha saṃvarā, tappaṭipakkhabhāvena🔽asaṃvarā aṭṭha kathitā. Sīlasaṃvarādayopi pañceva saṃvarā sabbadvāresu uppajjamānāpi,
analyzed: ekajjham katvā kāyena saṃvaraḥ vuttaḥ tam idha bhinditvā aṭṭha saṃvarā tad paṭipakkha bhāvena  asaṃvarā aṭṭha kathitā sīla saṃvara ādayaḥ pi pañcā iva saṃvarā sabba dvāresu uppajjamānā api
translated: Restraint is said to be one, but it is divided here into eight kinds,

original: tappaṭipakkhabhāvena dussīlyādīni asaṃvarāti vuttāni. Tattha dussīlyaṃ pāṇātipātādicetanā.
analyzed: tad paṭipakkha bhāvena dussīlya ādīni vuttāni tattha dussīlyam pāṇātipāta ādi cetanā
translated: and non-restraint is said to be eight kinds, being the opposites of the eight kinds of restraint. The five beginning with virtue restraint are also restraint, but they are called “bad conduct” and so on, being the opposites of the eight kinds of non-restraint, though they arise in the same five doors. Herein, bad conduct is the volition of killing breathing things, and so on.

original: Muṭṭhassaccaṃ satipaṭipakkhā akusalā dhammā. Pamādanti keci. Sītādīsu paṭigho akkhanti.
analyzed: muṭṭhassaccam sati paṭipakkhāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ pamādanti keci sītā ādīsu paṭighaḥ
translated: Some say that lack of mindfulness is unwholesome states opposed to mindfulness. Indolence is laziness.

original: Thinamiddhaṃ kosajjaṃ.🔽Vinā vacīdvārena suddhaṃ kāyadvārasaṅkhātanti idaṃ vacīdvārasallakkhitassa musāvādādinopi🔽kāyadvāre pavattisabbhāvā asuddhatā atthīti taṃnivāraṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Na hi taṃ kāyakammaṃ
analyzed: thinam iddham kosajjam  vinā vacī dvārena suddham kāya dvāra saṅkhātanti idam vacī dvāra sallakkhitassa musāvāda ādinaḥ api  kāya dvāre pavatti sabbhāvā asuddha tā atthi iti tad nivāraṇa attham vuttam na hi tam kāya kammam
translated: Sloth-and-torpor is sluggishness.🔽“Pure in the sense-sphere of body, leaving aside the speech-door” is said in order to exclude the impurity of such things as lying, which are classed as speech-doors,🔽since they occur in the sense-sphere of body. For that is not bodily action;

original: hoti. Suddhavacīdvāropalakkhitaṃ pana vacīkammameva hotīti. Ettha asaṃvaroti etena
analyzed: hoti suddhavacī dvāra upalakkhitam pana vacī kammam eva hoti iti ettha etena
translated: it is only verbal action classed as the sense-sphere of speech. Herein, “non-restraint” is said

original: suddhakāyadvārena upalakkhito asaṃvaro dvārantare uppajjamānopi vutto. Dvārantarānupalakkhitaṃ🔽sabbaṃ taṃdvārikākusalañceti veditabbaṃ. Evañca katvā kammapathasaṃsandane “copanakāyaasaṃvaradvāravasena🔽uppajjamāno asaṃvaro akusalaṃ kāyakammameva hotī”tiādi “akusalaṃ kāyakammaṃ copanakāyaasaṃvaradvāravasena
analyzed: suddha kāya dvārena upalakkhitaḥ asaṃvaraḥ dvāra antare uppajjamānaḥ api vuttaḥ dvāra antara anupalakkhitam  sabbam tat dvārikā kusalam ca iti veditabbam evam ca katvā kamma patha saṃsandane copana kāya asaṃvara dvāra vasena  uppajjamānaḥ asaṃvaraḥ akusalam kāya kammam eva hoti itiādi akusalam kāya kammam copana kāya asaṃvara dvāra vasena
translated: Non-restraint, which is manifested by the bodily door, is called “arisen by way of the bodily door” even when it arises by way of the mental door.🔽All that is unwholesome that is not manifested by the doors should be understood as “arisen by way of the bodily door.”🔽When it is stated thus, there is no contradiction in the explanation of the courses of kamma in the Paṭṭhāna: “Non-restraint is unwholesome bodily kamma arisen by way of the bodily door and by way of non-restraint.”

original: vacīasaṃvaravasena ca uppajjatī”tiādinā saha aviruddhaṃ hoti. Asaṃvaro hi dvārantare🔽uppajjamānopi sadvāre evāti vuccati, sadvāravasena uppannoti ca, kammaṃ aññadvāre
analyzed: vacī asaṃvara vasena ca uppajjati iti ādinā saha aviruddham hoti asaṃvaraḥ hi dvāra antare  uppajjamānaḥ api sa dvāre eva ati vuccati sa dvāra vasena uppannaḥ ti ca kammam añña dvāre
translated: And also: “Unwholesome bodily kamma is arisen by way of the bodily door and by way of non-restraint and by way of verbal restraint.”🔽For although non-restraint arises by way of the mental door, it is called “arisen by way of the six doors” and “arisen by way of the six doors.”

original: aññadvāravasena cāti evaṃ aviruddhaṃ.
analyzed: añña dvāra vasena ca ati evam aviruddham
translated: And kamma is arisen by way of the other doors and by way of the other doors.

original: Atha vā etthāti suddhaṃ asuddhanti etaṃ avicāretvā etasmiṃ copaneti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: atha vā ettha ati suddham a suddham ti etam a vicāretvā etasmin copanā iti vuttam hoti
translated: Or else, “here” means “without investigating whether it is pure or impure, it is stated as ‘arisen by way of the bodily door.’”

original: Evaṃ sati dvārantaropalakkhitaṃ kammapathabhāvappattatāya vacīmanokammaṃ copanakāyaasaṃvaradvāre
analyzed: evam sati dvāra antara upalakkhitam kammapatha bhāva ppatta tāya vacī manaḥ kammam copana kāya asaṃvara dvāre
translated: When it is stated thus, verbal and mental kamma, which have reached the state of courses of kamma by being manifested by the mental door, are called “arisen by way of the bodily door and by way of non-restraint.”

original: uppannaṃ, sesaṃ sabbaṃ taṃdvāruppannākusalaṃ viya “copanakāyaasaṃvaro”ti vuccati.
analyzed: uppannam sesam sabbam tat dvāra uppanna akusalam viya copana kāya asaṃvaro ti vuccati
translated: and the rest is called “restraint by cognizance arisen by reaction” like the unprofitable cognizance arisen by reaction.

original: Kammapathabhāvappattiyā dvārantaruppannaṃ kāyakammañca tathā na vuccatīti kammapathasaṃsandanavirodho
analyzed: kamma patha bhāva ppattiyā dvāra antar uppannam kāya kammam ca tathā na vuccati iti kamma patha saṃsandana virodho
translated: But the bodily action that is arisen by reaction to the door is not called that, and so there is a contradiction in the application of the terms of the courses of action.

original: siyā, tadavirodhaṃ tattheva vakkhāma. Sīlasaṃvarādayo pañca nikkhepakaṇḍe āvi bhavissanti.
analyzed: siyā tad avirodham tattha eva vakkhāma sīla saṃvara ādayaḥ pañca nikkhepa kaṇḍe bhavissanti
translated: But we shall explain the non-contradiction of that in the appropriate place. The five beginning with virtue of restraint are dealt with in the chapter on the Refuges.

original: Tattha ñāṇasaṃvare paccayasannissitasīlassa, vīriyasaṃvare ca ājīvapārisuddhiyā antogadhatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tattha ñāṇa saṃvare paccaya sannissita sīlassa vīriya saṃvare ca ājīva pārisuddhiyāḥ antogadha tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: Herein, virtue dependent on requisites should be regarded as included in the virtue of restraint, and purification of livelihood as included in the energy of restraint.

original: Akusalakammapathakathāvaṇṇanā🔽Saraseneva ca patanasabhāvassa pāṇassa antarā eva atīva pātanaṃ atipāto, saṇikaṃ
analyzed: akusala kammapatha kathā vaṇṇanā  sa rasena iva ca patana sabhāvassa pāṇassa antarā eva atīva pātanam atipātaḥ saṇikam
translated: The unprofitable courses of action🔽and the falling of the hand that is naturally falling is excessive falling, and the meaning is that it falls quickly without allowing itself to fall slowly.

original: patituṃ adatvāva sīghaṃ pātananti attho. Atikkamma vā satthādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanaṃ
analyzed: patitum a datvā ava sīgham pātanam ti atthaḥ atikkamma vā sattha ādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanam
translated: Or alternatively, excessive falling is falling after exceeding the stick, etc., and overcoming them.

original: atipāto. Payogavatthumahantatādīhi mahāsāvajjatā tehi paccayehi uppajjamānāya cetanāya
analyzed: atipātaḥ payoga vatthu mahanta tā ādīhi mahā sāvajja tā tehi paccayehi uppajjamānāya cetanāya
translated: The excessive blameableness due to the greatness of the means, the object, and so on, is due to the volition that arises with those conditions.

original: balavabhāvato. Yathāvuttapaccayavipariyāyepi taṃtaṃpaccayehi uppajjamānāya cetanāya🔽balavābalavavaseneva appasāvajjamahāsāvajjatā veditabbā. Iddhimayo kammavipākajiddhimayo
analyzed: balava bhāvataḥ yathā vutta paccaya vipariyāye pi taṃ taṃ paccayehi uppajjamānāya cetanāya  balava abalava vasena iva appa sāvajja mahā sāvajja tā veditabbā iddhi mayo kamma vipāka jiddhi mayo
translated: and by strength. And in the opposite way to the stated conditions, too, the volition that arises through the various conditions should be understood as less blameworthy or more blameworthy according to the strength or weakness of the conditions. The supernormal power that is a natural endowment, the supernormal power that is kamma-result,🔽🔽

original: dāṭhākoṭikādīnaṃ viya.🔽Gottarakkhitā sagottehi rakkhitā. Dhammarakkhitā sahadhammikehi rakkhitā. Sasāmikā🔽sārakkhā. Yassā gamane raññā daṇḍo ṭhapito, sā saparidaṇḍā. Atthabhañjakoti kammapathappattaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Kammapathakathā hesāti. Attano santakaṃ adātukāmatāyātiādi musāvādasāmaññato
analyzed: dāṭhā koṭikā dīnam  gotta rakkhitā sa gottehi rakkhitā dhamma rakkhitā sahadhammikehi rakkhitā sa sāmikā  sa ārakkhā yassā gamane raññā daṇḍo ṭhapito sā sa paridaṇḍā attha bhañjakā iti kammapatha ppattam  vuttam kammapatha kathā ha isā ti attanaḥ santakam a dātu kāma tāya atiādi musāvāda sāmaññato
translated: As to strength: in the opposite way to the order of the conditions stated, the volition that arises through the several conditions should be understood as less blameworthy or more blameworthy according to the strength or weakness of the conditions. The power of supernormal power is that of supernormal power born of kamma-result.

original: vuttaṃ. Hasādhippāyena visaṃvādanapurekkhārasseva musāvādo. Suññabhāvanti pītivirahitatāya🔽rittataṃ. Atthavipannatāya na hadayaṅgamā. Aggaṇhanteti asaddahante kammapathabhedo
analyzed: vuttam hasa adhippāyena visaṃvādana purekkhārassa iva musāvādaḥ pīti virahita tāya 🔽attha vipanna tāya na hadayaṅgamāḥ aggaṇhanta iti a saddahante kamma patha bhedaḥ

original: na hoti. Yo koci pana samphappalāpo dvīhi sambhārehi sijjhatīti. Attano pariṇāmanaṃ
analyzed: na hoti yaḥ koci pana samphappalāpaḥ dvīhi sambhārehi sijjhati iti attano pariṇāmanaṃ
translated: But any idle chatter succeeds by means of two requisites.

original: cittenevāti veditabbaṃ. Micchā passatīti vitathaṃ passati.
analyzed: cittena iva ati veditabbam micchā passati iti vitatham passati
translated: It should be understood that the transformation is by means of the mind.🔽He sees wrongly: he sees falsely.

original: Koṭṭhāsatoti phassapañcamakādīsu cittaṅgakoṭṭhāsesu ye koṭṭhāsā honti, tatoti attho.
analyzed: koṭṭhāsato ti phassa pañcamaka ādīsu cittaṅga koṭṭhāsesu ye koṭṭhāsāḥ honti tatas ti attho
translated: As to portion: the meaning is as to the portion of the mind among the five aggregates beginning with contact.

original: Nanu ca cetanā kammapathesu na vuttāti paṭipāṭiyā sattannaṃ kammapathabhāvo na yuttoti?
analyzed: nanu ca cetanā kamma pathesu na vuttā ati paṭipāṭiyā kamma patha bhāvaḥ na yutto ti
translated: But surely, since volition is not mentioned among the courses of kamma, it is not proper to say that seven are courses of kamma in the order stated?

original: Na, avacanassa aññahetuttā. Na hi cetanāya akammapathattā kammapatharāsimhi avacanaṃ,
analyzed: na avacanassa añña hetu ttā na hi cetanāya akammapatha ttā kammapatha rāsimhi avacanam
translated: No, because there is another reason for its not being mentioned. For it is not because volition is not a course of kamma that it is not mentioned among the “heap of courses of kamma” .

original: kadāci pana kammapatho hoti, na sabbadāti kammapathabhāvassa aniyatattā avacanaṃ.
analyzed: kadāci pana kamma pathaḥ hoti na sabbadā ati kamma patha bhāvassa aniyata ttā avacanam
translated: But it is not mentioned because its state as a course of kamma is not invariable, since sometimes it is a course of kamma and sometimes not.🔽But when it is a course of kamma, there is no prevention of its being included in the “heap of courses of kamma.”

original: Yadā pana kammapatho hoti, tadā kammapatharāsisaṅgaho na nivāritoti. “Pañca sikkhāpadā
analyzed: yadā pana kamma pathaḥ hoti tadā kamma patha rāsi saṅgaho na nivārito ti pañca sikkhāpadā
translated: The five training precepts🔽are only of a limited scope.

original: parittārammaṇā evā”ti etena adinnādānādīnaṃ sattārammaṇabhāvavirodhaṃ “sattasaṅkhāte
analyzed: paritta ārammaṇāḥ eva iti etena adinnādāna ādīnam satta ārammaṇa bhāva virodham satta saṅkhāte
translated: This contradicts the fact that taking what is not given, etc., have living beings as their object.

original: saṅkhāre eva ārabbha pavattito”ti sayameva pariharissati. “Natthi sattā opapātikā”ti
analyzed: saṅkhāre eva ārabbha pavattito ti sayam eva pariharissati natthi sattā opapātikā ati
translated: The view that occurs thus: ‘There are no beings who reappear after death’

original: pavattamānā diṭṭhi tebhūmakadhammavisayāvāti saṅkhārārammaṇatā vuttā. Vipākanissandaphalāni
analyzed: pavattamānā diṭṭhi tebhūmaka dhamma visayā vā ati saṅkhāra ārammaṇa tā vuttā vipāka nissanda phalāni
translated: has as its domain the dhammas of the three planes.🔽The result is the unhappy destinies, such as hell, and so on.

original: yathākkamaṃ nirayādivipākaduggatatādīni.
translated: The outcome is the suffering of the unhappy destinies, and so on.

original: Akusalakammapathakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: akusala kammapatha kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the unprofitable courses of action is ended.

original: Kusalakammapathakathāvaṇṇanā🔽Pāṇātipātādīhi pana viratiyoti etaṃ yāhi viratīhi sampayuttā cetanā “kāyavacīkammānī”ti🔽vuccanti, tāsañca kammapathabhāvo yuttoti katvā vuttaṃ. Tathā hi vakkhati “paṭipāṭiyā🔽satta cetanāpi vaṭṭanti viratiyopī”ti. Allasasamaṃsanti jīvamānakasasamaṃsaṃ. Voropetā
analyzed: kusala kammapatha kathā vaṇṇanā  pāṇa atipāta ādīhi pana etam yāhi viratīhi sampayuttā cetanā kāya vacī kammāni iti  vuccanti tāsam ca kamma patha bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ ti katvā vuttam tathā hi vakkhati paṭipāṭiyā  satta cetanā api vaṭṭanti jīvamānaka sasa maṃsam
translated: The profitable courses of action

original: hutvā nābhijānāmi. Dussīlyādārammaṇā tadārammaṇā. Jīvitindriyādiārammaṇā kathaṃ dussīlyādīni
analyzed: hutvā na abhijānāmi dussīlyāt ārammaṇā tad ārammaṇā jīvitindriya ādi ārammaṇā katham dussīlya ādīni
