translated: and the jhana of the mind-made is mentioned as being similar to the jhana of all the visible-data, etc., as objects.

original: Avasesehi pana tesaṃ aññesañca sabbavatthudukādīhi yojanāya na labbhantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: avasesehi pana tesam aññesam ca sabba vatthu duka ādīhi yojanāya na labbhanti iti veditabbā
translated: But it is not possible to make them out with the rest by the method of the ‘cloth-piece’ .

original: Uddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the description is ended.

original: Rūpavibhatti
analyzed: rūpa vibhatti
translated: The exposition of matter

original: Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the single terms

original: 594. Avijjamānavibhāgassa vibhāgābhāvadassanameva niddeso nicchayakaraṇato, tasmā
analyzed: a vijjamāna vibhāgassa vibhāga abhāva dassanam eva niddesaḥ nicchaya karaṇato tasmā
translated: The description is the showing of the non-existence of any division in what is undivided. It is the making of a definition.

original: “sabbaṃ rūpaṃ na hetumevā”tiādinā vibhāgābhāvāvadhāraṇena eva-saddena niddesaṃ karoti.
analyzed: sabbam rūpam na hetum eva ati ādinā vibhāga abhāva avadhāraṇena eva saddena niddesam karoti
translated: So he makes the description with the word eva , which is a definition, by the exclusion of any division in the sense of ‘ All matter is not a cause, etc.’ .

original: Hetuhetūti mūlahetu, hetupaccayahetūti vā ayamattho. Mahābhūtā hetūti ayamevattho🔽mahābhūtā paccayoti etenapi vuttoti. Hetupaccayasaddānaṃ samānatthattā paccayo eva
analyzed: hetu hetū iti mūla hetu hetu paccaya hetū ti vā ayam atthaḥ mahābhūtāḥ hetū iti ayam eva atthaḥ  paccayaḥ ti etena api vuttaḥ ti hetu paccaya saddānam samāna attha ttā paccayaḥ eva
translated: Cause and cause-originated: either root-cause and root-cause condition, or this is the meaning. The great primaries are the cause: this is the meaning.

original: hetu paccayahetu. Yo ca rūpakkhandhassa hetu, so eva tassa paññāpanāya hetūti vutto
analyzed: hetu paccaya hetu yaḥ ca rūpa kkhandhassa hetu saḥ eva tassa paññāpanāya hetu iti vuttaḥ
translated: They are the condition, too, by the words ‘ great primaries as condition.’ The words ‘ cause ’ and ‘ condition ’ have the same meaning. The condition is the cause. The cause is the condition. The cause of the materiality aggregate is the same as the cause for its being known.

original: tadabhāve abhāvato. Atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākanti
analyzed: tad abhāve abhāvataḥ atīta anāgata paccuppannānam kamma samādānānam ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ vipākam ti
translated: It is said that it is the cause for its being known because of its non-existence when that does not exist. The ripening of the past, future and present kamma-acquisitions is the cause in the sense of the place of their origination.

original: ettha vijjamānesupi aññesu paccayesu iṭṭhāniṭṭhavipākaniyāmakattā uttamaṃ padhānaṃ
analyzed: ettha vijjamānesu pi aññesu paccayesu iṭṭha aniṭṭha vipāka niyāmaka ttā uttamam padhānam
translated: And since it determines the desirable and undesirable results even when the other conditions are present, it is the supreme condition.

original: kusalākusalaṃ gatiupadhikaālapayogasampattivipattiṭṭhānanipphāditaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇañca🔽kammamiva padhānattā “hetū”ti vuttanti iminā adhippāyena kammārammaṇāni “uttamahetū”ti
analyzed: kusala akusalam gati upadhika āla payoga sampatti vipatti ṭṭhāna nipphāditam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇam ca  kammam iva padhāna ttā hetū ti vuttanti iminā adhippāyena kamma ārammaṇāni uttama hetū ti
translated: And it is the desirable and undesirable object that produces the profitable and unprofitable, and the desirable and undesirable object that produces the states consisting in the attainment of a happy destiny, etc., and the states consisting in the failure to attain a happy destiny, etc.

original: vuttāni. Vakkhati ca “gatiupadhikālapayogā vipākassa ṭhānaṃ, kammaṃ hetū”ti. Idha
analyzed: vuttāni vakkhati ca gati upadhi kāla payogā vipākassa ṭhānam kammam hetu idha
translated: And since it is the supreme condition in the way already stated, it is called “cause” like kamma. It is because of this intention that the objects of kamma are called “supreme causes” in the text. And it is said: “Destiny, sign, and the time of doing, And the place, and kamma too, Are the cause of ripening;

original: pana kammamiva uttamattā ārammaṇampi hetuvacanaṃ arahatīti “uttamahetū”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana kammam iva uttama ttā ārammaṇam pi hetu vacanam arahati iti uttama hetu iti vuttam
translated: But here the object is called a “supreme cause” because it is worthy of the name of cause since it is supreme like kamma.

original: Saṅkhārānanti puññābhisaṅkhārādīnaṃ avijjā sādhāraṇapaccayattā “hetū”ti vuttā. Pharatīti
analyzed: saṅkhāra ananti puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīnam avijjā sādhāraṇa paccaya ttā hetu uti vuttā pharati iti
translated: And ignorance is called “cause” because it is a common condition for the formations consisting in merit, etc., in the way already stated. It “spreads” ;

original: gacchati pāpuṇāti. Paṭikkhepaniddesoti idaṃ mātikāya āgatapaṭikkhepavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gacchati pāpuṇāti paṭikkhepa niddeso ti idam mātikāya āgata paṭikkhepa vasena vuttam
translated: it goes, it reaches.

original: Idha pana mātikāya na hetupadādisaṅgahitatā ca rūpassa vuttā taṃtaṃsabhāvattā, avadhāritatā ca anaññasabhāvato.
analyzed: idha pana mātikāya na hetu pada ādi saṅgahita tā ca rūpassa vuttā taṃ taṃ sabhāva ttā avadhārita tā ca anañña sabhāvato
translated: Here, however, the fact that materiality is not included in the categories of cause, etc., is stated because of its own individual essence, and the fact that it is determined is because of its non-otherness .

original: Rūpīduke rūpīpadameva idha “rūpa”nti vuttaṃ. Tena rūpīrūpapadānaṃ ekatthatā siddhā
analyzed: rūpīduke rūpī padam eva idha rūpan ti vuttam tena rūpī rūpa padānam ekattha tā siddhā
translated: In the “perceptible” triad, the “perceptible” itself is called “materiality” here. Thus the identity of the terms “perceptible” and “materiality” is established.

original: hoti ruppanalakkhaṇayuttasseva rūpīrūpabhāvato. Uppannaṃ chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyanti
analyzed: hoti ruppana lakkhaṇa yuttassa iva rūpī rūpa bhāvataḥ uppannam chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyanti
translated: For it is only that which possesses the characteristic of being molested that is perceptible and material. The words “arisen and cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness”

original: arūpato vidhuraṃ rūpassa sabhāvaṃ dasseti. Na hi arūpaṃ uppannaṃ chahi viññāṇehi
analyzed: arūpataḥ vidhuram rūpassa sabhāvam dasseti na hi arūpam uppannam chahi viññāṇehi
translated: show the individual essence of materiality as devoid of immateriality. For immateriality is not arisen and cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness

original: viññeyyaṃ yathā rūpaṃ, tena rūpaṃ uppannaṃ chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyaṃ, na arūpanti
analyzed: viññeyyam yathā rūpam tena rūpam uppannam chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyam na arūpanti
translated: as materiality is. Therefore, “materiality is arisen and cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness, not immateriality.”

original: arūpato nivattetvā rūpe eva etaṃ sabhāvaṃ niyameti, na rūpaṃ etasmiṃ sabhāve. Atthi
analyzed: arūpataḥ nivattetvā rūpe eva etam sabhāvam niyameti na rūpam etasmin sabhāve atthi
translated: Thus, having excluded immateriality, it determines the individual essence of materiality alone. Materiality is not in that individual essence.

original: hi rūpaṃ atītānāgataṃ yaṃ uppannaṃ chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyasabhāvaṃ na hotīti. Etameva
analyzed: hi rūpam atīta anāgatam yam uppannam chahi viññāṇehi viññeyya sabhāvam na hoti iti etam eva
translated: For there is materiality that is past and future, which is not arisen and cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness.

original: ca niyamaṃ puna evasaddena niyameti “yathāvutto niyamo rūpe atthi eva, arūpe viya
analyzed: ca niyamam punar eva saddena niyama iti yathā vuttaḥ niyamaḥ rūpe atthi eva arūpe viya
translated: And it determines that very individual essence again by the word “only”: “Only that individual essence stated exists in materiality, not in immateriality, as it does in materiality.”

original: na natthī”ti. Atha vā sabbaṃ rūpanti bhūtupādāyarūpaṃ kālabhedaṃ anāmasitvā “sabba”nti🔽vuttaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ arūpehi samānaviññeyyasabhāvaṃ atītānāgataṃ nivattetuṃ uppannanti
analyzed: na natthi iti atha vā sabbam rūpam iti bhūta upādāya rūpam kāla bhedam an āmasitvā sabbanti  vuttam tat sabbam arūpehi samāna viññeyya sabhāvam atīta anāgatam nivattetum uppannanti
translated: “There is no such thing as all materiality.”🔽Or else, “all materiality” is said without specifying any particular time period,🔽and all that is meant to be included is materiality, which is of the same nature as what is cognizable by the eye, etc., in the past, future, and present. In order to exclude the past and future, he says “arisen.”🔽

original: etena viseseti, taṃ uppannaṃ sabbaṃ rūpaṃ chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyamevāti attho.🔽Nanu evaṃ rūpāyatanassapi sotaviññāṇādīhi viññeyyatā āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati rūpaṃ🔽sabbaṃ sampiṇḍetvā ekantalakkhaṇadassanavasena ekībhāvena gahetvā arūpato vidhurassa🔽chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyasabhāvassa dassanato. Paccuppannarūpameva chahi viññāṇehi🔽viññeyyanti etasmiṃ pana niyame “sabbaṃ rūpa”nti etthāyaṃ viññeyyabhāvaniyamo na
analyzed: etena viseseti tat uppannam sabbam rūpam chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyam eva ati attho  nanu evam rūpa āyatanassa api sota viññāṇa ādīhi viññeyya tā āpajjati iti na āpajjati rūpam  sabbam sampiṇḍetvā ekanta lakkhaṇa dassana vasena ekībhāvena gahetvā arūpataḥ vidhurassa  chahi viññāṇehi viññeyya sabhāvassa dassanato paccuppanna rūpam eva chahi viññāṇehi  viññeyyanti etasmin pana niyame sabbam rūpan ti ettha ayam viññeyya bhāva niyamaḥ na
translated: Or else all materiality is called “all” without specifying a time division. That all is of the same nature as what is cognizable by the immaterial dhammas. In order to exclude the past and future, he specifies “present.” The meaning is that all present materiality is cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness.

original: vutto, atha kho paccuppannanti sabbarūpassa ekantalakkhaṇaniyamo dassito na siyā.
analyzed: vuttaḥ atha kho paccuppanna nti sabba rūpassa ekanta lakkhaṇa niyamaḥ dassitaḥ na siyā
translated: But in that case, does not the visible-data base become cognizable by ear-consciousness, etc., too? It does not. For materiality is cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness in the sense that it is all classed together and apprehended as a single concept by seeing its general characteristics without distinguishing its particular characteristics. But it is cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness in the sense that present materiality is cognizable by the six kinds of consciousness. But in the latter case the specification “all” is not stated in the former case, and the specification “present” is not stated in the latter case.

original: Pāḷiyañca viññeyyamevāti eva-kāro vutto, na uppannamevāti. Tasmā uppannasseva manoviññeyyaniyamāpatti
analyzed: pāḷiyam ca viññeyyam evā ti eva kāraḥ vuttaḥ na uppannam evā ti tasmai uppannassa iva manaḥ viññeyya niyama āpatti
translated: The word ‘only’ is stated in the text to show that the meaning is to be construed in the way stated, not that the sound is only what is born.🔽So there is no restriction to the born only as what is cognizable by the mind.

original: natthīti kiṃ sotapatitattena, tasmā vuttanayenattho yojetabbo.🔽Kathaṃvidhanti guṇehi kathaṃ saṇṭhitaṃ. Ñāṇameva ñāṇavatthu. Samānajātikānaṃ saṅgaho,
analyzed: na atthi iti kim tasmā vutta nayena atthaḥ yojetabbo  kathaṃvidhanti guṇehi katham saṇṭhitam ñāṇam eva ñāṇa vatthu samāna jātikānam saṅgahaḥ
translated: What is the point of its being what is born? Therefore the meaning should be construed in the way stated.🔽How is it disposed? —How is it arranged by its qualities?🔽Knowledge is the same as the object of knowledge.🔽The inclusion of those of the same kind is the inclusion of those of the same class.

original: samānajātiyā vā saṅgaho sajātisaṅgaho. Sañjāyanti etthāti sañjāti, sañjātiyā saṅgaho🔽sañjātisaṅgaho, sañjātidesena saṅgahoti attho. Aññamaññopakāravasena avippayogena🔽ca samādhidese jātā sammāsatiādayo samādhikkhandhe saṅgahitā. Yattha ca satiādisahāyavato
analyzed: samāna jātiyā vā saṅgahaḥ sajāti saṅgahaḥ sañjāyanti ettha ati sañjāti sañjātiyā saṅgahaḥ  sañjātisaṅgahaḥ sañjā atidesena saṅgaho ti attho aññamañña upakāra vasena a vippayogena  ca samādhi dese jātā sammā sati ādayo samādhi kkhandhe saṅgahitāḥ yattha ca sati ādi sahāyavataḥ
translated: Those born here are the kinds of being; the inclusion of the kinds of being is the inclusion of the kinds of being.🔽The meaning is that the inclusion is by way of the kinds of being.🔽The states of concentration that are born in the place of concentration are included in the concentration category by non-separation through mutual assistance.🔽And the state of consciousness in which concentration, which has mindfulness, etc., as its companions, performs its own function is a place of concentration.

original: samādhissa attano kiccakaraṇaṃ, so cittuppādo samādhideso. Sammāsaṅkappassa ca appanābhāvato
analyzed: samādhissa attano kicca karaṇam so cittuppādaḥ samādhi deso sammāsaṅkappassa ca appanā bhāvato
translated: And since right thought has no absorption, its function is similar to that of penetration.

original: paṭivedhasadisaṃ kiccanti samānena paṭivedhakiccena diṭṭhisaṅkappā paññakkhandhe saṅgahitā.
analyzed: paṭivedha sadisam kiccanti samānena paṭivedha kiccena diṭṭhi saṅkappā pañña kkhandhe saṅgahitā
translated: So right thought is included in the understanding category by its function of penetrating correctly.

original: Rūpavibhattiekakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rūpa vibhatti ekaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Description of the classification of materiality is ended.

original: Dukaniddeso
analyzed: duka niddeso
translated: The dyad

original: Upādābhājanīyakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādābhājanīya kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the bowl and the refuse-rag robe

original: 596. Apparajakkhādisattasamūhadassanaṃ buddhacakkhu, chasu asādhāraṇañāṇesu indriyaparopariyattañāṇaṃ
analyzed: appara jakkha ādi satta samūha dassanam buddha cakkhu chasu asādhāraṇa ñāṇesu indriya para upari yatta ñāṇam
translated: The Buddha eye is the seeing of the mass of living beings of little dust, etc., and the knowledge of the difference in the acumen of others’ faculties among the six kinds of knowledge not shared by disciples .

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabbasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatadassanaṃ samantacakkhu. “Dukkhaṃ pariññeyyaṃ pariññāta”nti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sabba saṅkhata asaṅkhata dassanam samanta cakkhu dukkham pariññeyyam pariññātam
translated: The knowledge-and-vision eye is the seeing of all formed and unformed states. The knowledge-and-vision eye is the seeing of the four noble truths in the way beginning, “Suffering is to be fully known” .

original: evamādinā ākārena pavattaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ ñāṇacakkhu, tampi purimadvayamiva kāmāvacaraṃ.
analyzed: evamādinā ākārena pavattam ñāṇa dassanam ñāṇa cakkhu tat pi purima dvayam iva kāmāvacaram
translated: That too, like the first two, is of the sense sphere.🔽The Dhamma eye is the seeing of the four noble truths as dhammas.

original: Catusaccadhammadassanaṃ dhammacakkhu. Upatthambhabhūtā catusamuṭṭhānikarūpasantatiyo
analyzed: catu acca dhamma dassanam dhammacakkhu upatthambha bhūtā catu samuṭṭhānika rūpa santatiyaḥ
translated: The “constituents” are the continuity of materiality derived from the four primary elements, which is the support for the eye-consciousness element.🔽“With constituents” is with the constituents, possessing constituents.

original: sambhārā. Saha sambhārehi sasambhāraṃ, sambhāravantaṃ. Sambhavoti āpodhātumeva sambhavasambhūtamāha.
analyzed: sambhārā saha sambhārehi sa sambhāram sambhāravantam āha
translated: “Origination” is the water element, which is the origin of the origination of material instances.🔽“Configuration” is the visible-form base, which is the configuration of the round, etc.

original: Saṇṭhānanti vaṇṇāyatanameva parimaṇḍalādisaṇṭhānabhūtaṃ. Tesaṃ pana visuṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhānam ti vaṇṇa āyatanam eva parimaṇḍala ādi saṇṭhāna bhūtam tesam pana visum vacanam
translated: The separate mention of these two, however,

original: tathābhūtānaṃ atathābhūtānañca āpodhātuvaṇṇāyatanānaṃ yathāvutte maṃsapiṇḍe vijjamānattā.
analyzed: tathābhūtānam a tathābhūtānam ca āpodhātu vaṇṇa āyatanānam yathāvutte maṃsa piṇḍe
translated: and because the visible-data bases consisting of the water element are present in the lump of flesh in the way already stated in the case of those that are and in the case of those that are not.

original: Cuddasasambhāro hi maṃsapiṇḍo. Sambhavassa catudhātunissitehi saha vuttassa dhātuttayanissitatā
analyzed: cuddasa sambhāraḥ hi maṃsa piṇḍaḥ sambhavassa catu dhātu nissitehi saha vuttassa dhātu ttaya nissita tā
translated: For the lump of flesh is a collection of fourteen components. The fact that the three elements are present in the collection of the four elements together with the origination is to be construed as follows:

original: yojetabbā. Āpodhātuvaṇṇāyatanānameva vā sambhavasaṇṭhānābhāvā visuṃ vuttāti catudhātunissitatā
analyzed: yojetabbā āpodhātu vaṇṇa āyatanānam eva vā sambhava saṇṭhāna abhāvā visum vuttā iti catu dhātu nissita tā
translated: or else the visible-data bases consisting of the water element are not mentioned separately because they have no origination and shape. So the fact that the three elements are present in the four elements

original: ca na virujjhati. Yaṃ maṃsapiṇḍaṃ setādinā sañjānanto na pasādacakkhuṃ sañjānāti,
analyzed: ca na virujjhati yam maṃsa piṇḍam seta ādinā sañjānantaḥ na pasāda cakkhum sañjānāti
translated: is not contradicted. When he discerns the lump of flesh as white, etc., he does not discern the eye as sensitive matter;

original: patthiṇṇatādivisesaṃ vattukāmo “pathavīpi atthī”tiādi vuttampi vadati.
analyzed: patthiṇṇa tā ādi visesam vattu kāmo pathavī pi atthi itiādi vuttam pi vadati
translated: and when he wants to say that there is a difference in the way of being entered upon, he says, “Earth is present too,” and so on.

original: Sarīrasaṇṭhānuppattidesabhūteti etena avasesaṃ kaṇhamaṇḍalaṃ paṭikkhipati. Snehamiva
analyzed: sarīra saṇṭhāna uppatti desa bhūtā iti etena avasesam kaṇha maṇḍalam paṭikkhipati sneham iva
translated: By “in the place where the bodily shape originates” he excludes the rest of the black circle. Like the oil

original: sattakkhipaṭalāni byāpetvā ṭhitāheva attano nissayabhūtāhi catūhi dhātūhi katūpakāraṃ
analyzed: satta kkhipaṭalāni byāpetvā ṭhitāhi iva attanaḥ nissaya bhūtāhi catūhi dhātūhi katu upakāram
translated: in sesame seeds, it is present pervading the seven layers of the skin. It is assisted by the four elements that are its support.

original: taṃnissitehi eva āyuvaṇṇādīhi anupālitaparivāritaṃ tisantatirūpasamuṭṭhāpakehi utucittāhārehi
analyzed: tad nissitehi eva āyu vaṇṇa ādīhi anupālita parivāritam ti santati rūpa samuṭṭhāpakehi utu citta āhārehi
translated: It is guarded and protected by the life faculty, etc., which are based on it. It is maintained by the nutriment of temperature, which causes the generation of the three-plane materiality consisting of the octad with physical basis and the octad without physical basis.

original: upatthambhiyamānaṃ tiṭṭhati. Sattakkhipaṭalānaṃ byāpanavacanena ca anekakalāpagatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: upatthambhiyamānam tiṭṭhati satta kkhipaṭalānam byāpana vacanena ca aneka kalāpa gata bhāvam
translated: and it stands supported by them. And by the words “it is spread over the seven bones” he shows that it is to be found in the various parts of the seven bones.

original: cakkhussa dasseti. Pamāṇato ūkāsiramattanti ūkāsiramatte padese pavattanato vuttaṃ.🔽Rūpāni manupassatīti ma-kāro padasandhikaro. Atha vā manūti macco. Upakārabhūtehi
analyzed: cakkhussa dasseti pamāṇataḥ ūkāsiramattanti ūkāsiramatte padese pavattanato vuttam  rūpāni manu passati iti makāro pada sandhi karo atha vā upakāra bhūtehi
translated: As to measure: the size of a span is said because it occurs in a space the size of a span.🔽The word “forms” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “forms” is a collective term for the four primaries.🔽The word “sees” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “sees” is a collective term for the four eye-consciousnesses.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.

original: saṅgahito. Pariyāyenāti catunnaṃ pasādo tesu ekassa dvinnañcātipi vattuṃ yutto samānadhanānaṃ🔽dhanaṃ viyāti etena pariyāyena. Sarīraṃ rūpakkhandho eva. Paṭighaṭṭanameva nighaṃso🔽paṭighaṭṭanānighaṃso. Rūpābhimukhabhāvena cakkhuviññāṇassa nissayabhāvāpattisaṅkhāto
analyzed: saṅgahitaḥ pariyāyena ati catunnam pasādaḥ tesu ekassa vattum yuttaḥ samāna dhanānam  dhanam viyāti etena pariyāyena sarīram rūpa kkhandhaḥ eva paṭighaṭṭanam eva nighaṃsaḥ  paṭighaṭṭana anighaṃsaḥ rūpa abhimukha bhāvena cakkhu viññāṇassa nissaya bhāva āpatti saṅkhāto
translated: The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.

original: paṭighaṭṭanato jāto vā nighaṃso paṭighaṭṭanānighaṃso.
analyzed: paṭighaṭṭanataḥ jātaḥ vā nighaṃsaḥ paṭighaṭṭana anighaṃsaḥ
translated: The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.🔽The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “eye” is a collective term for the four eyes.

original: Parikappavacanaṃ “sace āpāthaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti hetukiriyaṃ, “passeyyā”ti phalakiriyañca
analyzed: parikappa vacanam sace āpātham āgaccheyya ati hetu kiriyam passeyya ati phala kiriyam ca
translated: The word “eye” is a mere demonstrative. Or alternatively, “

original: parikappetvā tena parikappena vacanaṃ. Ettha ca hetukiriyā anekattā avuttāpi viññāyatīti🔽daṭṭhabbā. “Passe vā”ti iminā vacanena tīsupi kālesu cakkhuviññāṇassa nissayabhāvaṃ
analyzed: parikappetvā tena parikappena vacanam ettha ca hetu kiriyā aneka attā a vuttā api viññāyati iti  daṭṭhabbā passe vā ti iminā vacanena tīsu pi kālesu cakkhu viññāṇassa nissaya bhāvam
translated: and the word “seeing” is used in the sense of the function of seeing. And here the eye is to be regarded as the cause of seeing, though not mentioned as such, because of the multiplicity of causes.

original: anupagacchantaṃ cakkhuṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Dassane pariṇāyakabhāvo dassanapariṇāyakaṭṭho.🔽Yathā hi issaro “idañcidañca karothā”ti vadanto tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kicce sapurise pariṇāyati
analyzed: an upagacchantam cakkhum saṅgaṇhāti dassane pariṇāyaka bhāvaḥ dassana pariṇāyaka ṭṭho  yathā hi issaraḥ idam cidam ca karotha ati vadantaḥ tasmim tasmim kicce sa purise pariṇāyati
translated: By the word “seeing” he includes the eye that does not act as the support of eye-consciousness in any of the three instances. The meaning of “seeing” is the meaning of the eye as the instigator of seeing.

original: pavattayati, evamidampi cakkhusamphassādīnaṃ nissayabhāvena te dhamme dassanakicce
analyzed: pavattayati evam idam pi cakkhu samphassa ādīnam nissaya bhāvena te dhamme dassana kicce
translated: For just as a master, when he says, “Do this and that,” instigates, sets going, the men who are his subordinates in the various tasks, so too this eye instigates, sets going, those states beginning with eye-contact in the task of seeing, as if it were ordering them, “You, see!”

original: āṇāpentaṃ viya pariṇāyatīti cakkhūti vuccati. Cakkhatīti hi cakkhu, yathāvuttena
analyzed: āṇāpentam viya pariṇāyati iti cakkhu iti vuccati cakkhati iti hi cakkhu yathā vuttena
translated: That is why it is called “eye” . The meaning is that it makes known, it instigates, in the way already stated.

original: nayena ācikkhati pariṇāyatīti attho. Atha vā samavisamāni rūpāni cakkhati ācikkhati,
analyzed: nayena ācikkhati pariṇāyati iti attho atha vā sama visamāni rūpāni cakkhati ācikkhati
translated: Or alternatively, it is the eye because it sees, it makes known, it reveals, uneven and even visible objects.

original: pakāsetīti vā cakkhu. Sañjāyanti etthāti sañjāti. Ke sañjāyanti? Phassādīni. Tathā
analyzed: pakāseti iti vā cakkhu sañjāyanti ettha ati sañjāti ke sañjāyanti phassa ādīni tathā
translated: The meaning of “origin” is the meaning of the eye as the origin of the states beginning with contact. What is the meaning of “origin”?

original: samosaraṇaṃ. Cakkhusamphassādīnaṃ attano tikkhamandabhāvānupavattanena indaṭṭhaṃ🔽kāretīti. Niccaṃ dhuvaṃ attāti gahitassapi lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena. Vaḷañjanti pavisanti
analyzed: samosaraṇam cakkhu samphassa ādīnam attanaḥ tikkha manda bhāva anupavattanena indaṭṭham  kāreti iti niccam dhuvam attā ati gahitassa api lujjana palujjana aṭṭhena vaḷañjanti pavisanti
translated: and the meeting together of the three. It makes the eye-contact, etc., its own by the occurrence of its own keenness and slowness.

original: etenāti vaḷañjanaṃ, taṃdvārikānaṃ phassādīnaṃ vaḷañjanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: etena ati vaḷañjanam taṃdvārikānam phassa ādīnam vaḷañjana ṭṭhena
translated: It is the “winking” because the eye, etc., enter in and out by means of it.🔽The meaning of “discernment” is the same as that of “discrimination” stated above.

original: 597. Pubbe vutto parikappo eva vikappanattho. Ghaṭṭayamānamevāti pasādassa abhimukhabhāvavisesaṃ gacchantameva.🔽599. Rūpaṃ ārabbha cakkhusamphassādīnaṃ uppattivacaneneva tesaṃ taṃdvārikānaṃ aññesañca
analyzed: pubbe vuttaḥ parikappaḥ eva vikappana atthaḥ ghaṭṭayamānam eva ati pasādassa abhimukha bhāva visesam gacchantam eva  rūpam ārabbha cakkhu samphassa ādīnam uppatti vacanena iva tesam taṃdvārikānam aññesam ca
translated: “Striking”: going to a special state of facing the object.🔽By the statement that eye-contact, etc., arise with visible data as object, it is said that they arise with visible data, etc., as object, and also that other states arise with visible data, etc., as object.

original: rūpaṃ ārabbha uppatti vuttā hoti. Yathā ca tesaṃ rūpaṃ paccayo hoti, tena paccayena🔽uppatti vuttā hotīti adhippāyena “iminā”tiādimāha. Tattha cakkhupasādavatthukānaṃ
analyzed: rūpam ārabbha uppatti vuttā hoti yathā ca tesam rūpam paccayaḥ hoti tena paccayena  uppatti vuttā hoti iti adhippāyena iminā atiādim āha tattha cakkhu pasāda vatthukānam
translated: And by the statement that they arise with that condition it is said that visible data, etc., are a condition for them.🔽With the intention of showing this he says “by this” , etc. Herein, by the words “contact, etc., with the eye-sensitivity as their support” ,

original: phassādīnanti iminā vacanena tadālambanarūpārammaṇatāya taṃsadisānaṃ manodhātuādīnañca
analyzed: phassa ādīnam ti iminā vacanena tad ālambana rūpa ārammaṇa tāya manaḥ dhātu ādīnam ca
translated: states of mind such as the mind element and the mind-consciousness element that have the same object as the visible-data-object are also included by the words “with visible data as object.”

original: purejātapaccayena uppatti dassitāti daṭṭhabbā. Yattha pana viseso atthi, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: purejāta paccayena uppatti dassitā ati daṭṭhabbā yattha pana visesaḥ atthi tam dassetum
translated: and the arising of the rest by the condition being present.

original: “cakkhudvārajavanavīthipariyāpannāna”ntiādimāha. Tāni hi rūpaṃ garuṃ katvā pavattamānassādanābhinandanabhūtāni
analyzed: cakkhu dvāra javana vīthi pariyāpannāna nti ādim āha tāni hi rūpam garum katvā pavatta māna ssādana abhinandana bhūtāni
translated: “In the cognitive series that occurs through the eye door” is said in order to show the difference in the case of the eye-consciousness element.🔽For these are the nutriment that is consciousness, and they arise by object-predominance and object-decisive-support conditions,

original: taṃsampayuttāni ca ārammaṇādhipatiārammaṇūpanissayehi uppajjanti, aññāni ārammaṇapurejātenevāti
analyzed: tad sampayuttāni ca ārammaṇa adhipati ārammaṇa upanissayehi uppajjanti aññāni ārammaṇa purejātena iva āti
translated: while the others arise by object-prenascence condition only.

original: evaṃ “ārabbhā”ti vacanaṃ ārammaṇapaccayato aññapaccayabhāvassapi dīpakaṃ, ārammaṇavacanaṃ
analyzed: evam ārabbha ati vacanam ārammaṇa paccayataḥ añña paccaya bhāvassa api dīpakam ārammaṇa vacanam
translated: So the word “in dependence on” indicates that there is a condition other than object condition, and the word “object”

original: ārammaṇapaccayabhāvassevāti ayametesaṃ viseso.
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccaya bhāvassa iva ati ayam etesam viseso
translated: indicates that there is object condition only. This is the difference between them.

original: 600. Suṇātīti sotaviññāṇassa nissayabhāvena suṇāti. Jivhāsaddena viññāyamānā kiriyā
analyzed: suṇāti iti sota viññāṇassa nissaya bhāvena suṇāti jivhā saddena viññāyamānā kiriyā
translated: “Hears” : it hears by way of being the support for ear-consciousness. The word “tongue” is used because the function of tasting is manifested by the tongue.

original: sāyananti katvā “sāyanaṭṭhenā”ti āha. Kucchitānaṃ dukkhasampayuttaphassādīnaṃ āyoti
analyzed: sāyanam ti katvā sāyanaṭṭhena ati āha kucchitānam dukkha sampayutta phassa ādīnam
translated: “In the sense of lying down” : he said “in the sense of lying down” because the body lies down with the painful feeling, etc., that are its outcome.

original: kāyo, dukkhadukkhavipariṇāmadukkhānaṃ vā. Kāyāyatanassa byāpitāya cakkhupasāde kāyapasādabhāvopi
analyzed: kāyaḥ dukkha dukkha vipariṇāma dukkhānam vā kāya āyatanassa byāpitāya cakkhu pasāde kāya pasāda bhāvaḥ api
translated: The body is the door for the painful feeling, etc., that are associated with pain, or for the pain that is natural suffering and suffering as change.🔽Because the eye-sensitivity is spread over the body, there is also eye-sensitivity in the body.

original: atthi, tena cakkhupasādassa anuviddhattā no byāpitā ca na siyā, vuttā ca sā. Tasmā
analyzed: atthi tena cakkhu pasādassa anuviddha ttā no byāpitā ca na siyā vuttā ca sā tasmā
translated: and it is not that it is not pervaded by it because it is penetrated by it. And that is said. Therefore

original: cakkhupasādassa phoṭṭhabbāvabhāsanaṃ kāyapasādassa ca rūpāvabhāsanaṃ āpannanti lakkhaṇasammissataṃ
analyzed: cakkhu pasādassa phoṭṭhabba avabhāsanam kāya pasādassa ca rūpa avabhāsanam āpannanti lakkhaṇa sammissa tam
translated: he accuses him of a confusion of characteristics, saying that the manifestation of tangible data by the eye faculty and the manifestation of visible data by the body faculty are included.

original: codeti. Cakkhukāyānaṃ aññanissayattā kalāpantaragatatāya “aññassa aññattha abhāvato”ti🔽āha. Rūparasādinidassanaṃ samānanissayānañca aññamaññasabhāvānupagamena aññamaññasmiṃ
analyzed: codeti cakkhu kāyānam añña nissaya ttā kalāpa antara gata tāya aññassa aññattha abhāvato ti  āha rūpa rasa ādi nidassanam aññam añña sabhāva anupagamena aññam aññasmin
translated: Because the eye and the body have different supports, and because they are in different sets, he says, “because of the absence of one in the other.”

original: abhāvo, ko pana vādo asamānanissayānanti dassetuṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Rūpābhighātāraho ca so bhūtappasādo cāti rūpābhighātārahabhūtappasādo. Evaṃlakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: abhāvaḥ kaḥ pana vādaḥ asamāna nissayānam ti dassetum vuttam  rūpa abhighāta araho ca so bhūta ppasādo ca ati rūpa abhighāta araha bhūta ppasādaḥ evaṃlakkhaṇam
translated: And because the manifestation of visible data, etc., is in those that have a common support, and because it is not in those that have different supports, he says, “how much less in those that have different supports?”🔽in order to show that. And that physical basis that is capable of being struck by visible data is the eye faculty. That is the characteristic of the eye.🔽And the striking of visible data is the meaning of visible-data striking, or it is the striking of the visible data.

original: cakkhu. Rūpābhighātoti ca rūpe, rūpassa vā abhighātoti attho. Paripuṇṇāparipuṇṇāyatanattabhāvanibbattakassa
analyzed: cakkhu rūpa abhighāto ti ca rūpe rūpassa vā abhighāto ti attho paripuṇṇa a paripuṇṇa āyatana atta bhāva nibbattakassa
translated: The eye is the physical basis that is capable of being struck by visible data.

original: kammassa nidānabhūtā kāmataṇhā rūpataṇhā ca tadāyatanikabhavapatthanābhāvato daṭṭhukāmatādivohāraṃ🔽arahatīti dutiyo nayo sabbattha vutto. Tattha daṭṭhukāmatānidānaṃ kammaṃ samuṭṭhānametesanti
analyzed: kammassa nidāna bhūtā kāma taṇhā rūpa taṇhā ca tad āyatanika bhava patthanā bhāvataḥ daṭṭhu kāma tā ādi vohāram  arahati iti dutiyaḥ nayaḥ sabbattha vuttaḥ tattha daṭṭhu kāma tā nidānam kammam samuṭṭhānam etesan ti
translated: Craving for sensual desires and craving for form, which are the source of the kamma, are called “desire to see” and so on because they are the aspiration for the kind of becoming that has those sense-bases.

original: daṭṭhukāmatānidānakammasamuṭṭhānāni, evaṃvidhānaṃ bhūtānaṃ pasādalakkhaṇaṃ cakkhu,
analyzed: daṭṭhu kāma tā nidāna kamma samuṭṭhānāni evaṃvidhānam bhūtānam pasāda lakkhaṇam cakkhu
translated: This is the second method. Herein, kamma that has desire to see as its source is “originated by kamma that has desire to see as its source.” The eye has the characteristic of sensitivity of the kinds of primary elements of this kind.

original: evaṃvidho vā bhūtappasādo daṭṭhukāmatāni…pe… pasādo. Evaṃlakkhaṇaṃ cakkhu. Rūpesu
analyzed: evaṃvidhaḥ vā bhūta ppasādaḥ daṭṭhu kāma tā nipe pasādaḥ evaṃlakkhaṇam cakkhu rūpesu
translated: Or the sensitivity of the primary elements of this kind is the eye. It has the characteristic of sensitivity of this kind.

original: puggalassa vā viññāṇassa vā āviñchanarasaṃ.
analyzed: puggalassa vā viññāṇassa vā āviñchana rasam
translated: Its function is to make visible objects known to consciousness.

original: Kāyo sabbesanti ko ettha viseso, nanu tejādiadhikānañca bhūtānaṃ pasādā sabbesaṃyevāti?
analyzed: kāyaḥ sabbesan ti kaḥ ettha visesaḥ nanu teja ādi adhikānam ca bhūtānam pasādā sabbesam yeva āti
translated: The body is all: what is the difference here? Are not the sensitivities of the primary elements of fire, etc., all?

original: Saccametaṃ, idaṃ pana “sabbesa”nti vacanaṃ “samānāna”nti imamatthaṃ dīpeti anuvattamānassa
analyzed: saccam etam idam pana sabbesan ti vacanam samānānam ti imam attham dīpeti anuvattamānassa
translated: That is true, but the word “all” indicates that they are the same.

original: ekadesādhikabhāvassa nivāraṇavasena vuttattā. Tejādīnanti padīpasaṅkhātassa tejassa
analyzed: eka desa adhika bhāvassa nivāraṇa vasena vutta ttā padīpa saṅkhātassa tejassa
translated: Because it is said in order to exclude the possibility of anyone thinking that there is a predominance of one or other of the primary elements. Fire, etc., is the fire called “lamp,”

original: obhāsena vāyussa saddena pathaviyā gandhena kheḷasaṅkhātassa udakassa rasenāti purimavāde🔽pacchimavāde ca yathāyogaṃ taṃtaṃbhūtaguṇehi anuggayhabhāvato rūpādiggahaṇe upakaritabbatoti
analyzed: obhāsena vāyussa saddena pathaviyāḥ gandhena kheḷa saṅkhātassa udakassa rasena ati purima vāde  pacchima vāde ca yathāyogam taṃ taṃ bhūta guṇehi anuggayha bhāvataḥ rūpa ādi gahaṇe upakaritabbato ti
translated: and by the light, sound, smell, and taste of the respective elements.

original: attho. Rūpādīnaṃ adhikabhāvadassanatoti aggimhi rūpassa pabhassarassa vāyumhi saddassa🔽sabhāvena suyyamānassa pathaviyā surabhiādino gandhassa āpe ca rasassa madhurassa
analyzed: atthaḥ rūpa ādīnam adhika bhāva dassanato ti aggimhi rūpassa pabhassarassa vāyumhi saddassa  sabhāvena suyyamānassa pathaviyā surabhi ādinaḥ gandhassa āpe ca rasassa madhurassa
translated: In the first and last statements, the meaning is that the four great primaries are to be understood as helpful in apprehending visible data, etc., because they are present in the form of the respective properties of the elements.🔽Because it shows the predominance of visible data, etc., the first speaker says: “Visible data are the property of fire, sound is the property of air,🔽smell is the property of earth, and taste is the property of water.”

original: visesayuttānaṃ dassanato “rūpādayo tesaṃ guṇā”ti paṭhamavādī āha. Tasseva ca “iccheyyāmā”tiādinā
analyzed: visesa yuttānam dassanataḥ rūpa ādayaḥ tesam guṇā ti paṭhamavādī āha tassa iva ca iccheyyāma ati ādinā
translated: The second speaker replies: “I should like to know how you arrive at that conclusion.”

original: uttaramāha. Imināvupāyena dutiyavādissapi niggaho hotīti.🔽Atha vā rūpādivisesaguṇehi tejaākāsapathavīāpavāyūhi cakkhādīni katānīti vadantassa
analyzed: uttaram āha iminau upāyena dutiya vādissa api niggahaḥ hoti iti  atha vā rūpa ādi visesa guṇehi teja ākāsa pathavī āpa vāyūhi cakkha ādīni katāni iti vadantassa
translated: By this means the second speaker’s view is refuted too.

original: kaṇādassa vādaṃ tatiyaṃ uddharitvā taṃ niggahetuṃ “athāpi vadeyyu”ntiādi vuttanti
analyzed: kaṇādassa vādam tatiyam uddharitvā tam niggahetum atha api vadeyyuḥ tiādi vuttanti
translated: Or alternatively, the third statement is introduced with the words “Or they might argue” in order to refute the view of Kaṇāda, who maintains that the eye, etc., are made of the elements fire, space, earth, and air, respectively, because they have the respective properties of visible data, etc.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Āsave upalabbhamānopi gandho pathaviyā āposaṃyuttāya kappāsato visadisāyāti🔽na kappāsagandhassa adhikabhāvāpattīti ce? Na, anabhibhūtattā. Āsavehi udakasaṃyuttā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam āsave upalabbhamānaḥ api gandhaḥ pathaviyā āpaḥ saṃyuttāya kappāsataḥ visadisāya ati  na kappāsa gandhassa adhika bhāva āpatti iti ce na an abhibhūta ttā āsavehi udaka saṃyuttā
translated: and it is to be seen.🔽But even though the smell is perceived as mixed with water, it is not the same as the smell of cotton mixed with water.🔽If it be said that it is not the same because the smell of cotton is not predominant,

original: pathavī udakena abhibhūtā, na kappāsapathavīti tassāyeva adhikena gandhena bhavitabbanti.
analyzed: pathavī udakena abhibhūtā na kappāsa pathavī ti tassāya iva adhikena gandhena bhavitabbanti
translated: no, because it is not overwhelmed. The earth mixed with water is overwhelmed by the water,🔽but the earth mixed with cotton is not overwhelmed by the water. Therefore it is the smell of the cotton that is predominant.

original: Uṇhodakasaññutto ca aggi upalabbhanīyo mahantoti katvā tassa phasso viya vaṇṇopi🔽pabhassaro upalabbhitabboti uṇhodakavaṇṇato agginā anabhisambandhassa sītudakassa
analyzed: uṇha udaka saññuttaḥ ca aggi upalabbhanīyaḥ mahanto ti katvā tassa phassaḥ viya vaṇṇo api  pabhassaraḥ upalabbhitabbo ti uṇha udaka vaṇṇataḥ agginā anabhisambandhassa sīta udakassa
translated: And since the fire that is perceived as mixed with hot water is great, its touch is strong,🔽and so its colour should be perceived as brilliant.

original: vaṇṇo parihāyetha. Tasmāti etassubhayassa abhāvā. Tadabhāvena hi rūpādīnaṃ tejādivisesaguṇatā
analyzed: tasmā ati etassa ubhayassa tad abhāvena hi rūpa ādīnam teja ādi visesa guṇa tā
translated: Therefore the colour of cold water, which is not mixed with fire, should be diminished in comparison with the colour of hot water.🔽Thus, because of the absence of both,

original: nivattitā, taṃnivattanena “tejādīnaṃ guṇehi rūpādīhi anuggayhabhāvato”ti idaṃ kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: nivatti tā tad nivattanena teja ādīnam guṇehi rūpa ādīhi anuggayha bhāvataḥ ti idam kāraṇam
translated: the distinction of visible data, etc., as special qualities of fire, etc., is eliminated. And because of the elimination of that, the reason stated thus, ‘because of the conformity of visible data, etc., with the special qualities of fire, etc.,’

original: nivattitanti. Evaṃ paramparāya ubhayābhāvo visesakappanappahānassa kāraṇaṃ hotīti
analyzed: evam paramparāya ubhaya abhāvaḥ visesa kappana pahānassa kāraṇam hoti iti
translated: is eliminated. So the absence of both, which is effected by this process of elimination, is the reason for the abandoning of the assumption of a distinction.

original: āha “tasmā pahāyetheta”ntiādi. Ekakalāpepi rūparasādayo visadisā, ko pana vādo nānākalāpe
analyzed: āha eka kalāpe pi rūpa rasa ādayaḥ visadisā kaḥ pana vādaḥ nānā kalāpe
translated: He says “Therefore, having abandoned this” and so on. Even in a single aggregate, such as a lump of flesh, there are different kinds of matter, such as color, odor, etc., to say nothing of different aggregates.

original: cakkhādayo bhūtavisesābhāvepīti dassetuṃ rūparasādinidassanaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cakkha ādayaḥ bhūta visesa abhāve pi iti dassetum rūpa rasa ādi nidassanam vuttam
translated: The mention of color, odor, etc., is made in order to show that even though there is no specific element, there is a specific eye, etc.

original: Yadi bhūtaviseso natthi, kiṃ pana cakkhādivisesassa kāraṇanti taṃ dassetuṃ “yaṃ aññamaññassā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: yadi bhūta visesaḥ natthi kim pana cakkha ādi visesassa kāraṇanti tam dassetum yam aññamaññassa atiādim āha
translated: If there is no specific element, what is the cause of the specific eye, etc.? In order to show that, he says “The specific kamma” and so on.

original: Ekampi kammaṃ pañcāyatanikattabhāvapatthanānipphannaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ visesahetuttā “aññamaññassa🔽asādhāraṇa”nti ca “kammaviseso”ti ca vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi taṃ yena visesena
analyzed: ekam pi kammam pañcāyatanika tta bhāva patthanā nipphannam cakkha ādīnam visesa hetuttā aññamaññassa  asādhāraṇanti ca kamma visesaḥ ti ca vuttanti daṭṭhabbam na hi tam yena visesena
translated: It should be understood that a single kamma is the cause for the specific eye, etc., because it is the cause for the production of the five bases of the eye, etc., which are not common to each other.

original: cakkhussa paccayo, teneva sotassa hoti indriyantarābhāvappattito. “Paṭisandhikkhaṇe
analyzed: cakkhussa paccayaḥ tena iva sotassa hoti indriya antara abhāva ppattitaḥ paṭisandhi kkhaṇe
translated: For that specific kamma is not the cause of the ear, etc., because the other sense bases do not exist by means of that specific kamma.

original: mahaggatā ekā cetanā kaṭattārūpānaṃ kammapaccayena paccayo”ti vacanena paṭisandhikkhaṇe
analyzed: mahaggatā ekā cetanā kaṭattā rūpānam kamma paccayena paccayaḥ ti vacanena paṭisandhi kkhaṇe
translated: “At the moment of rebirth-linking, a single volition of the fine-material sphere is a condition, by way of kamma condition, for the kamma-originated material dhammas” .

original: vijjamānānaṃ sabbesaṃ kaṭattārūpānaṃ ekā cetanā kammapaccayo hotīti viññāyati. Nānācetanāya
analyzed: vijjamānānam sabbesam kaṭattā rūpānam ekā cetanā kamma paccayaḥ hoti iti viññāyati nānā cetanāya
translated: It is evident that a single volition is the kamma condition for all the material instances that exist, since

original: hi tadā indriyuppattiyaṃ sati parittena ca mahaggatena ca kammunā nibbattitaṃ kaṭattārūpaṃ
analyzed: hi tadā indriya uppattiyam sati parittena ca mahaggatena ca kammunā nibbattitam kaṭattā rūpam
translated: if there were to be the arising of the faculties with a single volition, then material instances produced by a small amount of kamma and by a great amount of kamma would

original: āpajjeyyāti na cekā paṭisandhi anekakammanibbattā hotīti siddhamekena kammena anekindriyuppatti
analyzed: āpajjeyya iti na ca ikā paṭisandhi aneka kamma nibbattā hoti iti siddham ekena kammena aneka indriya uppatti
translated: come to be found in the same place. But a single rebirth-linking consciousness is not produced by many kammas. So it is established that the arising of many faculties is due to a single kamma.

original: hotīti. Anallīno nissayo etassāti anallīnanissayo, rūpasaddasaṅkhāto visayo. Gandharasānaṃ🔽nissayā ghānajivhānissaye allīyantīti te nissayavasena allīnā, phoṭṭhabbaṃ sayaṃ🔽kāyanissayaallīnaṃ bhūtattayattā. Dūre…pe… sampatto eva nāma paṭighaṭṭananighaṃsajanakatoti
analyzed: hoti iti an allīnaḥ nissayaḥ etassa ati an allīna nissayaḥ rūpa sadda saṅkhātaḥ visayaḥ gandha rasānaṃ  nissayāḥ ghāna jivhā nissaye allīyanti iti te nissaya vasena allīnā phoṭṭhabbam sayam  kāya nissaya allīnam eva nāma paṭighaṭṭana nighaṃsa janaka tā ti
translated: “Without attachment” : the object consisting of visible form and sound is without attachment. The object of smell and taste🔽is with attachment, since the nose and tongue are attached to their objects by entering into them. The object of touch is with attachment by reason of the body’s being attached to it. The object of mental data is with attachment by reason of the mind’s being attached to it.🔽The intention is this: “Far” means that which is not reached by the impact of the object on the sense faculty. “Near” means that which is reached by the impact of the object on the sense faculty.

original: adhippāyo. Saddo pana dhātuparamparāya vāyu viya āgantvā nissayavasena sotanissaye
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ saddaḥ pana dhātu paramparāya vāyu viya āgantvā nissaya vasena sota nissaye
translated: Sound, however, is with attachment by reason of the ear’s being attached to it as its support, like the wind that has entered a bamboo.

original: allīyitvā sotaṃ ghaṭṭetvā vavatthānaṃ gacchanto saṇikaṃ vavatthānaṃ gacchatīti vutto.
analyzed: allīyitvā sotam ghaṭṭetvā vavatthānam gacchanto saṇikam vavatthānam gacchati iti vutto
translated: and when it reaches the ear and is discerned, it is said to be discerned slowly.

original: Evaṃ pana saticittasamuṭṭhānaṃ saddāyatanaṃ sotaviññāṇassa kadācipi ārammaṇapaccayo
analyzed: evam pana sati citta samuṭṭhānam sadda āyatanam sota viññāṇassa kadāci pi ārammaṇa paccayo
translated: But the sound base, which is a product of the mind’s in-breath and out-breath, is never a condition as object for ear-consciousness.

original: na siyā. Na hi bahiddhā cittasamuṭṭhānuppatti upapajjatīti.
analyzed: na siyā na hi bahiddhā citta samuṭṭhāna uppatti upapajjati iti
translated: For it is not admitted that what is a product of the mind arises externally.

original: Cirena suyyeyyāti kasmā etaṃ vuttaṃ, nanu dūre ṭhitehi rajakādisaddā cirena suyyantīti?🔽Na, dūrāsannānaṃ yathāpākaṭe sadde gahaṇavisesato. Yathā hi dūrāsannānaṃ vacanasadde
analyzed: cirena kasmai etam vuttam nanu dūre ṭhitehi rajaka ādi saddā cirena suyyanti iti  na dūra āsannānam yathā apākaṭe sadde gahaṇa visesataḥ yathā hi dūra āsannānam vacana sadde
translated: Why is it said, “It would be heard after a long time”? Are not the sounds of a washer-man, etc., heard after a long time when they are far away?🔽No. Because of the difference in the way the sound is apprehended, according to whether it is clear or not. For just as, in the case of the sound of speech,

original: yathā pākaṭībhūte gahaṇavisesato ākāravisesānaṃ aggahaṇaṃ gahaṇañca hoti, evaṃ rajakādisaddepi
analyzed: yathā pākaṭībhūte gahaṇa visesataḥ ākāra visesānam aggahaṇam gahaṇam ca hoti evam rajaka ādi sadde pi
translated: the apprehension of the difference in the mode of articulation is sometimes made and sometimes not made according to whether the sound is clear or not, so too in the case of the sound of a washer-man, etc.,

original: āsannassa ādito pabhuti yāvāvasānā kamena pākaṭībhūte dūrassa cāvasāne majjhe vā
analyzed: āsannassa āditas pabhuti yāva avasānā kamena pākaṭībhūte dūrassa ca avasāne majjhe vā
translated: when the sound of the near one becomes clear from the beginning to the end in due course, and that of the far one becomes clear only by the end or by the middle

original: piṇḍavasena pavattipākaṭībhūte nicchayagahaṇānaṃ sotaviññāṇavīthiyā parato pavattānaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍa vasena pavatti pākaṭībhūte nicchaya gahaṇānam sota viññāṇa vīthiyā paratas pavattānam
translated: in the form of a segment, then the ascertainment and apprehension of the sound by the ear-consciousness process that occurs after the sound has been heard

original: visesato lahukaṃ suto cirena sutoti abhimāno hoti. So pana saddo yattha uppanno,
analyzed: visesataḥ lahukam sutaḥ cirena sutaḥ ti abhimānaḥ hoti saḥ pana saddo yattha uppanno
translated: and especially if it is a faint sound or one heard after a long time. But that sound reaches the ear’s threshold only in dependence on the place where it arises.

original: taṃ nissitova attano vijjamānakkhaṇe sotassa āpāthamāgacchati. Dūre ṭhito pana saddo🔽aññattha paṭighosuppattiyā bhājanādicalanassa ca ayokanto viya ayocalanassa paccayo🔽hotīti daṭṭhabbo. Yathā vā ghaṇṭābhighātānujāni bhūtāni anuravassa nissayabhūtāni
analyzed: tam nissitaḥ uva attanaḥ vijjamāna kkhaṇe sotassa āpātham āgacchati dūre ṭhitaḥ pana saddaḥ  aññattha bhājana ādi calanassa ca ayo kantaḥ viya ayo calanassa paccayo  hoti iti daṭṭhabbaḥ yathā vā ghaṇṭā abhighāta anujāni bhūtāni anuravassa nissaya bhūtāni
translated: But a sound that is far away is a condition for the movement of the medium, that is to say, for the movement of the air, in the way that a magnet is for the movement of iron, and for the production of the reflection in another place.🔽Or just as the elements that are the support for the sound of a bell are of the nature of striking when they are assisted by the striking of the bell,

original: ghaṭṭanasabhāvāni, evaṃ ghaṭṭanānujāni yāva sotappasādā uppattivasena āgatāni bhūtāni
analyzed: ghaṭṭana sabhāvāni evam ghaṭṭana anujāni yāva sota ppasādāḥ uppatti vasena āgatāni bhūtāni
translated: so too the elements that are the support for the sound of the striking of the drum are of the nature of striking when they are assisted by the striking of the drum.

original: ghaṭṭanasabhāvānevāti taṃnissito saddo nissayavasena dhātuparamparāya ghaṭṭetvā saṇikaṃ
analyzed: ghaṭṭana sabhāvān evā ti tad nissitaḥ saddaḥ nissaya vasena dhātu paramparāya ghaṭṭetvā saṇikam
translated: And so the sound, in dependence on that, goes on reaching definition by a succession of elements that are the support for it, and it does so more and more faintly.

original: vavatthānaṃ gacchatīti vutto. Asukadisāya nāmāti na paññāyeyya. Kasmā? Sotappadesasseva saddassa gahaṇato.
analyzed: vavatthānam gacchati iti vuttaḥ asuka disāya nāma ati na paññāyeyya kasmā sota ppadesassa iva saddassa gahaṇato
translated: It would not be known as “in the east, etc.” Why? Because the sound is apprehended only in the place occupied by the ear.

original: Visame ajjhāsayo etassāti visamajjhāsayo, ajjhāsayarahitampi cakkhu visamaninnattā
analyzed: visame ajjhāsayo etassa ati visamajjhāsayaḥ ajjhāsaya rahitam pi cakkhu visama ninnattā
translated: It has an uneven direction, thus it is uneven in direction . Even though the eye is without direction, still it is said to be so because of the uneven direction of the object.

original: visamajjhāsayaṃ viya hotīti “visamajjhāsaya”nti vuttaṃ. Cakkhumato vā puggalassa
analyzed: visamajjhāsayam viya hoti iti visamajjhāsayanti vuttam cakkhumataḥ vā puggalassa
translated: It is called “with an uneven middle” because it is like a middle that is uneven, or

original: ajjhāsayavasena cakkhu “visamajjhāsaya”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Kaṇṇakūpachiddeyeva pavattanato ārammaṇaggahaṇahetuto ca tattheva “ajjhāsayaṃ karotī”ti
analyzed: ajjhāsaya vasena cakkhu visamajjhāsayanti vuttam  pavattanataḥ ārammaṇa ggahaṇa hetuto ca tattha iva ajjhāsayam karoti iti
translated: because it is the eye of a person who is discerning.🔽It is said that it “makes its middle uneven” because it occurs only in the eye sockets and because it is the cause for apprehending the object there.

original: vuttaṃ. Tassa sotassa sotaviññāṇanissayabhāvena saddasavane. Ajaṭākāsopi vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: vuttam tassa sotassa sota viññāṇa nissaya bhāvena sadda savane ajaṭā kāso pi vaṭṭati iti
translated: The ear is suitable for hearing sounds by way of being the support for the ear-consciousness.

original: etassa aṭṭhakathādhippāyena atthaṃ vadanto “antoleṇasmi”ntiādimāha. Attano adhippāyena
analyzed: etassa aṭṭhakathā adhippāyena attham vadantaḥ antoleṇasmin ti ādim āha attanaḥ adhippāyena
translated: The intention of the commentary is that it is “in the inner cavity.”

original: vadanto “kiṃ etāya dhammatāyā”tiādimavoca.🔽Vātūpanissayo gandho gocaro etassāti vātūpanissayagandhagocaraṃ. Ettha ca gandhaggahaṇassa
analyzed: vadantaḥ kim etāya dhammatāya atiādim avoca  vātu upanissayaḥ gandhaḥ gocaraḥ etassa ati vātu upanissaya gandha gocaram ettha ca gandha ggahaṇassa
translated: The intention of the author is that it is “in the inner space.”🔽The object of the nose is the smell that is supported by the wind.

original: vāto upanissayo, tabbohārena pana gandho “vātūpanissayo”ti vutto. Atha vā vāto eva
analyzed: vātaḥ upanissayaḥ tad uhārena pana gandhaḥ vāta upanissayaḥ ti vuttaḥ atha vā vātaḥ eva
translated: Herein, the wind is the support for the apprehension of the smell, but the smell itself is called “supported by the wind” because it is conveyed by the wind. Or else, the wind itself is the support, and that is “supported by the wind.”

original: upanissayo vātūpanissayo. Kassāti? Ghānaviññāṇassa. So sahakārīpaccayantarabhūto
analyzed: upanissayaḥ vātu upanissayaḥ kassa ati ghāna viññāṇassa so sahakārī paccaya antara bhūto
translated: Of what? Of the nose-consciousness. It is a co-nascent and decisive support.

original: etassa atthīti vātūpanissayo, gandho paccayo.
analyzed: etassa atthi iti vāta upanissayaḥ gandhaḥ paccayaḥ
translated: The meaning is: it has that, i.e. odour, as its support.🔽And water is a co-operating condition in the form of spittle, etc., and so is earth.

original: Āpo ca sahakārīpaccayantarabhūto kheḷādiko. Tathā pathavī. Gahetabbassa hi phoṭṭhabbassa
analyzed: āpaḥ ca sahakārī paccaya antara bhūto kheḷa ādiko tathā pathavī gahetabbassa hi phoṭṭhabbassa
translated: For when a tangible object is to be seized,🔽earth is the support of the body that is being pressed down by the tangible object,

original: uppīḷiyamānassa ādhārabhūtā pathavī kāyassa ca phoṭṭhabbena uppīḷiyamānassa nissayabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: uppīḷiyamānassa ādhāra bhūtā pathavī kāyassa ca phoṭṭhabbena uppīḷiyamānassa nissaya bhūtānam
translated: and it is the support of the body that is being pressed down by the tangible object.

original: ādhārabhūtā sabbadā phoṭṭhabbagahaṇassa upanissayoti. Uppīḷanena pana vinā phoṭṭhabbagahaṇe
analyzed: ādhāra bhūtā sabbadā phoṭṭhabba gahaṇassa upanissayaḥ ti uppīḷanena pana vinā phoṭṭhabba gahaṇe
translated: But when the tangible object is seized without pressing down,

original: kāyāyatanassa nissayabhūtā pathavī upanissayoti daṭṭhabbā. Sabbadāpi ca tassā upanissayabhāvo yutto eva.
analyzed: kāya āyatanassa nissaya bhūtā pathavī upanissayaḥ ti daṭṭhabbā sabbadā api ca tassāḥ upanissaya bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ eva
translated: earth should be regarded as the support of the body faculty. And its state as support is always appropriate.

original: Pañcavaṇṇānanti vacanaṃ tadādhārānaṃ suttānaṃ nānattadassanatthaṃ. Pañcappakārā pañcavaṇṇā.
analyzed: pañca vaṇṇānam ti vacanam tad ādhārānam suttānam nānatta dassana tham pañca ppakārā pañca vaṇṇā
translated: The words “five colours” are said for the purpose of showing the variety of the threads that are its support. The five kinds are the five colours.

original: Ekantatoti idaṃ sabbadā uppīḷanena vinibbhujjituṃ asakkuṇeyyānaṃ kalāpantararūpānaṃ
analyzed: ekantataḥ ti idam sabbadā uppīḷanena vinibbhujjitum
translated: “Always” is said of the component material instances that cannot be separated by pressing down at all times.

original: sabbhāvā tesaṃ nivattanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Na hi tāni ekantena avinibhuttāni kalāpantaragatattāti.
analyzed: sabbhāvā tesam nivattana attham vuttam na hi tāni ekantena a vinibhuttāni kalāpa antara gata ttā ti
translated: For the purpose of preventing their being taken as always pressed down, since they are included in the component material instances. For they are not always pressed down.

original: 616. Vaṇṇanibhāti rūpāyatanameva niddiṭṭhanti tadeva apekkhitvā “sanidassana”nti🔽napuṃsakaniddeso kato. Tasmāti nippariyāyarūpānaṃ nīlādīnaṃ phusitvā ajānitabbato
analyzed: vaṇṇa nibhā ti rūpa āyatanam eva niddiṭṭhanti tat eva apekkhitvā sa nidassananti  napuṃsaka niddeso kataḥ tasmā ati nippariyāya rūpānam nīla ādīnam phusitvā a jānitabbato
translated: “The visible-data base itself is what is demonstrated” : it is only that which is referred to when “demonstrable” is said.🔽The neuter form is used because of the absence of the masculine and feminine in the ultimate sense.🔽“Because the blue, etc., of the ultimate sense cannot be known by touching,

original: dīghādīnañca phusitvā jānitabbato na nippariyāyena dīghaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ. Taṃ taṃ nissāyāti🔽dīghādisannivesaṃ bhūtasamudāyaṃ nissāya. Tathā tathā ṭhitanti dīghādisannivesena
analyzed: dīgha ādīnam ca phusitvā jānitabbataḥ na nippariyāyena dīgham rūpa āyatanam tam tam nissāya ati  dīgha ādi sannivesam bhūta samudāyam nissāya tathā tathā dīgha ādi sannivesena
translated: and because the long, etc., can be known by touching, the visible-data base is not long, etc., in the ultimate sense.🔽“Depending on that or that” : depending on the collection of primaries arranged as long, etc.

original: ṭhitaṃ vaṇṇasamudāyabhūtaṃ rūpāyatanameva dīghādivohārena bhāsitaṃ. Aññamaññaparicchinnaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitam vaṇṇa samudāya bhūtam rūpa āyatanam eva dīgha ādi vohārena bhāsitam aññam añña paricchinnam
translated: “It is spoken of by the term ‘long,’ etc.,” : it is only the visible-data base, which is a collection of colours, that is spoken of by the terms “long,” etc., according to how it is arranged.🔽“It is delimited by the other” : in one there is no other.

original: ekasmiṃ itarassa abhāvā. Visayagocarānaṃ viseso anaññatthabhāvo tabbahulacāritā ca cakkhuviññāṇassa.🔽620. Bherisaddādīnañca vāditasaddattā “vuttāvasesāna”nti āha. Amanussavacanena na
analyzed: ekasmin itarassa abhāvāḥ visaya gocarānam visesaḥ anaññatthabhāvo tad bahula cāri tā ca cakkhu viññāṇassa  bheri sadda ādīnam ca vādita saddattāḥ vutta avasesānam ti āha amanussa vacanena na
translated: The difference in the domain of the eye-consciousness is due to the fact that it has a different object, that it does not have the same meaning, and that it has a different habit.🔽“The rest are spoken of by the remainder of the terms” : the sound of a drum, etc., is spoken of by the term “sound.”

original: manussehi aññe pāṇino eva gahitā, atha kho kaṭṭhādayopīti adhippāyena “seso sabbopī”ti
analyzed: manussehi aññe pāṇinaḥ eva gahitāḥ atha kho kaṭṭha ādayaḥ api iti adhippāyena seso sabbaḥ api iti
translated: “The rest are all” : the intention is that not only animals other than human beings are meant by the word “non-human,” but also sticks, etc.

original: āha. Evaṃ santepi vatthuvisesakittanavasena pāḷiyaṃ anāgato tathā kittetabbo ye vā
analyzed: āha evam sante pi vatthu visesa kittana vasena pāḷiyam anāgataḥ tathā kittetabbaḥ ye vā
translated: He says: “Even so, it is intended that it should be mentioned by the description of the special physical basis, though it is not mentioned in the text.”

original: panāti vuttoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pana iti vuttaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Or the meaning may be taken as “or it should be mentioned thus.”

original: 624. Vissagandhoti virūpo maṃsādigandho. Lambilanti madhurambilaṃ.
analyzed: vissagandhaḥ iti virūpaḥ maṃsa ādi gandhaḥ madhu rambilam
translated: “Odourless” : odour of flesh, etc., is absent. “Betel” : sweet betel.

original: 632. Sañjānanti etenāti sañjānanaṃ, upalakkhaṇaṃ. Sakena sakena kammacittādinā paccayena
analyzed: sañjānanti etena ati sañjānanam upalakkhaṇam sakena sakena kamma citta ādinā paccayena
translated: “Perceived by” : the meaning is “perceived with this.” It is a distinguishing mark.

original: samuṭṭhitānipi itthiliṅgādīni indriyasahite sarīre uppajjamānāni taṃtadākārāni hutvā
analyzed: samuṭṭhitāni api itthi liṅga ādīni indriya sahite sarīre uppajjamānāni taṃ tad ākārāni hutvā
translated: Though the sex-marks, etc., arise in a body endowed with faculties, produced by their several causes, such as the consciousness of the kamma of becoming, etc.,

original: uppajjantīti “itthindriyaṃ paṭicca samuṭṭhahantī”ti vuttāni. Itthiliṅgādīsu eva ca🔽adhipatibhāvā etassa indriyatā vuttā, indriyasahite santāne itthiliṅgādiākārarūpapaccayānaṃ
analyzed: uppajjanti iti itthi indriyam paṭicca samuṭṭhahanti iti vuttāni itthi liṅga ādīsu eva ca  adhipati bhāvā etassa indriya tā vuttā indriya sahite santāne itthi liṅga ādi ākāra rūpa paccayānam
translated: they arise in the form of the sex-marks, etc., and are therefore said to “arise with the sex-faculty as their support.”🔽And the faculty is said to be dominant in the sex-marks, etc.,

original: aññathā anuppādanato itthiggahaṇassa ca tesaṃ rūpānaṃ paccayabhāvato. Yasmā pana
analyzed: aññathā an uppādanato itthi ggahaṇassa ca tesam rūpānam paccaya bhāvato yasmā pana
translated: because the conditions for the material instances in the form of the sex-marks, etc., arise in a continuity endowed with the faculty, and because the apprehension of the sex is a condition for those material instances.

original: bhāvadasakepi rūpānaṃ itthindriyaṃ na janakaṃ, nāpi anupālakaṃ upatthambhakaṃ vā,
analyzed: itthi indriyam na janakam na api anupālakam upatthambhakam vā
translated: But the sex-faculty is not a producer of material instances, nor a preserver or supporter of them,

original: na ca aññakalāparūpānaṃ, tasmā taṃ jīvitindriyaṃ viya sakalāparūpānaṃ āhāro viya
analyzed: na ca tasmā tam jīvitindriyam āhāraḥ
translated: and it is not a condition for the other material instances, as is the life faculty,🔽or for the material instances of the other aggregates, as is nutriment.

original: vā kalāpantararūpānañca indriyaatthiavigatapaccayoti na vuttaṃ. Esa nayo purisindriyepi.
analyzed: vā indriya atthi avigata paccayo ti na vuttam esa nayo purisa indriye pi
translated: So it is not said of it as it is of the life faculty that it is a condition by way of faculty for the material instances of the other aggregates. The same method applies in the case of the male faculty.

original: Liṅgādiākāresu rūpesu rūpāyatanassa cakkhuviññeyyattā liṅgādīnaṃ cakkhuviññeyyatā vuttā.
analyzed: liṅga ādi ākāresu rūpesu rūpa āyatanassa cakkhu viññeyya ttā liṅga ādīnam cakkhu viññeyya tā vuttā
translated: As regards the material instances such as the sex, since the visible-form base is cognizable by the eye, the sex is said to be cognizable by the eye.

original: 633. Ubhayampi…pe… kusalena patiṭṭhātīti sugatiṃ sandhāya vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Duggatiyañhi
analyzed: ubhayam pipe kusalena patiṭṭhāti iti sugatim sandhāya vuttam ti veditabbam duggatiyam hi
translated: Both are rooted in profitable kamma … and so on. It should be understood that this is said with reference to a happy destiny. For in an unhappy destiny

original: paṭisandhi akusalenevāti tadā uppajjamāno bhāvopi akusaleneva bhaveyya, paṭisandhiyaṃ🔽viya pavattepīti. Tayidaṃ dvayaṃ yasmā santāne saha na pavattati “yassa itthindriyaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi akusalena iva ati tadā uppajjamānaḥ bhāvaḥ api akusalena iva bhaveyya paṭisandhiyam  tayidam dvayam yasmā santāne saha na pavattati yassa
translated: the rebirth-linking consciousness is only unprofitable. So the resultant consciousness that arises then would be only unprofitable, and its material instances would be the same as those of the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: uppajjati, tassa purisindriyaṃ uppajjatīti? No”tiādivacanato, tasmā ubhatobyañjanakassapi
analyzed: uppajjati tassa purisa indriyam uppajjati iti na uti ādi vacanato tasmā ubhatobyañjanakassa api
translated: But since these two are not found occurring together in a continuity, it is said that “If the female faculty arises in a certain continuity, does the male faculty arise in that continuity? No” , and so on.

original: ekamevindriyaṃ hotīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ekam eva indriyam hoti iti vuttam
translated: So it is said that in the case of one who has both sexes there is only one faculty.

original: 635. Ekantaṃ kāyaviññattiyaṃ kāyavohārassa pavattidassanatthaṃ “kāyena saṃvaro sādhū”ti🔽sādhakasuttaṃ āhaṭaṃ. Bhāvassa gamanaṃ pakāsanaṃ copanaṃ. Thambhanāti vāyodhātuadhikānaṃ🔽bhūtānaṃ thambhanākāro viññattīti attho. Uddhaṅgamavātādayo viya hi yo vātādhiko🔽kalāpo, tattha bhūtānaṃ viññattiākāratā hotīti. Teneva “kāyaṃ thambhetvā thaddhaṃ🔽karotīti thambhanā”ti vāyodhātukiccavasena viññatti vuttā. Tato eva ca “vāyodhātuyā🔽ākāro kāyaviññattī”ti ca vattuṃ vaṭṭati, tathā “pathavīdhātuyā vacīviññattī”ti pathavīdhātuadhikabhūtavikārato.
analyzed: ekantam kāya viññattiyam kāya vohārassa pavatti dassana attham kāyena saṃvaro sādhu iti  sādhaka suttam āhaṭam bhāvassa gamanam pakāsanam copanam thambhanā ati  bhūtānam thambhana ākāraḥ viññatti iti atthaḥ uddhaṅgama vāta ādayaḥ viya hi yaḥ vāta adhikaḥ  kalāpo tattha bhūtānam viññatti ākāra tā hoti iti tena iva kāyam thambhetvā thaddham  karoti iti thambhanā ati vāyo dhātu kicca vasena viññatti vuttā tatas eva ca vāyo dhātuyā  ākāro kāya viññatti iti ca vattum vaṭṭati tathā pathavī dhātuyā vacī viññatti iti pathavī dhātu adhika bhūta vikārato
translated: The verse “Restraint of the body is good” was stated in order to show that bodily intimation is the occurrence of bodily action.

original: 636. Pabhedagatā vācā evāti tissa phussāti pabhedagatā. Atha vā vacīsaṅkhārehi vitakkavicārehi
analyzed: pabheda gatā vācā eva ati phussā ati pabheda gatā atha vā vacī saṅkhārehi vitakka vicārehi
translated: The meaning of “stiffness” is the mode of intimation of the material phenomena that are predominant in the air element. For just as the collection of phenomena that is predominant in the upward moving air, etc., is called “upward moving air,” etc., so too, in a collection of phenomena that is predominant in the air element, the mode of intimation of the phenomena is called “stiffness.” That is why intimation is described as a function of the air element in the way beginning, “stiffening the body, it makes it rigid” . And that is why it is proper to say that the mode of the air element is bodily intimation. And likewise, “the mode of the earth element is verbal intimation” should be understood as due to the modification of the phenomena that are predominant in the earth element.

original: pariggahitā savanavisayabhāvaṃ anupanītatāya abhinnā tabbhāvaṃ nīyamānā vācā “vacībhedo”ti
analyzed: pariggahitā savana visaya bhāvam an upanīta tāya abhinnā tad bhāvam nīyamānā vācā
translated: The speech that has not yet been brought into the objective field of hearing by being apprehended is unbroken. That which is being brought into that objective field is called “broken speech.”

original: vuccati. Iriyāpathampi upatthambhentīti yathāpavattaṃ iriyāpathaṃ upatthambhenti.
analyzed: vuccati iriyāpatham pi upatthambhenti iti yathāpavattam iriyāpatham upatthambhenti
translated: “They support the postures”: they support the postures as they occur.

original: Yathā hi abbokiṇṇe bhavaṅge vattamāne aṅgāni osīdanti paviṭṭhāni viya honti, na evaṃ
analyzed: yathā hi abbokiṇṇe bhavaṅge vattamāne aṅgāni osīdanti paviṭṭhāni viya honti na evam
translated: For just as the limbs sag and seem to sink in when the life-continuum is occurring uninterruptedly,

original: “dvattiṃsa chabbīsā”ti vuttesu jāgaraṇacittesu vattamānesu. Tesu pana vattamānesu
analyzed: dvattiṃsa chabbīsā ati vuttesu jāgaraṇa cittesu vattamānesu tesu pana vattamānesu
translated: so they do not when the consciousnesses of the waking state, which are called “thirty-two” and “twenty-six” , are occurring.

original: aṅgāni upatthaddhāni yathāpavattiriyāpathabhāveneva pavattantīti. Khīṇāsavānaṃ cuticittanti
analyzed: aṅgāni upatthaddhāni yathā pavatti riyāpatha bhāvena iva pavattanti iti khīṇa āsavānam cuti cittam
translated: But when these are occurring, the limbs are braced up and occur in the posture that is proper to them.

original: visesetvā vuttaṃ, “kāmāvacarānaṃ pacchimacittassa uppādakkhaṇe yassa cittassa anantarā
analyzed: visesetvā vuttam kāmāvacarānam pacchima cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe yassa cittassa anantarā
translated: “The death consciousness of one free from lust”: this is said distinguishing it from the death consciousness of one not free from lust.🔽“At the moment of arising of the last consciousness of the sense sphere”: after which consciousness there arises

original: kāmāvacarānaṃ pacchimacittaṃ uppajjissati, rūpāvacare arūpāvacare pacchimabhavikānaṃ,
analyzed: kāmāvacarānam pacchima cittam uppajjissati rūpāvacare arūpāvacare pacchimabhavikānam
translated: the last consciousness of the sense sphere, and the fine-material and immaterial kinds of rebirth-linking,

original: ye ca rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacaraṃ upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti, tesaṃ cavantānaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: ye ca rūpāvacaram arūpāvacaram upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti tesam cavantānam tesam
translated: and of those who, having been reborn in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of existence, will attain Nibbāna there, at the moment of their passing away,

original: vacīsaṅkhāro nirujjhissati, no ca tesaṃ kāyasaṅkhāro nirujjhissatī”ti pana vacanato
analyzed: vacī saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhissati no ca tesam kāya saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhissati iti pana vacanato
translated: But since it is said, “The mental formations will cease, but not the bodily formations of those who have entered the attainment of cessation,”

original: aññesampi cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpetīti viññāyati. Na hi rūpasamuṭṭhāpakacittassa
analyzed: aññesam pi cuti cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti viññāyati na hi rūpa samuṭṭhāpaka cittassa
translated: it is evident that the death consciousness does not generate materiality. For the consciousness that generates materiality

original: gabbhagamanādivinibaddhābhāvena kāyasaṅkhārāsamuṭṭhāpanaṃ atthi, na ca yuttaṃ “cuto
analyzed: gabbha gamana ādi vinibaddha abhāvena kāya saṅkhāra asamuṭṭhāpanam atthi na ca yuttam cutaḥ
translated: does not generate bodily formations by being bound up with the process of entering the womb, etc.,🔽and it is not proper to say that “after death consciousness occurs in one who has materiality” or that “the death consciousness generates materiality.”

original: ca cittasamuṭṭhānañcassa pavattatī”ti, nāpi “cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetī”ti pāḷi atthīti.🔽637. Na kassatīti na vilekhiyati. Gatanti viññātaṃ. Asamphuṭṭhaṃ catūhi mahābhūtehīti
analyzed: ca citta samuṭṭhānam ca assa pavattati iti na api cuti cittam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti atthi iti  na kassati iti na vilekhiyati gatanti viññātam a samphuṭṭham catūhi mahābhūtehi iti
translated: Nor does the text say so.🔽“Not clung to” : not clung to by the kamma-resultant material dhammas.🔽“Not contacted” : not contacted by the four great primaries.

original: yasmiṃ kalāpe bhūtānaṃ paricchedo, teheva asamphuṭṭhaṃ. Vijjamānepi hi kalāpantarabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: yasmin kalāpe bhūtānam paricchedaḥ tehi iva a saṃphuṭṭham vijjamāne pi hi kalāpa antara bhūtānam
translated: “Not intermixed with the four great primaries” : not intermixed with the great primaries in the same mass. For even though the great primaries in one mass

original: kalāpantarabhūtasamphuṭṭhabhāve taṃtaṃbhūtavivittatā rūpapariyanto ākāsoti yesaṃ
analyzed: kalā apantara bhūta samphuṭṭha bhāve rūpa pariyantaḥ yesam
translated: are intermixed with the great primaries in another mass, the space that is the mere absence of the great primaries in the ultimate particular material states,

original: yo paricchedo, tehi so asamphuṭṭhova, aññathā paricchinnabhāvo na siyā tesaṃ bhūtānaṃ
analyzed: yo paricchedo tehi so a samphuṭṭhaḥ uva aññathā paricchinna bhāvaḥ na siyā tesam bhūtānam
translated: which is their delimitation, is not intermixed with them. Otherwise, the delimitation of those great primaries would not be evident.

original: byāpitabhāvāpattito. Abyāpitā hi asamphuṭṭhatāti.
analyzed: byāpita bhāva āpattitaḥ a byāpitā hi a samphuṭṭha tā ati
translated: because it has become pervasive. For what is not pervasive is not all-pervading.

original: 638. Lahutādīnaṃ aññamaññāvijahanena dubbiññeyyanānattatā vuttāti taṃtaṃvikārādhikarūpehi🔽taṃtaṃnānattappakāsanatthaṃ “evaṃ santepī”tiādimāha. Yathāvuttā ca paccayā taṃtaṃvikārassa
analyzed: lahu tā ādīnam aññamañña avijahanena dubbiññeyya nānatta tā vuttā ati taṃ taṃ vikāra adhika rūpehi  evam sante pi iti ādim āha yathā vuttā ca paccayā taṃ taṃ vikārassa
translated: Lightness, etc., are said to have different individual essences because they cannot be discerned separately from each other.

original: visesapaccayabhāvato vuttā, avisesena pana sabbe sabbesaṃ paccayāti.
analyzed: visesa paccaya bhāvataḥ vuttāḥ avisesena pana sabbe sabbesam paccayā ti
translated: So in order to show their different individual essences by means of their respective functions, he said “Nevertheless” , etc. And the respective conditions mentioned are stated as the specific conditions for the respective functions, but all are conditions for all in a general way.

original: 641. Ādito cayo ācayo, paṭhamuppatti. Upari cayo upacayo. Pabandho santati. Tattha🔽uddese avuttopi ācayo upacayasaddeneva viññāyatīti “yo āyatanānaṃ ācayo punappunaṃ🔽nibbattamānānaṃ, sova rūpassa upacayo”ti āha. Pāḷiyaṃ pana upa-saddo paṭhamattho
analyzed: āditas cayo ācayo paṭhama uppatti upari cayo upacayo pabandho santati tattha  uddese a vuttaḥ api ācayaḥ upacaya saddena iva viññāyati iti yaḥ āyatanānam ācayo punappunam  nibbattamānānam saḥ uva rūpassa upacayaḥ ti āha pāḷiyam pana upasaddo paṭhama atthaḥ
translated: The “accumulation” is the first “coming together,” the first arising. The “growth” is the subsequent “coming together,” the subsequent arising. The “bond” is the continuity.🔽Herein, although “accumulation” is not mentioned in the text, it is known by the word “growth.” So he said, “The accumulation of the bases, the repeated arising of materiality, is its growth.”

original: upariattho ca hotīti “ādicayo upacayo, uparicayo santatī”ti ayamattho viññāyatīti.
analyzed: upari attho ca hoti iti ādi cayaḥ upacayaḥ upari cayaḥ santati iti ayam attho viññāyati iti
translated: But in the text the prefix upa- has the meaning of first and the prefix upa- has the meaning of subsequent. So the meaning of the text should be understood as follows: “The first accumulation is the growth; the subsequent accumulation is the continuity.”

original: Aññathā hi ācayasaṅkhātassa paṭhamuppādassa avuttatā āpajjeyya.
analyzed: aññathā hi ācaya saṅkhātassa paṭhama uppādassa a vutta tā āpajjeyya
translated: Otherwise, the first arising called “accumulation” would not be mentioned.

original: Evanti “yo āyatanānaṃ ācayo”tiādiniddesena kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti? Āyatanena ācayo kathito.
analyzed: evanti kim kathitam hoti āyatanena ācayo kathito
translated: What is stated by the description beginning with “The growth of the bases”? The growth is stated by the base.

original: Ācayūpacayasantatiyo hi nibbattibhāvena ācayo evāti āyatanehi ācayādīnaṃ pakāsitattā
analyzed: ācaya upacaya santatiyaḥ hi nibbatti bhāvena ācayaḥ evā ati āyatanehi ācaya ādīnam pakāsita ttā
translated: For the growth of the bases is stated by the bases, since the continuity of growth and increase is growth in the sense of arising.

original: tehi ācayo kathito. Āyatanānaṃ ācayādivacaneneva ācayasabhāvāni uppādadhammāni āyatanānīti
analyzed: tehi ācayaḥ kathitaḥ āyatanānam ācaya ādi vacanena iva ācaya sabhāvāni uppāda dhammāni āyatanāni iti
translated: By the words “the growth of the bases” the bases that have the nature of growth, which are subject to arising, are stated.

original: ācayena taṃpakatikāni āyatanāni kathitāni. Lakkhaṇañhi uppādo, na rūparūpanti. Tenevādhippāyenāha
analyzed: ācayena taṃpakatikāni āyatanāni kathitāni lakkhaṇam hi uppādaḥ na tena iva adhippāyena āha
translated: For growth is a characteristic, not form. With this intention it is said: “The base is stated.”

original: “āyatanameva kathita”nti. Ācayañhi lakkhaṇaṃ kathayantena taṃlakkhaṇāni āyatanāneva
analyzed: āyatanam eva kathitanti ācayan hi lakkhaṇam kathayantena tad lakkhaṇāni āyatanāni eva
translated: For by one who states the characteristic of growth the bases that have that characteristic are stated.

original: kathitāni hontīti. Evampi kiṃ kathitaṃ hotīti āyatanācayehi ācayāyatanehi ācayameva
analyzed: kathitāni honti iti evam pi kim kathitam āyatana ācayehi ācaya āyatanehi ācayam eva
translated: In the same way, what is stated by the description beginning with “The growth of the bases”? The growth is stated by the base.

original: āyatanameva kathentena uddese niddese ca ācayoti idameva avatvā upacayasantatiyo
analyzed: āyatanam eva kathentena uddese niddese ca idam eva avatvā upacaya santatiyo
translated: By the description and the explanation, growth is stated by the base, by the growth of the bases.

original: uddisitvā tesaṃ vibhajanavasena āyatanena ācayakathanādinā kiṃ kathitaṃ hotīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: uddisitvā tesam vibhajana vasena āyatanena ācaya kathana ādinā kim kathitam hoti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is this: “Without saying ‘growth’ he has described the continuity of growth and increase by the words ‘the growth of the bases,’ and by the explanation beginning with ‘The growth is stated by the base’ what is stated?”

original: Ācayoti upacayamāha, upacayoti ca santatiṃ. Tadevubhayaṃ yathākkamaṃ vivaranto “nibbatti🔽vaḍḍhi kathitā”ti āha. Upacayasantatiyo hi atthato ekattā ācayovāti taduddesavibhajanavasena
analyzed: ācaya uti upacayam āha upacaya uti ca santatim tat eva ubhayam yathākkamam vivarantaḥ nibbatti  vaḍḍhi kathitā iti āha upacaya santatiyaḥ hi atthataḥ ekattā tad uddesa vibhajana vasena
translated: “Accumulation” means growth, and “growth” means continuity. Both these terms are explained respectively in the passage: “The arising of the aggregates is called growth” .🔽For the terms “accumulation” and “growth” are synonymous.🔽

original: āyatanena ācayakathanādinā nibbattivaḍḍhiākāranānattaṃ ācayassa kathitanti attho.
analyzed: āyatanena ācaya kathana ādinā nibbatti vaḍḍhi ākāra nānattam ācayassa kathitanti attho
translated: “Accumulation” is said to be “growth,” and “continuity” is said to be “series.” The Master, explaining these two terms in order, says: “Production and growth are said to be accumulation.” For accumulation and continuity are the same in meaning. The meaning is that the diversity of the modes of production and growth is said to be accumulation by way of the exposition of the bases, the exposition of accumulation, and so on.

original: Imamevatthaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “atthato hī”tiādimāha. Yasmā ca ubhayampi etaṃ jātirūpassevādhivacanaṃ,🔽tasmā jātirūpassa lakkhaṇādivisesesu ācayādīsu pavattiādīsu ca ācayādilakkhaṇādiko
analyzed: imam eva attham vibhāvetum atthataḥ hi iti ādim āha yasmā ca ubhayam pi etam  tasmā jāti rūpassa lakkhaṇa ādi visesesu ācaya ādīsu pavatti ādīsu ca ācaya ādi lakkhaṇa ādiko
