translated: For the purpose of showing the distinction between the associated states and the path factors in this method,

original: maggahetukatā siddhāti.
analyzed: magga hetuka tā siddhā ati
translated: which is like the third method, is the intention.🔽The rest of the path factors are already stated before.🔽For in the first method it is established that contact, etc., are causes of the path.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiyā dutiyanayepi ṭhapitāya tatiyanaye sahetukabhāvo dassito. Kathaṃ dassito,🔽nanu ariyamaggasamaṅgissa “alobho adoso ime dhammā maggahetū”ti avatvā “alobho adoso
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ dutiya naye pi ṭhapitāya tatiya naye sa hetuka bhāvaḥ dassito katham dassito  nanu ariya magga samaṅgissa alobhaḥ adosaḥ ime dhammā magga hetu iti avatvā alobhaḥ adosaḥ
translated: When right view is stated in the second method, the third method shows that it has a cause. How is it shown?

original: amoho ime dhammā maggahetū”ti visuṃ sammādiṭṭhiādike maggahetū dassetvā “taṃsampayutto…pe…
analyzed: amohaḥ ime dhammā magga hetū ti visum sammādiṭṭhi ādike magga hetū dassetvā tad sampayutta upe
translated: Is it not so that, instead of saying, “Non-greed and non-hate are causes of the path,” the text says, “Non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion are causes of the path,” and then, after showing right view, etc., separately as causes of the path, it says, “The consciousness aggregate associated with that …🔽… the consciousness aggregate is a cause of the path” , and thus shows the causes of the path separately?

original: viññāṇakkhandho”ti visuṃ maggahetukānaṃ dassitattā “maggahetūsu amoho”ti vuttāya
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandho ti visum magga hetukānam dassita ttā magga hetūsu amoho ti vuttāya
translated: So it is said that non-delusion is a cause of the path.

original: sammādiṭṭhiyā maggahetukatā na dassitā siyā? No na dassitā. Yathā hi tīṇi saṃyojanāni🔽dassetvā “tadekaṭṭho lobho doso moho, ime dhammā dassanena pahātabbahetū”ti visuṃ
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ magga hetuka tā na dassitā siyā no na dassitā yathā hi tīṇi saṃyojanāni  dassetvā tad ekaṭṭhaḥ lobhaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ ime dhammāḥ dassanena pahātabba hetu uti visum
translated: But is it not shown that right view has the path as its cause? —No, it is not. For just as, after showing the three fetters,🔽the three roots are specified separately as causes to be abandoned by seeing thus: “Greed, hate, and delusion, these states have causes that are to be abandoned by seeing” ,

original: pahātabbahetū niyametvā “tadekaṭṭhā ca kilesā”tiādivacanena lobhadosamohā ca aññamaññasahajekaṭṭhā🔽aññamaññasampayuttā saṅkhārakkhandhabhūtā ca dassanenapahātabbahetukāti dassitā honti,🔽evamidhāpi “alobhādayo ime dhammā maggahetū”ti nigamitāpi aññamaññasampayuttasaṅkhārakkhandhabhāvato
analyzed: pahātabba hetū niyametvā tad ekaṭṭhā ca kilesa ati ādi vacanena lobha dosa mohā ca aññamañña sahajā ekaṭṭhā  aññam añña sampayuttā saṅkhāra kkhandha bhūtā ca dassanena apahātabba hetukā ati dassitāḥ honti  evam idha api alobha ādayaḥ ime dhammāḥ magga hetū ti nigamitā api añña mañña sampayutta saṅkhāra kkhandha bhāvato
translated: and then the greed, hate, and delusion that are the roots of the remaining defilements are shown to have causes to be abandoned by seeing by the words “and the defilements that have these as their roots” ,

original: taṃsampayuttasaṅkhārakkhandhavacanena “maggahetukā”ti dassitā evāti siddhaṃ hoti,
analyzed: tad sampayutta saṅkhāra kkhandha vacanena magga hetukā ati dassitā eva ati siddham hoti
translated: so too here, although the non-greed, etc., are stated in the conclusion thus, “These states have the path as their cause,” they are shown to have the path as their cause by the words “the formations associated with them” because they are formations associated with the non-greed, etc.,🔽and because they are the formations aggregate associated with the non-greed, etc.🔽And the fact that non-delusion is shown to have the path as its cause by the words “right view” is established in the same way.

original: sammādiṭṭhiyāpi amohoti vuttāya maggahetukabhāvadassanaṃ. Sace pana yo dutiyanaye
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyā api amoho ti vuttāya magga hetuka bhāva dassanam sace pana yaḥ dutiya naye
translated: But if it is said that the words “the formations associated with them” are stated in the second method

original: maggo ceva hetu cāti vutto, tato aññasseva aññena asādhāraṇena pariyāyena maggahetubhāvaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ ca iva hetu ca ati vuttaḥ tatas aññassa iva aññena asādhāraṇena pariyāyena magga hetu bhāvam
translated: and it is said that the path is a cause. But the path is a cause in a way not common to other things, and so is the root of the profitable.

original: dassetvā taṃsampayogato sammādiṭṭhiyā maggahetukabhāvadassanattho tatiyanayo siyā.
analyzed: dassetvā tad sampayogataḥ sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ magga hetuka bhāva dassana ttho tatiya nayaḥ siyā
translated: and it is said that it is both the path and a cause. Then, after showing that it is a cause of the path by a different method not common to the other path factors, the third method may be understood as intended to show that right view is a cause of the path since it is associated with it.

original: “Ariyamaggasamaṅgissa alobho adoso ime dhammā maggahetū”tiādi vattabbaṃ siyā. Yasmā🔽pana “maggahetū”ti iminā aññena sādhāraṇena pariyāyena yesaṃ maggahetubhāvo sambhavati,
analyzed: ariya magga samaṅgissa alobhaḥ adosaḥ ime dhammā magga hetu uti ādi vattabbam siyā yasmā  pana magga hetu uti iminā aññena sādhāraṇena pariyāyena yesam magga hetu bhāvaḥ sambhavati
translated: “Non-greed and non-hate are states that are a cause of the path” should be said. But since🔽non-delusion is a cause of the path by a different method not common to the others,

original: te sabbe “maggahetū”ti dassetvā taṃsampayuttānaṃ tesaṃ aññesañca maggahetukabhāvadassanattho
analyzed: te sabbe magga hetū ti dassetvā tad sampayuttānam tesam aññesam ca magga hetuka bhāva dassana ttho
translated: it is shown that it is a cause of the path by the words “a cause of the path” and then the third method is intended to show that it is a cause of the path since it is associated with the other path factors.

original: tatiyanayo, tasmā tattha “amoho”tipi vuttaṃ. Na hi so maggahetu na hotīti. Ime pana
analyzed: tatiya nayo tasmā tattha amohaḥ ti pi vuttam na hi so magga hetu na hoti iti ime pana
translated: That is why “non-delusion” is mentioned, for it is not that it is not a cause of the path.🔽But these three methods should be regarded as “stated according to meaning” because they are stated according to the different meanings of the words. Or alternatively,

original: tayopi nayā atthavisesavasena nikkhittattā atthato nikkhepā daṭṭhabbā. Atha vā sarūpena
analyzed: tayo api nayā attha visesa vasena nikkhitta ttā atthataḥ nikkhepāḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ atha vā sarūpena
translated: they are stated according to the words.

original: vacanaṃ dhammato nikkhepo, atthena atthatoti evampi yojanā sambhavati. Tattha dutiyatatiyanayā🔽sarūpato hetuhetumantudassanavasena dhammato nikkhepo. Paṭhamanayo tathāadassanato
analyzed: vacanam dhammataḥ nikkhepaḥ atthena atthato ti evam pi yojanā sambhavati tattha dutiya tatiya nayā  sarūpataḥ hetu hetumantu dassana vasena dhammataḥ nikkhepo paṭhama nayo tathā adassanato
translated: The interpretation is possible in this way: “By the Dhamma” is by the way of the teaching; “by the meaning” is by the way of the meaning.🔽Herein, by the second and third methods🔽the “casting out by the Dhamma” is by showing the cause and the presence of a cause in the literal sense.

original: atthena ca maggaṅgataṃsampayuttānaṃ hetuhetumantubhāvāvagamanato atthato nikkhepoti.
analyzed: atthena ca hetu hetu mantu bhāva avagamanataḥ atthataḥ nikkhepaḥ ti
translated: By the first method it is “casting out by the meaning” because the cause and the presence of a cause are not shown in that way.

original: 1040. Yasmiṃ sabhāvadhamme ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena cittaṃ pavattati, so tassa ārammaṇādhipati
analyzed: yasmin sabhāva dhamme ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena cittam pavattati saḥ tassa ārammaṇa adhipati
translated: The object that the mind moves towards with a sense of depression, submission, and inclination is the object’s predominance condition for that mind.

original: veditabbo. Cetopariyañāṇena jānitvā paccavekkhamāno tena paccavekkhamānoti vutto.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ cetas pariya ñāṇena jānitvā paccavekkhamāno tena paccavekkhamāno ti vutto
translated: The one who, having known by means of the knowledge of penetration of minds, reflects, is called “one who reflects by that.”

original: Etthāpīti etasmimpi aṭṭhakathāvacane, ettha vā paṭṭhāne maggādīni ṭhapetvā aññesaṃ🔽adhipatipaccayabhāvassa avacaneneva paṭikkhepapāḷiyaṃ. Ayamevatthoti attano maggaphalaṃ
analyzed: ettha api iti etasmim pi aṭṭhakathā vacane ettha vā paṭṭhāne magga ādīni ṭhapetvā aññesam  adhipati paccaya bhāvassa a vacanena iva paṭikkhepa pāḷiyam ayam eva atthaḥ ti attanaḥ magga phalam
translated: Here too, in this commentarial passage, or here in the Schedule, by the mere fact that the path, etc., are excepted and the rest are not called predominance conditions,🔽the negation is stated. This is the meaning: “Excepting his own path and fruit,

original: ṭhapetvāti attho. Vīmaṃsādhipateyyanti padhānena adhipatinā sahajātādhipati nidassito,
analyzed: ṭhapetvā ti atthaḥ vīmaṃsa ādhipateyyam ti padhānena adhipatinā sahajāta adhipati nidassito
translated: the predominance of investigation” shows the conascence predominance by the predominance of the chief factor.

original: tayidaṃ nayadassanamattameva hotīti aññopi evaṃpakāro sahajāto maggādhipati nidassito
analyzed: tayidam naya dassana mattam eva hoti iti aññaḥ api evaṃpakāraḥ sahajātaḥ magga adhipati nidassito
translated: But this is only a way of looking at it. Another concomitant of the path is shown as the dominant condition.

original: hoti, tasmā vīriyādhipateyyanti ca yojetabbaṃ. Idampi hi atthato vuttamevāti.🔽1041. Attano sabhāvo attabhāvo. Laddhokāsassa kammassa vipāko kappasahassātikkame
analyzed: hoti tasmā vīriya ādhipateyyanti ca yojetabbam idam pi hi atthataḥ vuttam eva ati  attano sabhāvaḥ attabhāvaḥ laddha ukāsassa kammassa vipāko kappa sahassa atikkame
translated: So it should be construed as “with energy as its dominant condition.” For this is said in the same sense.🔽“Its own individual essence”: its own individual existence.

original: uppajjati anekakappasahassāyukānaṃ sattānaṃ, kappasahassātikkamepi vā laddhokāsaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati aneka kappa sahassa āyukānam sattānam kappa sahassa atikkame pi vā laddha okāsam
translated: The result of the kamma that has had opportunity to yield result arises after the lapse of a thousand aeons, in the case of beings who have a life-span of a thousand aeons, or after the lapse of a thousand aeons, in the case of those who have had opportunity to yield result even after the lapse of a thousand aeons.

original: yaṃ bhavissati, tadapi laddhokāsamevāti attano vipākaṃ sandhāya vuccati. Natthi nāma🔽na hotīti anuppanno nāma na hotīti adhippāyo. Uppādīsu antogadhattā “uppādino dhammā”ti
analyzed: yat bhavissati tat api laddha ukāsam eva ati attanaḥ vipākam sandhāya vuccati natthi nāma  na hoti iti anuppannaḥ nāma na hoti iti adhippāyaḥ uppādīsu antogadhattā uppādino dhammā ti
translated: That too is said with reference to its own result, since it is said: “There is no such thing as”🔽the non-arisen. The intention is: “There is no such thing as non-arisen.”🔽“Arisen states” are said with the intention that they are included among the kinds of arising.

original: etena vacanena vuccatīti katvā āha “uppādino dhammā nāma jāto”ti. Arūpasaṅkhāto attāti
analyzed: etena vacanena vuccati iti katvā āha uppādinaḥ dhammā nāma jātaḥ ti arūpa saṅkhātaḥ attā iti
translated: “The self consisting of the immaterial aggregates” is the immaterial life-continuum.

original: arūpabhavaṅgaṃ āha. Tattha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññādimayo attāti hi atthato vohāro pavattoti.
analyzed: arūpa bhavaṅgam āha tattha ākāsa anañcāyatana saññā ādi mayaḥ attā iti hi atthataḥ vohāro pavatto ti
translated: Herein, the usage is in terms of the self consisting of the perception of the base consisting of boundless space, and so on.

original: Yadi pana āyū…pe… sabbaṃ vipākaṃ dadeyya, aladdhokāsañca vipākaṃ detīti katvā vipakkavipākañca
analyzed: yadi pana āyūpe sabbam vipākam dadeyya a laddha ukāsam ca vipākam deti iti katvā vipakka vipākam ca
translated: But if the life faculty … were to give all its ripening, it would give ripening without opportunity, and it would give ripening that has already given ripening, and it would give ripening that has not yet given ripening, and it would give ripening that is being given.🔽

original: dadeyya, tato ekasseva kammassa sabbavipākena bhavitabbanti aññassa kammassa okāso
analyzed: dadeyya tatas ekassa iva kammassa sabba vipākena bhavitabbanti aññassa kammassa okāsaḥ
translated: If, however, it were to give all its ripening at once, and if it were to give ripening even without having had an opportunity to do so, then it would have to be the ripening of a single kamma that would be all the ripening. Consequently,

original: na bhaveyya niratthakattā, uppattiyāyeva okāso na bhaveyya, uppannassa vā phaladāne.
analyzed: na bhaveyya niratthaka ttā uppattiyāya iva okāsaḥ na bhaveyya uppannassa vā phala dāne
translated: there would be no opportunity for any other kamma to ripen. And it would be pointless for it to have arisen, or for it to give its fruit when it has arisen, since it would have to give its fruit even without having had an opportunity to do so.

original: Atha vā aladdhokāsassa vipākadāne paccayantararahitassapi vipākadānaṃ āpannanti avijjātaṇhādipaccayantarakhepakassa
analyzed: atha vā aladdha ukāsassa vipāka dāne paccaya antara rahitassa api vipāka dānam āpannanti avijjā taṇhā ādi paccaya antara khepakassa
translated: Or else, if it were to give its fruit even without having had an opportunity to do so, then it would follow that it would give its fruit even without the other conditions such as ignorance, craving, etc.,

original: aññassa apacayagāmikammassa kammakkhayakarassa okāso na bhaveyya. Bhāvitepi magge
analyzed: aññassa apacaya gāmi kammassa kamma khaya karassa okāsaḥ na bhaveyya bhāvite pi magge
translated: and so there would be no opportunity for any other kamma that causes diminution to ripen, or for any kamma that causes exhaustion of kamma to ripen. And even if the path were developed,

original: avijjādipaccayantararahitassa ca kammassa vipaccanato samatthatā na siyāti attho.
analyzed: avijjā ādi paccaya antara rahitassa ca kammassa vipaccanataḥ samattha tā na siyāti attho
translated: it would not be possible for it to be effective, since kamma that lacks the other conditions such as ignorance, etc., would ripen.

original: Sabbadā vā vipākappavattiyā eva bhavitabbattā vipākato aññassa pavattiokāso na bhaveyya.
analyzed: sabbadā vā vipāka ppavattiyāḥ eva bhavitabba ttā vipākataḥ aññassa pavatti okāsaḥ na bhaveyya
translated: Or else, since it would have to give its fruit all the time, there would be no opportunity for anything else to occur apart from the fruit of kamma.

original: Taṃ panāti āyūhitaṃ kammaṃ. Idaṃ pana dhuvavipākassa vipākena adhuvavipākassapi laddhokāsassa🔽vipākaṃ uppādīti dassetuṃ āraddhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo ca balavavirahe
analyzed: tam pana ati āyūhitam kammam idam pana dhuva vipākassa vipākena adhuva vipākassa api laddha okāsassa  vipākam uppādi iti dassetum āraddhanti daṭṭhabbam aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ ca balava virahe
translated: But that is the kamma that has been stored up. But this is begun in order to show that the result of kamma that is bound to ripen must ripen before the result of kamma that is not so bound, though it has had occasion to do so, can ripen.

original: aggamaggabhāvanāvirahe ca appahīnasabhāvato dhuvaṃ vipaccantīti dhuvavipākāti vuttā.
analyzed: agga magga bhāvanā virahe ca appahīna sabhāvataḥ dhuvam vipaccanti iti dhuva vipākā ati vuttā
translated: And the eight attainments are called “bound to ripen” because they are bound to ripen in the absence of a powerful counter-state and in the absence of the development of the supramundane states, since they have not abandoned their individual essences.🔽When it is said “stored up,” why is it said of what has not arisen?

original: Āyūhitakamme vuccamāne anuppannaṃ kasmā vuttanti? Yaṃ āyūhitaṃ bhavissati, tatthāpi🔽āyūhita-saddappavattisabbhāvā.
analyzed: āyūhita kamme vuccamāne anuppannam kasmā vuttan ti yat āyūhitam bhavissati tattha api  āyūhita sadda ppavatti sabbhāvā
translated: Because the word “stored up” will apply to that when it has arisen.

original: 1050. Upādinnāti ettha na upetena ādinnāti ayamattho, upasaddo pana upasaggamattameva,🔽tasmā upādānārammaṇā upādānehi, aññe ca anabhinivesena “ahaṃ maggaṃ bhāvayiṃ, mama🔽maggo uppanno”tiādikena gahaṇena ādinnā icceva upādinnā. Upādinna-saddena vā amaggaphaladhammāyeva
analyzed: upādinnā ati ettha na upetena ādinnā ati ayam attho upasaddo pana upasagga mattam eva  tasmai upādāna ārammaṇā upādānehi aññe ca anabhinivesena aham maggam bhāvayim mama  maggaḥ uppannaḥ ti ādikena gahaṇena ādinnāḥ icca iva upādinnāḥ upādinna saddena vā amagga phala dhammāya iva
translated: As to “acquired”: the meaning here is not “taken up by what has approached,” but the prefix upa is merely a prefix.🔽So what is acquired by the kinds of acquiring consisting in the four kinds of grasping and by the other kinds of acquiring consisting in non-adherence, etc., is called “acquired” in the sense that it is taken up by such acquiring as “I develop the path,” “The path has arisen in me,” and so on.

original: vuttā, itarehi maggaphaladhammā cāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttāḥ itarehi magga phala dhammā ca ati veditabbam
translated: Or alternatively, what is called “acquired” should be understood as states other than the path and fruition, which are called “acquired” by the word “acquired,” while the path and fruition are called “not acquired.”

original: Tikanikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tika nikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section on the triple round is ended.

original: Dukanikkhepakathāvaṇṇanā🔽1062. Mettāyanavasenāti mettāpharaṇavasena. “Mettayanavasenā”ti vattabbe dīghaṃ katvā🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mettā, medanaṃ vā mettāyanaṃ, tañca sinehavasena. Anudayatīti🔽anudāti vattabbe “anuddā”ti da-kārāgamanaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Anuddāyanākāroti anurakkhaṇākāro.🔽Rakkhaṇañhi dāyanā. Anuddāyitassāti anuddāya ayitassa. “Jātipi dukkhā”tiādiṃ suṇantassa
analyzed: duka nikkhepa kathā vaṇṇanā  mettāyana vasena ati mettā pharaṇa vasena mettayana vasena ati vattabbe dīgham katvā  vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam mettā medanam vā mettāyanam tat ca sineha vasena anudayati iti  an udā ti vattabbe an uddā ti dakāra āgamanam katvā vuttam an uddāyana ākāraḥ ti anurakkhaṇa ākāraḥ  rakkhaṇan hi an uddāyitassa ati an uddāya ayitassa suṇantassa
translated: The commentary on the section on the double round

original: savane, aniccādito sammasantassa sammasane, maggenettha sammohaṃ viddhaṃsentassa🔽paṭivedhe, paṭivijjhitvā paccavekkhantassa paccavekkhaṇeti catūsu kālesu dukkhe ñāṇaṃ vattati.🔽1065. Cittassa saṃrañjanaṃ cittassa sārāgo. Gijjhantīti abhikaṅkhanti. Sañjaṃntīti
analyzed: savane anicca āditaḥ sammasantassa sammasane maggena ittha sammoham viddhaṃsentassa 🔽paṭivedhe paṭivijjhitvā paccavekkhantassa paccavekkhaṇa iti catūsu kālesu dukkhe ñāṇam vattati 🔽cittassa saṃrañjanam cittassa sārāgaḥ gijjhanti iti abhikaṅkhanti sañjanti iti

By the way of lovingkindness: by the spreading of lovingkindness. “By the way of lovingkindness” should be said; but it is said by lengthening the vowel of the final a of the first word. original: bandhanti. Lagganaṭṭhenāti saṃvaraṇaṭṭhena, olambanaṭṭhena vā. Tassa tasseva bhavassāti
analyzed: bandhanti laggana ṭṭhena ati saṃvaraṇa ṭṭhena olambana ṭṭhena vā tassa tassa iva bhavassa ati
translated: ‘For the purpose of tying’ means for the purpose of binding, or for the purpose of hanging on to. ‘To that and that becoming’ means

original: kāmabhavādisaṅkhātassa vipākakaṭattārūpassa abhinibbattiatthaṃ paṭisandhiyā paccayabhāvavasena
analyzed: kāma bhava ādi saṅkhātassa vipāka kaṭattā rūpassa abhinibbatti attham paṭisandhiyā paccaya bhāva vasena
translated: They bind. As the binding of the fetters: as the binding, or as the hanging down. For the sake of the particular kind of becoming: for the sake of the manifestation of the materiality of the kamma-result called the sensual-desire becoming, etc.,

original: parikaḍḍhati. Cittamassa bhavantare vidhāvati nibbattati. Taṇhāvipphanditaniveso
analyzed: parikaḍḍhati cittam assa bhavantare vidhāvati nibbattati taṇhā vipphandita niveso
translated: he leads on by way of being a condition for rebirth-linking. His consciousness runs on in the next becoming and is reborn. The spreading out of craving:

original: aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritādibhāvena taṇhāpavattiyeva.🔽Saritānīti rāgavasena allāni. Taṃsampayuttapītivasena siniddhāni sinehitāni. Visatāti🔽vitthatā. Rūpādīsu tebhūmakadhammesu byāpanavasena visaṭā. Purimavacanameva ta-kārassa🔽ṭa-kāraṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Visālāti vipulā. Visakkatīti parisappati, sahati vā. Ratto
analyzed: aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicarita ādi bhāvena taṇhā pavattiyā iva  saritāni iti rāga vasena allāni tad sampayutta pīti vasena siniddhāni sinehitāni  vitthatā rūpa ādīsu tebhūmaka dhammesu byāpana vasena purima vacanam eva takārassa  ṭakāram katvā vuttam visālāti vipulā visakkati iti parisappati sahati vā rattaḥ
translated: the occurrence of craving in the eighty-nine modes of craving, etc., is itself the spreading out of craving.🔽The flowing: the flowing with lust is the flowing with greed. The trickling: the trickling with greed is the trickling with greed. The spreading:

original: hi rāgavatthunā pādena tāliyamānopi sahatīti. Osakkanaṃ, vipphandanaṃ vā visakkananti
analyzed: hi rāga vatthunā pādena tāliyamānaḥ api sahati iti osakkanam vipphandanam vā visakkananti
translated: the spreading is the spreading out. It is the spreading out by way of pervading the states of the three planes beginning with materiality. The word “spreading” is said by changing the “ta” of the word “flowing” to “da.” The spreading out: the spreading out is the spreading out. The spreading out is the spreading out by way of pervading the states of the three planes beginning with materiality. The spreading out is the spreading out. original: vadanti. Aniccādiṃ niccādito gaṇhantī visaṃvādikā hoti. Visaṃharatīti tathā tathā
analyzed: vadanti anicca ādim nicca ādeḥ gaṇhantī visaṃvādikā visaṃharati iti tathā tathā
translated: They say: It is deceptive, taking what is impermanent, etc., as permanent, etc. It deceives, in the sense that it deceives by making things appear otherwise than they are.

original: kāmesu ānisaṃsaṃ passantī vividhehākārehi nekkhammābhimukhappavattito cittaṃ saṃharati
analyzed: kāmesu ānisaṃsam passantī vividhehi ākārehi nekkhamma abhimukha ppavattitaḥ cittam saṃharati
translated: They say: It is deceptive because it takes what is impermanent, etc., as permanent, etc. It draws together: it draws together, it gathers, the mind that is inclined to renunciation by occurring in various ways with the perception of the advantages in renunciation.

original: saṅkhipati. Visaṃ vā dukkhaṃ, taṃ harati vahatīti attho. Dukkhanibbattakassa kammassa🔽hetubhāvato visamūlā, visaṃ vā dukkhavedanāmūlaṃ etissāti visamūlā. Dukkhasamudayattā
analyzed: saṅkhipati visam vā dukkham tam harati vahati iti atthaḥ dukkha nibbattakassa kammassa  hetu bhāvataḥ visa mūlā visam vā dukkha vedanā mūlam etissa ati visa mūlā dukkha samudaya ttā
translated: Or it draws out, it carries out, what is harmful, is the meaning. It is harmful because it is the root of the kamma that generates suffering.🔽Or it is harmful because it goes to the root of the harmful feeling of pain. It is harmful because it goes to the fruit of the harmful, that is, because it is the origin of suffering.

original: visaṃ phalaṃ etissāti visaphalā. Taṇhāya rūpādikassa dukkhasseva paribhogo hoti,
analyzed: visam phalam etissa ati visa phalā taṇhāya rūpa ādikassa dukkhassa iva paribhogaḥ hoti
translated: Because of craving, there is the enjoyment of only suffering in the form, etc., that is enjoyed,

original: na amatassāti sā “visaparibhogā”ti vuttā. Sabbattha niruttivasena padasiddhi veditabbā.🔽Yo panettha padhāno attho, taṃ dassetuṃ puna “visatā vā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Itthabhāvaññathābhāvanti
analyzed: na amatassa ati sā visa paribhogā ati vuttā sabbattha nirutti vasena pada siddhi veditabbā  yaḥ pana ittha padhānaḥ attho tam dassetum puna visatā vā pana atiādi vuttam ittha bhāva aññathābhāvanti
translated: not of the deathless. That is why it is said to be the enjoyment of the harmful. The derivation of the words should be understood as having the meaning of “without outlet” in all instances.

original: manussabhāvadevādibhāvabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: manuḥ sabhāva deva ādi bhāva bhūtam
translated: But in order to point out the principal meaning here, it is said again: “Or alternatively, it is harmful because it is a poison,” and so on. The state of being a woman, etc., is the state of being a human being, a god, and so on.

original: Paṇidhānakavasenāti cittassa rūpādīsu ṭhapanakavasena. Aññopi bandhu taṇhāya eva
analyzed: paṇidhānaka vasena āti cittassa rūpa ādīsu ṭhapanaka vasena aññaḥ api bandhu taṇhāya eva
translated: By way of resolve : by way of the resolve of the mind to stand fast on form, etc.

original: hoti, so pana abandhupi hoti. Taṇhā pana niccasannissitāti “pāṭiyekko bandhū”ti vuttā.
analyzed: hoti saḥ pana hoti taṇhā pana nicca sannissitā ti pāṭiyekkaḥ bandhu iti vuttā
translated: Other relatives are relatives only by way of craving. But they may not be relatives at all. Craving, however, is always a relative.🔽By way of eating : by way of eating after having swallowed. Both are shown by “by way of devouring.”

original: Asanatoti byāpanato bhuñjanato ca. Tadubhayaṃ dasseti “ajjhottharaṇato”tiādinā. Āsīsanavasenāti
analyzed: asanataḥ ti byāpanataḥ bhuñjanataḥ ca tat ubhayam dasseti ajjhottharaṇataḥ ti ādinā āsīsana vasena ati
translated: By way of desire : by way of wishing.

original: icchanavasena. Aññenākārenāti jappanājappitattānaṃ jappāya anaññattadassanākārena.
analyzed: icchana vasena aññena ākārena ati jappana a jappita ttānam jappāya an aññatta dassana ākārena
translated: By another method : by the method of not seeing that the one who is being chewed is different from the one who is chewing.

original: Cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhātīti cittaṃ mūsati. Mārapāsoti mārena gahitatāya rāgo mārapāso.
analyzed: cittam pariyuṭṭhāti iti cittam mūsati māra pāsaḥ iti mārena gahita tāya rāgaḥ māra pāsaḥ
translated: It obsesses the mind : it obsesses the mind and deceives it. The snare of Mara : because it is seized by Mara, craving is the snare of Mara.

original: 1066. Saṅkhāresu uppanno kammapathabhedaṃ na karotīti etena sattesu uppanno aṭṭhānakopo🔽karotīti viññāyati. “Atthaṃ me nācari, na carati, na carissati, piyassa me manāpassa
analyzed: saṅkhāresu uppannaḥ kamma patha bhedam na karoti iti etena sattesu uppannaḥ aṭṭhāna kopaḥ  karoti iti viññāyati attham me na acari na carati na carissati piyassa me manāpassa
translated: By this he shows that it does not make the distinction of the courses of kamma that arise in formations.🔽By “does not make” is shown the anger that arises in beings and is groundless.🔽“He does not do what is good for me, is not doing it, and will not do it. He does not do what is good for my loved ones …

original: atthaṃ nācari, na carati, na carissati, appiyassa me amanāpassa anatthaṃ nācari,
analyzed: attham na acari na carati na carissati appiyassa me amanāpassa anattham na acari
translated: He does what is not good for me … for my loved ones …

original: na carati, na carissatī”ti uppajjamānopi hi kopo avatthusmiṃ uppannattā aṭṭhānakopo
analyzed: na carati na carissati iti uppajjamānaḥ api hi kopaḥ avatthusmim uppanna ttā aṭṭhāna kopaḥ
translated: For even if anger arises, it is not proper to arise in a non-ground, and so it is called “anger that is not proper to arise.”

original: eva bhavituṃ yutto. Āghātentoti hananto. Punaruttidoso paṭisedhitoti dosa-padassa🔽paṭivirodha-padassa ca dvikkhattuṃ āgatattā vuttaṃ. Paṭighassa vā visesanatthaṃ pubbe
analyzed: eva bhavitum yuttaḥ āghātento ti hananto punarutti doso paṭisedhito ti dosa padassa  paṭivirodha padassa ca dvi kkhattum āgata ttā vuttam paṭighassa vā visesana attham pubbe
translated: “Striking” means “killing.” The fault of repetition is avoided,🔽because the words dosa and paṭivirodha are used twice. Or, in order to specify paṭighā,

original: “paṭivirodho”ti, padosādivisesanatthaṃ “doso”ti ca vuttaṃ, dussanādivisesanatthaṃ
analyzed: paṭivirodho ti padosa ādi visesana attham doso ti ca vuttam dussana ādi visesana attham
translated: “paṭivirodha” is used first, and in order to specify padosa, etc.,

original: pacchā “doso”ti, virodhavisesanatthañca “paṭivirodho”ti vuttanti natthi punaruttidoso.🔽1091. Aniddhāritaparicchede dhammānaṃ atthitāmattadīpake mātikuddese aparicchedena
analyzed: pacchā doso ti virodha visesana attham ca paṭivirodho ti vuttan ti natthi punarutti doso  a niddhārita paricchede dhammānam atthi tā a matta dīpake mātikā uddese a paricchedena
translated: “dosa” is used later. And in order to specify virodha, “paṭivirodha” is used. So there is no fault of repetition.🔽In the chapter on the Undetermined, the headings are stated to show the mere existence of dhammas without determining them. Therefore, the question is asked in the plural,

original: bahuvacanena uddeso katoti bahuvacaneneva pucchati – “katame dhammā appaccayā”ti.
analyzed: bahuvacanena uddeso kato ti bahuvacanena iva pucchati katame dhammā appaccayā ti
translated: “What are the dhammas that are not conditions?”

original: Sabhāvasaṅkhāparicchedādivasena hi dhamme ajānantassa vasena uddeso pucchā ca karīyatīti.
analyzed: sabhāva saṅkhā pariccheda ādi vasena hi dhamme a jānantassa vasena uddeso pucchā ca
translated: For the question and the answer are given from the point of view of one who does not know dhammas by way of their individual essences, by way of their determination, etc.

original: Tasmā paricchedaṃ akatvā uddiṭṭhā pucchitā ca. Imeti asaṅkhatadhātuto uddhaṃ natthīti
analyzed: tasmā paricchedam a katvā uddiṭṭhā pucchitā ca imā iti asaṅkhata dhātutaḥ natthi iti
translated: So without making any such distinction, they are mentioned and asked about. And the plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.🔽The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.

original: dīpanatthaṃ ekampi taṃ niddisitvā bahuvacaneneva nigamanaṃ kataṃ niddesato pubbe
analyzed: dīpana ttham ekam pi tam niddisitvā bahuvacanena iva nigamanam katam niddesataḥ pubbe
translated: The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.

original: bodhaneyyassa ajānanakālaṃ upādāya.
analyzed: bodhaneyyassa a jānana kālam upādāya
translated: The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.

original: 1101. Kiṃ pana natthi, kiṃ tena na vuttāti yojanā kātabbā. Idameva manoviññeyyanti🔽niyamābhāvo vavatthānābhāvo. Cakkhuviññāṇādiviññeyyameva cakkhādiviññeyyanti pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: kim pana natthi kim tena na vuttā ati yojanā kātabbā idam eva manaḥ viññeyyanti  niyama abhāvaḥ vavatthāna abhāvaḥ cakkhu viññāṇa ādi viññeyyam eva cakkha ādi viññeyyanti pāḷiyam
translated: The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.🔽The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.

original: vuttanti manoviññāṇaviññeyyenapi manoviññeyyena bhavitabbanti katvā aṭṭhakathāya🔽“kiṃ pana manoviññāṇenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kehici viññeyyā kehici aviññeyyāti idaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ
analyzed: vuttam ti manaḥ viññāṇa viññeyyena api manaḥ viññeyyena bhavitabban ti katvā aṭṭhakathāya  kim pana manaḥ viññāṇena atiādi vuttam kehici viññeyyā kehici aviññeyyā ti idam kāmāvacaram
translated: The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.🔽The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.

original: manoviññāṇaṃ ārammaṇādivasena bhinditvā yojetabbaṃ. Rūpāvacarādiārammaṇena hi kāmāvacaramanoviññāṇena
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇam ārammaṇa ādi vasena bhinditvā yojetabbam rūpāvacara ādi ārammaṇena hi kāmāvacara manaḥ viññāṇena
translated: The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing beyond the unformed element.🔽The demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in order to show that the unformed element is the only one of its kind.🔽The plural form in the phrase “these three kinds of unformed element” is used in order to show that there is nothing

original: rūparāgādisampayuttena ca kāmāvacaradhammā na viññeyyā, itarena ca viññeyyā. Evaṃ
analyzed: rūpa rāga ādi sampayuttena ca kāmāvacara dhammā na viññeyyāḥ itarena ca viññeyyāḥ evam
translated: And states of the sense sphere associated with attachment to materiality, etc., are not cognizable by the latter, but they are cognizable by the former.

original: kāmāvacarānameva ārammaṇānaṃ kesañci saddādīnaṃ rūpārammaṇādīhi aviññeyyatā viññeyyatā
analyzed: kāmāvacarānam eva ārammaṇānam kesañci sadda ādīnam rūpa ārammaṇa ādīhi aviññeyya tā viññeyya tā
translated: So too with the other kinds of sense-sphere states.

original: ca yojetabbā, tathā dvārabhedavasena. Atha vā somanassasahagatasantīraṇaṃ iṭṭhārammaṇamevāti
analyzed: ca yojetabbā tathā dvāra bheda vasena atha vā somanassa sahagata santīraṇam iṭṭha ārammaṇam eva ati
translated: Or alternatively, applied thought accompanied by joy is only on a desirable object,

original: itaraṃ tena na viññeyyaṃ. Evaṃ upekkhāsahagate kusalavipāke akusalavipāke cāti sabbattha🔽yathāyogaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Rūpāvacarādayo kāmāvacaravipākādīhi aviññeyyā, kecideva viññeyyā
analyzed: itaram tena na viññeyyam evam upekkhā sahagate kusala vipāke akusala vipāke ca ati sabbattha  yathāyogam yojetabbam rūpāvacara ādayaḥ kāmāvacara vipāka ādīhi aviññeyyā kecid eva viññeyyā
translated: so the other is not cognizable by it. So too with the profitable resultant and the unprofitable resultant accompanied by equanimity.🔽The kinds of states cognizable and not cognizable should be construed in each case according to the method stated.🔽The kinds of states of the fine-material sphere, etc., are not cognizable by the kinds of states of the sense sphere, etc., but some are cognizable by some.

original: arūpāvacarehīti yojetabbaṃ anuvattamānattā. Nibbānena aviññeyyattāti “kehici aviññeyyā”ti
analyzed: arūpāvacarehi iti yojetabbam anuvattamāna ttā nibbānena a viññeyya ttā ati kehici a viññeyyā ati
translated: The kinds of states of the immaterial sphere are not cognizable by the kinds of states of the sense sphere and fine-material sphere, but some are cognizable by some.

original: imassa padassa atthasambhavamattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na nibbānassa anuvattamānamanoviññāṇabhāvato.
analyzed: imassa padassa attha sambhava mattam sandhāya vuttam na nibbānassa anuvattamāna manaḥ viññāṇa bhāvato
translated: As to “not cognizable by Nibbāna”: this is said merely to point out the meaning of the words “not cognizable by some,” not to point out the fact that Nibbāna is not cognizable by the mind that occurs in conformity with it.

original: 1102. Pañcakāmaguṇikarāgoti ukkaṭṭhavasena vuttaṃ. Bhavāsavaṃ ṭhapetvā sabbo lobho
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇika rāgo ti ukkaṭṭha vasena vuttam bhava āsavam ṭhapetvā sabbaḥ lobho
translated: All greed except for the taint of existence🔽is fitting to be called the taint of sensual desire.

original: kāmāsavoti yuttaṃ siyā. Sassatadiṭṭhisahagato rāgo bhavadiṭṭhisampayuttattā “bhavāsavo”ti
analyzed: kāma āsavaḥ ti yuttam siyā sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgaḥ bhava diṭṭhi sampayutta ttā bhava āsavaḥ ti
translated: The lust associated with the eternalist view is called the taint of existence in the commentary because it is associated with the view of existence.🔽But the taint of existence is said in the text

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vutto. Bhavāsavo pana “diṭṭhigatavippayuttesu eva uppajjatī”ti pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttaḥ bhava āsavaḥ pana diṭṭhi gata vippayuttesu eva uppajjati iti pāḷiyam
translated: to arise only in the states dissociated from false views.🔽That lust is also fitting to be the taint of sensual desire.

original: vutto. Sopi rāgo kāmāsavo bhavituṃ yutto. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikadukkhānaṃ kāraṇabhūtā
analyzed: vuttaḥ saḥ api rāgaḥ kāma āsavaḥ bhavitum yuttaḥ diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika dukkhānam kāraṇa bhūtā
translated: The taints of sensual desire, etc., which are the cause of suffering in this life and in future lives,

original: kāmāsavādayopi dvidhā vuttā.🔽1103. Kāmāsavaniddese ca kāmesūti kāmarāgadiṭṭhirāgādiārammaṇabhūtesu tebhūmakesu
analyzed: dvidhā vuttā  kāma āsava niddese ca kāmesu iti kāma rāga diṭṭhi rāga ādi ārammaṇa bhūtesu tebhūmakesu
translated: are also said to be twofold.🔽And in the description of the taint of sensual desire, the words “in the sense desires”🔽can be taken to mean “in the sense desires as objects,” that is, in the sense desires of the three planes as objects of lust for sense desires and lust for views.

original: vatthukāmesūti attho sambhavati. Tattha hi uppajjamānā sā taṇhā sabbāpi na kāmacchandādināmaṃ
analyzed: vatthu kāmesu iti atthaḥ sambhavati tattha hi uppajjamānā sā taṇhā sabbā api na kāmacchanda ādi nāmam
translated: For all craving that arises there does not get the name “lust for sense desires,” etc.

original: na labhatīti. Kattukamyatāchando akusalepi uppajjati, na pana dhammacchando.
analyzed: na labhati iti kattu kamya tā chandaḥ akusale pi uppajjati na pana dhamma chandaḥ
translated: The desire to do is found in the unwholesome, but not the desire for the Dhamma.

original: 1105. Aññaṃ jīvanti gahaṇaṃ yadipi upādānakkhandhesveva pavattati, rūpe…pe… viññāṇe🔽vā pana na patiṭṭhāti. Tato aññaṃ katvā jīvaṃ gaṇhātīti sassatadiṭṭhi hotīti. Brahmādiṃ
analyzed: aññam jīvanti gahaṇam yadi api upādānakkhandhesu eva pavattati viññāṇe  vā pana na patiṭṭhāti tatas aññam katvā jīvam gaṇhāti iti sassata diṭṭhi hoti iti brahma ādim
translated: If he apprehends the life-continuum as “another,” then he has the eternalist view that “the life-continuum is not established in material form, etc.,

original: ekaccaṃ attānaṃ “hotī”ti niccato aññañca “na hotī”ti aniccato gaṇhantassa “hoti ca🔽na ca hotī”ti ekaccasassatadiṭṭhi. “Hotī”ti ca puṭṭhe “nevā”ti, “na hotī”ti ca puṭṭhe🔽“na”iti sabbattha paṭikkhipantassa amarāvikkhepadiṭṭhi, amarā anupacchedā, amaramacchasadisī
analyzed: ekaccam attānam hoti iti niccatas aññam ca na hoti iti aniccatas gaṇhantassa hoti ca  na ca hoti iti ekacca sassata diṭṭhi hoti iti ca puṭṭhe na iva ati na hoti iti ca puṭṭhe  na eti sabbattha paṭikkhipantassa amara a vikkhepa diṭṭhi amarā an upacchedā amara maccha sadisī
translated: but it exists as something other than that.” If he apprehends the self as “existing” in the sense of permanence and as “not existing” in the sense of impermanence, then he has the view of partial-eternalism.

original: vā vikkhepadiṭṭhīti attho.🔽Pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgo kāmāsavoti vuttoti katvā brahmānaṃ vimānādīsu rāgassa diṭṭhirāgassa
analyzed: vā vikkhepa diṭṭhī iti atthaḥ  pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ rāgaḥ kāmāsavaḥ ti vutto ti katvā brahmānam vimāna ādīsu rāgassa diṭṭhi rāgassa
translated: If he denies the question “Does it exist?” by saying “It does not,” and if he denies the question “Does it not exist?” by saying “It does not not exist,” then he has the view of endless equivocation. The meaning is that he equivocates like an immortal, i.e., without interruption, or like an immortal being.

original: ca kāmāsavabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Yadi pana lobho kāmāsavabhavāsavavinimutto atthi,
analyzed: ca kāma āsava bhāvam paṭikkhipati yadi pana lobho kāma āsava bhava āsava vinimutto atthi
translated: Since lust for the five strands of sense pleasure is called the taint of sensual desire, he denies that lust for the divine mansions, etc., and lust for the view are the taint of sensual desire. But if there is greed that is separate from the taint of sensual desire and the taint of existence,

original: so yadā diṭṭhigatavippayuttesu uppajjati, tadā tena sampayutto avijjāsavo āsavavippayuttoti
analyzed: so yadā diṭṭhi gata vippayuttesu uppajjati tadā tena sampayuttaḥ avijjā āsavaḥ āsava vippayuttaḥ ti
translated: But when it arises in the four types of consciousness dissociated from false view, then ignorance associated with it is dissociated from the defilements.

original: domanassavicikicchuddhaccasampayuttassa viya tassapi āsavavippayuttatā vattabbā siyā
analyzed: domanassa vicikicchu ddhacca sampayuttassa viya tassa api āsava vippayutta tā vattabbā siyā
translated: So it should be said that it is dissociated from the defilements, like joy and grief and doubt and the rest.

original: “catūsu diṭṭhigatavippayuttesu lobhasahagatesu cittuppādesu uppanno moho siyā āsavasampayutto
analyzed: catūsu diṭṭhi gata vippayuttesu lobha sahagatesu cittuppādesu uppannaḥ mohaḥ siyā āsava sampayutto
translated: “Delusion that arises in the four types of consciousness dissociated from false view and accompanied by joy is either associated with the defilements or dissociated from the defilements” .

original: siyā āsavavippayutto”ti. “Kāmāsavo aṭṭhasu lobhasahagatesu cittuppādesu uppajjatī”ti,🔽“kāmāsavaṃ paṭicca diṭṭhāsavo avijjāsavo”ti ca vacanato diṭṭhisahagato rāgo kāmāsavo
analyzed: siyā āsava vippayutto ti kāma āsavaḥ aṭṭhasu lobha sahagatesu cittuppādesu uppajjati iti  kāma āsavam paṭicca diṭṭha āsavaḥ avijjā āsavaḥ ti ca vacanataḥ diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgaḥ kāma āsavaḥ
translated: “The sensual-desire inherent tendency arises in the eight types of consciousness accompanied by joy” .🔽“The sensual-desire inherent tendency is a condition, as a decisive-support condition, for the false-view inherent tendency and the ignorance inherent tendency” .🔽So it cannot be said that lust associated with false view is not the sensual-desire inherent tendency. It is proper to quote it in the order of the defilements.

original: na hotīti na sakkā vattuṃ. Kilesapaṭipāṭiyāpi āharituṃ vaṭṭatīti āsavānaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: na hoti iti na sakkā vattum kilesa paṭipāṭiyā api āharitum vaṭṭati iti āsavānam vacanam
translated: The words “for the purpose of showing what is to be abandoned” are said

original: pahātabbadassanatthanti katvā te pahāne āhariyamānā pahātabbānampi tesaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: pahātabba dassana attham ti katvā te pahāne āhariyamānā pahātabbānam pi tesam kilesānam
translated: with reference to the abandoning of the inherent tendencies. When they are quoted in order of abandoning, it is proper to quote them in the order of the objects to be abandoned.

original: uddesakkamena āharituṃ vaṭṭanti pajahanakānaṃ maggānampīti attho.
analyzed: uddesa kkamena āharitum vaṭṭanti pajahanakānam maggānam pi iti attho
translated: The meaning is: it is proper to quote them in the order of the paths that abandon them.

original: 1121. Paṭhamakamānabhājanīyeti “seyyohamasmī”ti mānassa niddese. Tattha hi “ekacco🔽jātiyā vā gottena vā kolaputtiyena vā vaṇṇapokkharatāya vā dhanena vā ajjhenena vā🔽kammāyatanena vā sippāyatanena vā vijjāṭṭhānena vā sutena vā paṭibhānena vā aññataraññatarena🔽vā vatthunā mānaṃ jappeti, yo evarūpo māno maññanā…pe… ketukamyatā cittassā”ti seyyassa
analyzed: paṭhamaka māna bhājanīyā iti seyya uham asmi iti mānassa niddese tattha hi ekaccaḥ  jātiyā vā gottena vā kola puttiyena vā vaṇṇa pokkharatāya vā dhanena vā ajjhenena vā  kamma āyatanena vā sippa āyatanena vā vijjāṭṭhānena vā sutena vā paṭibhānena vā aññatara aññatarena  vā vatthunā mānam jappeti yaḥ evarūpaḥ mānaḥ maññanāpe ketu kamya tā cittassa ati seyyassa
translated: In the description of the conceit “I am better” in the first section on the kinds of persons not fit for the higher austerity, for example, it is said: “Here someone is conceited because of birth, race, family, beauty, wealth, craft, or vehicle, or because of one or other of the sciences, or because of fields of activity, or because of learning or memory or eloquence or because of head-shaving and the wearing of the ochre robe. Whatever conceit there is of this kind, this conceiving is conceiving in self, I say, or conceiving in things pertaining to self, I say, or conceiving in conceit, I say, or conceiving in the sign of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the defilement of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the manifestation of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the sign of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the defilement of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the manifestation of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the sign of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the defilement of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the manifestation of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the sign of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the defilement of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the manifestation of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the description of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the description of the sign of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the description of the defilement of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the description of the manifestation of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description of the description of the description of the description of conceit, I say, or conceiving in the description of the description

original: sadisassa hīnassa ca pavattamāno puggalavisesaṃ anāmasitvā seyyamāno vibhattoti imamatthaṃ🔽sandhāya “eko māno tiṇṇaṃ janānaṃ uppajjatīti kathito”ti āha. Na kevalañcāyaṃ paṭhamakamānabhājanīye🔽eva evaṃ kathito, dutiyakatatiyakamānabhājanīyepi kathito evāti nidassanamatthaṃ
analyzed: sadisassa hīnassa ca pavattamānaḥ puggala visesam an āmasitvā seyyamānaḥ vibhattaḥ ti imam attham 🔽sandhāya ekaḥ mānaḥ tiṇṇam janānam uppajjati iti kathitaḥ iti āha na kevalam ca ayam paṭhamaka māna bhājanīye 🔽eva evam kathitaḥ dutiyaka tatiyaka māna bhājanīye pi kathitaḥ eva ati nidassanam attham
translated: In the first section on the vessel of conceit, in the description of the conceit “I am better” . Herein, “one conceives himself on account of some such ground as birth, race, clan, family line, wealth, grain, gold, silver, property, action, or occupation, or on account of some such ground as knowledge, craft, or skill, or on account of some such ground as ‘I am handsome, good-looking, pleasing, of lovely complexion, of lovely skin,’ or on account of some such ground as ‘I am strong, healthy, free from illness, and able to endure hardship’ or on account of some such ground as ‘I am well-known, famous, renowned, and celebrated,’ or on account of some such ground as ‘I am happy, joyful, confident, and well-behaved,’ or on account of some such ground as ‘I am virtuous, learned, a Dhamma-man, a virtue-and-Dhamma-man, a meditator, a concentration-man, a wise man, a concentration-and-wisdom-man, a man who has attained, a man of insight, a man of concentration, a man of wisdom, a man of deliverance, a man who has known and experienced the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are without influxes, and I live in conformity with that deliverance’—in each case it is the conceiving, the conceiving of, the act of conceiving, the conceiving that has arisen, the arisen conceiving, the conceiving that has appeared, the appearance of conceiving, the bond of conceiving, the underlying tendency to conceiving, the deviousness of conceiving, the perverseness of conceiving, the perversion of conceiving, the agitation of conceiving, the mental proliferation of conceiving, the mental proliferations of conceiving, the conceiving that is the dart of Mara, the great tangle of Mara, the slavery to Mara, the yoke of Mara, the conceit ‘I am,’ the conceit ‘I am this,’ the conceit ‘I am better,’ the conceit ‘I am worse,’ the conceit ‘I am equal,’ the conceit ‘I,’ the conceit ‘mine,’ the conceit ‘I will be,’ the conceit ‘I will not be,’ the conceit ‘I will be possessed of form,’ the conceit ‘I will be formless,’ the conceit ‘I will be percipient,’ the conceit ‘I will be non-percipient,’ the conceit ‘I

original: etaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā puggale anissāya vuttānaṃ tiṇṇampi mānānaṃ bhājanīyaṃ “paṭhamakamānabhājanīye”ti
analyzed: etam daṭṭhabbam atha vā puggale a nissāya vuttānam tiṇṇam pi mānānam bhājanīyam paṭhamaka māna bhājanīya iti
translated: This is how it should be regarded. Or alternatively, the first kind of “receptivity to the kinds of conceit” is stated in order to show the kind of person who is a vessel for the three kinds of conceit mentioned in the way beginning, “Conceit in the sense of ‘I am’ in dependence on a person” .🔽For the second kind of “receptivity to the kinds of conceit” is the kind of person who is a vessel for the nine kinds of conceit mentioned in the way beginning, “The conceit ‘I am superior’ in one who is inferior” .

original: āha. Seyyassa “seyyohamasmīti māno”tiādīnañhi puggalaṃ āmasitvā vuttānaṃ navannaṃ🔽mānānaṃ bhājanīyaṃ dutiyakamānabhājanīyaṃ hoti, tassa mānarāsissa puggalaṃ anāmasitvā🔽vuttamānarāsito dutiyatatiyakattāti, athāpi ca yathāvutte dutiyakamānabhājanīye “ekekassa
analyzed: āha seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti māno ti ādīnam hi puggalam āmasitvā vuttānam  mānānam bhājanīyam dutiyaka māna bhājanīyam hoti tassa māna rāsissa puggalam an āmasitvā  vutta māna rāsitaḥ dutiya tatiyaka ttā ati atha api ca yathā vutte dutiyaka māna bhājanīye ekekassa
translated: The third kind of “receptivity to the kinds of conceit” is the kind of person who is a vessel for the nine kinds of conceit mentioned in the way beginning, “The conceit ‘I am superior’ in one who is equal” , without specifying the person as “inferior” or “equal.”

original: tayo tayo mānā uppajjantīti kathita”nti idha vuttāya atthavaṇṇanāya samānadassanatthaṃ🔽“paṭhamakamānabhājanīye”ti vuttaṃ. So eva māno idhāgatoti tattha kathito eva attho
analyzed: tayaḥ tayaḥ mānāḥ uppajjanti iti kathitan ti idha vuttāya attha vaṇṇanāya samāna dassana attham  paṭhamaka māna bhājanīyā iti vuttam saḥ eva mānaḥ idha āgataḥ ti tattha kathitaḥ eva attho
translated: Or alternatively, the first kind of “receptivity to the kinds of conceit” is stated in order to show that the explanation of the meaning given here is the same as that given in the way beginning, “Three kinds of conceit arise in one who is inferior” in the second kind of “receptivity to the kinds of conceit” stated in the way already quoted.🔽The intention is that the meaning stated there is appropriate here, since the conceit is the same in both places.

original: yujjatīti adhippāyo. Mānakaraṇavasenāti “seyyo”tiādikiccakaraṇavasena. Aparāpare
analyzed: yujjati iti adhippāyaḥ māna karaṇa vasena ati seyyo ti ādi kicca karaṇa vasena apara apare
translated: By the “mode of conceiving” is meant the mode of conceiving in the way beginning, “I am superior.”

original: upādāyāti idaṃ purimapurimā mānā aparāpare upanissayabhāvena te uppādentā accuggacchantīti
analyzed: upādāya ati idam purima purimāḥ mānāḥ apara apare upanissaya bhāvena te uppādentā accuggacchanti iti
translated: ‘Taking as its support’: this is said in order to show that the former and former kinds of conceit arise and grow in dependence on the latter and latter kinds.

original: imamatthaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ketukamyatācittaṃ accuggatabhāvaṃ gacchatīti katvā citteneva visesitaṃ.
analyzed: imam attham sandhāya vuttam ketu kamyatā cittam accuggata bhāvam gacchati iti katvā cittena iva visesitam
translated: The ‘mind that desires a banner’ is distinguished by the word ‘mind’ because it is the mind that grows in importance.🔽‘Disrespect’ is the manifestation of the state of not bearing with . ‘Honouring’ is the paying of respect in such a way as to please the mind. The meaning is: it is called ‘conceit’.

original: 1126. Akkhamanabhāvappakāsanaṃ khiyyanaṃ. Manena piyakaraṇanti evaṃpakāraṃ pūjanaṃ mānananti vuccatīti attho. Issākaraṇavasenāti lābhādiakkhamanakiccavasena.
analyzed: akkhamana bhāva pakāsanam khiyyanam manena piya karaṇanti evaṃpakāram pūjanam mānananti vuccati iti attho issā karaṇa vasena ati lābha ādi akkhamana kicca vasena
translated: ‘Out of envy’: because of the function of not bearing with gain, etc.

original: 1127. Ariyasāvakāti vacanaṃ “ariyasāvakānaṃyeva paṭivedho atthi, te ca taṃ na maccharāyantī”ti
analyzed: ariya sāvakā ati vacanam ariya sāvakā naṃyā iva paṭivedhaḥ atthi te ca tam na mat śarāyanti iti
translated: The statement ‘noble disciples’ is for the purpose of showing that only noble disciples have penetration and that they do not become envious of the Dhamma of penetration.

original: paṭivedhadhamme macchariyābhāvadassanatthaṃ. Ganthoti pāḷi. Kathāmaggoti aṭṭhakathāpabandho.
analyzed: paṭivedha dhamme macchariya abhāva dassana attham gantho ti kathā maggo ti aṭṭhakathā pabandho
translated: ‘The text’ is the text of the scriptures. ‘The commentary’ is the commentary that is a connected whole.

original: Dhammantaranti kusalādidhammaṃ bhinditvā akusalādiṃ attano lolatāya tathāgatabhāsitaṃ
analyzed: dhammantaran ti kusala ādi dhammam bhinditvā akusala ādim lola tāya tathāgata bhāsitam
translated: ‘Another doctrine’: having divided the wholesome, etc., into unwholesome, etc., he becomes confused and makes the Tathāgata’s word

original: titthiyabhāsitaṃ vā karonto ālolessati. Attānaṃ āvikatvāti attānaṃ aññathā santaṃ
analyzed: titthiya bhāsitam vā karontaḥ ālolessati attānam āvikatvā ati attānam aññathā santam
translated: or the word of the sectarians in that way. ‘He makes himself known’: he makes himself known as being otherwise than he is.

original: aññathā pavedayitvā. Yo panāti titthiyo gahaṭṭho vā attano samayassa sadosabhāvaṃ
analyzed: aññathā pavedayitvā yaḥ pana ati titthiyaḥ gahaṭṭhaḥ vā attano samayassa sa dosa bhāvam
translated: Having announced it otherwise. If he, etc. : if a sectarian or a householder, not wishing to see the fault in his own view,

original: daṭṭhuṃ anicchanto aññāṇena abhinivesena vā.
analyzed: daṭṭhum an icchantaḥ aññāṇena abhinivesena vā
translated: through ignorance or through adherence,

original: Byāpitumanicchoti viviccho, tassa bhāvo vevicchaṃ. Anādaroti macchariyena dāne ādararahito.
analyzed: byāpitum aniccho ti tassa bhāvaḥ veviccham anādaro ti macchariyena dāne ādara rahitaḥ
translated: not wishing to give it up, i.e. to abandon it, the state of that is vevicchaṃ. Anādaro means one who is not respectful in giving through miserliness.

original: Kaṭacchunā gāho bhattassa kaṭacchuggāho, kaṭacchuggāho viya kaṭacchuggāho. Yathā
analyzed: kaṭacchunā gāhaḥ bhattassa kaṭacchu ggāhaḥ kaṭacchu gāhaḥ viya kaṭacchu ggāhaḥ yathā
translated: Kaṭacchunā gāho bhattassa kaṭacchuggāho, kaṭacchuggāho viya kaṭacchuggāho. Yathā

original: hi kaṭacchuggāho yathāvutte bhatte na saṃpasārayati, evaṃ macchariyampi āvāsādīsūti.
analyzed: hi kaṭacchuggāhaḥ yathā vutte bhatte na saṃpasārayati evam āvāsa ādīsu iti
translated: hi kaṭacchuggāho yathāvutte bhatte na saṃpasārayati, evaṃ macchariyampi āvāsādīsūti.

original: Gayhati etenāti vā gāho, kaṭacchu eva gāho kaṭacchuggāho. So yathā saṅkuṭitaggo na
analyzed: gayhati etena ati vā gāhaḥ kaṭacchu eva gāhaḥ kaṭacchuggāhaḥ saḥ yathā saṅkuṭi taggaḥ na
translated: Gayhati etenāti vā gāho, kaṭacchu eva gāho kaṭacchuggāho. So yathā saṅkuṭitaggo na

original: saṃpasārayati, evaṃ macchariyampīti. Āvaritvā gahitaṃ aggahitaṃ, tassa bhāvo aggahitattaṃ,
analyzed: saṃpasārayati evam mat śariyam pi iti āvaritvā gahitam aggahitam tassa bhāvaḥ aggahitattaṃ
translated: saṃpasārayati, evaṃ macchariyampīti. Āvaritvā gahitaṃ aggahitaṃ, tassa bhāvo aggahitattaṃ,

original: macchariyaṃ. “Āvāsādi parehi sādhāraṇamasādhāraṇaṃ vā mayheva hotū”ti pavattivasena
analyzed: mad śariyam āvāsa ādi parehi sādhāraṇam asādhāraṇam vā mayhā iva hotu iti pavatti vasena
translated: macchariyaṃ. “Āvāsādi parehi sādhāraṇamasādhāraṇaṃ vā mayheva hotū”ti pavattivasena

original: attasampattiggahaṇalakkhaṇatā, “mā aññassā”ti pavattivasena attasampattinigūhaṇalakkhaṇatā🔽ca yojetabbā. Yaṃ pana “parasantakaṃ gaṇhitukāmo”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ macchariyassa parasantakalobhassa
analyzed: atta sampatti ggahaṇa lakkhaṇa tā mā aññassa ati pavatti vasena atta sampatti nigūhaṇa lakkhaṇa tā  ca yojetabbā yam pana para santakam gaṇhitu kāmaḥ iti vuttam tam macchariyassa para santaka lobhassa
translated: and the characteristic of grasping at one’s own excellence, and the characteristic of concealing one’s own excellence by the occurrence of the thought “Let no one else have it.”

original: upanissayabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yadi hi taṃ macchariyappavattidassanaṃ,
analyzed: upanissaya bhāvam dassetum vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam yadi hi tam mad śariya ppavatti dassanam
translated: But what is said here, namely, “he who is desirous of taking what belongs to another,” should be regarded as said in order to show the condition of the greed that is miserliness and the greed that is covetousness. For if it were shown that miserliness is the occurrence of greed,

original: parasampattiggahaṇalakkhaṇatā ca vattabbā siyāti.🔽1140. Abhijjhākāmarāgānaṃ viseso āsavadvayaekāsavabhāvo siyā, naabhijjhāya noāsavabhāvo🔽cāti noāsavalobhassa sabbhāvo vicāretabbo. Na hi atthi “āsavo ca noāsavo ca dhammā
analyzed: para sampatti ggahaṇa lakkhaṇa tā ca vattabbā siyāti  abhijjhā kāma rāgānam visesaḥ āsava dvaya eka āsava bhāvaḥ siyā na abhijjhāya no āsava bhāvaḥ  ca ati noāsava lobhassa sabbhāvaḥ vicāretabbaḥ na hi atthi āsavaḥ ca noāsavaḥ ca dhammā
translated: then the characteristic of grasping at another’s excellence would have to be mentioned.🔽The difference between covetousness and greed for sensual pleasure is that the former is a single taint and the latter is a taint and a category of the effluent of sense desire. But the nature of the greed that is not a taint

original: āsavassa dhammassa āsavassa ca noāsavassa ca dhammassa hetupaccayena paccayo”ti sattamo
analyzed: āsavassa dhammassa āsavassa ca noāsavassa ca dhammassa hetu paccayena paccayo ti sattamaḥ
translated: should be investigated. For there is no seventh or ninth question such as “Are there states that are a taint and not a taint, and are there states that are a taint and a taint and not a taint?”

original: ca navamo ca pañho. Gaṇanāya ca “hetuyā sattā”ti vuttaṃ, na “navā”ti. Diṭṭhisampayutte
analyzed: ca navamaḥ ca pañhaḥ gaṇanāya ca hetuyā sattā ati vuttam na navā ti diṭṭhi sampayutte
translated: and the reckoning is stated thus “In the case of a cause, seven” , not “nine.” And it is said of the greed that is not a taint that it is associated with wrong view.

original: pana lobhe noāsave vijjamāne sattamanavamāpi pañhavissajjanaṃ labheyyuṃ, gaṇanā ca
analyzed: pana lobhe no āsave vijjamāne sattama navama api pañha vissajjanam labheyyum gaṇanā ca
translated: But if there were no-poisons in greed, the answer to the ninth question would be available, and the calculation

original: “hetuyā navā”ti vattabbā siyā. Diṭṭhivippayutte ca lobhe noāsave vijjamāne pubbe dassito dosoti.🔽1159. Kāmacchandanīvaraṇaniddese kāmesūti tebhūmakesu sāsavesu sabbesu vatthukāmesu.
analyzed: hetuyā navā ti vattabbā siyā diṭṭhi vippayutte ca lobhe noāsave vijjamāne pubbe dassitaḥ doso ti  kāmacchanda nīvaraṇa niddese kāmesu iti tebhūmakesu sa āsavesu sabbesu vatthu kāmesu
translated: would have to be made thus: “Nine by cause.” And if there were no-poisons in greed not associated with false view, the answer to the first question would be available, and the calculation would have to be made thus: “Ten by cause.”

original: Sabbo hi lobho kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ. Teneva tassa āruppe uppatti vuttā “nīvaraṇaṃ🔽dhammaṃ paṭicca nīvaraṇo dhammo uppajjati na purejātapaccayā. Āruppe kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: sabbaḥ hi lobho kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam tena iva tassa āruppe uppatti vuttā nīvaraṇam  dhammam paṭicca nīvaraṇaḥ dhammo uppajjati na purejāta paccayā āruppe kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam
translated: In the Description of the Hindrance of sensual desire, in the clause “in regard to sensual desires” , sensual desires are all the kinds of sensual desires classed as objects of sense desire in the three planes, for all greed is the hindrance of sensual desire.🔽That is why it is said that it arises in the immaterial sphere.

original: paṭicca uddhaccanīvaraṇaṃ avijjānīvaraṇaṃ. Āruppe kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ paṭicca thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭicca uddhacca nīvaraṇam avijjā nīvaraṇam āruppe kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam paṭicca thinamiddha nīvaraṇam
translated: “With a hindrance as condition there arises in the immaterial sphere the hindrance of restlessness, the hindrance of ignorance,

original: uddhaccanīvaraṇaṃ avijjānīvaraṇa”nti.
analyzed: uddhacca nīvaraṇam
translated: the hindrance of stiffness and torpor, the hindrance of doubt” .

original: 1162. Iriyāpathikacittanti iriyāpathūpatthambhakaṃ aṭṭhapaññāsavidhaṃ cittaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: iriyāpathika cittanti iriyāpathu upatthambhakam aṭṭha paññāsavidham cittam tattha
translated: In the clause “in the cognizance that is the support for postures” , the cognizance is the fifty-eight kinds that are the support for postures. Herein,

original: pana balavathinamiddhasahagataṃ cittaṃ “iriyāpathaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkonta”nti vuttaṃ. Olīyatīti olambati.
analyzed: pana balavathinam iddha sahagatam cittam iriyāpatham sandhāretum asakkontanti vuttaṃ olīyati iti olambati
translated: But the state of consciousness accompanied by strong sluggishness is said to be “unable to sustain the postures” . It sags: it hangs down.🔽It is covered: it is concealed, or it is hidden away.

original: 1163. Onayhatīti chādeti, avattharati vā. Nānārammaṇesu pavattinivāraṇena, vipphārikatānivāraṇeneva
analyzed: onayhati iti chādeti avattharati vā nānā ārammaṇesu pavatti nivāraṇena vipphārika tā nivāraṇena iva
translated: The inward contraction is the prevention of occurrence in the various objects or the prevention of the spreading out in them.🔽Some: of the trees such as the sirīsa, etc.

original: vā antosamorodho. Ekaccānanti sirīsādirukkhānaṃ. Rūpakāyeneva siyuṃ, tena sukhappaṭisaṃvedananibbānasacchikiriyānaṃ
analyzed: vā antosamorodho sirīsa ādi rukkhānam rūpa kāyena iva siyum tena sukha ppaṭisaṃvedana nibbāna sacchikiriyānaṃ
translated: They would be only with the material body. The intention is that the attainment of materiality would be for the experiencing of pleasure and for the realization of Nibbāna.

original: rūpatāpatti siyāti adhippāyo. Tasmāti “kāyassā”ti vacanassa rūpattāsādhakattā. Na🔽hi nāmakāyo supatīti idaṃ thinamiddhasamuṭṭhitarūpehi rūpakāyassa garubhāvappattaṃ
analyzed: rūpa tā āpatti siyā ti adhippāyaḥ tasmāti kāyassa ati vacanassa rūpa ttā a sādhaka ttā na  hi nāmakāyaḥ supati iti idam thinamiddha samuṭṭhita rūpehi rūpakāyassa garu bhāva ppattam
translated: Because: because of the words “of the body” which are the means to the attainment of materiality.

original: aṅgapaccaṅgādīnaṃ saṃsīdanaṃ soppanti sandhāya vuttaṃ, na jāgaraṇacittarahitaṃ bhavaṅgasantatinti.
analyzed: aṅga paccaṅga ādīnam saṃsīdanam sandhāya vuttam na jāgaraṇa citta rahitam bhavaṅga santatin ti
translated: For it is not the immaterial body that sleeps. This is said with reference to the sagging of the limbs, secondaries, etc., which is the attainment of heaviness in the material body by means of the materiality originated by sluggishness and torpor, not with reference to the mere occurrence of the life-continuum devoid of the consciousness of waking.

original: Tassa phalattāti phalūpacārena indriyaṃ viya middhaṃ dassetuṃ middhassa phalattā
analyzed: tassa phala ttā ati phala upacārena indriyam viya middham dassetum middhassa phala ttā
translated: Because it is the fruit of that: in order to show sluggishness as a faculty by figurative extension of the fruit, as in the case of the faculty of understanding ,

original: indriyaniddese viya liṅgādīni middhaniddesepi soppādīni vuttānīti attho.
analyzed: indriya niddese viya liṅga ādīni middha niddese pi soppa ādīni vuttāni iti attho
translated: As in the case of the faculties, so in the case of the signs, etc., in the description of sleep, the terms “light” and so on are used.

original: Rūpakāyassa antosamorodho natthīti so nāmakāye vuttoti viññāyati. Tena saha vuttā
analyzed: rūpakāyassa antosamorodho natthi iti so nāmakāye vutto ti viññāyati tena saha vuttā
translated: It is understood that the “contraction” of the material body is mentioned in the mental body, because there is no contraction of the material body.🔽The “expansion” and “contraction” mentioned together with that are also in the mental body.

original: onāhapariyonāhā ca. Rūpakāyassa vā vipphārikāvipphārikabhāvo nāma attano sabhāvena
analyzed: onāha pariyonāhā ca rūpa kāyassa vā vipphārika avipphārika bhāvaḥ nāma attanaḥ sabhāvena
translated: Or, the material body has no such thing as “expansion” and “contraction” in the sense of the extension or non-extension of its own nature.

original: natthi, nāmakāyassa nāmakāye vipphārike lahuko, avipphārike garukoti avipphārikabhāvena
analyzed: natthi nāmakāyassa nāmakāye vipphārike lahukaḥ a vipphārike garukaḥ ti a vipphārika bhāvena
translated: The mental body, however, has “contraction” by the non-extension of its own nature.

original: onāhanādi nāmakāyasseva hotīti onāhanādayopi nāmakāye viññāyanti. Tenāha “na hi rūpaṃ🔽nāmakāyassa onāho…pe… hotī”ti. Āvaraṇabhāvo viya hi onāhanādibhāvopi nāmakāyasseva
analyzed: onāhana ādi nāmakāyassa iva hoti iti onāhana ādayaḥ api nāmakāye viññāyanti tena āha na hi rūpam  nāmakāyassa hoti iti āvaraṇa bhāvaḥ viya hi onāhana ādi bhāvaḥ api nāmakāyassa iva
translated: “Expansion” and so on are also understood in the mental body because of that. Therefore it is said: “For contraction, etc., of the material body is not found in the mental body” .🔽For “contraction,” etc., are in the mental body just as “obstruction,” etc., are.

original: hotīti. Itaro adhippāyaṃ ajānanto meghādīhi rūpehi rūpānaṃ onāhanādiṃ passanto “nanu
analyzed: hoti iti itaraḥ adhippāyam a jānantaḥ megha ādīhi rūpehi rūpānam onāhana ādim passantaḥ nanu
translated: The other, not understanding the intention, sees the “contraction,” etc., of material things by means of material things such as clouds, and he says: “But is it not so?”

original: cā”tiādimāha. Yadi evanti yadi rūpassa onāhanāditā siddhā, arūpassa na siyā, setubandhādīsu
analyzed: ca ati ādim āha yadi evam ti yadi rūpassa onāhana ādi tā siddhā arūpassa na siyā setubandha ādīsu
translated: If so, if the “contraction,” etc., of material things is established, it would not be in immaterial things. In the case of the binding of a bridge, etc.,

original: rūpassa āvaraṇaṃ diṭṭhanti āvaraṇampi arūpassa na bhaveyyāti attho.🔽Surāmerayapānaṃ akusalanti katvā yutto tassa upakkilesabhāvo, surā…pe… pamādaṭṭhānānuyogassa
analyzed: rūpassa āvaraṇam diṭṭhanti āvaraṇam pi arūpassa na bhaveyya attho  surā meraya pānam akusalanti katvā yuttaḥ tassa upakkilesa bhāvaḥ surāpe pamāda ṭhāna anuyogassa
translated: The meaning is that if seeing were an obstruction to materiality, it would not be an obstruction to immateriality either.

original: ca akusalattā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇabhāvo yutto, tathāpi parassa adhippāyaṃ anujānitvā
analyzed: ca akusala ttā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇa bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ tathā api parassa adhippāyam anujānitvā
translated: The fact that drinking liquor is unwholesome makes it proper to call it a defilement. The fact that the pursuit of the conditions for heedlessness is unwholesome makes it proper to call it a weakening of wisdom. Nevertheless, in order to comply with the intention of others,🔽the liquor is called a defilement and the weakening of wisdom is called a weakening of wisdom,

original: surāmerayassa upakkilesatā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇatā ca upakkilesānaṃ paññāya dubbalīkaraṇānañca
analyzed: surā merayassa upakkilesa tā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇa tā ca upakkilesānam paññāya dubbalīkaraṇānam ca
translated: because the liquor and the pursuit of the conditions for heedlessness are conditions for defilement and for the weakening of wisdom respectively.

original: paccayattā phalavohārena vuttāti dassento āha “na, paccayaniddesato”ti. Evameva khoti
analyzed: paccaya ttā phala vohārena vuttā iti dassentaḥ āha na paccaya niddesato ti evam eva kho ti
translated: The expression “just as” is used in the sense of “just so.”

original: yathā jātarūpassa ayo lohaṃ tipu sīsaṃ sajjanti pañcupakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ jātarūpaṃ
analyzed: yathā jātarūpassa ayaḥ loham tipu sīsam sajjanti pañca upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭham jātarūpam
translated: Just as iron, copper, tin, lead, and silver are the five impurities of gold, so the five impurities of the gold of the noble path are the liquor, etc.,🔽and the weakening of wisdom is the weakening of wisdom. Just as the gold of the noble path, when defiled by the five impurities,

original: na ceva mudu hoti, na ca kammaniyaṃ, na ca pabhassaraṃ pabhaṅgu ca, na ca sammā upeti
analyzed: na ca iva mudu hoti na ca kammaniyam na ca pabhassaram pabhaṅgu ca na ca sammā upeti
translated: is not malleable, not wieldy, not radiant, brittle, and not fit for work,🔽so the gold of the noble path, when defiled by the five impurities, is not malleable, etc.

original: kammāya, evameva. Paccayaniddesatoti upakkilesapaññādubbalīkaraṇānaṃ paccayabhāvaniddesato,
analyzed: kammāya evam eva paccaya niddesato ti upakkilesa paññā dubbalīkaraṇānam paccaya bhāva niddesato
translated: “From the description of conditions” means from the description of the conditions for defilement and for the weakening of wisdom.

original: paccaye phalaniddesatoti attho. Sayameva kileso upakkilesaniddesesu niddiṭṭhoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: paccaye phala niddesato ti attho sayam eva kilesaḥ upakkilesa niddesesu niddiṭṭhaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: the meaning is, by describing the condition in terms of the fruit. The intention is that the defilement itself is described in the description of the subsidiary defilements.

original: Nīvaraṇaṃ hutvāva nīvaraṇasampayutte dassiyamāne na nīvaraṇatādassanattho ārambho,🔽atha kho siddhanīvaraṇabhāvassa nīvaraṇasampayuttatādassanatthoti yathālābhavasena🔽ca asampayuttassa vacanaṃ na yujjati. Yathā hi tiṭṭhantampi carantampīti sippisambukādīsu🔽yathālābhasambhavaṃ taṃ dvayaṃ vuttaṃ, na evaṃ “thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ sampayuttampi
analyzed: nīvaraṇam hutvā ava nīvaraṇa sampayutte dassiyamāne na nīvaraṇa tā dassana atthaḥ ārambhaḥ  atha kho siddha nīvaraṇa bhāvassa nīvaraṇa sampayutta tā dassana tthaḥ ti yathā lābha vasena  ca a sampayuttassa vacanam na yujjati yathā hi tiṭṭhantam pi carantam pi iti sippi sambuka ādīsu  yathā lābha sambhavam tam dvayam vuttam na evam thinam iddha nīvaraṇam
translated: When it is shown that the hindrances are associated with the hindrances, the purpose is not to show the hindrances as hindrances;🔽but rather to show the associatedness of what has already become a hindrance. So it is not proper to say that the unassociated is mentioned according to the way it occurs.🔽For just as the two states of standing and walking are mentioned according to the way they occur in the case of the sippisambuka, etc.,

original: asampayuttampī”ti vacanaṃ atthi, yaṃ yathālābhaṃ sambhaveyyāti. Cittajassāsambhavavacanatoti
analyzed: a sampayuttam pi iti vacanam atthi yam yathālābham sambhaveyya ati citta jassa a sambhava vacanato ti
translated: so there is no such statement as “Dullness-and-drowsiness is associated with the hindrances and unassociated with the hindrances” by which it could be shown according to the way it occurs.

original: “cattattā”tiādivacanassa jhānakkhaṇe cittajassa thinamiddhassa asambhavavacanabhāvatoti
analyzed: cattattā ati ādi vacanassa jhāna kkhaṇe citta jassa thinamiddhassa asambhava vacana bhāvato ti
translated: The meaning is that the statement “because of the four” shows that dullness-and-drowsiness is not possible in consciousness at the moment of jhāna.

original: attho, “cattattā”tiādivacanena vā asambhavassa vacanato pakāsanatoti attho.
analyzed: attho cattattā ati ādi vacanena vā asambhavassa vacanataḥ pakāsanato ti attho
translated: Or the meaning is that the statement “because of the four” shows, makes clear, that it is not possible.

original: Kāmesu kho pana…pe… sudiṭṭhoti iminā kāmādīnave aññāṇassa pahānamāha. Taṃ tattha
analyzed: kāmesu kho panape su diṭṭhaḥ ti iminā kāma ādīnave aññāṇassa pahānam āha tam tattha
translated: “In regard to sensual desires … well seen” : he says that the abandoning of ignorance in regard to the dangers of sensual desires, etc., is the “giving up” .

original: pahānanti taṃ tattha rūpe pahānanti pahānaṃ apekkhitvā “ta”nti vuttaṃ, taṃ vinayananti🔽vā attho. Tena rūpassa appahātabbattameva dasseti, na pana “cha dhamme pahāyā”tiādīsu🔽middhassa appahātabbatādassanato añño pakāro vutto. Na yathā…pe… vuttanti cha dhammā
analyzed: pahānam ti tam tattha rūpe pahānam ti pahānam apekkhitvā tam ti vuttam tam vinayanam ti  vā attho tena rūpassa appahātabba ttam eva dasseti na pana cha dhamme pahāya atiādīsu  middhassa a ppahātabba tā dassanataḥ aññaḥ pakāraḥ vuttaḥ na yathā āpe vuttanti cha dhammā
translated: “In regard to that” : “in regard to that” is said with reference to the “giving up” . The meaning is: “in regard to the abandoning of that” .🔽He shows that material form is not to be given up, but he does not say that there is another way of giving up the five hindrances, etc., as there is in the passage: “Having given up six ideas” .

original: pañca nīvaraṇāni ca yathā pahātabbāneva hontāni “pahātabbānī”ti vuttāni, na evaṃ
analyzed: pañca nīvaraṇāni ca yathā pahātabbāni na eva hontāni pahātabbāni iti vuttāni na evam
translated: “Not as … said” : the meaning is: not as the five hindrances and the six ideas are said to be “to be given up” because they are only to be given up,

original: rūpaṃ pahātabbameva hontaṃ “pahātabba”nti vuttanti attho.
analyzed: rūpam pahātabbam eva hontam pahātabbanti vuttan ti attho
translated: so material form is said to be “to be given up” because it is only to be given up.

original: Aññehi ca suttehīti vuttasuttānaṃ dassanatthaṃ “tathā hī”tiādimāha. Kusalappavattiṃ
analyzed: aññehi ca suttehi iti vutta suttānam dassana attham tathā hi itiādim āha kusala ppavattim
translated: “In other suttas” : he says “for thus” in order to show the suttas referred to.

original: āvarantīti āvaraṇā. Nīvārentīti nīvaraṇā. Cittaṃ abhibhavantā ārohantīti cetaso ajjhāruhā.
analyzed: āvaranti iti āvaraṇāḥ nīvārenti iti nīvaraṇāḥ cittam abhibhavantāḥ ārohanti iti cetasaḥ ajjhāruhā
translated: The hindrances are hindrances because they hinder the occurrence of the profitable. They obstruct is the meaning of “hindrances” . They ascend, overcoming the mind, is the meaning of “adhering to the mind” .

original: Āvaraṇādikiccañca arūpasseva yujjati, tathā andhakaraṇādikiccaṃ. Tattha catūsu padesu
analyzed: āvaraṇa ādi kiccam ca arūpassa iva yujjati tathā andha karaṇa ādi kiccam tattha catūsu padesu
translated: And the function of obscuring, etc., is appropriate only for the immaterial, as also the function of blinding, and so on. Herein, the meaning of each subsequent term is included in each preceding one.

original: purimapurimassa pacchimapacchimo attho. Saṃsāradukkhaṃ vighāto, taṃjanakatāya vighātapakkhikaṃ.
analyzed: purima purimassa pacchima pacchimaḥ attho saṃsāra dukkham vighāto taṃ janaka tāya vighātapakkhikam
translated: The suffering of the round of rebirths is “distress,” and the unprofitable is “the source of distress” because it generates that.

original: Cetaso pariyuṭṭhānaṃ ayonisomanasikārato uppatti akusalarāsibhāvo ca arūpasseva hotīti arūpameva middhaṃ.
analyzed: cetaso pariyuṭṭhānam a yoniso manasikārato uppatti akusala rāsi bhāvo ca arūpassa iva hoti iti arūpam eva middham
translated: The arising of sleep from unreasoned attention and its being a mass of unprofitable things belong only to the immaterial, so sleep is immaterial.

original: 1166. Gaṇabhojanādiakappiyabhojanaṃ kappiyasaññī bhuñjitvā puna jānitvā koci vippaṭisārī
analyzed: gaṇa bhojana ādi akappiya bhojanam kappiya saññī bhuñjitvā puna jānitvā koci vippaṭisārī
translated: Having eaten what is allowable, such as food at a communal meal, etc., some one, perceiving it as allowable, may later on, when he finds out, be remorseful.

original: hoti, anavajjañca bhikkhudassanacetiyavandanādiṃ vajjasaññī akatvā katvā ca koci
analyzed: hoti anavajjam ca bhikkhu dassana cetiya vandana ādim vajja saññī a katvā katvā ca koci
translated: And some one who is faithless, without perceiving as blameworthy what is blameless, such as seeing bhikkhus, worshipping a shrine, and so on, and after doing it,

original: assaddho vippaṭisārī hoti. Vatthunti mūlaṃ. Evarūpanti mūlavasena evaṃpakāranti attho.
analyzed: assaddhaḥ vippaṭisārī hoti vatthum ti mūlam evarūpan ti mūla vasena evaṃpakāran ti attho
translated: is remorseful. “Basis” is the root. “Such as this” means such as this by way of the root.

original: Kukkuccapadaṃ yevāpanakesu “kucchitaṃ kataṃ kukataṃ, tassa bhāvo”ti vuttatthameva.
analyzed: kukkucca padam yevāpanakesu kucchitam katam kukatam tassa bhāvaḥ ti vutta ttham eva
translated: The word “remorse” is in the same way as the word “done by one who is remorseful” in the case of the offences of expiation involving confession.

original: Kukkuccāyanākāroti kukkuccabhāvanākāro kukkuccakaraṇākāro kukkuccagamanākāro vā.
analyzed: kukkucca ayana ākāraḥ iti kukkucca bhāvanā ākāraḥ kukkucca karaṇa ākāraḥ kukkucca gamana ākāraḥ vā
translated: The mode of the worry is the mode of the state of worry, the mode of the act of worrying, the mode of the occurrence of worry.

original: Etena kukkuccaṃ kiriyabhāvena dasseti. “Kappati na kappatī”ti pavattacittuppādova vinayakukkuccaṃ.
analyzed: etena kukkuccam kiriya bhāvena dasseti kappati na kappati iti pavatta cittuppādaḥ va vinaya kukkuccam
